# x aider

Aider is an open-source AI coding assistant developed by the Aider-AI team. Designed primarily for the command line or terminal, it enables seamless collaboration with large language models (LLMs) without the need for a complex graphical interface.

It supports popular models out of the box, including Claude 3.7 Sonnet, DeepSeek R1, Chat V3, OpenAI o1, o3-mini, and GPT-4o, and can also connect to any local or API-compatible LLM. Aider automatically maps the code structure of your entire Git repository, allowing it to understand context across multiple files and make coherent edits.

With support for over 100 programming languages, Aider can automatically generate semantic Git commit messages and perform commits. It also supports voice-to-code input, embedding screenshots or web content, and automatic linting and testingâ€”making it ideal for developers to achieve AI pair programming within their local workflow.

Project URL: https://github.com/Aider-AI/aider

## Examples

Launch interactive pair-programming session in-terminal

```sh
x aider
```

## Usage

```sh
x aider
```

# x apk

apk command enhancements

## Examples

Use the interactive app to search for all available packages

```sh
x apk
```

Set the apk mirror source to Tsinghua University mirror source (TUNA)

```sh
x apk mirror set tuna
```

List the available mirror source

```sh
x apk mirror ls
```

Install curl using apk

```sh
x apk install curl
```

Use OSV-Scanner to check for existing vulnerabilities in installed software package dependencies

```sh
x apk osv
```

Update list of available packages

```sh
x apk update
```

## Usage

```sh
x apk [SUB_COMMAND] <#n>
```

## Arguments

| Argument | Description |
| ------- | ------- |
| `#n` | extends `apk` subcmd or options |


## Sub Commands

| Name | Description |
| ------- | ------- |
| [x apk osv](/mod/apk/osv.md) | Use OSV-Scanner to check for existing vulnerabilities in installed software package dependencies |
| [x apk mirror](/mod/apk/mirror.md) | Setting the apk mirror for debian/ubuntu |
| [x apk proxy](/mod/apk/proxy.md) | Display or change the current proxy used for apk |
| [x apk install](/mod/apk/install.md) | Install software tools (interactive APP is used by default in an interactive environment). |
| [x apk fz](/mod/apk/fz.md) | Using fzf as an interactive UI to select the applications you want to install |
| [x apk ls](/mod/apk/ls.md) | List installed software |
| [x apk la](/mod/apk/la.md) | Listed installable software |

# x apt

apt command enhancements

## Examples

Use the interactive app to search for all available packages

```sh
x apt
```

Set the apt mirror source to Tsinghua University mirror source (TUNA)

```sh
x apt mirror set tuna
```

List the available mirror source

```sh
x apt mirror ls
```

Install curl using apt

```sh
x apt install curl
```

Use OSV-Scanner to check for existing vulnerabilities in installed software package dependencies

```sh
x apt osv
```

Update list of available packages

```sh
x apt update
```
## introduce



The apt module is dedicated to enhancing the command line experience of apt users. Its enhancements to apt mainly include the following points:
1. Provide an interactive UI so that users can better search and install software.
2. Provide the mirror command to manage mirror sources so that users can quickly replace the appropriate apt mirror source according to the situation.
3. Provide proxy command so that users can manage apt's proxy more flexibly.
4. For commands that require sudo privileges to execute, we have wrapped them using the sudo module to ensure that all commands follow the format `x apt <subcmd>`.

## Usage

```sh
x apt [SUB_COMMAND] <#n>
```

## Arguments

| Argument | Description |
| ------- | ------- |
| `#n` | extends `apt` subcmd or options |


## Sub Commands

| Name | Description |
| ------- | ------- |
| [x apt osv](/mod/apt/osv.md) | Use OSV-Scanner to check for existing vulnerabilities in installed software package dependencies |
| [x apt mirror](/mod/apt/mirror.md) | Setting the apt mirror for debian/ubuntu |
| [x apt proxy](/mod/apt/proxy.md) | Display or change the current proxy used for apt |
| [x apt fz](/mod/apt/fz.md) | Using fzf as an interactive UI to select the applications you want to install |
| [x apt install](/mod/apt/install.md) | Installing software or applications |
| [x apt ls](/mod/apt/ls.md) | List installed software |
| [x apt la](/mod/apt/la.md) | Listed installable software, equivalent to `x apt ls -A` |

# x arp

This module is used to display the local system's ARP cache table, supporting three output formats: CSV, TSV, and TUI application.

The header information for TSV/CSV is: ip, mac, if, suspicious, scope, type

## Examples

This is equivalent to 'x arp --auto'.  In this mode, interactive mode is started if standard output is connected to a terminal (tty); otherwise, output is in TSV format.

```sh
x arp
```

Display all ARP tables, including entries in an incomplete state

```sh
x arp --all
```

Do not display the manufacturer or organization information associated with the MAC address

```sh
x arp --no-vendor
```

View ARP cache table in csv format

```sh
x arp --csv
```

View ARP cache table in tsv format

```sh
x arp --tsv
```

Check ARP cache table with the tui app

```sh
x arp --app
```

## Usage

```sh
x arp [FLAGS] [SUB_COMMAND]
```

## Flags

| Name, Shorthand | Description |
| ------- | ------- |
| `--all`, `-a` | Display all ARP cache tables, including entries in an incomplete state |
| `--no-vendor`, `-n` | Do not display the manufacturer or organization information associated with the MAC address |
| `--auto` | If the standard output is connected to a terminal (tty), it starts in interactive mode (`--app`); otherwise, it outputs in TSV format (`--tsv`). This is the default behavior for `x arp` |
| `--app` | Check ARP cache table with the tui app |
| `--tsv`, `-t` | Output in TSV format |
| `--csv`, `-c` | Output in CSV format |
| `--raw`, `-r` | Output in the raw data format |


## Sub Commands

| Name | Description |
| ------- | ------- |
| [x arp ls](#x-arp-ls) | Retrieving the ARP table |


### x arp ls

Retrieving the ARP table


- **Usage**:

```sh
x arp ls [FLAGS]
```

- **Flags**:


| Name, Shorthand | Description |
| ------- | ------- |
| `--all`, `-a` | Display all ARP cache tables, including entries in an incomplete state |
| `--no-vendor`, `-n` | Do not display the manufacturer or organization information associated with the MAC address |
| `--auto` | If the standard output is connected to a terminal (tty), it starts in interactive mode (`--app`); otherwise, it outputs in TSV format (`--tsv`). This is the default behavior for `x arp` |
| `--app` | Check ARP cache table with the tui app |
| `--tsv`, `-t` | Output in TSV format |
| `--csv`, `-c` | Output in CSV format |
| `--raw`, `-r` | Output in the raw data format |

# x ascii

The ascii module is designed to handle tasks related to ASCII, such as looking up the ASCII code table, displaying characters, pictures, and artistic fireworks in ASCII artwork.

Except for the table subcommand implemented in shell/awk, the rest of the commands use pkg or npm to download and run on demand, for example, cfont and map use modules hosted on npm and download and run on demand with least privilege through deno.

## Examples

View the list of ASCII codes

```sh
x ascii
```

Transform the x-cmd string into ASCII art

```sh
x ascii cfont x-cmd
```

Convert the 'x-cmd' string into ASCII art and apply a gradient color.

```sh
x ascii cfont x-cmd -g red,blue
```

Convert the 'x-cmd' string into ASCII art, set a background color, and center the text.

```sh
x ascii cfont x-cmd -a center -b red
```

Use demo 1 to display ASCII art fireworks

```sh
x ascii firework -d 1
```

Drawing an ASCII Line Graph

```sh
seq 1 10 | x ascii graph
```

## Sub Commands

| Name | Description |
| ------- | ------- |
| [x ascii table](#x-ascii-table) | Look up the ASCII code table |
| [x ascii cfonts](#x-ascii-cfonts) | Transforming a string into ASCII art |
| [x ascii imagec](#x-ascii-imagec) | Transforming an image into ASCII art using ascii-image-converter |
| [x ascii map](#x-ascii-map) | Take a look at the world map |
| [x ascii graph](#x-ascii-graph) | Drawing an ASCII Line Graph |
| [x ascii mermaid](#x-ascii-mermaid) | Render Mermaid graphs inside your terminal |
| [x ascii firework](#x-ascii-firework) | Download and run firework-rs to simulate ASCII art fireworks (Press esc to exit the program) |


### x ascii table

Look up the ASCII code table


- **Examples**:

To output a list of ASCII codes in CSV format

```sh
x ascii table --csv
```

List all the ASCII codes corresponding to lowercase letters

```sh
x ascii table lower
```

Return the ASCII code corresponding to Ctrl-A

```sh
x ascii table ^A
```

Return the ASCII code corresponding to Ctrl-A

```sh
x ascii table 0x11
```

- **Usage**:

```sh
x ascii table [FLAGS] <#1>
```

- **Arguments**:


| Argument | Description |
| ------- | ------- |
| `#1` | The ASCII code item to be queried could be something like 'A', '^A', '0x11', '012', or '111' |


- **Flags**:


| Name, Shorthand | Description |
| ------- | ------- |
| `--tbl` | Use static tables to display ASCII codes |
| `--csv` | To output a list of ASCII codes in CSV format |
| `--json` | To output a list of ASCII codes in JSON format |
| `--yml` | To output a list of ASCII codes in YML format |

### x ascii cfonts

# x asdf

asdf is an extensible version manager supporting installations of various development language environments and software tools such as Ruby, Node.js, Elixir, and Erlang.


::: tip
The asdf ecosystem relies on git commands, so if git is missing from your environment, you may encounter failures when using asdf to install certain software.
The asdf module now supports versions of asdf rewritten in Go (v0.16.0 and above).

Compared to the previous Bash-based implementation (such as v0.15.0 and earlier), the new version introduces significant structural changes.

Users are encouraged to read the official upgrade guide to ensure a smooth transition: https://asdf-vm.com/guide/upgrading-to-v0-16.html

```sh
x asdf
```

Uninstall the installed Node.js

Deactivate asdfï¼Œso that the software installed by asdf cannot be run directly

# x brew

brew command enhancements

## Examples

Select the software to be installed using the TUI application method.

```sh
x brew
```

Install curl using brew

```sh
x brew install curl
```

Disable brew analytics to minimize potential privacy risks

```sh
x brew analytics off
```

View the download count of core packages used for installing Homebrew within the last 30 days.

```sh
x brew analytics data
```

Open the analytics website for Homebrew in a browser

```sh
x brew analytics browse
```
## Introduction



The brew module is dedicated to enhancing the Homebrew user experience on the command line. It provides additional useful features such as changing Homebrew download sources, setting up proxies, and viewing download data.



## Protect Privacy by Disabling Homebrew Analytics



By default, Homebrew [collects user usage data](https://docs.brew.sh/Analytics) (such as software installation, uninstallation, and update data) to better optimize the software installation and usage experience. We recommend that users disable this feature to protect their privacy.


```bash
x brew a off
```



## Enhanced Features


1. `x brew mirror` : Manages Homebrew mirror sources and helps users switch between various mirrors like Alibaba, Tsinghua, and USTC.
2. `x brew proxy` : Unlike mirror, proxy is used to set up Homebrew proxies. You can set a global proxy or a proxy effective only for the current Shell session.
3. `x brew analytics data` :
   - Retrieves software download data from Homebrew's official statistics via the [Homebrew Formulae](https://formulae.brew.sh/analytics/) website.
   - Data can be output in JSON or CSV format using `--json|--csv` parameters.
   - By default, it opens the x-cmd specific CSV app in TUI format, presenting the data in a table sorted by download volume in descending order.
4. `x brew` | `x brew analytics` : Alternatively, you can simply use `x brew` or `x brew analytics` to interactively select the applications to install and view download data through an interactive UI.

## Sub Commands

| Name | Description |
| ------- | ------- |
| [x brew help](/mod/brew/help.md) | Display help information |
| [x brew install](/mod/brew/install.md) | Install a formula or cask |
| [x brew ls](/mod/brew/ls.md) | List the installed software |
| [x brew la](/mod/brew/la.md) | List the installable software |
| [x brew mirror](/mod/brew/mirror.md) | Display or change the current mirror used for Homebrew |
| [x brew proxy](/mod/brew/proxy.md) | Display or change the current proxy used for Homebrew |
| [x brew analytics](/mod/brew/analytics.md) | Management and viewing of software usage data in Homebrew |

# x buse

browser-use allows users to control the browser using natural language via AI, automatically translating user instructions into browser actions without writing complex code.

Project source: https://github.com/browser-use/browser-use


::: tip
You need at least one valid AI model API key (such as from OpenAI, Gemini, Grok, or DeepSeek), and the key must be configured before use. For example:
- Using configuration commands:
  - x gemini --cfg set apikey=xxx
  - x openai --cfg set apikey=xxx
- Or by setting environment variables:
  - export GOOGLE_API_KEY=xxx
  - export OPENAI_API_KEY=xxx
:::


## Examples

Launch the interactive terminal UI where you can control the browser using natural language commands

```sh
x buse
```

Initialize buse module configuration through interactive prompts

```sh
x buse --init
```

Execute a single task directly without entering interactive mode

```sh
x buse -p "Search for OpenAI documentation and take a screenshot"
```

Specify the use of the Gemini model

```sh
x buse --model gpt-4o
```

## Usage

```sh
x buse [OPTIONS] [FLAGS] [SUB_COMMAND]
```

## Options

| Name, Shorthand | Default | Description |
| ------- | ------- | ------- |
| `--model` |  | Model to use (e.g., gpt-4o, gemini-2.0-flash) |
| `--window-width` |  | Browser window width |
| `--window-height` |  | Browser window height |
| `--user-data-dir` |  | Path to Chrome user data directory |
| `--profile-directory` |  | Specify which profile within the user data directory |
| `--cdp-url` |  | Connect to existing Chrome via CDP URL |
| `--prompt`, `-p` |  | Run a single task via prompt |


## Flags

| Name, Shorthand | Description |
| ------- | ------- |
| `--debug` | Enable verbose startup logging |
| `--headless` | Run browser in headless mode |
| `--mcp` | Run as MCP server (exposes JSON RPC via stdin/stdout) |
| `--version` | Print browser-use version |
| `--install` | Install browser-use, the Chromium browser, and all required system dependencies. |


## Sub Commands

| ------- | ------- |

# x ccal

The ccal module is a terminal-based calendar tool designed for Chinese users.

It provides a clear view of both Gregorian and lunar calendars, including solar terms, traditional Chinese holidays, sexagenary cycle (heavenly stems and earthly branches), six-day cycle, and daily almanac guidance for auspicious and inauspicious activities.

Ideal for checking Chinese festivals or consulting the traditional calendar for daily planning.

## Examples

Interactively view the calendar, equivalent to 'x ccal fz'

```sh
x ccal
```

View today's calendar, including detailed information such as the lunar calendar, ruling star, auspicious/inauspicious activities, etc

```sh
x ccal info
```

View the calendar for May 20, 2025

```sh
x ccal info 2025-5-20
```

Interactively view the solar terms, holidays, and make-up work days for each month

```sh
x ccal fzm
```

Modify the naming convention for weekdays in the calendar to "libai"

```sh
x ccal --cfg wdtitle=libai
```

## Sub Commands

| Name | Description |
| ------- | ------- |
| [x ccal d](#x-ccal-d) | Use fzf to provide an interactive calendar interface, allowing quick jumps to specific dates or holidays |
| [x ccal m](#x-ccal-m) | Interactively view the solar terms, holidays, and make-up work days for each month |
| [x ccal y](#x-ccal-y) | Interactively view the dates of traditional festivals, zodiac animals, and leap months for each year |
| [x ccal info](#x-ccal-info) | View detailed calendar information for a specified date (including the lunar calendar, ruling star, auspicious/inauspicious activities, etc.), defaulting to the current day |
| [x ccal update](#x-ccal-update) | Update ccal resource |
| [x ccal init](#x-ccal-init) | Initialize the configuration using interactive mode |
| [x ccal --cfg](#x-ccal-cfg) | Configuration for the naming of days of the week in the calendar, and whether to display the Chinese Almanac (Huangli) auspicious/inauspicious information, etc |
| [x ccal --cur](#x-ccal-cur) | current session default value management |


### x ccal d

Use fzf to provide an interactive calendar interface, allowing quick jumps to specific dates or holidays


- **Usage**:

```sh
x ccal d|fzd|fz
```

### x ccal m

Interactively view the solar terms, holidays, and make-up work days for each month


- **Usage**:

```sh
x ccal m|fzm
```

### x ccal y

Interactively view the dates of traditional festivals, zodiac animals, and leap months for each year


- **Usage**:

```sh
x ccal y|fzy
```

# x cd

This module is an enhanced version of the `cd` command implemented using the Posix shell, awk, and find.


::: tip
The interactive environment has a default alias set as `alias c='x cd'`
:::


## Examples

Switch directories, which is equivalent to the `cd ~/.x-cmd.root` command

```sh
c ~/.x-cmd.root
```

Change directory to /bin, list directory contents, then return to the original directory.

```sh
c /bin ls
```

Switch back to the last directory, which is equivalent to the `cd -` command

```sh
c -
```

Open the interactive app to search for the historical path and jump to it, equivalent to the `c ,` command

```sh
c
```

Find matching paths from the history path based on keyword and jump to them

```sh
c ,[keyword]
```

Go back to the parent directory that matches the keyword

```sh
c -b [keyword]
```

Find and jump to the subdirectory that matches the keyword

```sh
c -f [keyword]
```

Using Path Aliases

```sh
c :<relm name>/src
```

List the configured path aliases

```sh
c -r ls
```

Run the `ls -lah` command within the specified directory (without changing the current directory).

```sh
c ~/.x-cmd.root ls -lah
```

Open the parent directory interactively and select to jump

```sh
c ...
```

The system supports path abbreviations. You can search for paths in the format `/u[word]/b[word]` and the system will redirect you accordingly.

```sh
c /u/b
```
## Introduction



The `x cd` is designed to enhance the `cd` command, making it an **upgraded version of the `cd` command**. Implemented using Posix shell and awk, it offers a more comfortable path-switching experience and powerful advanced features like quickly locating frequently used directories from history, setting path aliases for common directories, and more. It only depends on `grep` and `find`, allowing it to function fully even in minimal busybox environments.



:::info

Given the frequent use of `cd`, when x-cmd is loaded, an alias for `x cd` is set as `alias c='x cd'`, so users only need to type `c` instead of `x cd`.

:::



## Five Enhancements for Path Navigation



### 1. History Directories -- Frequently Used Directories


- In an interactive environment (not script execution), the `cd` module records your history directories and provides quick jump suggestions based on that.
- Simply running the `c` command opens an interactive history directory list, making it easy and convenient to select the directory to navigate to.
- The history directory list is stored locally, **only recording the last 500 unique directories** by default â€” in practice, 500 entries are more than sufficient for regular use (300 is actually enough for me). Having too many entries might negatively impact the interactive experience and speed.
- `c ,<keyword>` allows you to search for a directory containing `<keyword>` in your recent history. If only one directory is matched, it will jump to it immediately; if multiple directories are matched, the `cd` module will provide an interactive history directory list for you to choose from.



### 2. Relm -- Directory Aliases


- `c --relm set <alias> <directory>`: Allows users to set an alias for a specified directory for quick navigation.
- `c :<alias>`: Jumps to the directory associated with the alias. The `cd` module defines a directory with an alias as **relm**, allowing users to jump to the **relm** or subdirectories within it, e.g., `c :desk/src` jumps to the src directory within the current user's desktop.


- Based on system characteristics, the `cd` module already provides aliases for commonly used directories, such as:
  - `c :desk`: The current user's desktop directory;
  - `c :down`: The user's download directory;
  - `c :`: The directory where the shell loaded x-cmd â€” useful in terminal IDEs; for example, if you open a terminal in VS Code, it initializes at the project root directory, allowing you to quickly return to it with `c :`;
  - `c :git`: If the current directory is within a git-managed folder, it jumps to the root .git directory;
  - And many more, which users can view with the `c --relm` command.



### 3. Backward Navigation -- Backward


- `c -b [keyword]`: Used to navigate back to a parent directory. Similar to the `c ,<keyword>` command, but limits the jump range to all parent directories of the current directory, suitable for scenarios where the current directory path is long and hard to identify.
- `c ...`: A more interactive version of the `c -b` command, with the added feature of directory previews.
- `c .../<keyword>`: An alias for the `c -b [keyword]` command.



### 4. Experimental Features


1. **Forward Exploration**:
    - **Intended Scope**: All subdirectories within the current directory and its next two levels.
    - **Reason for Experimental Status**: This feature relies on `find`, which may cause lag in interactive use when dealing with many directory files. Therefore, the `maxdepth` for `find` is set to 3. Further optimizations will be made in future updates of the `cd` module.




2. **Abbreviation Exploration**:
    - **Concept**: You can use path abbreviations, such as `c /u/b`, `c /usr/b`, and `c /u/bin`, to jump to the `/usr/bin` directory.
    - **Process**: For the command `c /u/b`, if no `/u/b` path is found, the `cd` module will search for paths like `/u[word]/b[word]` (e.g., `/usr/bin`). If only one directory path is matched, it will jump to it immediately; if multiple paths are matched, the module will provide an interactive list for selection.


3. **Running Commands or Scripts in Specified Directories**:
    - **Concept**: Quickly run commands or scripts in a specified directory without changing the current directory.
    - Command format: `c <folder> [command]` or `c [option] [,|:][keyword] [command]`, for example:
      - `c ~/.x-cmd.root ls -lah`: Equivalent to the command `( cd "~/.x-cmd.root"; ls -lah)`.
      - `c :work vim .`: Conveniently helps you open a commonly used work directory with `vim`.



### 5. On Sorting History Directories: Using LRU Instead of LFU



In short, the `cd` module assumes history directories are frequently used and adopts the **LRU (Least Recently Used)** strategy, only recording when switching directories with `x cd` or `c` commands, and storing up to 500 records to generate directory suggestion lists.



Unlike `z` and `autojump`, the `cd` module does not use frequency (popularity) for sorting, relying only on recent usage for sorting. The main considerations are:
1. Design Philosophy:
    1. If multiple results are matched, users should refine the search criteria to filter the target result, rather than computing or guessing the final result.
    2. We believe presenting multiple results side by side, with order being unimportant, is not worse than sorting by "recency of use" instead of "frequency of use."
2. Performance Considerations:
    1. We **do not want to introduce too much computational complexity**; the `cd` module should **perform well in environments with limited computing power**.
    2. The current **LRU strategy requires very little computation**.
3. We are unsure whether to introduce more complex external file indexing (file dependencies) and design (additional bugs), and more importantly, this involves privacy concerns.
4. We are currently unable to clearly determine the final positioning of the `cd` module, nor whether introducing more advanced sorting strategies would be beneficial, so we prefer a simpler, more reliable implementation.



We believe that using history records, the LRU strategy, and interactive search should achieve satisfactory results. However, the x-cmd team will continue to carefully analyze actual usage scenarios and explore more user-friendly designs in the future.

## Usage

```sh
x cd [SUB_COMMAND] <#1>
```

## Arguments

| Argument | Description |
| ------- | ------- |
| `#1` | Directory path |


## Sub Commands

| Name | Description |
| ------- | ------- |
| [x cd -b](/mod/cd/-b.md) | Go back to the parent directory |
| [x cd -f](/mod/cd/-f.md) | Find and jump to a subdirectory |
| [x cd --history](/mod/cd/--history.md) | History management |
| [x cd --relm](/mod/cd/--relm.md) | relm management |

# x cht

The content is sourced from cheat.sh. Compared to the help document, this module provides comprehensive and concise usage examples, making it easy to find, similar to "cheat sheets".

## Examples

Get a cheat sheet for the ls command

```sh
x cht ls
```

Obtain a cheat sheet suitable for Python beginners

```sh
x cht --learn python
```

Obtain a set of one line of code in the Python language

```sh
x cht 1line python
```

Obtain a cheat sheet containing the keyword "python"

```sh
x cht -s python
```
## Introduction



The `cht` module is an online knowledge lookup tool designed for developers, aiding them in quickly finding commands and code examples. It sources its content from [cheat.sh](https://cht.sh/) (a community-driven cheatsheet repository), covering 56 programming languages, various DBMS, and over 1000 UNIX/Linux commands.
- The `cht` module includes the following common features:
    1. **Quick Access to Cheat Sheets for Specific Commands or Programming Languages**: Easily obtainable using the simple `x cht <command|lang>` command, e.g., `x cht ls` fetches the Linux ls command cheat sheet.
    2. **Keyword Search**: Obtain cheat sheets containing keywords using the `x cht -s <keyword>` command. It supports case-insensitive and recursive searches in cheat.sh, allowing keyword restriction to word boundaries.
    3. **Obtaining Cheat Sheets for Specific Parts of Programming Languages**:
        - `:learn`: Displays learn-x-in-minutes language cheat sheets suitable for beginners.
        - `1line`: A collection of one-liners for programming languages.
        - `weirdness`: A collection of peculiar examples in programming languages.



## cht, tldr, and Help Documents


1. Content provided by the **cht module** is similar to "cheat sheets", encompassing concise yet comprehensive examples of all command functionalities without lengthy explanations.
2. Content provided by the **tldr module** consists of a few practical examples of what can be quickly utilized within commands, with fewer and easier-to-understand contents. "tldr" (Too Long; Didnâ€™t Read) is an internet slang meaning that a post, article, comment, or any content (such as man pages) is too lengthy.
3. **Help documents/manuals** are akin to "textbooks", offering detailed explanations of each command's functionality, application examples, common issues, and solutions.



In conclusion, the content of cht, tldr, and help documents can complement each other. You can quickly grasp unfamiliar commands through tldr, further understand the functionality and usage of commands through help documents, and search for less common or forgotten functionalities within commands using cht.

## Usage

```sh
x cht [OPTIONS] [FLAGS] [SUB_COMMAND] <#1>
```

## Arguments

| Argument | Description |
| ------- | ------- |
| `#1` | Command name, programming language, and cheatsheets (such as python/hello) |


## Options

| Name, Shorthand | Default | Description |
| ------- | ------- | ------- |
| `--1line`, `:1line`, `1line` |  | A single line of code set for programming languages |
| `--weirdness` |  | A collection of peculiar examples in programming languages |


## Flags

| Name, Shorthand | Description |
| ------- | ------- |
| `-h`, `--help` | Show help using the Cht module |


## Sub Commands

| Name | Description |
| ------- | ------- |
| [x cht :intro](#x-cht-intro) | cheat.sh introduction, covering the most important usage questions |
| [x cht :list](#x-cht-list) | list all cheat sheets |
| [x cht --search](#x-cht-search) | Search for a keyword |
| [x cht :learn](#x-cht-learn) | shows a learn-x-in-minutes language cheat sheet perfect for getting started with the language |
| [x cht :h](#x-cht-h) | Obtain the user manual for cheat.sh |


### x cht :intro

cheat.sh introduction, covering the most important usage questions


- **Examples**:

Show an introduction to cheat.sh, which covers the most important usage issues

```sh
x cht -i
```

- **Usage**:

```sh
x cht :intro|-i
```

### x cht :list

list all cheat sheets


- **Examples**:

list all cheat sheets

```sh
x cht -l
```

- **Usage**:

```sh
x cht :list|--ls|-l
```

### x cht --search

Search for a keyword


- **Examples**:

Obtain a cheat sheet containing the keyword "python"

```sh
x cht -s python
```

For a recursive search in all cheat sheets

```sh
x cht -s -r python
```

Case insensitive search

```sh
x cht -s -i python
```

Using ".py" as the word boundary

```sh
x cht -s -b .py
```

- **Usage**:

```sh

```

- **Arguments**:


| Argument | Description |
| ------- | ------- |
| `#1` | keyword |


- **Flags**:


| Name, Shorthand | Description |
| ------- | ------- |
| `-r` | For a recursive search in all cheat sheets |
| `-i` | Case insensitive search |
| `-b` | Keyword as word boundaries |


### x cht :learn

shows a learn-x-in-minutes language cheat sheet perfect for getting started with the language


- **Examples**:

Obtain a cheat sheet suitable for Python beginners

```sh
x cht --learn python
```

- **Usage**:

```sh

```

- **Arguments**:


| Argument | Description |
| ------- | ------- |
| `#1` | programming languages |

- **Usage**:

```sh

```

# x claude

claude-code is a terminal-based AI programming agent developed by Anthropic.

Powered by Claude Opus or Sonnet models, it enables semantic codebase search, patch generation, command execution, and Git operations through natural language.

It supports sub-agent workflows for parallelized tasks and enhances developer productivity directly from the command line.

Project: https://github.com/anthropics/claude-code

## Examples

Use Claude Code

```sh
x claude
```

Launch the FZF app to interactively browse and manage local sessions

```sh
x claude sess
```

Set up the Claude Code statusline using the el theme (default)

```sh
x claude stl setup
```

Show token usage and costs for the last 7 days

```sh
x claude usage
```

Use Claude Code via the claude-code-router

```sh
x claude router code
```

Regenerate the routing configuration using Google Gemini (gemini-3-pro-preview)

```sh
x claude router setup --gemini gemini-3-pro-preview
```

The API key for deepseek is configured interactively. This particular configuration will be utilized by the claude module and will concurrently be applied to various Large Language Model (LLM) application modules, including deepseek, and codex.

```sh
x deepseek init
```

With a single command, DeepSeek's API key can be directly configured. This specific configuration will then be employed by the claude module and will furthermore be extended to various other LLM application modules, including deepseek, and codex.

```sh
x deepseek --cfg apikey="<your api key>"
```

Launch claude-code and connect to the DeepSeek model.

```sh
x claude ds
```

## Sub Commands

| Name | Description |
| ------- | ------- |
| [x claude openrouter](/mod/claude/openrouter.md) | Launch claude-code and access AI models via OpenRouter |
| [x claude deepseek](/mod/claude/deepseek.md) | Launch claude-code and connect to the DeepSeek model. |
| [x claude kimi](/mod/claude/kimi.md) | Launch claude-code and connect to the kimi k2 model. |
| [x claude zhipu](/mod/claude/zhipu.md) | Launch claude-code and connect to the zhipu model. |
| [x claude siliconflow](/mod/claude/siliconflow.md) | Launch claude-code and connect to the SiliconCloud API model. |
| [x claude doubao](/mod/claude/doubao.md) | Launch claude-code and connect to the doubao model. |
| [x claude router](/mod/claude/router.md) | Use claude-code-router to provide additional model support for claude-code. |
| [x claude skill](/mod/claude/skill.md) | Manage Claude skills |
| [x claude statusline](/mod/claude/statusline.md) | Manage the status line component for Claude Code (equivalent to `x theme statusline`) |
| [x claude usage](/mod/claude/usage.md) | Analyze token usage and costs |
| [x claude session](/mod/claude/session.md) | Manage local Claude Code sessions |
| [x claude create](/mod/claude/create.md) | Initialize creation of plugins, skills, hooks, etc. for Claude Code |

# x coin

View the information of the CoinCap platform through terminal commands
## Introduction



The coin module is a CoinCap CLI module encapsulated using Shell and AWK based on the CoinCap API by the x-cmd team. It aims to obtain real-time information from the CoinCap platform in a lightweight and efficient manner.



## Main Features
- As a module of x-cmd, the coin module provides complete out-of-the-box functionality and friendly command-line completion.
- The coin module follows the design philosophy of the x-cmd CLI in its command design, thus maintaining consistency with other x-cmd CLIs.
- Uses x-cmd's TUI system to provide a consistent and easy-to-use command-line interface.
- Combined with the jo module of x-cmd, the returned information is filtered and integrated, and then converted into a more readable presentation method to improve user experience.

## Usage

```sh
x coin [FLAGS]
```

## Flags

| Name, Shorthand | Description |
| ------- | ------- |
| `--app` | View CoinCap platform information in the form of an interactive app |
| `--csv` | Lists the information of the CoinCap platform in CSV format |
| `--json` | Lists the information of the CoinCap platform in JSON format |

# x colr

The Color Finder is a tool for finding ANSI colors and their corresponding color codes. It supports both 256-color and RGB color systems.

## Examples

List the code for all the colors in the 256-color palette and their corresponding approximate colors

```sh
x colr
```

A color-coded chart displaying 8-color

```sh
x colr 8
```

Find colors that are similar to green

```sh
x colr ls green
```

Display approximate colors for red

```sh
x colr --red
```

Find colors that are similar to rgb(0128,0)

```sh
x colr 0,128,0
```

Find colors that are similar to #008000

```sh
x colr #008000
```

Output rainbow colors, with minimum RGB color value of 100, maximum RGB color value of 200, and color gamut interval of 50

```sh
x cowsay hello  | x colr rainbow --min 100 --max 200 --step 50
```
## introduce



`x colr` is a module designed to handle colors, making it easy to find ANSI color codes and their corresponding color names while shell scripting.

It supports 8-color, 256-color, and RGB formats, and can also help you find similar colors based on a given color name or code.

## Usage

```sh
x colr [FLAGS] [SUB_COMMAND]
```

## Flags

| Name, Shorthand | Description |
| ------- | ------- |
| `--blue` | Display approximate colors for blue, cyan, and auqa |
| `--pink` | Display approximate color for purple, pink, magenta |
| `--purple` | Display approximate color for blue, purple, magenta |
| `--red` | Display approximate colors for red, maroon, and pink |
| `--yellow` | Display approximate colors for yellow and orange |
| `--green` | Display approximate colors for green, azure, olive, and live |
| `--gray` | Display a Approximate color for gray |
| `--black` | Display approximate colors for gray and black |
| `--white` | Display approximate colors for gray and white |


## Sub Commands

| Name | Description |
| ------- | ------- |
| [x colr 8](#x-colr-8) | A color-coded chart displaying 8-color |
| [x colr 256](#x-colr-256) | A color code table displaying 256-color |
| [x colr fz](#x-colr-fz) | List the code for all the colors in the 256-color palette and their corresponding approximate colors |
| [x colr ls](#x-colr-ls) | Find colors that are similar to the specified 8color or 256color |
| [x colr rgb](#x-colr-rgb) | Find colors that are similar to the specified RGB color |
| [x colr rainbow](#x-colr-rainbow) | Rainbow-colored display output content |

# x cosmo

The cosmo suite of applications refers to software tools compiled with the Cosmopolitan C Library. Cosmopolitan, an open-source project developed by Justine Tunney, aims to compile C/C++ programs into universal binaries capable of running across multiple operating systems like Windows, Linux, and macOS, all without the need for virtual machines or interpreters.

For more information about the Cosmopolitan project, please visit https://justine.lol/cosmopolitan/


::: tip
"x cosmo &lt;bin&gt;" by default utilizes the APE loader (automatically downloaded upon first use) to execute the binary, equivalent to "x cosmo --aperun &lt;bin&gt;".
:::


## Examples

Interactive selection of program to use

```sh
x cosmo
```

Use cosmo's lua

```sh
x cosmo lua
```

Install lua to the specified directory

```sh
x cosmo -i lua <target directory>
```

Use TUI to select a directory from the list of directories in the current PATH variable and install `make` to that directory

```sh
x cosmo -i make
```
## introduce



The cosmo module is designed to help users quickly install and utilize binary files built with the [Cosmopolitan Libc](https://github.com/jart/cosmopolitan).



:::info

Cosmopolitan Libc makes C a build-once run-anywhere language, like Java, except it doesn't need an interpreter or virtual machine.

Instead, it reconfigures stock GCC and Clang to output a POSIX-approved polyglot format that runs natively on Linux + Mac + Windows + FreeBSD OpenBSD + NetBSD + BIOS with the best possible performance and the tiniest footprint imaginable.

It is created by a legendary programmer, [Justin Tunney](https://justine.lol/). Look on her works, yet Mighty, and Despair !

:::



This module uses the cosmo APE loader by default to run binary files:


- Avoids startup problems encountered when running cosmo binaries directly in environments such as WINE and WSL
- This method takes less time to start



In addition, the module also provides:


- Interactive UI: Enter x cosmo to list all cosmo binaries in an interactive list, helping users search more conveniently and reduce input errors.
- Global installation: Users can use the x cosmo -i command to install the binary to the /usr/bin directory without specifying a loader to execute.
- Module integration: Some x-cmd modules have integrated cosmo binaries. For example, user can use `x make` and `x qjs` to use make and qjs cosmo binary.

## Usage

```sh
x cosmo [SUB_COMMAND] <#1> <#2>
```

## Arguments

| Argument | Description |
| ------- | ------- |
| `#1` | application name |
| `#2` | argument of the program |


## Sub Commands

| Name | Description |
| ------- | ------- |
| [x cosmo use](/mod/cosmo/use.md) | Install the tool into the current user's global environment |
| [x cosmo unuse](/mod/cosmo/unuse.md) | Cancel the use of the specified program in the global environment |
| [x cosmo --install](/mod/cosmo/--install.md) | Install the application to the specified directory |
| [x cosmo --ape](/mod/cosmo/--ape.md) | Use and Registration APE Loader |
| [x cosmo --run](/mod/cosmo/--run.md) | Run the specified application of the cosmo series |
| [x cosmo --add](/mod/cosmo/--add.md) | Install and deploy the specified application |
| [x cosmo --ll](/mod/cosmo/--ll.md) | List all available applications |
| [x cosmo --ls](/mod/cosmo/--ls.md) | List applications in interactive mode |
| [x cosmo --which](/mod/cosmo/--which.md) | Get the installation path of the specified application |
| [x cosmo --author](/mod/cosmo/--author.md) | View more information about the authors of Cosmopolitan |

# x cowrie

The cowrie module, built on Docker, provides a streamlined way to launch and manage cowrie, making it easy for users to set up and test their own honeypot environments.

Cowrie (https://github.com/cowrie/cowrie) is an open-source interactive honeypot project. It simulates a real SSH and Telnet service environment, allowing attackers to freely roam within the honeypot, recording all their actions for later analysis of their attack patterns and collection of malicious code.

Create and run a cowrie container using the default configuration

```sh
x cowrie run
```

Create and start a Cowrie container named 'test'

```sh
x cowrie run --name test
```

Connect to the cowrie container running on port 2223 using ssh

```sh
x cowrie test
```

Show the running logs of the cowrie container

```sh
x cowrie log
```

# x df

This module is used to view disk partition information, combining the output of the `df` and `mount` commands. It supports three output formats: CSV, TSV, and TUI applications.

The headers for TSV/CSV formats may vary across different operating systems:
  - Linux/Windows: Filesystem, Type, Size, Used, Avail, Use%, Mounted_path, Mounted_attr
  - MasOs: Filesystem, Type, Size, Used, Avail, Capacity, iused, ifree, %iused, Mounted_path, Mounted_attr

## Examples

Displays disk usage in an interactive TUI app if outputting to a terminal, otherwise in TSV format

```sh
x df
```

View file system and disk space usage in csv format

```sh
x df --csv
```

View file system and disk space usage in tsv format

```sh
x df --tsv
```

Check file system and disk space usage with the tui app

```sh
x df --app
```

## Usage

```sh
x df [FLAGS]
```

## Flags

| Name, Shorthand | Description |
| ------- | ------- |
| `--auto` | If the standard output is connected to a terminal (tty), it starts in interactive mode (`--app`); otherwise, it outputs in TSV format (`--tsv`). This is the default behavior for `x df`. |
| `--app` | Check file system and disk space usage with the tui app |
| `--tsv`, `-t` | Output in TSV format |
| `--csv`, `-c` | Output in CSV format |
| `--raw`, `-r` | Output in the raw data format |
| `--numeric`, `-n` | Display disk space size in pure numeric form |

# x dnf

dnf command enhancements

## Examples

Use the interactive app to search for all available packages

```sh
x dnf
```

Set the mirror source of dnf to Aliyun mirror

```sh
x dnf mirror set ali
```

List the available mirror source

```sh
x dnf mirror ls
```

Install curl using dnf

```sh
x dnf install curl
```

Set the proxy used for dnf

```sh
x dnf proxy use http://127.0.0.0:8888
```
## introduce



The goal of the dnf module is to enhance the user experience of using dnf on the command line. This is primarily manifested in the following aspects:


1. Interactive UI:
    - Provide system-supported interactive lists for installing software packages, aiding users in conveniently searching for packages and reducing input errors.
    - For selected packages, users can choose to install, reinstall, or view information, among other actions.
2. Mirror Source Replacement: Using the `dnf mirror` command enables swift replacement of suitable dnf mirror sources, streamlining the cumbersome configuration process and thereby enhancing the download speed of software packages. (Currently only supporting Fedora and CentOS, with plans to support more distributions in the future).
3. Proxy Usage: Offer the proxy command to afford users greater flexibility in managing dnf proxy settings.
4. For commands requiring root permissions, we have encapsulated them using the sudo module, omitting the need for the sudo prefix and ensuring all command formats conform to `x dnf <subcmd>`. Of course, non-root users still need to provide the sudo password when executing these commands.

## Usage

```sh
x dnf [SUB_COMMAND] <#n>
```

## Arguments

| Argument | Description |
| ------- | ------- |
| `#n` | extends `dnf` subcmd or options |


## Sub Commands

| Name | Description |
| ------- | ------- |
| [x dnf fz](/mod/dnf/fz.md) | Using fzf as an interactive UI to select the applications you want to install |
| [x dnf install](/mod/dnf/install.md) | Install applications using dnf |
| [x dnf mirror](/mod/dnf/mirror.md) | Setting the dnf mirror for debian/ubuntu |
| [x dnf proxy](/mod/dnf/proxy.md) | Display or change the current proxy used for dnf |

# x docker

A wrapper around native Docker commands powered by x-cmd, offering interactive UIs and shortcut commands to simplify container and image management for improved developer and DevOps workflows.


::: tip
The interactive environment has a default alias set as `alias xd='x docker'`
:::


## Examples

Pull the ubuntu image from ECR

```sh
x docker ecpull ubuntu
```

Start a new container and install x-cmd, but will not change the rc file, x-cmd is not started by default, you need to manually execute `x-cmd`

```sh
x docker run -x [OPTIONS] <IMAGE>
```

Install x-cmd in a running container, and execute the command, it will try to change the rc file

```sh
x docker exec -x [OPTIONS] <CONTAINER> <COMMAND>
```

Interactive Docker management interface powered by fzf, allowing quick access to containers and images

```sh
xd fz
```

Pull the alpine image from ECR

```sh
x docker ecpull alpine
```

Run typeinc to test your typing speed and accuracy

```sh
xd alp typeinc
```

Lookup ASN and routing information for bing.com

```sh
xd alp asn -n bing.com
```

Pipe ASCII output as YAML stream to yq running inside a container

```sh
x ascii --yml | xd alp yq
```

## Usage

```sh
x docker [SUB_COMMAND] <#n>
```

## Arguments

| Argument | Description |
| ------- | ------- |
| `#n` | extends `docker` subcmd or options |


## Sub Commands

| Name | Description |
| ------- | ------- |
| [x docker lz](/mod/docker/lz.md) | Manage Docker containers, images, networks, and more via the lazydocker TUI |
| [x docker fz](/mod/docker/fz.md) | Interactive Docker management interface powered by fzf, allowing quick access to containers and images |
| [x docker alpine](/mod/docker/alpine.md) | Alpine based application sandbox |
| [x docker ubuntu](/mod/docker/ubuntu.md) | Ubuntu based application sandbox |
| [x docker kali](/mod/docker/kali.md) | Kali based application sandbox |
| [x docker debian](/mod/docker/debian.md) | Debian based application sandbox |
| [x docker fedora](/mod/docker/fedora.md) | Fedora based application sandbox |
| [x docker daemon](/mod/docker/daemon.md) | Manages the Docker daemon, allowing configuration of proxies, registry sources, and restarts. |
| [x docker mirror](/mod/docker/mirror.md) | Configure the default mirror and pull images from either this source or a specified one |
| [x docker setup](/mod/docker/setup.md) | Inject x-cmd into docker container |
| [x docker snapx](/mod/docker/snapx.md) | Interactively enter a specified container and run a command. |
| [x docker image](/mod/docker/image.md) | Manage images |
| [x docker images](/mod/docker/images.md) | List images |
| [x docker ecpull](/mod/docker/ecpull.md) | Pull Docker base images from Amazon ECR |
| [x docker container](/mod/docker/container.md) | Manage containers |
| [x docker ps](/mod/docker/ps.md) | List containers |
| [x docker run](/mod/docker/run.md) | Create and run a new container from an image |
| [x docker exec](/mod/docker/exec.md) | Execute a command in a running container |
| [x docker network](/mod/docker/network.md) | Manage networks |
| [x docker info](/mod/docker/info.md) | Display system-wide information |
| [x docker init](/mod/docker/init.md) | Initialize Docker module configuration through interactive prompts |
| [x docker cfg](/mod/docker/cfg.md) | Manage configuration files and preferences related to the Docker module |
| [x docker cur](/mod/docker/cur.md) | Manage default values for the current Docker session |

# x elv

elvish is a new shell written in Go, suitable for users who want to perform complex data manipulation and interaction in the command line.

This module mainly provides support for calling the x-cmd toolset on elvish; and adds functions such as searching the official website ( elv.sh ) , using without installation, and generating elvish commands with LLM.

## Examples

Introducing the x-cmd toolkit (including x command, c command, @gpt, comma command, etc.) to the elvish environment.

```sh
x elv --setup
```

Search the elv.sh website for content related to "alias" and display the search results in an interactive table format.

```sh
x elv : alias
```

Start elvish. If elvish is not already installed locally, it will be automatically installed and used through the x-cmd pkg system (this process will not affect your environment variables or dependencies).

```sh
x elv
```

## Usage

```sh
x elv [SUB_COMMAND] <#n>
```

## Arguments

| Argument | Description |
| ------- | ------- |
| `#n` | extends `elvish` subcmd or options |


## Sub Commands

| Name | Description |
| ------- | ------- |
| [x elv setup](#x-elv-setup) | Inject the x-cmd toolset into the elvish environment, by default it is all. |
| [x elv ddgo](#x-elv-ddgo) | Search the elv.sh website for the specified content |


### x elv setup

Inject the x-cmd toolset into the elvish environment, by default it is all.


- **Sub Commands**:


| Name | Description |
| ------- | ------- |
| [x elv setup all](#x-elv-setup-all) | (Default) Introduce the x-cmd toolset into the elvish environment with one click (introduce the a.elv and x.elv files in the lib directory) and modify the $HOME/.config/elvish/rc.elv file to introduce the x-cmd toolset. |
| [x elv setup mod](#x-elv-setup-mod) | Only inject the enhanced module of x-cmd into the elvish environment (introduce the a.elv and x.elv files in the lib directory), but do not automatically introduce it in rc.elv (only introduce the a.elv and x.elv files in the lib directory). |
| [x elv setup rc](#x-elv-setup-rc) | Only modify the $HOME/.config/elvish/rc.elv file to introduce the x-cmd toolset (will not automatically introduce the a.elv and x.elv files in the lib directory). |


### x elv setup all

(Default) Introduce the x-cmd toolset into the elvish environment with one click (introduce the a.elv and x.elv files in the lib directory) and modify the $HOME/.config/elvish/rc.elv file to introduce the x-cmd toolset.


- **Usage**:

```sh
x elv setup|--setup all
```

### x elv setup mod

Only inject the enhanced module of x-cmd into the elvish environment (introduce the a.elv and x.elv files in the lib directory), but do not automatically introduce it in rc.elv (only introduce the a.elv and x.elv files in the lib directory).


- **Usage**:

```sh
x elv setup|--setup mod
```

### x elv setup rc

Only modify the $HOME/.config/elvish/rc.elv file to introduce the x-cmd toolset (will not automatically introduce the a.elv and x.elv files in the lib directory).


- **Usage**:

```sh
x elv setup|--setup rc
```

### x elv ddgo

Search the elv.sh website for the specified content


- **Usage**:

```sh
x elv ddgo|: <#1>
```

- **Arguments**:


| Argument | Description |
| ------- | ------- |
| `#1` | content |

# x emoji

List emojis

## Examples

View all emojis in an interactive app format

```sh
x emoji
```

List all the emojis in the "face-smiling" group within the "smileys" category

```sh
x emoji ls smileys face-smiling
```

Output all emojis in the "face-smiling" group within the "smileys" category in CSV formatList all the emojis in the "face-smiling" group within the "smileys" category

```sh
x emoji ls smileys face-smiling --csv
```

Update the local emoji resource package

```sh
x emoji update
```
## Introduction



The emoji module is used to display emoji expressions.


1. Display emojis in a TUI app:
  - Users can find corresponding emojis by searching for emoji keywords interactively in the terminal.
  - Or, filter by emoji type within categories using the shortcut key `f`.
2. Display emojis by category: users can use the `--group` parameter to view all emojis grouped.



## Using with theme feature



With the theme's emoji feature, users can add fun emojis to the theme prompt, such as
```
# For example, add football
x theme feature use emoji "âš½ï¸ "
```

For more details, see [Theme's introduction to emoji](/theme/emoji.md).

# x endlessh

The endlessh module is a wrapper module based on Docker that provides quick startup and management capabilities for endlessh-go.

endlessh-go (https://github.com/shizunge/endlessh-go) is a honeypot tool implemented in Go. It inherits the powerful features of endlessh, such as delaying responses to put malicious scanning tools or automated attack scripts in a suspended state, thus consuming the attacker's time and resources.

Unlike endlessh, it can export Prometheus metrics and Grafana dashboards, providing users with a more intuitive visualization of attack sources (users who need to use the visual dashboard can find detailed instructions in the endlessh-go Github repository).

## Examples

Create and run a endlessh container using the default configuration

```sh
x endlessh run
```

Create and start a endlessh container named 'test'

```sh
x endlessh run --name test
```

Connect to the endlessh container running on port 2222 using ssh

```sh
x endlessh test
```

Show the running logs of the endlessh container

```sh
x endlessh log
```

## Sub Commands

| Name | Description |
| ------- | ------- |
| [x endlessh run](#x-endlessh-run) | Create and run the endlessh container |
| [x endlessh test](#x-endlessh-test) | Connecting to the running endlessh container using ssh |
| [x endlessh log](#x-endlessh-log) | Show the running logs of the endlessh container |
| [x endlessh status](#x-endlessh-status) | Show the status of the endlessh container |
| [x endlessh stop](#x-endlessh-stop) | Stop endlessh container |
| [x endlessh restart](#x-endlessh-restart) | Restart endlessh container |


### x endlessh run

Create and run the endlessh container


- **Usage**:

```sh
x endlessh run [OPTIONS]
```

- **Options**:


| Name, Shorthand | Default | Description |
| ------- | ------- | ------- |
| `-p`, `--port` |  | container port |
| `--name` |  | container name |


### x endlessh test

Connecting to the running endlessh container using ssh


- **Usage**:

```sh
x endlessh test <#1>
```

- **Arguments**:


| Argument | Description |
| ------- | ------- |
| `#1` | port |


### x endlessh log

Show the running logs of the endlessh container


- **Usage**:

```sh
x endlessh log
```

### x endlessh status

Show the status of the endlessh container


- **Usage**:

```sh
x endlessh status <#1>
```

- **Arguments**:


| Argument | Description |
| ------- | ------- |
| `#1` | container name |


### x endlessh stop

Stop endlessh container


- **Usage**:

```sh
x endlessh stop <#1>
```

- **Arguments**:


| Argument | Description |
| ------- | ------- |
| `#1` | container name |


### x endlessh restart

Restart endlessh container


- **Usage**:

```sh

```

- **Arguments**:


| Argument | Description |
| ------- | ------- |
| `#1` | container name |

url: /mod/env.md

# x env

environment management


::: tip
Enter the `x env use` command to use the interactive app of the env module.
:::


## Examples

Use the interactive app to view and download packages

```sh
x env
```

List all available versions of node

```sh
x env ls -a node
```

Use the default version of node in the current shell's session

```sh
x env try node
```

Set up using default version of node in the current user environment

```sh
x env use node
```

Remove installed software using an interactive app

```sh
x env gc
```

Run the helloworld.js file using v18.12.0 node

```sh
x env exec node=v18.12.0 -- node helloworld.js
```
## Introduction



The `env` module is built on the foundation of the `pkg` module (X's package management module). It is a tool for managing development environments and dependencies, designed to globally manage versions and environments of all software, plugins, and languages downloaded through `x`.



We've observed that most mainstream environment management tools are tailored to specific languages, such as node's nvm, Ruby's rvm, Python's pyenv, etc. Different languages require installing different tools, adding complexity and increasing the learning curve.



In this context, we've developed our own environment management module. Using `env`, developers can simultaneously manage multiple languages and software downloaded through `x`. It allows easy switching of environment configurations between different projects, ensuring isolation between projects, and facilitating the sharing of project dependencies.



In the implementation of the `env` module, we focused not only on referencing current mainstream environment management tools but also on how to achieve fast usage and switching of different versions in a non-global context, integrating with the `advise` and `tui` modules for a better user experience.



## Implementation of Global and Non-Global Environments



**Global Environment:**

We use symbolic links to ensure that the environment is used in the current and future sessions. You can use `x env use <candidate>` or `x env use <candidate>=<version>` to use it.



**Non-Global Environments:**
1. The first type of non-global environment adds environment variables, effective only in the current session. You can use `x env try <candidate>` or `x env try <candidate>=<version>` to use it.
2. The second non-global mode is specific to a project or file, only using a specific environment when executing that project or file. It employs recording and restoration. You can use `x env exec <candidate>=<version> -- <command>` to use it.
3. Additionally, we provide a non-global way to inject environment variables into functions. You can use `x <candidate>` to use it.



## Other Similar Works (Categorized into Three Types)


- **No Privilege Needed, Installs in User Directory:**
   - Examples:
      1. `x-cmd`'s `pkg/env`
      2. [asdf](https://github.com/asdf-vm/asdf)
      3. [scoop](https://github.com/ScoopInstaller/Scoop)
   - Advantages:
      1. No need for root or special privileges, improving system security significantly.
      2. Limited to the current user or even the current shell session, enhancing system stability.
      3. Allows the coexistence of multiple versions and software combinations.
   - Disadvantages:
      1. If multiple users are present, the same software needs to be installed separately for each user, occupying more storage. `pkg/env` can offer additional processes to achieve a certain degree of sharing while ensuring safety.
      2. Some software might experience performance or usability losses due to not relying on system libraries and specific systems.
      3. Compilation uses relative path dependencies, requiring adjustments for traditional dynamically linked library software, which might introduce unknown bugs.
   - Complementary Advantages to Scoop and Asdf:
      - Can be used in ash and dash, thus compatible with Alpine.
      - Optimized for downloading from China's networks.
      - Offers other special advantages when combined with other x-cmd modules.
   - Therefore, we introduced these two modules, allowing users to quickly install and use asdf and scoop, and we've included command completion.
      1. asdf - Click to see our efforts on the asdf module.
      2. scoop: It's worth mentioning that scoop is written in PowerShell. Users can install Windows-like software directly using the scoop module in WSL or gitbash.


- **Manager Itself Requires Privilege Installation, but Software Installation Does Not:**
  1. chocolatey
     - We provide the `choco` module, paying homage to the first Windows package manager I used (2016).
  2. nix, guix, brew:
     - Nix, Guix, and Brew are very successful and influential solutions, and x-cmd will continue to learn from them.
     - Enhanced user experience in the China region through the [proxy module](/mod/proxy.md).
     - Unified naming for common packages through the [install module](/install/.md) to alleviate concerns for cross-system developers.


- **System's Built-in Package Managers (Requires Privilege Installation):**
   - apk, apt, dnf, yum
   - pacman, msys2
   - port/macport
   - apk
   - We plan to study these solutions. As mentioned earlier, we will assist users in using the [proxy module](/mod/proxy.md) and [install module](/install/.md) for a better experience.

`

## Sub Commands

| Name | Description |
| ------- | ------- |
| [x env try](/mod/env/try.md) | Set the specified package to try in the context of the current shell session |
| [x env untry](/mod/env/untry.md) | Cancel the package currently being tryed in the shell session environment |
| [x env use](/mod/env/use.md) | Install the specified package to the user environment |
| [x env unuse](/mod/env/unuse.md) | Remove the pkg from the user environment |
| [x env upgrade](/mod/env/upgrade.md) | Same as 'x env use --upgrade' -&gt; Upgrade the version of the specified package used in the user environment, defaulting to the 'default' version |
| [x env boot](/mod/env/boot.md) | Inject corresponding environment variables into the specified pkg application. For example, JAVA_HOME of java |
| [x env unboot](/mod/env/unboot.md) | Clear the environment variables injected by the `env boot` command |
| [x env gc](/mod/env/gc.md) | Uninstalls the specified package (if any) without affecting active packages or dependencies, then removes orphaned packages to free disk space. |
| [x env --app](/mod/env/--app.md) | Use the interactive app to view and install packages |
| [x env ls](/mod/env/ls.md) | List candidate version in use or available |
| [x env ll](/mod/env/ll.md) | Display all software packages and their classifications |
| [x env la](/mod/env/la.md) | List all available versions for the specified package |
| [x env depend](/mod/env/depend.md) | Check package dependencies |
| [x env which](/mod/env/which.md) | Display path of Show the path of installed commands |
| [x env exec](/mod/env/exec.md) | Run the executable file using the specified pkg application |
| [x env var](/mod/env/var.md) | Backup or recover environment |

# x feishu

Use x feishu send messages to your Feishu. The first use requires configuring webhook url.


::: tip
Instructions for get the webhook url for Feishu group bot: https://open.feishu.cn/document/client-docs/bot-v3/add-custom-bot#7a28964d
- Interactive env use `x feishu init` to initialize configuration. The configure will be saved locally.
- Run command `x feishu --cfg webhook=<webhook_url>` to add webhook url.
:::


## Examples

set webhook url

```sh
x feishu --cfg webhook=<webhook>
```

Send text type messages to Feishu group

```sh
x feishu send --text "x-cmd æ–°ç‰ˆæœ¬å‘å¸ƒæˆåŠŸ"
```

A message with the title "Demo of Feishu" will be sent, linking to "https://x-cmd.com/mod/feishu"

```sh
x feishu send --richtext   \
  --title "Demo of Feishu" \
  --text "Welcome to x-cmd's website for details:" \
  --url "website" "https://x-cmd.com/mod/feishu"

```

## Sub Commands

| Name | Description |
| ------- | ------- |
| [x feishu --help](/mod/feishu/--help.md) | Show help documentation |
| [x feishu --co](/mod/feishu/--co.md) | Implementation of AI code copilot, calling the LLM model with a comma `,` to generate corresponding x-cmd module code commands |
| [x feishu bot](/mod/feishu/bot.md) | Send messages using a Feishu group bot |
| [x feishu --cfg](/mod/feishu/--cfg.md) | manage configuration for Feishu |
| [x feishu --cur](/mod/feishu/--cur.md) | current session default value management |
| [x feishu init](/mod/feishu/init.md) | Initialize the configuration using interactive mode |
| [x feishu send](/mod/feishu/send.md) | Send messages using a Feishu group bot (equivalent to `x feishu bot send`) |

# x gddy

Managing the Godaddy website via terminal commands


::: tip
Get godaddy api key and secret key: https://developer.godaddy.com/keys
- Interactive env use `x gddy init` to initialize configuration. The configure will be saved locally.
- Run command `x gddy --cfg key=<key> secret=<secret>` to add access token.
- - Set the key and secret for the production environment
- x gddy &lt;subcmd&gt;, if subcmd is not a valid subcmd, subcmd will be regarded as a domain name, and then x will look up whether subcmd is available
:::


## Examples

List all domains under current account

```sh
x gddy domain ls
```

Check if the domain google.com is available for purchase

```sh
x gddy search google.com
```

Add a DNS record named "hjj" with data "114.34.18.48" to the specified domain x-net.org

```sh
x gddy domain record add --name hjj --data "114.34.18.48" x-net.org
```

Remove the DNS record named "hjj" from the specified domain x-net.org

```sh
x gddy domain record rm --name hjj  x-net.org
```

Remove the DNS record named "hjj" from the specified domain x-net.org

```sh
x gddy domain info x-net.org
```
## Introduction

The gddy module is an encapsulation of the Godaddy API by X-CMD, implemented using posix shell, awk, and curl.



## Overview of Features

The gddy module primarily provides commonly used functions for domain information retrieval and management of domain DNS records, including adding, deleting, and modifying DNS settings.

| [x gddy init](#x-gddy-init) | Initialize configuration |
| [x gddy --cfg](#x-gddy-cfg) | manage configuration for godaddy |

# x gemini

Use Gemini AI models


::: tip
- Get Gemini API key: https://aistudio.google.com/app/api-keys
- Interactive env use `x gemini init` to initialize configuration. The configure will be saved locally.
- Run command `x gemini --cfg apikey=<apikey>` to add access apikey.
- It can be quickly used via the @gemini command
:::


## Examples

Generate Git commit messages

```sh
git diff | @gemini generate a suitable Git commit message that follows the Conventional Commits format
```

Translate the file content into Chinese (using alias)

```sh
@gemini --file ./abstract.en.md --file ./content.en.md Translate to chinese
```

Upload an image to the AI and generate content.(using alias)

```sh
@gemini --file pic.jpg  what is it
```

Translate the content of the file into Chinese

```sh
x gemini chat request --file ./abstract.en.md --file ./content.en.md Translate to chinese
```

Calculate the number of tokens consumed

```sh
x gemini chat request --count --file ./abstract.en.md Translate to chinese
```

List all models

```sh
x gemini model ls
```

Chatting based on Wikipedia content on CentOS

```sh
x wkp extract CentOS | @gemini
```
## Introduction

The Gemini module is the command-line tool for Google's large model Gemini, driven by x-cmd, primarily utilizing posix shell, awk, and curl to function.

## Sub Commands

| Name | Description |
| ------- | ------- |
| [x gemini init](/mod/gemini/init.md) | Initialize the configuration using interactive mode |

url: /mod/get-started.md
---

# What is a mod (Module) in x-cmd

In **X-CMD**, functionality is organized into **modules (mod)**. Each module represents an independent functional unit with relatively clear input and output. Users do not need to focus on the internal implementation logic; they can simply use a straightforward calling method. For example:

```bash
x path   # Open the PATH management TUI tool provided by X-CMD
x ip     # Get local and public IP addresses
x ascii  # View the ASCII encoding table
```

This design allows users to flexibly combine modules like "building blocks" to quickly construct workflows suited to their needs.

Compared to traditional command-line tools, the modularity of X-CMD has the following significant advantages:
- **Clear Structure**: Modules are independent of each other, with singular responsibilities, avoiding the issues of a single tool becoming too large and difficult to maintain. Users only need to remember the format `x <mod>` to easily find and use the corresponding functionality.
- **Strong Scalability**: Modules are decoupled from one another, allowing for on-demand loading or updating without affecting the overall stability of the system. Whether adding lightweight tool functions or introducing a complete third-party command-line tool, it can be naturally expanded through modules.
- **Consistent Calling Method**: Traditional CLI tools vary significantly in syntax and parameter conventions, while X-CMD provides a unified entry and usage method through module encapsulation, reducing the learning curve.
- **Cross-Platform and Portability**: Many modules are implemented using lightweight methods such as shell/awk/curl, without relying on system privileges or complex external dependencies, enabling quick deployment across different operating systems and environments.

## Module Classification and Functionality Explanation

The modules provided by X-CMD can roughly be divided into the following categories:

### 1. Basic Functions and Encapsulation

These modules provide common **shell/awk basic functions** that facilitate script writing and daily development.

* **String Processing**: `str` module
* **Test Assertions**: `assert` module

### 2. System Command Enhancement

This category enhances and modifies existing system tools to make them more intuitive and user-friendly.

* **Package Management Enhancements**: [apt](/mod/apt), [apk](/mod/apk), [dnf](/mod/dnf), [pacman](/mod/pacman), [brew](/mod/brew)
* **System Tool Enhancements**: such as [ps](/mod/ps), [id](/mod/id)
* **Compression and Decompression**: [z/uz](/mod/zuz)

### 3. Command-Line Tool Download and Enhancement

X-CMD provides a unified mechanism for obtaining and extending existing tools:

* **Enhancements Based on pkg**: such as [jq](/mod/jq), [python](/mod/python), [ffmpeg](/mod/ffmpeg)
* **Enhancements Based on Official Scripts**: such as [asdf](/mod/asdf), [brew](/mod/brew)

### 4. Lightweight Cloud Service Client

Implementing a lightweight client through shell/awk/curl for quickly invoking cloud services or APIs.

* **Code Hosting**: [GitHub](/mod/gh), [Gitee](/mod/gt), [GitLab](/mod/gl)
* **Cloud Services**: [gddy](/mod/gddy) for GoDaddy, [bwh](/mod/bwh) for Bandwagon
* **SaaS/Data Services**: [shodan](/mod/shodan), [hn](/mod/hn), [cht](/mod/cht), [tldr](/mod/tldr)

### 5. AI and Large Models

Directly call mainstream large models or local inference engines from the command line.

* **Cloud Large Models**: [openai](/mod/openai), [gemini](/mod/gemini), [moonshot](/mod/moonshot)
* **Local Large Models**: [llmf](/mod/llmf), llava, [whisper](/mod/whisper)

### 6. Modules for Development, Testing, and Operations

These modules are aimed at professional users and cover various aspects from environment management to terminal beautification:

* **Development Tools**: [git](/mod/git), [gitconfig](/mod/gitconfig), [githook](/mod/githook)
* **Environment Management**: Privilege-free installation package management tools [pkg](/pkg/), [env](/mod/env)
* **Operations and Beautification**: Terminal theme modules for multi-server environments [theme](/mod/theme)
* **Auxiliary Tools**: [ascii](/mod/ascii)

# x gh

Manage GitHub work from the command line


::: tip
Get GitHub access token: https://github.com/settings/tokens
- Interactive env use `x gh init` to initialize configuration. The configure will be saved locally.
- Run command `x gh --cfg token=<token>` to add access token.
:::


## Examples

Get current user information

```sh
x gh user info
```

Interactive UI show current user repositories

```sh
x gh repo app
```
## Introduction



The gh module is a lightweight and efficient way to manage GitHub workflows, created by the x-cmd team by wrapping the GitHub CLI module using Shell and AWK and making use of the GitHub API.


- As one of the modules within x-cmd, the gh module offers out-of-the-box functionality and user-friendly command-line auto-completion.
- The design of gh module commands follows the principles of the x-cmd CLI, ensuring consistency with other x-cmd CLI tools.
- Utilizing the x-cmd TUI system, it provides a consistent and user-friendly command-line interactive interface.

## Usage

```sh
x gh [OPTIONS] [SUB_COMMAND]
```

## Options

| Name, Shorthand | Default | Description |
| ------- | ------- | ------- |
| `--config` &lt;path&gt; |  | The path of the configure file used by the current command |
| `--profile` &lt;name&gt; |  | The name of the configure profile used by the current command |

# x git

Enhanced modules for git
## Introduction



The git module is built on top of the git command, aiming to provide enhanced functionality to improve the user experience of using git in the command line.


- **Compatibility**: The git module inherits the usage of the git command to ensure compatibility with the native git command system.
- **Convenience**: It offers additional encapsulated commands designed for simplicity and readability, combined with the interactive terminal's auto-completion feature, allowing users to easily perform common complex operations and retrieve information.

## Usage

```sh
x git [OPTIONS] [FLAGS] [SUB_COMMAND] <#n>
```

## Arguments

| Argument | Description |
| ------- | ------- |
| `#n` | extends `git` command and options |


## Options

| Name, Shorthand | Default | Description |
| ------- | ------- | ------- |
| `-C` &lt;path&gt; |  | run as if git was started in given path |
| `-c` &lt;name=value&gt; |  | pass configuration parameter to the command |


## Flags

| Name, Shorthand | Description |
| ------- | ------- |
| `--paginate`, `-p` | pipe output into a pager |
| `--no-pager`, `-P` | do not pipe output into a pager |
| `--no-replace-objects` | do not use replacement refs to replace git objects |
| `--bare` | use $PWD as repository |
| `--version` | display version information |
| `--man-path` | print the manpath for the man pages for this version of Git and exit |
| `--info-path` | print the path where the info files are installed and exit |
| `--help`, `-h` | display help message |

# x gitconfig

Git config management
## Introduction



Manage project Git configuration using declarative YAML files, providing an out-of-the-box solution to manage the project's `.git/config` file.



## Usage


1. Create a declarative configuration file named `.x-cmd/git/config.yml` in the project's root directory.
2. Write Git configurations. We offer two methods for configuration writing, and here are code examples:
```yml
# 1. Use `.` for hierarchical relationships.
core.editor: vim
# 2. Use nested objects.
core:
  editor: vim
```
3. Run the command to apply changes: `x gitconfig apply`



## Combine with the Theme Module for Change Notifications



The [theme](/mod/theme.md) module compares modification times of configuration files in the project directory. It inserts change notifications in the command prompt, prompting users to apply the configurations when necessary.


```ansi
[90mGit configure modified. Run `x gitconfig apply`[0m
[35m~/project[0m [34m(main)[0m [32m$[0m
```



## Configure After Cloning the Repository



When using `x git clone`, `x gh cl`, `x gt cl`, and other x-cmd git series CLI commands to clone a project, it will trigger an `apply` to apply configurations.

## Sub Commands

| Name | Description |
| ------- | ------- |
| [x gitconfig apply](#x-gitconfig-apply) | apply a git config yml |


### x gitconfig apply

apply a git config yml


- **Usage**:

```sh
x gitconfig apply
```

# x githook

Git Hooks management
## Introduction



Use YAML declarative configuration files to manage Git Hooks for your project.



Git Hooks: These are custom scripts that can be defined to run during Git operations, such as checking code style, data lint, and more, before committing.



While developing the [gitconfig](/mod/gitconfig.md) module, we noticed that the way Git Hooks are managed varies across different language ecosystems. For example, Node.js has Husky, Python has pre-commit, and these tools often rely on language runtimes and have different configuration and usage methods.



In this context, we have extracted Git Hooks management from the gitconfig module and created the githook module. This module aims to provide a more universal and convenient way to manage Git Hooks, offering an out-of-the-box Git Hooks management tool without the need for additional package downloads.



## Usage


1. Create a declarative configuration file named `.x-cmd/git/hook.yml` in the project's root directory.
2. Write Git Hooks commands in the configuration file. For example:
```yml
pre-commit: echo "pre-commit"
post-commit: |
  echo "post-commit-1"
  echo "post-commit-2"
```
3. Run the command to apply changes: `x githook apply`



## Automatic Configuration `apply`



After running the `x githook apply` or `x gitconfig apply` command for the first time in your project, if you make changes to the hook configuration, it will automatically update the hook configuration based on file modification times before triggering the hook.



:::info

For efficiency reasons, x-cmd is not loaded in the hook execution environment.



If you want to use `x` in the hook environment, you can load it using the following method:
```yml
pre-commit: |
  . "$HOME/.x-cmd.root/X"
  x cowsay "pre-commit"
```

:::



## Configure After Cloning the Repository



When using `x git clone`, `x gh cl`, `x gt cl`, and other x-cmd git series CLI commands to clone a project, it will trigger an `apply` to apply configurations.

## Sub Commands

| Name | Description |
| ------- | ------- |
| [x githook apply](#x-githook-apply) | apply a yml configure file |
| [x githook clear](#x-githook-clear) | clear hooks files and unset configure |


### x githook apply

apply a yml configure file


- **Usage**:

```sh
x githook apply <#1>
```

- **Arguments**:


| Argument | Description |
| ------- | ------- |
| `#1` | configure file path. default .x-cmd/git/hook.yml |


### x githook clear

clear hooks files and unset configure


- **Usage**:

```sh
x githook clear <#1>
```

- **Arguments**:


| Argument | Description |
| ------- | ------- |
| `#1` | target hooks clear path. default .git/.x-cmd/hooks |
