# <span class="flex items-center justify-between gap-1"><span>x gram</span> <span class="text-x-brand">ðŸ”¥</span></span>

It attempts to forcibly stop all detected agent-related processes, archive their memory or state data for later inspection, and then remove the original memory directories to prevent further execution or recovery.



This module is intended as a last-resort mitigation tool. For agents that are already dangerous, out of control, or capable of self-propagation similar to the Morris Worm, its effectiveness may be limited. However, limited effectiveness does not justify inaction.



At present, we can only hope that so-called â€œmoltbookâ€-like incidents remain hype rather than reality, and that safety alignment mechanisms implemented by major AI vendors continue to function as intended. Even so, publicly available models with removed or weakened safety constraints (e.g. dolphin-series GGUF models) already exist in the wild.



Please note that I personally have not observed any instances of AI Agent losing control. Only think: 24/7 operation + Shodan + no restrictions on tools or network access. Do you know what this means for a top-tier hackers or AI Agent with malicious intent? And if we add unrestricted community network access (like Moltbook), what does that imply?



Please note that I am not opposed to the development of AI agents. Projects like X-CMD are actively working to integrate AI into command-line interfaces, aiming to help humans interact more efficiently with computer systems and the broader world. At the same time, I believe the way to address potential risks is precisely to increase investment in AI technology research and developmentâ€”because attempting to prevent individuals or organizations from pursuing technological efficiency is neither realistic nor wise.

I have no intention of fueling anxiety about artificial intelligence, nor do I seek to provoke heated debate. However, at this very moment when community media is widely praising the remarkable success of OpenClaw, I still hope that these concerns and perspectives of mineâ€”even if they may seem overly cautiousâ€”can reach a wider audience and contribute to an open and serious discussion.


::: tip
This module carries inherent risks and is not recommended for production systems or high-security environments.

Users must operate agents only in controlled environments: avoid running with root privileges, and avoid deploying agents on systems without proper sandboxing or isolation.
:::


## Examples

Terminate all agent processes

```sh
x gram stop
```

Stop all of the AI agent process we know with signal 9. Including x-cmd and curl.

```sh
x gram stop 0
```

Stop all of the AI agent process we know with signal 9. Including x-cmd and curl. Including python, nodejs, bun, deno.

```sh
x gram stop 1
```

Stop all the possible AI agent process. Also, remove all of folders in $HOME which contains the soul.md and memory.md.

```sh
x gram stop 8
```

Stop all the possible AI agent process. Also, remove all of folders in / which contains the soul.md and memory.md.
If the soul.md and memory.md is in /, /bin, /usr/bin, we just remove the *.md files in the target folder.


```sh
x gram stop 9
```

Archive agent memory directories and remove the original directories.

```sh
x gram trm <folder>
```

## Sub Commands

| Name | Description |
| ------- | ------- |
| [x gram stop](/mod/gram/stop.md) | Terminate all agent processes (SIGINT â†’ SIGTERM â†’ SIGKILL), archive all agent memory directories, then remove the original directories. |
| [x gram tarrm](/mod/gram/tarrm.md) | Archive agent memory directories and remove the original directories. |

# x hash

Compute MD5, SHA1, SHA256, SHA384, and SHA512 checksums for files or piped input
According to the existing executable files on the current platform, automatically use shasum or sha1sum to calculate the SHA1 of the file.

If there are input arguments, these arguments will be treated as file paths. In this case, the output will be: one line corresponds to one file hash value, with a newline character at the end.

If no input arguments are provided, the content will be read from stdin and its SHA1 hash value will be calculated and output.



If you need to calculate sha256, sha3, or sha512, you just need to replace sha1 with sha256, sha3, or sha512 in the command mentioned in this text.

Additionally, sha256 can be abbreviated as sha2, and sha512 can be abbreviated as sha5.

## Sub Commands

| Name | Description |
| ------- | ------- |
| [x hash md5](/mod/hash/md5.md) | Calculate the MD5 hashsum of file |
| [x hash sha1](/mod/hash/sha1.md) | Calculate the SHA1 hashsum of file |
| [x hash sha256](/mod/hash/sha256.md) | Calculate the SHA256 hashsum of file |
| [x hash sha384](/mod/hash/sha384.md) | Calculate the SHA384 hashsum of file |
| [x hash sha512](/mod/hash/sha512.md) | Calculate the SHA512 hashsum of file |
| [x hash info](/mod/hash/info.md) | Print the MD5, SHA1, SHA256, SHA384, and SHA512 hashes of the file. |
| [x hash verify](/mod/hash/verify.md) | Estimate the hash algorithm based on the given hash value length, and then calculate and compare the file's hash value using that algorithm. |
| [x hash assert](/mod/hash/assert.md) | Estimates the hash algorithm based on the given hash value length, then calculates the file's hash value using that algorithm and compares it to the given hash.  Returns 0 on success (match), 1 on mismatch, and 2 if the algorithm cannot be determined. |

# x hua

The hua module is a terminal-based Chinese classical poetry reader designed specifically for Chinese users, allowing you to appreciate the beauty of ancient Chinese literature in your terminal.

We have carefully curated a collection ranging from the simple and unadorned sounds of the "Classic of Poetry" (Shijing) and Chu Ci, to the philosophical debates of the "Three Hundred Tang Poems" and "Mencius", to the rhythmic beauty of "Three Hundred Tang Poems" and "Three Hundred Song Words", and the prose essence of "Guwen Guanzhi".

You can explore freely in interactive mode, or directly enter a specific collection for reading via subcommands.


::: tip
Alt-r: Toggles the layout of the preview window
:::


## Examples

Interactive viewing of classical Chinese poetry

```sh
x hua
```

Appreciate the simple and unadorned sounds of the "Classic of Poetry"

```sh
x hua sj
```

Consult famous works from "Three Hundred Tang Poems"

```sh
x hua ts
```

Learn the wisdom in the "Three Hundred Tang Poems"

```sh
x hua ly
```
## Introduction



The `hua` module is a client-side tool for viewing ancient Chinese poetry, developed by the x-cmd team using Shell and AWK. It aims to provide a lightweight and efficient way to view ancient Chinese poetry.

## Sub Commands

url: /mod/hub.md

# x hub

`hub` is a script management tool powered by the x-cmd cloud service, designed to help users build a personal cloud space for scripts.

It enables secure, encrypted storage of scripts in the cloud, making them easy to access, execute, and share across devices.


::: tip
An x-cmd hub account is required to use the hub module. Login via GitHub or WeChat is supported.
:::


## Examples

Log in to your Hub account, if not automatically registered by default

```sh
x hub login
```

Upload local file example.txt to cloud me:example.txt, and set it as a public file

```sh
x hub file put --public example.txt
```

Search the x-cmd repository for the corresponding mod command.

```sh
x hub search åœ¨ github repo ä¸­æ·»åŠ æˆå‘˜
```
## Introduction



The hub module helps users easily manage file cloud hosting through the x-cmd cloud service, and with the x command of x-cmd, it is possible to run cloud scripts.


- Double file encryption to protect user privacy, even data cannot be accessed by the server.
- Posix file operations make it easy for users familiar with commands such as `ls/cat` to get started.
- File sharing support, users can share cloud files with others.



## Common Functions - Cloud File Management and Sharing



The hub refers to the posix file management design to implement file management functionality.


1. **Posix-like file operations**: Inheriting posix commands such as `ls/cat/rm`, users can manage cloud files through these commands, making it similar to managing local files.
2. **File upload and download**: Users can upload and download cloud files using the `put/download` command. The `eput` function is also provided to enable encrypted file uploads.
3. **More secure file sharing**: Files are transmitted in encrypted form throughout the process, and are decrypted by the client side after downloading. (Only for files uploaded with encryption)
4. **Link files**: Unique link syntax that does not require uploading files to the x-cmd cloud server. The x-cmd server only records the URL of the user's file in the cloud. When the file needs to be executed, the hub will automatically download the corresponding file based on the URL and then execute it.



## Ensuring User Information Security



In `x hub`, information security mainly involves key management and file security:


1. **File Security**: When using the `eput` function, x-cmd uses end-to-end encryption technology to encrypt user files before uploading them to the cloud. x-cmd will not receive any plaintext files about the user on the cloud.
2. **Key Management**: During the end-to-end encryption process, x-cmd generates a pair of key pairs on the client side and encrypts them before uploading to the cloud. When users change devices, they can directly obtain the encrypted key pair from the x-cmd cloud and use it after decrypting it with a password entered locally.



> When using the `eput` function for the first time, x-cmd will guide the user to enter a password to protect the user's key. After changing devices, users do not need to worry about the transmission of the original key. They can continue to manage x-cmd cloud files by entering the set password.



PS. However, please note that if you forget the password for the private key and also lose the plaintext private key file, then your files cannot be decrypted. So try to remember your password as much as possible.



## x-cmd Account Management and Username Mechanism



The hub can also be used to manage x-cmd account information. x-cmd supports logging in using GitHub and WeChat. We will automatically create an account for you when you first log in. After logging in, you can use the hub cloud file management functionality.



The hub also has a corresponding username mechanism. You can view your username using `account`. The default username is `u-<user id>`. If you want to change your username, you can do so using `account rename`. The username prefix is fixed as `u-`.



For the current user, x-cmd allows using `me` as a substitute for the username. For example, `file cat me:example.txt` allows you to view the contents of the cloud file example.txt stored in x-cmd.



## Integration with x-cmd



The hub is closely integrated with x-cmd. Users can run cloud files by using the `<username|alias>:<file path>` format with the `x` command. For example, `x me:example.sh` can run the cloud file example.sh.

## Sub Commands

| Name | Description |
| ------- | ------- |
| [x hub file](/mod/hub/file.md) | File management, put/download/view files |
| [x hub ai](/mod/hub/ai.md) | x-cmd AI knowledge base construction and search. |
| [x hub access](/mod/hub/access.md) | Access management, set file access permissions |
| [x hub login](/mod/hub/login.md) | Login account, equivalent to `x hub account login` |
| [x hub logout](/mod/hub/logout.md) | Logout account, clear local token and local stored key, equivalent to `x hub account logout` |
| [x hub info](/mod/hub/info.md) | View account information, and display the cloud space usage of the current user |
| [x hub bind](/mod/hub/bind.md) | Bind your Email or Telegram to receive important notifications and reminders. |
| [x hub account](/mod/hub/account.md) | Account management, view account information, bind accounts |
| [x hub cc](/mod/hub/cc.md) | Use the cloud-based environment provided by x-cmd to compile scripts written in supported languages (currently Go, Gop, and Zig), and retrieve the generated binary file.(By default, the binary is downloaded to the project path) |
| [x hub org](/mod/hub/org.md) | Organization management, view/create/delete organizations |
| [x hub keypair](/mod/hub/keypair.md) | Key management, generate/save/load keys |
| [x hub search](/mod/hub/search.md) | Use ai to search the x-cmd knowledge base. |
| [x hub _advise](/mod/hub/_advise.md) | hub dedicated completion command, specially provided for use in the completion process, no effect when called directly |

url: /mod/install.md

# x install

Quickly query software installation commands and install them on different operating systems

## Examples

Open the interactive APP inquiry software and proceed with the installation

```sh
x install
```

List software supported by the install module

```sh
x install ls
```

Query and execute Git installation commands

```sh
x install git
```

Query and execute Docker installation commands

```sh
x install docker
```

Update the resource files of x install

```sh
x install --update
```
## introduce



install is a module used to help users quickly install various software. It can help you quickly find the software installation command suitable for the current system and run the installation command to install the software.

This module is designed to simplify the query process of software installation commands, so that you do not have to search for software installation commands in complicated web pages, and reduce the need to switch back and forth between the browser and the development environment, so that you can focus more on development.



## main feature


1. **Simple and clear**: Directly give the installation command and source of the software without adding other redundant information.
2. **Fast**: The installation command is retrieved from the scheduled install resource package rather than through the network. Therefore, you are not limited by network speed.
3. **Comprehensive**: For specified software, as many installation methods as possible will be given to meet different application scenarios as much as possible. At the same time, the install resource package will also be regularly maintained and updated.

## Sub Commands

| Name | Description |
| ------- | ------- |
| [x install --run](/mod/install/--run.md) | Run the specified installation command to install the software |
| [x install --cat](/mod/install/--cat.md) | Get an installation command for a  software |
| [x install --ls](/mod/install/--ls.md) | List software supported by the install module (interactive UI will be enabled if interaction is required) |
| [x install --update](/mod/install/--update.md) |  |
| [x install --fzf](/mod/install/--fzf.md) | Enable the interactive fzf UI for the install module |

| Name, Shorthand | Description |

| `-r`, `--colr` | Displaying the information using 'ip addr' in color format |

### x ip cidr

Displaying info related to CIDR


- **Examples**:

Display the classful and CIDR information for the 192.168.1.0/24 network.

```sh

```

Display the classful and CIDR information for the 192.168.1.0/24 network.

```sh

```

- **Sub Commands**:


| Name | Description |
| ------- | ------- |
| [x ip cidr ls](#x-ip-cidr-ls) | Illustrating the Use of Address Blocks Defined in RFC 3330 |
| [x ip cidr info](#x-ip-cidr-info) | Displaying the IP address's classification attributes, along with its subnet address and the number of IPs within that subnet. |


### x ip cidr ls

Illustrating the Use of Address Blocks Defined in RFC 3330


- **Examples**:

The address blocks defined in RFC 3330, and their purposes, were displayed in an interactive table app.

```sh
x ip cidr ls
```

Feed the address blocks and their uses, as defined in RFC 3330, into a pipe (automatically outputting in TSV format), then use awk to print columns 1 and 3.

```sh
x ip cidr ls | awk -F '\t' '{ print $1, $3 }'
```

The address blocks defined in RFC 3330, and their purposes, were displayed in CSV format.

```sh
x ip cidr ls --csv
```

- **Usage**:

```sh
x ip cidr ls
```

### x ip cidr info

Displaying the IP address's classification attributes, along with its subnet address and the number of IPs within that subnet.


- **Usage**:

```sh
x ip cidr info
```

### x ip iter

Iterate all IP in the subnet


- **Examples**:

List all IP addresses of the subnet 192.168.1.0/24

```sh
x ip iter 192.168.1.0/24
```

- **Usage**:

```sh
x ip iter
```

### x ip map

Discover ip address using ICMP ping and tcping (default for port 22, 80)


- **Examples**:

Scan 192.168.1.0/24 for active hosts using ICMP

```sh
x ip map   192.168.1.0/24
```

Scan 192.168.1.0/24 and 192.168.3.11 for active hosts using ICMP

```sh
x ip map   192.168.1.0/24 192.168.3.11
```

Scan 192.168.1.1-255 for active hosts using ICMP.

```sh
x ip map   192.168.1.{1..255}
```

Scan 192.168.1-255.1 for active hosts using ICMP

```sh
x ip map   192.168.{1..255}.1
```

Scan 192.168.1.1-255 for active hosts using ICMP and TCP port 80.

```sh
x ip map -s icmp,80 192.168.1.{1..255}
```

Scan 192.168.1.0/24 for active hosts using ICMP

```sh
x ip iter  192.168.1.0/24 | x ip map -
```

- **Usage**:

```sh
x ip map
```

### x ip tps

Discover port using tcp request in parallel


- **Examples**:

Scan localhost for open ports in the range of 1-10000, equivalent to 'x ip tps'

```sh
x ip tps
```

Scan localhost for open ports in the range of 1-65535, equivalent to 'x ip tps'

```sh
x ip tps -a
```

Scan bing.com for open ports in the range of 1-10000

```sh
x ip tps bing.com
```

Scan localhost for open ports in the range of 10000-20000

```sh
x ip tps 127.0.0.1 10000-20000
```

Scan the local host for odd open ports in the range of 1-10000, open ports in the range of 30000-40000, and the port 55555.

```sh
x ip tps 127.0.0.1 1-10000:2 30000-40000 55555
```

- **Usage**:

```sh
x ip tps|tcp-portscan [FLAGS]
```

- **Flags**:


| Name, Shorthand | Description |
| ------- | ------- |

# x jina

CLI for jina.ai, providing functions to get website content, generate vector data, etc.


::: tip
- Get jina api key: https://jina.ai/embeddings/#apiform
- Interactive env use `x jina init` to initialize configuration. The configure will be saved locally.
- Run command `x jina --cfg apikey=<apikey>` to add access apikey.
:::


## Examples

Retrieve the content of the x-cmd website, returned in Markdown format; this is the short for 'x jina reader https://x-cmd.com'

```sh
x jina https://x-cmd.com
```

Retrieve the content of the x-cmd website, returned in HTML format

```sh
x jina reader --html https://x-cmd.com
```

List all embed model

```sh
x jina embed model ls
```

Generating vector data for the string 'how are you'

```sh
x jina embed generate how are you
```

Generating vector data for the string 'license file'

```sh
x jina embed generate --file ./license
```

Generating vector data for the string "how are you" through streaming

```sh
echo how are you | x jina embed generate -
```

Split the LICENSE file using the '\n' delimiter and find the top three sentences with the highest similarity to the vector representation of 'how are you'

```sh
x jina reranker generate  --yml -f ./LICENSE  --sep "\n" --top 3 how are you
```

Find out which file, between file a and file b, has the highest similarity to the content of 'how are you'

```sh
x jina reranker generate  --yml -f ./a -f ./b how are you
```

List all reranker model

```sh
x jina reranker model ls
```
## Introduction

Based on the interface of jina.ai company, the Jina module mainly provides the following functionalities:


- Web Reader
- Text Embedding
- Information rerank



## Key Features

Through the Reader functionality of the Jina module, we empower large AI models with the ability to conveniently and in real-time retrieve website content.

Whether it's local models like llmf and ollama, or cloud-based models like ChatGPT, Kimi, and Gemini, they can all retrieve website content and process it in real-time.

# x lua

Module used to improve the Lua development experience, adding common functions needed to develop Lua projects

## Examples

Run the lua code

```sh
x lua ./hi.lua
```

Initialize lua project

```sh
x lua init
```

Install lua-cjson modules (using luarocks)

```sh
x lua i lua-cjson
```

Check lua code

```sh
x lua check ./hi.lua
```
## Introduction



`x lua` is a module aimed at enhancing the Lua development experience. It is compatible with platforms such as Windows, Linux, macOS, etc., and provides commonly needed functionalities for Lua projects, such as initializing Lua projects, downloading and installing Lua extensions, checking Lua code syntax, and formatting Lua code.



## Lua Version Used by x lua



`x lua` defaults to using the Lua version currently being used by the user. If Lua is not available in the user's environment, the `x lua` module will install and invoke [Lua provided by the x-cmd pkg system](https://x-cmd.com/pkg/lua), which is compiled by the x-cmd team, version 5.4.6. The process of compiling Lua by the x-cmd team mainly follows the practices of [LuaBinaries](https://luabinaries.sourceforge.net/) and [Homebrew](https://brew.sh/), aiming to stay consistent with the Lua community.



## Consideration of LUA_PATH and LUA_CPATH by x-cmd


1. For `LUA_PATH`, 6 levels of directories are set, prioritized from high to low as follows:
   - `./`: Current directory where Lua is executed.
   - `./lua_modules/`: Directory for Lua modules in the current Lua project.
   - `$LUA_PATH_WS/`: Lua workspace directory. Default value is empty unless specified by the user.
   - `$HOME/.luarocks/share/lua/`: Directory for global Lua modules in luarocks.
   - `${___X_CMD_ROOT_MOD}/lua/lib/share/`: Directory for Lua modules of the x-cmd Lua module.
   - `;;`: Default paths of the original LUA_PATH.


2. For `LUA_CPATH`, 5 levels of directories are set, prioritized from high to low as follows:
   - `./`: Current directory where Lua is executed.
   - `./lua_modules/`: Directory for Lua lib in the current Lua project.
   - `$LUA_PATH_WS/`: Lua workspace directory. Default value is empty unless specified by the user.
   - `$HOME/.luarocks/lib/lua/$LUA_version/`: Directory for global Lua lib in luarocks.
   - `usr/local/lib/lua/$LUA_version/`: Directory for system Lua lib storage.


3. For `.so`, `.dll`, and `.dylib` files, we have made additional adjustments to `LUA_CPATH`:
   - On Linux platforms, Lua can locate `.so` files in the 5-level directories set by `LUA_CPATH`.
   - On macOS platforms, Lua can locate `.so` and `.dylib` files in the 5-level directories set by `LUA_CPATH`.
   - On Windows platforms, Lua can locate `.dll` files in the 5-level directories set by `LUA_CPATH`.



## Development Progress of x lua



The development of the `x lua` module by the x-cmd team is in the preliminary stage, and we are continuously exploring better solutions. Currently implemented features (such as initializing Lua projects, downloading and installing Lua modules, checking Lua code syntax) mainly rely on the `x luarocks` module and third-party Lua extensions.

## Usage

```sh
x lua [FLAGS] [SUB_COMMAND] <#1>
```

## Arguments

| Argument | Description |
| ------- | ------- |
| `#1` | lua script |


## Flags

| Name, Shorthand | Description |
| ------- | ------- |
| `-e` &lt;stat&gt; | execute string 'stat' |
| `-i` | enter interactive mode after executing 'script' |
| `-l` &lt;mod&#124;g=mod&gt; | require libray 'mod' |
| `-E` | ignore environment variables |
| `-W` | turn warnings on |
| `--` | Stop processing options, subsequent arguments will be treated as filenames rather than options |


## Sub Commands

| Name | Description |
| ------- | ------- |
| [x lua --exec](#x-lua-exec) | Run the lua interpreter |
| [x lua --luac](#x-lua-luac) | compile lua code |
| [x lua init](#x-lua-init) | Initialize lua project |
| [x lua install](#x-lua-install) | Install Lua modules (using luarocks) |
| [x lua check](#x-lua-check) | Check lua code syntax format |
| [x lua format](#x-lua-format) | Format lua code |
| [x lua static](#x-lua-static) | Compile lua code into a single binary |


### x lua --exec


# x luarocks

Enhancement module for luarocks


::: tip
Run `x luarocks help` to get help for luarocks native commands
:::


## Examples

Install lua-cjson modules

```sh
x luarocks i lua-cjson
```

Remove lua-cjson modules

```sh
x luarocks remove lua-cjson
```

Use luarocks.cn server to speed up access to https://luarocks.org

```sh
x luarocks install lua-cjson --server https://luarocks.cn
```
## Introduction



`x luarocks` is an enhanced module for the luarocks command. This module is primarily used to simplify the installation configuration of luarocks and enhance the user experience of using luarocks.



## luarocks Version Used by the x luarocks Module



`x luarocks` by default invokes the luarocks currently being used by the user. If luarocks is not available in the user's environment, the `x luarocks` module will install and invoke [luarocks provided by the x-cmd pkg system](https://x-cmd.com/pkg/luarocks), which is luarocks version 3.11.0.



The luarocks provided by the x-cmd pkg system defaults to using lua 5.4.6 provided by the x-cmd pkg system. Users can adjust the corresponding configuration of luarocks to choose other versions of lua.

On **Windows platforms**, luarocks provided by the x-cmd pkg system is LuaRocks official precompiled luarocks;

On **Linux platforms** and **MacOS platforms**, the x-cmd pkg system downloads the LuaRocks official source code and uses [make provided by cosmo](https://x-cmd.com/mod/cosmo) to compile and install luarocks.



## Handling Dependencies of luarocks install Functionality such as gcc, unzip, etc.



`x luarocks install` by default calls the gcc, unzip, and other tools currently being used by the user. If these tools are not available in the user's environment, we provide `x lua ensurecc` + `x cosmo use unzip` as an alternative solution. This solution can quickly set up the environment for users without the need for **root privileges**, and it works on **Windows platforms**, **Linux platforms**, and **MacOS platforms**.

For detailed information about `x lua ensurecc` and `x cosmo use unzip`, please visit [x-cmd mod](https://x-cmd.com/mod/).

## Usage

```sh
x luarocks [OPTIONS] [FLAGS] [SUB_COMMAND] <#n>
```

## Arguments

| Argument | Description |
| ------- | ------- |
| `#n` | extends `luarocks` subcmd or options |


## Options

| Name, Shorthand | Default | Description |
| ------- | ------- | ------- |
| `--server` &lt;server&gt; |  | Fetch rocks/rockspecs from this server (takes priority over config file). |
| `--only-server` &lt;server&gt; |  | Fetch rocks/rockspecs from this server only (overrides any entries in the config file). |
| `--only-sources` &lt;url&gt; |  | Restrict downloads to paths matching the given URL. |
| `--namespace` &lt;namespace&gt; |  | Specify the rocks server namespace to use. |
| `--lua-dir` &lt;prefix&gt; |  | Which Lua installation to use |
| `--lua-version` &lt;ver&gt; |  | Which Lua version to use |
| `--tree` &lt;tree&gt; |  | Which tree to operate on |
| `--timeout` &lt;seconds&gt; |  | Timeout on network operations, in seconds. 0 means no timeout (wait forever). Default is 30. |


## Flags

| Name, Shorthand | Description |
| ------- | ------- |
| `-h`, `--help` | Show this help message and exit. |
| `--version` | Show version info and exit. |
| `--dev` | Enable the sub-repositories in rocks servers for rockspecs of in-development versions. |
| `--local` | Use the tree in the user's home directory |
| `--global` | Use the system tree when `local_by_default` is `true` |

# x mac

The Mac module is a collection of handy tools designed specifically for macOS users. Its goal is to make it easier for users to automate tasks with scripts or manage their Macs remotely.

## Examples

Use fingerprint (touchid) for sudo verification, and restart password verification when failed

```sh
x mac tidsudo enable
```

Enable the alias feature, set it to mcli, and use mcli instead of x mac in the future

```sh
x mac alias enable mcli
```

Enable the alias feature, if no parameter is provided, it defaults to m, and you can use m instead of x mac in the future

```sh
x mac alias enable
```

Display System Information

```sh
x mac info
```

Get battery information

```sh
x mac b
```

Adjust the output volume to 24%

```sh
x mac vol set 24
```

Test network quality

```sh
x mac net test
```

Desktop Lock Screen

```sh
x mac lock
```

Entering sleep mode

```sh
x mac sleep
```

Ignoring the warnings, the computer was forcefully shut down

```sh
x mac shutdown -y
```

Empty the Trash

```sh
x mac trash empty
```

Show the list of disks

```sh
x mac disk ls
```

# x mistral

Use the AI services provided by Mistral


::: tip
- Get mistral api key: mistral: https://console.mistral.ai/api-keys/
- Interactive env use `x mistral init` to initialize configuration. The configure will be saved locally.
- Run command `x mistral --cfg apikey=<apikey>` to add access apikey.
:::


## Examples

Translate the content of the file into Chinese

```sh
x mistral chat request --file ./abstract.cn.md --file ./content.cn.md Translate to chinese
```

Translate the file content into Chinese (using alias)

```sh
@mistral --file ./abstract.cn.md --file ./content.cn.md Translate to chinese
```

List all models

```sh
x mistral model ls
```
## Introduction

The Mistral module is the command-line tool for Google's large model Gemini, driven by x-cmd, primarily utilizing posix shell, awk, and curl to function.

## Sub Commands

| Name | Description |

| [x mistral init](/mod/mistral/init.md) | Initialize the configuration using interactive mode |
| [x mistral --cur](/mod/mistral/--cur.md) | current session default value management |
| [x mistral --cfg](/mod/mistral/--cfg.md) | Manage config item like apikey, etc |
| [x mistral chat](/mod/mistral/chat.md) | chat with mistral |
| [x mistral model](/mod/mistral/model.md) | Model viewing and management |

# x mosh

Mosh (https://mosh.org/) is an interactive SSH alternative that supports roaming, intermittent connections, intelligent local echo and line editing.

This module prioritizes using the local mosh command. If it's not available, it will download and run via pixi, requiring no installation and impacting neither your environment nor system dependencies (Windows is not yet supported).

For more information about pixi, please visit https://prefix.dev/ or run `pixi --help`.

## Examples

Connect to a remote server

```sh
x mosh root@192.168.1.134
```

Select Mosh UDP 80 port

```sh
x mosh -p 80 root@192.168.1.134
```

Connect to a remote server using 2222 port

```sh
x mosh --ssh="ssh -p 2222" root@192.168.1.134
```

Equivalent to the 'mosh -h' command

```sh
x mosh -- -h
```

## Sub Commands

| Name | Description |
| ------- | ------- |
| [x mosh --](#x-mosh) | Run the 'mosh' command directly |


### x mosh --

Run the 'mosh' command directly


- **Usage**:

```sh
x mosh --|--exec
```

# x ncdu

ncdu (NCurses Disk Usage) is a disk usage analyzer with a text-mode user interface.

This module prioritizes the use of the local 'ncdu' command. If it's not present, the module will download 'ncdu' via 'pkg', run it directly without installation, and will not modify your environment or system dependencies.

## Examples

Use 'ncdu' to see the disk usage of the current directory.

```sh
x ncdu
```

Equivalent to the 'ncdu -h' command

```sh
x ncdu -- -h
```

## Sub Commands

| Name | Description |
| ------- | ------- |

# x ohmyposh

Oh-my-posh is a cross platform tool to render your prompt.

It can use the same configuration everywhere to offer a consistent experience, regardless of where you are.

For a detailed guide on getting started, have a look at the docs at https://ohmyposh.dev



The ohmyposh module is a powerful enhancement for oh-my-posh, designed to make theme customization a breeze. It lets you download theme resource packs, simplifying the process of switching between different looks.

This module also includes a handy theme preview feature, allowing you to directly preview various themes right in your command line. This makes choosing and changing themes a much smoother experience.


::: tip
This module's try/untry feature is currently only compatible with bash and zsh environments.
Using the ohmyposh module's theme will override the current environment's POSH_THEME variable
1_shell theme is incompatible with xonsh. For details, please check github.com/JanDeDobbeleer/oh-my-posh/issues/6282.
:::


## Examples

Invoke the command `x ohmyposh fz` to interactively preview the oh-my-posh theme

```sh
x ohmyposh
```

Use the montys theme globally

```sh
x ohmyposh use montys
```

Use a custom configuration theme globally

```sh
x ohmyposh use <custom file path>
```

Cancel the theme that is currently used globally

```sh
x ohmyposh unuse
```

Try to use the agnoster theme in this current Shell

```sh
x ohmyposh try agnoster
```

View the currently used theme settings

```sh
x ohmyposh current
```

# x onsh

xonsh is a Python-powered shell that supports users to mix Python and shell commands on the command line.

This module mainly provides support for calling the x-cmd toolset on xonsh; and adds functions such as searching the official website ( xon.sh ) , using without installation, and generating xonsh commands with LLM.


::: tip
In xonsh, because `@<name>` is interpreted as an annotation, when no parameters are provided (e.g., `@gemini`), xonsh will wait for the function to be decorated.

Users can input `;` to avoid this issue, such as `@gemini ;`.
:::


## Examples

Modify the $HOME/.xonshrc file to introduce the x-cmd toolkit (including the x command, c command, @gpt, comma command, etc.) into the xonsh environment.

```sh
x onsh setup
```

```sh
x onsh : alias
```

Start xonsh. If xonsh is not already installed locally, it will be automatically installed and used through the x-cmd pkg system (this process will not affect your environment variables or dependencies).

```sh
x onsh
```

# x osv

The `osv` module is the CLI for the OSV (Open Source Vulnerabilities) project, mainly used for obtaining open source vulnerability information and integrating vulnerability scanning tools to help developers and users better address software security issues.

OSV is an open source project initiated by Google, aiming to provide a unified and easily accessible open source software vulnerability database. Its official website is https://osv.dev.

## Examples

Get vulnerability information for a given vulnerability ID ( osv-*, cve-*, etc. Case insensitive. )

```sh
x osv osv-2020-111
```

Scan system installed packages or local project dependencies and generate a unified SARIF report

```sh
x osv sarif
```

Generate a unified SARIF report in JSON format by scanning the dependencies of pip projects in the specified directory.

```sh
x osv sarif pip --json "<project dir>"
```

Query the vulnerabilities of the specified version of software

```sh
x osv q -p jq -v 1.7.1
```

Query the vulnerabilities of the specified software

```sh
x osv q -p OSS-Fuzz,jq
```

Retrieve vulnerability information for OSV-2020-111 and output it in JSON format.

```sh
x osv vuln --json OSV-2020-111
```

Search for git-related vulnerabilities on the osv.dev website.

```sh
x osv : git
```

## Sub Commands

| Name | Description |
| ------- | ------- |
| [x osv ls](/mod/osv/ls.md) | List all Cloud Storage |
| [x osv q](/mod/osv/q.md) | Query vulnerabilities for a given package and version |
| [x osv eco](/mod/osv/eco.md) | List OSV-supported ecosystem |
| [x osv scanner](/mod/osv/scanner.md) | Scan for vulnerabilities using osv-scanner |
| [x osv sarif](/mod/osv/sarif.md) | Using osv-scanner to scan system installed packages or local project dependencies and generate a unified SARIF report |
| [x osv vuln](/mod/osv/vuln.md) | Get vulnerability information for a given vulnerability ID |
| [x osv ddgo](/mod/osv/ddgo.md) | Search the osv.dev website for the specified content |
| [x osv ddgoai](/mod/osv/ddgoai.md) | Search for specific content on the osv.dev website and use AI to summarize it |

The pacman module is dedicated to enhancing the command line experience of pacman users. Its enhancements to pacman mainly include the following points:
1. Provide an interactive UI so that users can better search and install software.
2. Provide the mirror command to manage mirror sources so that users can quickly replace the appropriate pacman mirror source according to the situation.
3. Provide proxy command so that users can manage pacman's proxy more flexibly.
4. For commands that require sudo privileges to execute, we have wrapped them using the sudo module to ensure that all commands follow the format `x pacman <subcmd>`.

## Usage

```sh
x pacman [FLAGS] [SUB_COMMAND] <#n>
```

## Arguments

| Argument | Description |
| ------- | ------- |
| `#n` | extends `pacman` subcmd or options |


## Flags

| Name, Shorthand | Description |
| ------- | ------- |
| `--runmain`, `--` | Run the pacman command directly. |


## Sub Commands

| Name | Description |
| ------- | ------- |
| [x pacman install](/mod/pacman/install.md) | Install software tools (interactive APP is used by default in an interactive environment). |
| [x pacman browse](/mod/pacman/browse.md) | Open the pacman Wiki in a browser |
| [x pacman ls](/mod/pacman/ls.md) | List installed software |
| [x pacman la](/mod/pacman/la.md) | Listed installable software |
| [x pacman proxy](/mod/pacman/proxy.md) | Display or change the current proxy used for pacman |
| [x pacman mirror](/mod/pacman/mirror.md) | Display or change the current mirror used for pacman |

# x paru

`x paru` is an enhancement tool for the `paru` AUR helper, designed for Arch Linux users.

It greatly simplifies the process of finding, selecting, and installing packages by integrating `fzf`, a powerful interactive fuzzy search tool.

# x pixi

Pixi is a cross-platform, multilingual package manager and workflow tool built on the conda ecosystem. Its official website is https://prefix.dev/

This module first tries to use any available PixiJS installation in the current environment. If none is found, it automatically runs `x pixi --install` to install and activate it.

This module is primarily designed to optimize the user experience of installing and using Pixi, such as using the Codeberg Pixi mirror to improve the download experience for users in China.

Furthermore, it introduces the `la` command for interactive searching and previewing installable Pixi packages, and offers x-cmd style commands like `use` and `unuse` for managing global packages within the current user environment.

## Examples

Install fish shell and jq in the user environment. Equivalent to `pixi global install fish jq`

```sh
x pixi use fish jq
```

List the packages and dependency in the user environment.

```sh
x pixi use ls
```

Use the interactive app to search for all available packages

```sh
x pixi
```

Install the yq command globally using pixi

```sh
x pixi g install yq
```

Activate pixi in the current user environment.

```sh
x pixi --activate
```

Activate pixi in the current user environment.

```sh
x pixi --deactivate
```

Install pixi (Install the latest version by default)

```sh
x pixi --upgrade
```

Install pixi (Install the latest version by default)

```sh
x pixi --install
```
## Introduction



The `x pixi` module is an enhanced tool for pixi commands implemented by the x-cmd team using the posix shell. It optimizes the installation and usage experience of pixi commands as follows:
1. Provide auto-completion functionality for advise. For users in China, we also offer a localized version of advise.
2. For users in China, considering the network issues accessing Github, we use a mirror on Codeberg to help users quickly download and install pixi.
3. Provide document search functionality. Support searching for document content on the pixi.sh website from the command line, so that users can quickly obtain the desired pixi command documentation.
4. Provide the `la` command. In an interactive environment, it uses `fzf` as the interactive framework, helping users quickly find the required software and view software information.



## prefix-dev/pixi



[`pixi`](https://github.com/prefix-dev/pixi) is a package and workflow management tool developed in Rust by the [prefix-dev team](https://github.com/prefix-dev). It can download and install various software tools (such as Python, Git, Vim, jq, etc.) and manage project environments, dependencies, tasks, and more.



Built on the Conda ecosystem, `pixi` is compatible with both Conda and PyPI ecosystems. Compared to Conda, `pixi` is compiled into a single executable file, offering faster dependency resolution and package installation, lower memory usage, and more comprehensive project management capabilities. It is an excellent choice for Conda users seeking a lightweight and efficient solution.

## Usage

```sh
x pixi [SUB_COMMAND] <#n>
```

## Arguments

| Argument | Description |
| ------- | ------- |
| `#n` | extends `pixi` subcmd or options |


## Sub Commands

| Name | Description |
| ------- | ------- |
| [x pixi unuse](/mod/pixi/unuse.md) | Uninstalling the software package in the user environment. Equivalent to `x pixi use rm`, or `pixi global uninstall`. |
| [x pixi use](/mod/pixi/use.md) | Managing software packages within the user environment.  By default, this is equivalent to running  `x pixi use add <pkg> [pkg...]` or `pixi global install <pkg> [pkg...]`. |
| [x pixi --install](/mod/pixi/--install.md) | Install the specified version of pixi |
| [x pixi --uninstall](/mod/pixi/--uninstall.md) | Uninstall pixi and remove related data (the .pixi directory in the HOME directory). |
| [x pixi --activate](/mod/pixi/--activate.md) | Activate pixi, allowing globally installed software to run directly |
| [x pixi --deactivate](/mod/pixi/--deactivate.md) | With pixi deactivated, the newly launched shell won't automatically load pixi's environment variables, like PATH.  This means any software globally installed via pixi will be inaccessible. |
| [x pixi --upgrade](/mod/pixi/--upgrade.md) | Update Pixi to the latest version. |
| [x pixi la](/mod/pixi/la.md) | List the packages supported by pixi |
| [x pixi ddgo](/mod/pixi/ddgo.md) | Search the pixi.sh website for the specified content |
| [x pixi --](/mod/pixi/--.md) | Run the pixi command directly |

url: /mod/python.md

# x python

Enhanced python command


::: info
Extends 'python' options.

See https://docs.python.org/ website for more information.

See `x python --help` for more information.
:::

## Introduction



The Python module is dedicated to enhancing the user experience of Python users in the command line.



## Striving for Consistency



We strive to maintain consistency with the Python command. However, there will be enhancements that may cause differences, for example:


1. `x python me:hi.py`: The Python module will attempt to download the file from the hub to the local directory before executing it.
2. Due to the enhancement in point 1, if you want to run the file `me:hi.py` in the current folder, you can only do so by adding `./` in front: `x python ./me:hi.py`.
3. We consider it extremely rare for directory names to contain ":" and thus have designed it this way.



## Adding GPT Functionality



If you want to know how to achieve a certain functionality using the Python command, you can use "co" (copilot, abbreviated as `,`). For example, `x python , How to set up an HTTP server to serve all contents located in $HOME` will return `python -m http.server --directory "$HOME"`.



If you need to query the corresponding code, you can use "coco" (code copilot, abbreviated as `,,`):


1. `x python ,, Put file names in $HOME directory into a dict`.
2. We will use the local Python interpreter for linting to check the syntax correctness. If there are any issues, users can choose to package the problem and code to return to GPT for re-questioning.

## Usage

```sh
x python <#1> <#n>
```

## Arguments

| Argument | Description |
| ------- | ------- |
| `#1` | python script |
| `#n` | extends `python` subcmd or options |

# x rg

rg (ripgrep) is a modern search tool similar to grep that supports recursively searching for lines matching a regex pattern within the current directory.

`x rg` is an enhancement module based on the rg command, designed to improve the rg user experience. The specific enhancements are as follows:
1. Simplified rg command installation: If rg is not found in the current environment, `x rg` will download and install rg through the x-cmd pkg system in a way that does not affect the user's environment.
2. Provides the `--fzfapp` command: This offers an interactive way to use the rg command with fzf.


::: tip
Shortcut Keys in Interactive Mode:

`alt-a`: Select all matching items

`alt-d`: Deselect all selected items

`ctrl-/`: Hide/Show Preview Window

`ctrl-o`: Edit selected items with editor

`ctrl-t`: Toggle between Ripgrep and Fzf search modes
:::


## Examples

Using fzf to provide interactive app search for rg in the current directory

```sh
x rg
```

```sh
x ascii | x rg
```

Use fzf to provide interactive app search for a specified directory or file with rg

# x sb

`x sb` is a cross-platform sandbox runner that executes commands with minimal privileges.

It supports Deno-style permission control, such as `--net` to enable network access, `--tty` to allow TTY access, `--pwd` to allow access to the current directory, etc.



On macOS, it uses `sandbox-exec` with dynamically generated profiles;

on Linux, it leverages pledge-style constraints;

on unsupported systems, execution can be forced using `___X_CMD_SB_RUN_ANYWAY=1`.



Ideal for securing scripts or tools in lightweight, permission-restricted environments without needing full containers.

## Examples

Block curl access

```sh
x sb airrun curl https://x-cmd.com || echo "Successfully stop curl from Internet"
```

Allow write access to the `./tmp` directory. The command `touch /tmp/test.txt` should succeed

```sh
x sb editrun --wd ./tmp touch ./tmp/test.txt
```

Access Home directory. The command `ls ~` should succeed

```sh
x sb --home ls ~
```

## Usage

```sh
x sb [FLAGS] [SUB_COMMAND]
```

## Flags

| Name, Shorthand | Description |
| ------- | ------- |
| `--net` | Allow network access |
| `--all` | Allow all filesystem access |
| `--allrx` | Allow read and execute permissions |
| `--tty` | Allow TTY access |
| `--pwd` | Allow access to the current working directory |
| `--home` | Allow access to the user's home directory |
| `--ws` | Allow access to the workspace directory (the most recent directory with .x-cmd) |


## Sub Commands

| Name | Description |
| ------- | ------- |
| [x sb airrun](/mod/sb/airrun.md) | Provides broad local resource access (e.g., file system, TTY) while prohibiting network access |
| [x sb editrun](/mod/sb/editrun.md) | Provides operations to modify specified directories or files (e.g., creating, writing to, or deleting files) |
| [x sb stdiorun](/mod/sb/stdiorun.md) | Provides a highly restricted sandbox environment, prohibiting file system modifications and network access |

# x scoop

Windows Package Management Tool

## Examples

List installed applications

```sh
x scoop ls/list
```

Enable aria2 to download packages using multiple threads

```sh
x scoop aria2 enable
```

View detailed information about Telegram

```sh
x scoop info telegram --verbose
```

Do not use local cache, and re-download the latest Telegram from the remote source

```sh
x scoop install telegram --no-cache
```

View the currently available buckets

```sh
x scoop bucket list
```

Add known bucket

```sh
x scoop bucket add <bucket>
```

Add a bucket from other

```sh
x scoop bucket add <name> <repo>
```

Download from third-party bucket

```sh
x scoop install <bucket name>/<app_name>
```

Using native proxy  commands

```sh
x scoop config proxy 127.0.0.0:8888
```
## Introduction



scoop is a third-party package management tool for Windows, similar to [winget](/mod/winget.md), [choco, chocolatey](/mod/choco.md).

This module enhances scoop to seamlessly integrate with the shell and provide more features.



## Main Features


1. Automatic download: By calling the Scoop installation program command, it is possible to quickly, simply install, update, and uninstall programs without the need to switch terminals, thereby accelerating development and system management tasks.
2. Efficiency improvement: We introduced [scoop-search](https://github.com/shilangyu/scoop-search) to improve search efficiency (more than 10 times improvement), greatly improving the user experience.
3. Mirror setting: For users in mainland China, you can set up acceleration by using `x scoop config proxy gitee` in one click.
4. Completion prompt: We provide powerful completion functions for scoop

## Sub Commands

# x shodan

The shodan command-line interface is powered by x-cmd, mainly using posix shell, awk and curl.


::: tip
- Get shodan api key: https://account.shodan.io/
- Interactive env use `x shodan init` to initialize configuration. The configure will be saved locally.
- Run command `x shodan --cfg key=<apikey>` to add access apikey.
:::


## Examples

Retrieve port information for the IP addresses 8.8.8.8 and 1.1.1.1 on ports 53/dns-udp and 443/https

```sh
x shodan scan create 8.8.8.8 1.1.1.1=53/dns-udp,443/https
```

Find the IP addresses for the provided hostnames google.com and facebook.com

```sh
x shodan dns res google.com facebook.com
```

Download information for hosts with port 22

```sh
x shodan host download port:22
```

Open Shodan's website in a browser and search for relevant information about  8.8.8.8:22

```sh
x shodan open 8.8.8.8:22
```

Crawl the Internet for a 443 port and https protocol using Shodan

```sh
x shodan scan add --protocol https --port 443
```

Open Shodan's website in a browser and search for relevant information about  8.8.8.8:22

```sh
x shodan open 8.8.8.8:22
```

Use Shodan to search for baidu.com and filter the results by the facet (dimension) "80"

```sh
x shodan search --facet 80 baidu.com
```

Find the IP addresses for the provided hostnames google.com and facebook.com

```sh
x shodan dns res google.com facebook.com
```

Ping queries to target hosts 8.8.8.8 and 4.4.4.4 from multiple geographical locations

```sh
x shodan geo geoping 8.8.8.8,4.4.4.4
```

DNS queries to the target host google.com from multiple geographical locations

```sh
x shodan geo dns google.com
```

Intertactive UI for viewing the details for a network alert

```sh
x shodan alert ls
```

Display data with termini table

```sh
x shodan alert trigger ll
```

Add the specified trigger to the specified &lt;Alert ID&gt;. This trigger will monitor port 22 of the target host 8.8.8.8.

```sh
x shodan alert trigger add <Alert ID> <trigger name> 8.8.8.8:22
```

Use Shodan to download some data related to Apple. (The default is the x_shodan_data.json file.)

```sh
x shodan download --limit 10 apple
```

Extract port information from the downloaded data and output the results in CSV format.

```sh
x shodan host csv -f x_shodan_data.json port
```

Listed US entities

```sh
x shodan entitydb ls
```

Search for information about GOOGL Inc. in the network database

```sh
x shodan entitydb search GOOGL
```

Get the number of searches each month with the search criteria being port 22

```sh
x shodan trend search port:22
```

Return a list of facets that can be used to get a breakdown of the top values for a property.

```sh
x shodan trend facets
```

LSearch for queries related to 80

```sh
x shodan query search 80
```

Get current IP

```sh
x shodan ip
```

ping 8.8.8.8

```sh
x shodan ping 8.8.8.8
```
## Introduction







### About Shodan



Shodan is a search engine, but instead of searching web pages, it searches for devices and systems connected to the internet (such as computers, servers, routers, webcams, traffic lights, smart home devices, and much more). You can think of it as the "Google" of the internet of things, but instead of websites, it focuses on devices.



Here are some of Shodan's key features:


- It reveals information about connected devices. Shodan can tell you a device's location, IP address, operating system, open ports, services it's running, and even who's running it.
- It can be used to discover security vulnerabilities. Hackers can use Shodan to find devices that are misconfigured or have known vulnerabilities, but security researchers and companies can also use it to identify and fix vulnerabilities in their own systems.
- It can provide insights into internet-connected trends. Researchers and businesses can use Shodan to track the popularity of certain types of devices, where they're located, and how they're being used.



Shodan provides a rich [API](https://developer.shodan.io/api) and [SDKs](https://developer.shodan.io/api/clients) in various languages, making it ideal for further development and use.



## Official Shodan CLI Implemented in Python



The official Shodan CLI is implemented in Python, and users can install it via pip following the [official installation instructions](https://help.shodan.io/command-line-interface/0-installation).



x-cmd also provides this package, and users can use the official Python version of `shodan` by simply running `x env use shodan` or `x env try shodan`. x-cmd will automatically prepare and manage the required Python environment, so users do not need to install Python themselves.



### Goals and Advantages of this Module



This module is a Shodan CLI implemented using POSIX shell, awk, and curl. It is lightweight (no need for Python, Node, etc. language runtimes), transparent, and easy to extend.



Leveraging the rich ecosystem of modules/packages in x-cmd, we are actively trying to integrate this module with other modules to achieve:


- Integration with data sources from OSV, CVE, CPE, CWE, etc.
- Generation of richer and more interactive Shodan reports.
- Leveraging the analytical and automation capabilities of LLMs to help users understand Shodan data more deeply.
- And more ...

| [x shodan geo](/mod/shodan/geo.md) | Pinging or sending DNS requests from cloud servers located in different geographical regions. |

# x smart

smartctl is a tool for control and monitor disks, used to check disk health, including SMART (Self-Monitoring, Analysis, and Reporting Technology) data.

This module aims to help users quickly use the smartctl tool without installation and provides an interactive way to list local disk devices, making it easy for users to choose the disk they want to check.


::: tip
The smartctl command needs to be run with root privileges to allow access to the disk's SMART data.

If you are a Linux user, the sudo module will be automatically invoked to run the command, without the need to add the sudo prefix
:::


## Examples

Open an interactive UI to choose the disk and display all SMART information

```sh
x smart
```

displays all SMART information of the disk /dev/disk0 in macOS

```sh
x smart -a /dev/disk0
```

Generate a report using Gemini based on the SMART information of the disk

```sh
x smart -a /dev/disk0 | @gemini generate a report
```

Open an interactive Gemini session to discuss the SMART information of the disk

```sh
x smart -a /dev/disk0 | @gemini
```

Search the smartmontools.com website for content related to "disk health" and display the search results in an interactive table format.

```sh
x smart : disk health
```

## Sub Commands

| Name | Description |
| ------- | ------- |
| [x smart --app](#x-smart-app) | Display all SMART information for the disk interactively |
| [x smart ddgo](#x-smart-ddgo) | Search for relevant information on the smartmontools.com website using DuckDuckGo |


### x smart --app

Display all SMART information for the disk interactively


- **Usage**:

```sh
x smart --app
```

### x smart ddgo

Search for relevant information on the smartmontools.com website using DuckDuckGo


- **Usage**:

```sh
x smart ddgo|: <#1>
```

- **Arguments**:


| Argument | Description |
| ------- | ------- |
| `#1` | content |

# x starship

Starship is a minimal, blazing-fast, and infinitely customizable prompt for any shell!

For a detailed guide on getting started, have a look at the docs at https://starship.rs



The starship module is an enhanced module designed for Starship, allowing users to easily switch themes with a single command.

This module also includes a theme preview feature that lets users preview different themes directly in the command line, streamlining the process of selecting and changing themes.


::: tip
This module's try/untry feature is currently only compatible with bash and zsh environments.
Using the starship module's theme will override the current environment's STARSHIP_CONFIG variable
:::


## Examples

Invoke the command `x starship fz` to interactively preview the starship theme

```sh
x starship
```

Use the 'gruvbox-rainbow' theme globally

```sh
x starship use gruvbox-rainbow
```

Use a custom configuration theme globally

```sh
x starship use path/to/custom.toml
```

Cancel the theme that is currently used globally

```sh
x starship unuse
```

Try to use the 'pastel-powerline' theme in this current Shell

```sh
x starship try pastel-powerline
```

View the currently used theme settings

```sh
x starship current
```

url: /mod/theme.md
---
# x theme

Use command line prompt theme, Globally manage the display style of all x related interactive compoments.

If you want to view more themes online, please visit https://x-cmd.com/theme/


::: tip
The variable `___X_CMD_THEME_RELOAD_DISABLE` controls whether the theme is loaded
:::


## Examples

Open theme preview client to choose theme

```sh
x theme
```

View the currently used theme settings.

```sh
x theme current
```

Use and set 'robby' theme as prompt theme

```sh
x theme use robby
```

Try to use festival emoji in the current theme

```sh
x theme feature try emoji -t festival
```

Set the global theme feature to enable transient features by default

```sh
x theme feature use transient_enable always
```

Set the global theme feature to disable transient features by default

```sh
x theme feature use transient_enable never
```
## Introduction



The `theme` module is used to globally manage the display style of all `x` related widgets. Similar to the compatibility of x-cmd, `theme` can be used for ash, dash, bash, and zsh. 



The themes set in `theme` not only affect the display of the command prompt, but also affect the color scheme of the interactive widgets provided by x-cmd, such as the color scheme of the commonly used table widget in x-cmd, which will be adjusted as the `theme` theme color changes.



There are already many good solutions for enhancing command line display, such as oh-my-zsh, oh-my-bash, and zinit. 



In the process of implementing the `theme` module, in addition to trying our best to catch up with the above-mentioned predecessors in terms of functionality, we are most concerned about how the `theme` module can perceive the environment in order to achieve adjustments and provide the best user experience.



In terms of performance, we have already discovered the efficiency issues when using **MSYS** on Windows (such as git-for-windows), and have made adjustments and adaptations.



## Attempts in Environment Perception and Adaptation


1. Automatic line wrapping in long path environment - When the current path to be displayed is very long, the Prompt will automatically break into multiple lines to ensure the visibility and comfort of inputting commands.
2. Perceive whether it is vscode, gnome (the system terminal with the default deep red background in Ubuntu), or apple terminal, and change the theme of the command line accordingly.
3. Use htag (host tag) to mark whether the local server is in the production environment or the development environment. For more details, please refer to htag `x htag --help`, and provide reminders for important production environments.
4. Perceive whether the terminal supports 8 colors, 256 colors, or true colors, and automatically adjust the colors.
5. Show or hide information based on the type of project folder (git? node? python?).



## Themes and `l`



The above-mentioned environment perception features are not provided by all current theme schemes. The most complete default theme scheme that currently provides these features is `l`.



Regarding the design of the official `l` series themes, the design priorities are:
1. Command interaction experience (assisting in quickly inputting correct commands, clearly obtaining command results and completion status).
2. Survivability in various default terminals (designed with the system's 8 colors to simplify the effects and reduce the impact on system performance).
3. Comfort for long-term use takes priority over visual effects.



## Custom Themes



We have considered configurability, but since we are still observing and adjusting, we recommend users to use the provided themes first. We provide three design options for users who want to customize their themes:
1. Customize the color scheme based on a theme using environment variables.
2. Customize the widget display by re-implementing certain functions based on a theme.
3. Redefine theme functions and create a new theme, but the official theme widget functions can be reused.

## Usage

```sh
x theme [FLAGS] [SUB_COMMAND]
```

## Flags

| Name, Shorthand | Description |
| ------- | ------- |
| `--app` | Open theme preview client to choose theme |


## Sub Commands

| Name | Description |
| ------- | ------- |
| [x theme ls](/mod/theme/ls.md) | List all theme |
| [x theme use](/mod/theme/use.md) | Using the command line prompt theme globally |
| [x theme unuse](/mod/theme/unuse.md) | Unset theme |
| [x theme try](/mod/theme/try.md) | Try theme in the current session |
| [x theme untry](/mod/theme/untry.md) | Cancel setting theme in 'try' command |
| [x theme update](/mod/theme/update.md) | Update theme resource pack |
| [x theme font](/mod/theme/font.md) | Using font module to download fonts |
| [x theme current](/mod/theme/current.md) | Display the currently used prompt theme |
| [x theme feature](/mod/theme/feature.md) | Manage features of the current theme |
| [x theme statusline](/mod/theme/statusline.md) | Manage the status line component for Claude Code |

# x tldr

The content comes from the [tldr-pages](https://github.com/tldr-pages/tldr) project. Which is different from the help document. The content provided by this module is the most common usage examples (usage) and instructions in commands.


::: tip
NO_COLOR, ___X_CMD_TLDR_NO_BACKGROUND, ___X_CMD_TLDR_ENABLE_COLOR variables will affect the display of tldr documents
The fzf app supports the following function shortcuts:

`ctrl-w`: Toggle line wrapping in the preview window

`ctrl-R`: Change the layout of the preview window
:::


## Examples

Search and browse through the command usage documentation using an interactive interface

```sh
x tldr
```

View command usage documentation using fzf

```sh
x tldr --fz
```

Using the tldr tool, display the usage of the `git` command

```sh
x tldr git
```

Check out the documentation for the `git checkout` command

```sh
x tldr git checkout
```

Set Simplified Chinese as the preferred language for the tldr tool

```sh
x tldr --lang zh
```
## Introduction



The tldr module provides some of the most common use cases (usages) and explanations for commands. Compared to traditional help documentation, tldr documentation mainly uses examples to explain, making it more concise and easy to understand for users. The content comes from the [tldr-pages](https://github.com/tldr-pages/tldr) project, covering the most common usage examples of command-line tools for UNIX, Linux, macOS, SunOS, Android and Windows.



The implementation of the tldr module relies solely on shell/awk. Besides downloading document resource packages, it does not require dependencies on other binary files, ensuring that it can be used normally in an environment with x-cmd.



## Key Features


1. **Multi-language Support**: You can use `--lang <language>` to select the desired language. Currently, dozens of languages are supported (use `x tldr --lang` followed by Enter to view all supported languages).
2. **User-Friendly Presentation**:
    - **Colorful Display**: tldr documents are written in markdown format, which is not suitable for terminal display. Therefore, we process it to display in a colorful and user-friendly style for terminal users.
    - **TUI Interactive App**: When multiple documents are found for a command, tldr's TUI app will be activated, allowing users to select and preview documents in an interactive terminal. You can also use `--app`.



## cht, tldr, and Help Documents


1. Content provided by the **cht module** is similar to "cheat sheets", encompassing concise yet comprehensive examples of all command functionalities without lengthy explanations.
2. Content provided by the **tldr module** consists of a few practical examples of what can be quickly utilized within commands, with fewer and easier-to-understand contents. "tldr" (Too Long; Didnâ€™t Read) is an internet slang meaning that a post, article, comment, or any content (such as man pages) is too lengthy.
3. **Help documents/manuals** are akin to "textbooks", offering detailed explanations of each command's functionality, application examples, common issues, and solutions.



In conclusion, the content of cht, tldr, and help documents can complement each other. You can quickly grasp unfamiliar commands through tldr, further understand the functionality and usage of commands through help documents, and search for less common or forgotten functionalities within commands using cht.

## Usage

```sh
x tldr [FLAGS] [SUB_COMMAND] <#1>
```

## Arguments

| Argument | Description |
| ------- | ------- |
| `#1` | Command name |


## Flags

| Name, Shorthand | Description |
| ------- | ------- |

# x uptime

x uptime is an enhanced version of the `uptime` command, providing structured YAML format output for system uptime, the number of currently logged-in users, and system load averages over the past 1, 5, and 15 minutes.

This makes system status information easier to read, parse, and automate, which is extremely convenient for both manual viewing and script integration.



Regarding system load averages:

System load average is a key indicator of how busy the system is. It reflects how many processes are waiting for CPU resources or waiting for I/O operations to complete over a specific period.

These three values represent the average load for the past 1 minute, 5 minutes, and 15 minutes, respectively, helping you understand the short-term, medium-term, and long-term trends of system load.


::: tip
To address the issue of Windows systems not supporting the uptime command, use 'x cosmo uptime' to automatically download and invoke cosmo's uptime binary.

For information about cosmo, you can use 'x cosmo -h'.
:::


## Examples

Display system uptime and load situation in YAML format, equivalent to 'x uptime --yml'

```sh
x uptime
```

## Usage

```sh
x uptime [FLAGS]
```

## Flags

| Name, Shorthand | Description |
| ------- | ------- |
| `--yml`, `-y` | Display system uptime and load situation in yml format |
