# Modules in X-CMD

Each feature in X-CMD is encapsulated into modules using shell/awk:

- Except for the core modules, other modules are **loaded on-demand**, as x-cmd places a strong emphasis on startup speed.
- To keep it lightweight, we use POSIX shell code to implement functionalities.
- For performance-critical functionalities, we use open-source binary projects, and these modules appear as shell-layer wrappers for those projects.

Generally, you can use a module by running `x <module_name>`. x-cmd also provides a way to directly call common functions within popular modules:

---

- Compression and Decompression:
  - This functionality is provided by the zuz module [=> zuz documentation](/mod/zuz.md).
  - `x z` calls `x zuz z`, allowing you to compress files based on the file's suffix, and `x uz` can decompress any format.
- Enhanced `cd`:
  - The cd module is similar to autojump and z [=> cd documentation](/mod/cd.md).
  - The cd module functions as an enhanced version of `cd`, offering extensive folder-jumping capabilities. Because of its common use, we've set up an alias: `alias c='x cd'`.
- Other modules can be invoked using `x <module_name>` as listed below:

| Module | Usage | Documentation |
| --- | --- | --- |
| theme | `x theme` to select a theme, supports bash/zsh/dash/ash | - [theme module documentation](/mod/theme.md)<br>- [theme getting started guide](/theme/.md) |
| env | Provides environment management similar to nvm, pyenv, sdkman, and direnv but with a different underlying implementation | - [env module documentation](/mod/env.md) |
| ws | Provides workspace management through the ws module, allowing you to customize environment variables for workspaces and provide workspace-specific script modules | - [ws module documentation](/mod/ws.md) |
<!-- | mirror | Quickly change mirror sources for apt, dnf, brew, and npm | - [mirror module documentation](/mod/mirror.md)  | -->

<!-- | hub | Allows quick uploads of scripts in various programming languages (shell, python, js, perl, even Java) to your personal account space. You can run commands on any environment with x-cmd installed. Run `x <username>:<script>` to execute. x-cmd uses the env module to download the required runtimes and binaries (python, node, jq, etc.) | - [hub module documentation](/mod/env.md)<br>- [hub getting started guide](/start/hub.md) | -->

## Core Modules: env and pkg

x-cmd provides comprehensive multi-version toolchain download, usage, and management features. pkg is responsible for implementing this functionality, and env is the user-facing encapsulation module that enhances user-friendliness.
<br>
x-cmd never intended to become a full-fledged package manager, a role better suited for system distributions. On non-privileged installations, Nix and Homebrew perform admirably.

**x-cmd's goals are:**

1. To provide development runtimes, allowing users to quickly deploy development scripts without needing sudo privileges or manual installations.
2. To offer common tools that typically do not require sudo permissions.
3. To provide tools that are as cross-platform as possible so that users can build powerful cross-platform scripts based on the tools provided by x-cmd.

- [env](/mod/env.md) explains the environment management feature in x-cmd.
- [pkg list](/pkg/.md) lists the tool packages supported by x-cmd along with detailed explanations.
<!-- - [pkg](/mod/pkg.md) explains the package management functionality in x-cmd. -->

---

1. Generally, users do not need to use `env` or `pkg` to install software; they simply need to use `x <software_name>`, and X-CMD will download the package on demand and execute it directly. <br> **Note that this does not install the software**, meaning it cannot be used directly as `<software_name>`. In this mode, the software can only be invoked using `x <software_name>`, which is convenient and <u>will not pollute the user's environment</u>.
2. Users can also choose to install software. Taking `jq` as an example, `x env try jq` installs `jq` in the current environment, allowing users to use the software as `<software_name>`. The software installed this way modifies the environment variables of the current shell but does not affect other shells.
3. Using `x env use jq` for global installation means that the binary of `jq` will be added to the X-CMD bin directory (which is automatically added to `$PATH` when X-CMD is loaded), allowing it to be used in other shells.

In the situation described in point 3, there may be a few exceptionsâ€”software that requires specific environment variables after installation. <br> For example, early versions of the Java environment required setting `JAVA_HOME`. <br> In this case, only the current shell (the one invoking `x env use`) and any subsequently started shell environments will load the relevant environment variables. Other shell environments will only recognize the existence of the Java binary but will not have `JAVA_HOME` configured. At this point, users can either restart the corresponding shell environment or use `x env reload java` to set it up.

This design process is complex but unavoidable. For most users, simply using `x <software_name>` is sufficient. However, for users managing multiple versions of multiple software packages, especially those with environment variable requirements (which are not common), X-CMD addresses this issue by exposing it and partially solving it in the most efficient and clear manner. The remaining complexity that requires user customization and decision-making (flexibility) still needs to be managed by the user.

## More Modules

x-cmd is built with POSIX shell, making it highly compatible with users' shell environments, allowing it to deliver various features (traditional commands and cloud CLIs) to users in the best possible way.

Currently, we have chosen some of the most frequently used and stable modules from the current release version (some of which have been used in our development environment for over a year) for public release:

[=> mod list](/mod/.md)

Those not listed can still be used, although they may lack documentation, and their functionality may undergo significant changes in future reviews.

## Modules Under Development

We are currently developing around 200 modules. However, due to limited resources, the current version only releases essential modules. These modules are reasonably usable for interaction but need some time for development and functions to stabilize.

## Supporting Our Work

If you appreciate our work and wish to support us in accelerating our efforts, consider purchasing our hub service or paid consultation service to support our work:

- [x-cmd hub](https://hub.x-cmd.com)
- [x-cmd paid consultation service](/consult.md)
- [x-cmd sponsorship](/sponsor.md)

<h1 class="visually-hidden">Nushell</h1>

## Overview

Nushell is a Rust-powered shell that provides a modern user interface and supports powerful data processing capabilities. We are working to bring the x-cmd toolset to Nushell to enhance its functionality and user experience.

## Install x-cmd and Activate Nushell Support

### One-click Installation: Easy Setup via curl or wget

With just one line of command, you can download and install x-cmd in Nushell using curl or wget:

```bash
curl https://get.x-cmd.com | sh

```

or

```bash
wget -O- https://get.x-cmd.com | sh

```

### **Other Cases:**

```sh
# x-cmd is installed, but x-cmd related commands cannot be found in Nushell
sh -c '. "$HOME/.x-cmd.root/X"; x upgrade latest; x nu --setup'
nu

```

### **Activating and Configuring Shell Tools**

* If you have installed tools **using x-cmd** (such as starship, asdf) and need to **activate or configure** them in `env.nu` according to their requirements, it is recommended to add your configuration code after the x-cmd activation code.

## Theme Customization: Cool Down Your Command Line

While the x-cmd [theme module](https://www.google.com/search?q=/mod/theme) only supports POSIX shells, you can easily use oh-my-posh and starship themes through x-cmd to give your Nushell a fresh look:

```bash
x starship

```

```bash
x ohmyposh

```

Standing on the shoulders of giants like starship and oh-my-posh, x-cmd has developed the [starship module](https://www.google.com/search?q=/mod/starship) and [ohmyposh module](https://www.google.com/search?q=/mod/ohmyposh). These provide features like automatic installation, configuration, and theme previews. Additionally, our unified theme control command allows you to set your favorite theme with ease.

## Behind the Scenes: How `x nu --setup` Works

When a user runs `x nu --setup`, we add a single line of code to `$HOME/.config/nushell/env.nu` to boot up x-cmd:

* [`const ___X_CMD_ROOT = '$HOME/.x-cmd.root'; source $"($___X_CMD_ROOT)/local/data/nu/rc.nu"; # boot up x-cmd`](https://www.google.com/search?q=%5Bhttps://github.com/x-cmd/x-cmd/blob/main/mod/nu/lib/__setup%5D(https://github.com/x-cmd/x-cmd/blob/main/mod/nu/lib/__setup))
* Note that this line ends with our identifier comment `# boot up x-cmd`.
* This line primarily introduces enhancement functions and updates the PATH.
* Occasionally, due to manual changes or code issues, x-cmd might insert new code redundantly. Our strategy is to avoid deleting code in `env.nu` as much as possible to prevent the loss of user custom configurations.
* We keep the x-cmd code in `env.nu` as simple as possible (just one line) to help users understand our basic principles. This allows users to disable (comment or delete) or customize it after activation as needed.

## Support Status

1. **Support for pixi installation and auto-activation.**
2. **Support for aliases starting with @**:
* Aliases starting with @ are mainly used for LLM modules (e.g., `@gpt`, `@gemini`, `@o` introduced by the chat module; `@zh`, `@en` introduced by the writer module).
* Since Nushell does not support aliases starting with `@`, x-cmd writer module aliases like `@en` and `@zh` will be provided to users as `a:en` and `a:zh`.
* Currently, it is not possible to disable aliases like writer and chat during Nushell startup using `x boot alias disable [ c|xx|xw|xd|xg|xp|co|coco|chat|writer ]`.

**Note**: The above support is currently in the Beta stage.

## Current Issues

1. **Pipe Issues**: We attempted to wrap the `x` command in a function to obtain Nushell environment variables, but we found this approach caused difficult-to-handle issues with pipe processing and detection. Therefore, the current `x` command will turn off environment variable inheritance in favor of passing them via files to ensure that pipes work correctly.

# Performance

X-CMD's performance goals aim to balance functionality and efficiency:

1. **Embedded System Compatibility:** Ensuring smooth operation on resource-constrained embedded Linux systems (e.g., Raspberry Pi 3/4), providing a good user experience. This is our primary goal.
2. **Fast Loading:** The goal is to achieve fast startup.  The total load time in interactive mode should be no more than 150ms, and no more than 30ms in script mode. Ideally, on a MacBook M3, these times now reach 45ms and 15ms respectively.

Currently, our embedded system testing is primarily conducted on Raspberry Pi 3/4, which have relatively limited resources.  After product stabilization, we will continuously optimize performance. X-CMD aims to run stably on various Linux embedded devices and provide a good CLI user experience.

<!-- TODO: Compare times on raspberry pi 3/4/macm1/macm2. -->

## Git-Bash Performance Issues and Mitigation Strategies

Git Bash's subshell implementation has efficiency issues, particularly noticeable in [theme](/theme.md) rendering. We have adapted to address this issue, striving to ensure a good user experience.

* **Upgrade Git Bash:** Using newer versions of Git Bash (Bash 5 and above) can significantly improve performance, as new features reduce reliance on external commands.

The [theme module](/mod/theme.md) provides theme functionality similar to oh-my-zsh, but on resource-constrained hardware, theme rendering and terminal UI display in Git Bash may still experience slight lag.

While WSL2 offers a better runtime environment and interoperability with Windows resources, we believe providing a native system execution solution remains crucial. We will continue to improve, providing a smoother user experience for Git Bash users.

# Introduction and Comparison of X-CMD PKG

The modules of X-CMD leverage the robust capabilities of POSIX shell, AWK, and a series of Unix pre-installed tools, while also utilizing a large array of powerful external tools (such as jq, yq, jj, fzf, etc.).

We aim to address the download and installation of these external tool dependencies in a secure manner that minimizes environmental impact. We don't pass these dependency installations onto the user, nor do we want to create additional burdens for the omnipotent root user.

Over the past three years of development, we have researched several mainstream solutions. The following comparisons are not to determine superiority or inferiority but to introduce the design philosophy and applicable scenarios of pkg.

## Characteristics/Design Philosophy of [`x pkg`](/pkg/.md)

- Available on Windows, Linux, and MacOS (with planned future support for BSD systems)
- Minimize the number and versions of packages to save effort for more supply chain monitoring:
  - Keep the number as low as possible while covering mainstream development and system operation scenarios
  - Keep software versions as low as possible while covering mainstream versions that are actively maintained
  - Uncovered software and versions by pkg can be met through other ecosystems
- Reduce the overhead: download size, load time, startup time
- Minimally alter the environment; if a change is unavoidable, it should be explicitly stated to avoid surprises that might lead to bugs (No surprise).

## [`x pkg`](/pkg/.md) vs System Package Management Tools

System package management tools refer to apt, dnf/yum, pacman, and other package management tools provided by system distributors.

1. System package management tools are relatively stable, reliable, and highly integrated with the operating system.
2. x-cmd has been enhanced through modules for everyday use: [apt](/mod/apt.md)/[yum](/mod/yum.md)/[dnf](/mod/dnf.md)/[pacman](/mod/pacman.md).

Let us talk about some limitations of system package management tools.

### Root Privileges Required to Install Applications

- In product-level operation scenarios, sometimes root access is unavailable or should be avoided.
- Updating software A might inadvertently update a series of system dependencies B, C, D ..., which could disrupt existing software's stability.
- I have observed system dependency update issues during operations, occurring at inopportune times like delivery demonstrations or crucial client presentations.
- For a tool like jq or fzf, introducing the risk of altering system dependencies seems unnecessary.
- Nevertheless, high risk results in lower work efficiency.

### Older Versions for Stability in Some System Releases

Taking `fzf` as an example, as of October 9, 2024, the latest version is <u>0.55.0</u>.
<br>
On Ubuntu 22.04, the version of `fzf` installed (an LTS version supported until 2027) is <u>0.29.0</u>.
<br>
The version of `fzf` installed on Ubuntu 24.04 is the latest <u>0.44.1</u>.

- Different use cases necessitate different installation methods; [x install](/install/.md) aims to minimize these costs.
- Old software versions can lead to reduced work efficiency and users facing known bugs.
- This inconsistency leads to potential bugs and usage problems, like unexpected behavior from unsupported parameters in scripts or errors from CLI tools.

### Summary

I don't want to spend time on the detailed issues of these tools in my job. The x-cmd pkg, by utilizing only additional space in the HOME directory, allows:

- Consistency in tool versions over a certain period
- Utilization of new features with safety
- Avoidance of known bugs in older versions to the greatest extent possible

## [`x pkg`](/pkg/.md) vs nix | brew

1. Not available on Windows
2. Requires privileges for installation, though not for usage
3. Without root privileges for operation, installing nix and brew becomes irrelevant
4. Installation overhead makes them unsuitable for small containers

### [`x pkg`](/pkg/.md) vs [pixi](/mod/pixi.md) | [asdf](/mod/asdf.md) | [pkgx](/mod/pkgx.md)

| Feature  | pixi  | [`x pkg`](/pkg/.md)  | asdf  |
|------------------|-----------------------|--------------------|-------------------|
| Development Language | Rust  | Posix shell  | Bash  |
| Release Package Size & Dependencies | 10MB  | Less than 1.5MB  | 3.3MB  |
| Total Software  | 30,000+  | 600+  | 800+  |
| Alpine Container | Many common tools do not run | Almost all tools run | Cannot run, requires Bash and Git |
| Ecosystem Maintenance | Conda, commercial and community | x-cmd team  | Community  |

### Alpine Metrics

- As a heavy user of Alpine containers, compatibility within Alpine containers is a key design metric.
- Ideally, container users shouldnâ€™t need to manage within the container, but in practice, this requirement is hard to avoid in testing and development scenarios.

### Pixi

- Pixi is based on the conda ecosystem: vast quantity and high quality.
- Developed in Rust: Excellent in size, startup efficiency, and user experience.
- Pixi currently faces a major issue where many commonly used tools available on conda cannot be used in Alpine (e.g., jq).
- The conda ecosystem is not available on OpenBSD, FreeBSD, and NetBSD, which have always been targets of x-cmd pkg.
- Currently, x-cmd considers Pixi as a complement to pkg:
  - Some x-cmd modules have already adopted tools from Pixi, such as [btop](/mod/btop.md) and [htop](/mod/htop.md).
  - These packages and tools were not introduced into x-cmd pkg.
  - Because this demand is perfectly met, we can focus our limited resources on maintaining other tools.

### pkgx

- A great tool initiated by Brew developers and developed using Typescript.
- The total number of packages in this tool is around 1,500+.
- Major issue: It cannot be used on Windows and Alpine platforms.
- We provide a pkgx module to help interested users quickly install and enable it, with added TUI.

We will provide more information on this tool later; like Pixi, we see it as a strong complement to the x-cmd pkg ecosystem.

### Complementing with the Above Ecosystems and Future Development Guidelines

This segmentâ€™s software closely aligns with the target scenarios and design philosophy of x-cmd pkg; our future development guidelines are:

1. Limit pkgâ€™s management scope; software that can be perfectly covered by pixi/conda and pkgx will not be introduced into pkg under the premise of point 2 below.
2. Reduce the cost of user choice:
  1. Enhance [x install](/install/.md) to unify tool/package names, making all installation methods clear at a glance.
  2. Package in modules the methods we comprehensively assess to be the best, fastest, and safest for use.
  3. Unless there are significant factors like system environment impact or security, we try not to let users be puzzled by whether xx packages should be implemented with pkg, pixi, or pkgx.

### asdf

**Why was x-cmd pkg developed despite the existence of the brilliant asdf?**

1. Developed in Bash, asdf requires Bash in the environment.
2. asdfâ€™s installation is dependent on Git:
    - asdf targets development scenarios, so relying on Git is a reasonable technical decision.
    - x-cmd is based on maintenance scenarios:
    - Operational machines rarely have Git pre-installed â€“ our assumption has always been a minimized environment, such as the Alpine image.
    - In 2022, we could not find a portable Git solution or mature alternative â€“ until the emergence of the jj project and pixi project; currently, the [asdf module](/mod/asdf.md) resolves asdf's Git dependency with these.
    - Installing and downloading <u>40MB+</u> Git just to install a tool software that might not even be <u>1MB</u> in size is quite an overhead.
3. asdf manages metadata with Git, and many of its download addresses are outside of China, making network acceleration for the region very difficult.

**x-cmd provides an [asdf module](/mod/asdf.md)** to enhance the asdf usage experience:

1. Provides TUI to make it easy for users to interactively browse and install packages/tools.
2. When Git is not present in the local environment, x-cmd uses pkg to download jj to replace asdf's Git dependency:
  - Note that we do not install jj to reduce environmental impact.
  - If users need to use jj directly in the current environment, they can use `x env try jj`

**The Unique Value of asdf**

asdf's internal implementation utilizes nvm/rbenv/pyenv, allowing it to recognize their configuration files:

- These tools have amassed a large number of developer usersâ€”I myself have used them extensively at different times.
- The env tool from x-cmd does not support such configuration files; clearly, asdf is a hassle-free and effective all-in-one solution.
- Currently, x-cmd does not use asdf's packages and tools outside of the asdf module.

**Others**

1. Users can directly install asdf using `x install asdf`.
2. If your environment lacks the git dependency needed by asdf, x-cmd will automatically install git through its package management system without impacting the global environment.
3. We have designed an asdf module, allowing users to directly use `x asdf`. If the asdf module is not present locally, we will automatically trigger the official asdf installation.

## Other Interesting Directions

### wasm

- I have been closely following the progress of wasm:
- Currently, x-cmd has included [wasmer](/pkg/wasmer.md), [wasmedge](/pkg/wasmedge.md), [wasmtime](/pkg/wasmtime.md).
- The current size of wasm's runtime is considerable, and both startup and execution times leave something to be desired.
- Personally, I believe the unified cross-platform security model is the most important highlight of wasmâ€”I'm very excited about this.

### cosmo

[cosmo](/mod/cosmo.md) is developed by legendary engineer [Justine Tunney](https://justine.lol); it is an amazing project that has emerged in recent years with a high level of completion.

We have recently added a module with the same name, which:

- Integrates functionalities to address common issues encountered when using the cosmo system.
- Automatically downloads and provides options for global and system installation of cosmo applications.
- Provides a TUI interactive application and command completion.

The current [cosmo](/mod/cosmo.md) ecosystem offers over 100 commonly used software tools.

### Containers (docker, podman, bwrap) and proot

- These tools and technologies are excellent but can only be used on Linux.
- I have been keeping an eye on rootless containers.
- x-cmd has showcased the strengths of these tools within the module.

## Use the [x install](/install/.md) module to choose any of the above installation methods!

1. Initially, this was to aggregate all `curl | sh` type official installation scripts, to avoid frequently searching and copy-pasting from the software's official website.
2. Moving forward, we plan to unify the names of commonly installable software (not all) across all these tools and integrate them into the install module.
3. Users can directly use `x install <software_name>` to install software.
4. During installation, we will list all suitable installation methods for the current system, allowing users to choose the appropriate one.
5. This task is not small; we are gradually organizing it.

# pkg

I never intended to build a complete package management system. Initially, I just wanted to provide a way for users to quickly install some common lightweight tools in a minimal system environment without needing privileged permissions. However, it has grown steadily. The current number of packages has become quite a burden for our small team.

Nevertheless, I stick to the following principles:

1. **Safety and Trustworthiness:** Better if directly supplied by the tool's author, followed by system-native package managers.
2. **Avoid Redundancy:** System-level software, service-based software, and overall package counts are better handled by package managers.
3. **Simplicity:** Projects with interrupted maintenance or those we consider to have perfect alternative projects are abandoned. While we might add more entries internally knowing which package is better for the same requirement, it translates to a higher cognitive burden for the users. Thus, we refrain from increasing these entries. If mistakenly added, we'll gradually remove them without affecting normal user usage.

Based on these principles:

1. **Regarding Point 1:** Prioritize using packages compiled by the tool's author, but recompress them using `xz` to optimize download size.
2. **Regarding Point 2:** We have the 'install' module, which aims to help users quickly locate the software name of the current system package manager.

At present, I want users to consider 'pkg' merely as a downloader for common tools and language development environments, not as a package manager.

1. In critical use cases, the system's native package manager is the best choice.
2. Going forward, I'll still strive to add more tools based on user requests (we have a huge internal list, estimated to be around 1500); however, with one premise: stability will always be our top priority.

<h1 class="visually-hidden">PowerShell</h1>

## Overview

[PowerShell](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/powershell/scripting/overview?view=powershell-7.4) is a cross-platform command-line interface and scripting language environment developed by Microsoft. Initially designed for system administration, it has now expanded into a general-purpose tool, supporting Windows, macOS, and Linux platforms. We are attempting to introduce the X-CMD toolset to the Windows platform's `PowerShell` to enhance its functionality and user experience.

## Installing X-CMD

Currently, using the X-CMD toolset in `PowerShell` requires calling X-CMD through `Git-Bash`. Therefore, during the following installation, the script will install Git-Bash as needed and then install X-CMD within it.

`PowerShell` requires **permission to execute scripts**, specifically the X-CMD startup code within the user profile.

:::info Note:
- By default, PowerShell's execution policy may be set to Restricted, which means no scripts are allowed to run (including the user profile script Microsoft.PowerShell_profile.ps1). You can check your execution policy settings beforehand using `Get-ExecutionPolicy -List` and **ensure that the user profile script can run**.  `Set-ExecutionPolicy RemoteSigned -Scope CurrentUser` is recommended.
- For more details, please refer to [PowerShell Execution Policies](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/powershell/module/microsoft.powershell.core/about/about_execution_policies?view=powershell-7.4) and the [Set-ExecutionPolicy documentation](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/powershell/module/microsoft.powershell.security/set-executionpolicy?view=powershell-7.4)
:::

::::ul
:::li Method 1: Install X-CMD by requesting the x-cmd.ps1 script over the network

```powershell
[System.Text.Encoding]::GetEncoding("utf-8").GetString($(Invoke-WebRequest -Uri "https://get.x-cmd.com/x-cmd.ps1").RawContentStream.ToArray()) | Invoke-Expression
```

The above script ensures that the user downloads and installs X-CMD and automatically executes the `x pwsh --setup` command to inject X-CMD's startup code into the `PowerShell` PROFILE file;<br>
This script will download Git-Bash and X-CMD as needed.

:::
:::li Method 2: Inject X-CMD into PowerShell's PROFILE through local Git-Bash
```sh
# Inject X-CMD from the Git-Bash environment into the PowerShell user profile script
x pwsh --setup
```
:::
::::

## Changes to PROFILE by `x pwsh --setup`

When the user executes the `x pwsh --setup` command, X-CMD adds a line of code to the `PowerShell` PROFILE to enable X-CMD on startup.


### **Code for activating X-CMD in the user profile script**

```powershell
if (Test-Path "$Home\.x-cmd.root\local\data\pwsh\_index.ps1") { Set-ExecutionPolicy Bypass -Scope Process; . "$Home\.x-cmd.root\local\data\pwsh\_index.ps1" };  # boot up x-cmd.
```

- The injection of the above code is performed by this function: [pwsh module code](https://github.com/x-cmd/x-cmd/blob/main/mod/pwsh/lib/__setup#L4). It mainly introduces enhanced functions and adds some PATH paths;
- There is an X-CMD identification comment at the end `# boot up x-cmd`;
- The executed script code file can also be viewed in the [pwsh module code](https://github.com/x-cmd/x-cmd/blob/main/mod/pwsh/lib/rc/_index.ps1).


:::info As can be seen from the startup code above, referencing X-CMD in the `PowerShell` environment currently requires permission to run scripts.
The `Set-ExecutionPolicy Bypass -Scope Process` command sets the permission level of the current process to `Bypass`, allowing PS1 scripts to be executed.
:::

### **Activating and configuring shell-like tools**

- If you have installed some tools (such as starship, asdf) using **X-CMD** and need to **activate or configure** them in the PROFILE **according to the requirements of these tools**, it is recommended to add your configuration code after the X-CMD activation code.

## Supported Features

1. **Supported Systems/Environments:** Windows platform's Git-Bash
2. **Tools provided by X-CMD:**
    - [Encapsulation of common commands](/mod/zuz.md): The encapsulated commands (such as cd, ip, ps, tar, apt, brew) are more intelligent and easier to use than native commands.
    - [Lightweight package management tool](/pkg/.md): We have implemented a lightweight package management tool using shell and awk, through which you can quickly obtain most commonly used software tools, such as jq, 7za, bat, nvim, python, node, go, etc.
    - [CLI for practical websites](/mod/cht.md): We have encapsulated the APIs provided by them (such as github.com, cht.sh) using shell and awk for daily use and to obtain corresponding services in scripts.
    - Note: Since `@` is a special character in PowerShell and cannot be used for alias or function names, we use `a:` to call X-CMD LLM-like modules through functions (e.g., @gpt, @gemini, @o, etc., introduced by the chat module, @zh, @en, etc., from the writer module).

**Note:** The above support is still in the Beta feature stage.

# X-CMD Running Modes on POSIX and Non-POSIX Shells

ðŸŽ¯ This document describes x-cmd's running modes and compatibility on various shells, including `dash`, `bash`, `zsh`, `fish`, `nushell`, and `elvish`.

## POSIX Shell

x-cmd is designed to run on most systems with minimal overhead, utilizing `POSIX`-compliant shell syntax.

1. Determining whether a shell conforms to the POSIX standard, while generally agreed upon (e.g., csh, fish, nu, and elvish are definitely not POSIX), can be somewhat ambiguous and prone to debate.
2. This document uses the terms "POSIX Shell" and "Non-POSIX Shell" for clarity and ease of understanding; it does not intend to delve into the intricacies of the POSIX Shell standard.
3. During development, x-cmd aims to leverage the common features implemented by mainstream `POSIX Shells`. For example, although the `local` keyword is not part of the POSIX standard specification, most POSIX Shells support it, except for `KSH AJM 93` (a variant of ksh). Therefore, to enhance engineering capabilities and runtime efficiency, x-cmd has chosen to extensively use `local` and forgo the possibility of running as a library in KSH AJM 93.

## Running Modes

Because x-cmd uses `POSIX`-compatible shell syntax, it can run directly on `POSIX Shells`. On `non-POSIX Shells`, a POSIX Shell is required as a runtime environment.

For clarity, we refer to running x-cmd directly in the shell as **function mode** and running x-cmd with a `POSIX Shell` as a runtime environment as **external command mode**.

### Function Mode

On supported `POSIX Shells` (like `bash` and `zsh`), users can call x-cmd's loaded functions directly, running x-cmd as a library, similar to importing and using a library/module in `Python`.  This is in addition to using x-cmd's provided external commands (like `x`, `c`, `@gpt`).

- This mode has the following advantages and disadvantages:
    1. **Low startup overhead**: x-cmd's code executes directly within the current shell process, eliminating the need to launch a new process, resulting in higher efficiency.
    2. **Easy state sharing**: Changes made by x-cmd's application modules can be directly passed through shell variables, without relying on external files or other methods for state persistence.

### External Command Mode

On `non-POSIX Shells` and some `POSIX Shells`, users can only access x-cmd's functionality through its external commands (e.g., `x`, `c`, `@gpt`). While this mode doesn't offer the same efficient function calls as function mode, it ensures broader compatibility.

- This mode has the following advantages and disadvantages:
    1. **Suitable for TUI applications**:  Currently, most x-cmd applications are TUI-based (e.g., `x ollama`, `x gh`, `x ls`). Running in external command mode doesn't hinder the full expression of x-cmd's capabilities.
    2. **Negligible startup overhead**: Compared to function mode, the extra process startup overhead in external command mode is barely noticeable in most scenarios, especially for TUI interactive applications. Furthermore, x-cmd continues to optimize its startup process, further reducing this overhead.
    3. **State management relies on external storage**: Due to the nature of external command mode, a new shell process is launched for each x-cmd execution.  Therefore, shell variables cannot be directly passed between different executions. Applications requiring variable modification and state persistence need to utilize external files or other persistence mechanisms.  x-cmd currently supports this feature and is continuously improving it, allowing applications to automatically detect the running mode and adapt to the appropriate state storage solution.


## x-cmd Supported Shells

### Supported POSIX Shells

x-cmd supports these shells in **function mode**.

#### Bash

`Bash` is one of the most common `POSIX Shells`, widely used in Linux and Unix-like environments.

- **Bash 4/5**:
    1. Most mainstream Linux distributions and WSL (Windows Subsystem for Linux) provide Bash 4 or Bash 5 by default.
    2. `Git for Windows` has defaulted to Bash 5 since 2023, further promoting the Bash 5 ecosystem.
    3. The Bash within the `cosmo` ecosystem is also Bash 5.

- **Bash 3**:
    1. MacOS's default `/bin/sh` is still based on Bash 3. Due to GPLv3 license restrictions, it's unlikely that macOS will upgrade to Bash 4/5 in the near future.
    2. macOS may transition to a lighter and more reliable shell for `/bin/sh` in the future, such as dash or ash.
    3. Bash 3 has some differences in syntax and features compared to later versions, with some historical quirks (which can be seen as features or bugs).

#### Zsh

MacOS pre-installs `zsh` and sets it as the default login shell. It offers powerful interactive capabilities and rich extension features. However, compared to bash, zsh has some bugs in certain system administration scenarios, limiting its influence in the `/bin/sh` domain.

#### Dash

Debian and its derivatives (Ubuntu, Kali, Manjaro, etc.) use `dash` as the default `/bin/sh` for improved shell execution efficiency. Compared to bash/zsh, dash is a lightweight shell known for its speed but lacks some advanced features.

#### Ash

The default shell for `BusyBox` and `Alpine`, `ash` is widely used in Docker and lightweight Linux distributions, making it the preferred shell for minimal Linux systems.

### Supported Non-POSIX Shells

x-cmd supports these shells in **external command mode** to ensure compatibility.

- [nushell](/start/nushell.md):  Employs a data-driven pipeline design, excelling in data processing and aligning well with x-cmd's data flow philosophy.
- [elvish](/start/elvish.md):  A unique and innovative shell with `Lisp`-style functional programming capabilities.
- [xonsh](/start/xonsh.md):  Combines Python syntax with shell features, allowing direct execution of Python code within the shell environment.
- [fish](/start/fish.md):  Features excellent design choices, providing rich completions and an efficient interactive experience by default.
- [tcsh](/start/tcsh.md):  The default login shell for FreeBSD, featuring a unique word-based data flow processing approach.
- [powershell](/start/powershell.md):  The pre-installed shell on Windows, supporting object pipeline passing.


### Ksh Support

x-cmd currently has limited support for Ksh (KornShell), especially PD Ksh (the default shell on OpenBSD).

- Due to Ksh 93's lack of support for the `local` keyword, its compatibility issues significantly impact the code, and it's not a priority for support in the short term.
- Due to function variable scoping issues in KSH AJM 93u, it's unlikely that x-cmd will support it in function mode, but external command mode compatibility will be maintained.
- We haven't conducted comprehensive testing on OpenBSD, nor have we ported the PKG system to OpenBSD and FreeBSD, so PD Ksh adaptation is not a priority at this time.

If you have specific requirements, please submit an issue or send us an email.

## Code Directory Search Work Before Loading

x-cmd is installed in the user's `$HOME/.x-cmd.root/` directory.

1. If you open bash interactively, bash generally loads either `$HOME/.bash_profile` or `$HOME/.bashrc`. Open these files, and you'll find a line like `[ ! -f "$HOME/.x-cmd.root/X" ] || . "$HOME/.x-cmd.root/X" # boot up x-cmd.`
2. `$HOME/.x-cmd.root/X` is the startup file for x-cmd. Open this file, and you'll find:
    1. The default version is set to `___X_CMD_VERSION_DEFAULT=latest`.
    2. If ___X_CMD_VERSION is not set, it uses the version set by ___X_CMD_VERSION_DEFAULT.
    3. Based on ___X_CMD_VERSION, ___X_CMD_ROOT is set to the specific installation directory of x-cmd code.
3. About the X file in the version folder:
   1. If it is a version directory like latest, alpha, beta, v1, v1.1.1, the X file inside actually points to a version folder marked with an eight-digit hexadecimal version number.
   2. If it is a specific source code folder, this X file will load the lastest file of the xrc module, which contains the specific feature loading code. The specific features are described in the next section.
   3. In x-cmd's view, latest and v1 are changeable. During operation, the versions can be modified based on actual needs. Users can also modify the local latest or v1 as needed. However, the eight-digit hexadecimal string is generated by the core code of the folder and represents an objectively describable version number.

## xrc Module

1. Loads necessary functions and code.
2. Loads user configuration files.
3. If it is an interactive environment:
   1. Loads relevant command completion functionalities.
   2. Configures aliases.
   3. Loads and configures the theme module.

<h1 class="visually-hidden">Support Us</h1>

# Support Us

## About Us

The X-CMD development team was founded in 2021, dedicated to the development and ecosystem construction of X-CMD. We are a group of developers passionate about technology, hoping to create a truly useful tool to help everyone improve efficiency.

We chose POSIX-SHELL, not because we don't understand other languages (such as Rust, Go, Python, TypeScript, C), but quite the opposite. Since 2018, the predecessor of X-CMD has tried these solutions. I also plan that X-CMD will gradually adopt features from other languages in appropriate parts and scenarios to enhance functionality and performance.

The reason for ultimately choosing POSIX-SHELL is a carefully considered trade-off: it boasts a wide range of operating environments, extremely high startup efficiency, transparent code, and comprehensive advantages in I/O time consumption in specific scenarios. My selection process was:

::::ul
:::li 2018~2019
`TypeScript` (similar to npx)
:::
:::li 2020
`Golang` (For startup efficiency)
:::
:::li 2020
`C/Rust` (For size and startup efficiency)
:::
:::li 2021
`Bash` (merging the x-bash project)
:::
:::li ~ Now
`POSIX-SHELL` (exploration, pushing the limits of POSIX-SHELL in terms of performance and functionality)`.  After multiple rewrites and comparisons, the final decision was made.
:::
::::

## Take Action Now, Power X-CMD's Growth

Your support is crucial to us; it allows us to invest more time in improving X-CMD and building a better product. You can support us in the following ways:

- Join our [user communication group](/start/community.md) to exchange experiences and suggestions with our developers and users. Your feedback is invaluable to us.
- Submit any problems or suggestions you encounter in [discussion](https://github.com/x-cmd/x-cmd/discussions) and [Issue](https://github.com/x-cmd/x-cmd/issues).
- Read more articles on our official website. You can provide feedback through [Issue](https://github.com/x-cmd/x-cmd/issues).
- Follow our official website articles and [Bilibili](https://space.bilibili.com/2058520408)/[Youtube channel](https://www.youtube.com/@x-cmd) to stay updated on the latest X-CMD news.
- [Give us a star on GitHub](https://github.com/x-cmd/x-cmd) to let more people know about X-CMD.


## Why We Are Not Currently Accepting External Contributions

We greatly appreciate everyone's enthusiasm and anticipation for X-CMD! Many friends hope to participate in the development of X-CMD, and we are very excited about this. However, we are not currently accepting external contributions for the following reasons:

1. **Maintaining Consistency and High Quality:** Although X-CMD uses a modular design for decoupling, we still strive for highly consistent design, naming, and interaction processes, which is crucial for improving the user experience of command-line tools. Imagine how frustrating it would be if the close button for every application were different! Currently, we are still working to understand the terminology, processes, and design of related products and continuously refining these details in real-world cases to ensure the overall consistency and high quality of X-CMD.
2. **Challenges of POSIX-SHELL Development:** Compared to other programming languages, POSIX-SHELL development lacks well-established engineering specifications. This makes code collaboration and maintenance more complex. We are actively exploring best practices and establishing a standardized development process to better collaborate with the community in the future.
3. **Security and Trust:** The security of open-source projects is paramount. The [xz injection incident](/pkg/security-20240329.md) that shocked the open-source world a year ago made us deeply aware of this and made us more cautious about code security and contributor authentication.  Until we establish a robust security mechanism, we cannot afford the potential risks of introducing external contributions. We believe a secure and reliable X-CMD is more important than a rapidly expanding community.
4. **Gradual Opening Plan:** We understand everyone's passion for participating in open-source projects and hope to collaborate with more developers to build X-CMD in the future. As the project matures and improves, and with the introduction of technologies like LLMs, we will gradually open up the contribution process and establish a more comprehensive community management mechanism. We believe that a high-quality foundation version is the basis for open collaboration. We are working hard and hope to achieve this goal as soon as possible!


## A Few Personal Thoughts

We are pleased to see more and more people using X-CMD. Everyone's feedback and suggestions help us continuously improve and perfect X-CMD.

Our team is small, focusing more on product quality and user experience rather than large-scale marketing. We believe word-of-mouth is the best form of advertising. Your actual usage experience and sharing are more valuable to us than any advertisement.

Of course, a larger community influence (such as the number of Bilibili fans or GitHub stars) can provide us with more resources to better serve everyone. We also hope more people will learn about and use X-CMD. However, we value long-term user trust and reputation accumulation more.

We have received many suggestions for collaborative promotion, and we appreciate your support. Currently, we are more focused on improving the product itself and communicating directly with users. While this approach may not be as efficient as large-scale marketing, it allows us to understand user needs more directly and thus better improve X-CMD.

If you like X-CMD and want to participate, welcome to join our [user communication group](/start/community.md). There, you can share your usage experience, provide suggestions, and even participate in the development of X-CMD. Your participation is crucial to us.

Thank you for your support, and we look forward to meeting you in the [user communication group](/start/community.md)!

# Installing x-cmd with System Package Manager

x-cmd can be installed using the system's built-in package manager.

âš ï¸  The method of installing `x-cmd` using the system package manager is still in the experimental stage, please use it with caution. We welcome your feedback to help us improve this installation method.

## Features of System Package Manager Installation

1.  The design philosophy of `x-cmd` is to be usable without relying on privileges, so by default it will only be installed in the current user's user space. At the same time, for security and privacy protection, the current version has not yet implemented multi-user data sharing. This means that for `x-cmd` instances installed through the system package manager, each user needs to activate and configure it separately.
2.  Although `x-cmd` can be called as an external command, `x-cmd` is written in POSIX shell, and its advantage lies in the deep customization and integration with the interactive shell. Therefore, loading `x-cmd` when the shell starts can maximize the advantages of the `x-cmd` module (such as faster startup speed, automatic modification of environment variables, etc.).

## Installation Process and Principles

Installing `x-cmd` through the package manager essentially places a stable version of the `x-cmd` source code in a globally user-readable directory (such as `/usr/share/x-cmd`) and places an executable bin script named `x-cmd` in `/usr/bin`.

Since it is not appropriate to modify the specific user's HOME directory when the system package manager installs `x-cmd`, after the installation is successful, the user needs to explicitly call the `x-cmd` command to complete the activation. This step will copy the `x-cmd` source code from `/usr/share/x-cmd` to the user's `$HOME/.x-cmd.root` directory, and load `x-cmd` when the shell interactive mode starts.

> We use copying instead of soft links to avoid failures such as missing code or inconsistent versions when the system package manager upgrades or removes `x-cmd` in the future, causing the `x-cmd` shell environment or scripts to be loaded in specific users. This method ensures the independence and stability of each user environment.

It is worth noting that due to the submission review cycle, the x-cmd version of the system package manager may be an older stable version (usually 5-10 minor versions behind the latest stable version). After activating x-cmd, users can call `x upgrade` as needed. This command will download the latest x-cmd version to the current user directory -- the x-cmd in the system global directory is still the older stable version.

## Currently Supported System Package Managers

**Step 1: Please select the package manager to install x-cmd according to your system:**

âš ï¸  Note that apt, apk, dnf, and pacman are still waiting for community review to pass

| System Package Manager | Installation Command            |
| ---------------------- | ------------------------------- |
| homebrew               | `brew install x-cmd`            |
| aur                    |   `yay -S aur` or `paru -S aur` |
| âš ï¸ apt                 | `sudo apt install x-cmd`        |
| âš ï¸ apk                 | `sudo apk add x-cmd`            |
| âš ï¸ dnf                 | `sudo dnf install x-cmd`        |
| âš ï¸ pacman              | `sudo pacman -Sy x-cmd`         |

**Step 2: After the installation is successful, you need to activate it in the current user environment:**

```bash
x-cmd
```

The activation command will install `x-cmd` to your user directory (`$HOME/.x-cmd.root`) and configure your shell environment.  **Be sure to perform this step!**  The activation process will modify your shell configuration file (e.g. `.bashrc`, `.zshrc`, etc.) so that `x-cmd` is automatically loaded each time the shell starts.

Generally speaking, the newly opened shell will automatically load x-cmd at this time, and users can directly use the `x` command.

**Step 3: (Optional) Configure Non-POSIX Shell**

Step 2 does not automatically load configurations for non-POSIX shells. Users need to enter the following commands to explicitly set them up.

| Non-POSIX Shell | Installation Command         |
| --------------- | ---------------------------- |
| fish            | `x-cmd fish --setup`         |
| elvish          | `x-cmd elv --setup`          |
| nushell         | `x-cmd nu --setup`           |
| xonsh           | `x-cmd onsh --setup`         |
| csh             | `x-cmd csh --setup`          |

If your shell has loaded x-cmd, you can directly use `x` to replace `x-cmd`.

## Future Development Directions

### Multi-User Sharing of x-cmd Source Code

The current system installation and activation strategy is very conservative, and stability and availability are the primary goals. Moreover, the x-cmd source code is small in size (gz compression is only 1.5MB), and the optimization requirements for storage occupation are not significant.

### Sharing [x-cmd pkg](/pkg.md) to Avoid Repeated Downloads (High Priority)

1.  Primary optimization -- network: In the future, we will prioritize optimizing the download cache sharing mechanism between users to avoid repeated downloads of installation packages. We will use strict hash verification to prevent user caches from being tampered with or deceived.
2.  Secondary optimization -- storage: Furthermore, we can consider using methods such as soft links or hard links to achieve sharing of software installation between multiple users, thereby reducing storage space occupation. But obviously, this requires users to use privileged mode or specific users/user groups to manage the shared software space.

## Common Problems

*   **Cannot use the `x` command after installation?**

    Please make sure that you have executed the `x-cmd` command to activate it under the current user.

    If you still cannot use it, please check whether your shell configuration file (e.g. `.bashrc`, `.zshrc`, etc.) is correctly configured with the `x-cmd` environment variables and shell functions. You can try restarting the shell or manually sourcing your shell configuration file.

*   **The `x-cmd` version installed by the system package manager is too old?**

    The `x-cmd` version in the system package manager is usually slightly behind the latest stable version. You can use the `x upgrade` command to upgrade to the latest version after activating `x-cmd`.

    Note that this will only upgrade the `x-cmd` version in the current user directory, and the version in the system global directory is still the old version.

*   **How to uninstall `x-cmd` installed by the system package manager?**

    Use the corresponding package manager command to uninstall `x-cmd`. For example, systems using `apt` can use the `sudo apt remove x-cmd` command to uninstall. After uninstallation, you may need to manually delete the `$HOME/.x-cmd.root` directory and clean up the configuration related to `x-cmd` in the shell configuration file.

*   **Why is it necessary to copy the `x-cmd` source code to the user directory?**

    As mentioned earlier, this is to avoid affecting the user's `x-cmd` environment when the system package manager upgrades or removes `x-cmd`. Copying the source code ensures the independence and stability of each user's `x-cmd` environment.

*   **What is the difference between system package manager installation and manual installation?**

    The main difference lies in the installation location and version management method. System package manager installation will install `x-cmd` to the system global directory, and the system package manager is responsible for version management. Manual installation will install `x-cmd` to the user directory, and the user is responsible for version management. In addition, system package manager installation requires manual activation by the user, while manual installation usually completes the activation automatically.

We welcome you to provide more feedback to help us improve the system package manager installation method!

<h1 class="visually-hidden">tcsh</h1>

## Overview

tcsh is a C shell with programmable command line completion, command line editing, and some other features. We are attempting to introduce the x-cmd toolset into tcsh to enhance its functionality and user experience.

## Installing x-cmd

1. **Using curl:**

    ```sh
    curl https://get.x-cmd.com | sh -i
    tcsh
    ```

2. **Using wget:**

    ```sh
    wget -O- https://get.x-cmd.com | sh -i
    tcsh
    ```

3. **Other cases:**

    ```sh
    # x-cmd is installed, but tcsh cannot find x-cmd related commands
    sh -c '. "$HOME/.x-cmd.root/X"; x upgrade latest; x tcsh --setup'
    tcsh
    ```

:::info Note, When executing the above command, you might see the following error message:

```sh
sh: Cannot set tty process group (No such process)
```

This error occurs because `sh -i` is used and commands are piped, preventing `sh -i` from acquiring a controlling terminal (tty) for interaction. This is normal shell behavior and will not affect the installation or normal operation of x-cmd. You can safely ignore this error.
:::

## Support Information

1. **Supported Systems/Environments:** Linux, MacOS, WSL (Windows Subsystem for Linux), Cygwin, MSYS2 (such as Gitbash)
2. **Tools Provided by x-cmd:**
    - [Wrappers for Common Commands (e.g., cd, ip, ps, tar, apt, brew)](/mod/zuz.md): These wrapped commands are more intelligent and easier to use compared to the native commands.
    - [Lightweight Package Management Tool](/pkg/.md): We have implemented a lightweight package management tool using shell and awk. Through it, you can quickly obtain most common software tools, such as jq, 7za, bat, nvim, python, node, go, etc.
    - [CLI for Useful Websites (e.g., github.com, cht.sh)](/mod/cht.md): We have wrapped their APIs using shell and awk for daily use and to obtain corresponding services in scripts.
    - [AI Tools](/mod/openai.md): We provide CLIs for ChatGPT, Gemini, Jina.ai, etc., and have wrapped corresponding shortcut commands for different application scenarios, such as `@gemini` for chatting with Gemini AI and `@zh` for using AI to translate specified content or command results.

**Note**: The above support is still in the Beta stage.


## Current Issue

We have not yet found a simple way to pass the file content verbatim to the variable in tcsh. If it is determined that there is no way, we will resort to generating code to solve it (obviously, this is inefficient).

# Supported Terminals

## Basic functions of x-cmd do not depend on specific terminals

x-cmd is designed as a cross-platform command-line tool; its core functionality does not rely on graphical components or specific terminal features. As long as the terminal emulator supports the VT100 standard, you can use the main commands of x-cmd within it without any additional configuration.

This means that whether you are using macOSâ€™s Terminal.app, a Linux tty, or Windows PowerShell, x-cmd can run its basic commands in these environments.

## Optional Enhancements: Icon and character support (requires installing special fonts)

Some x-cmd modules or integrated third-party tools (such as `x theme`, `lsd`, `starship`, etc.) utilize rich icons to enhance user experience. These icons depend on special fonts (e.g., [Nerd Fonts](/start/font.md)). If your terminal is not properly configured with these fonts, icons may appear garbled or as question marks.

It is recommended to install and enable fonts with icon extensions to fully enjoy the experience. This is especially important for tools like:

- **File listing tools**: such as [lsd](/pkg/lsd.md), which uses icons to differentiate directories, files, symlinks, etc.;
- **Terminal prompt themes**: such as [x theme](/mod/theme.md), [starship](/mod/starship.md), and [ohmyposh](/mod/ohmyposh.md).

> ðŸ‘‰ Font installation guide can be found at: [Font Configuration](/start/font.md)

## Optional Enhancements: Display images (requires Sixel protocol support)

x-cmd also supports tools capable of previewing images directly within the terminal (e.g., [yazi](/pkg/yazi.md)). These tools depend on the terminal supporting **Sixel graphics protocol** or similar graphic extensions.

Not all terminals support Sixel currently. It is recommended to use terminals that support image display features to enable this advanced function. We will specify in the following list of third-party terminals their support for Sixel.

## Third-party Terminals

Below are some popular third-party terminal emulators we have tested:

| Terminal  | Platform  | Sixel Image Support | Remarks  |
|------------|------------------------------|---------------------|--------------------------------------------------|
| Alacritty  | Linux, macOS, Windows  | â“ Unknown  | Fast and lightweight, but no image support  |
| Ghostty  | Linux, macOS, Windows  | â“ Unknown  | Still under development, modern design  |
| Tabby  | Linux, macOS, Windows  | âœ… Supported  | Cross-platform, visually appealing, supports image preview |
| Terminus  | Linux, macOS, Windows  | â“ Unknown  | Electron-based, user-friendly  |
| Kitty  | Linux, macOS  | âš  Not Sixel, supports images | Uses its own image protocol, incompatible with Sixel |

System default terminals (like macOS Terminal.app or default Linux terminals) often prioritize stability and may lack advanced features such as graphic display. As a result, many users prefer more feature-rich third-party terminals.

We welcome all kinds of excellent terminal solutions, whether open source, commercial, or proprietary. If you have good recommendations, feel free to share on [GitHub Discussion #224](https://github.com/x-cmd/x-cmd/discussions/224).

## Windows users: Compatibility issues with display

For Windows users, while Windows Terminal is a powerful modern terminal, there may be some display compatibility issues in specific scenarios (for example, when using `git-bash` with tools like `tmux` or `fzf` as of this documentâ€™s writing date [2025-04-29]). If you encounter such issues or are considering alternative options, you might explore other third-party terminals on this page that support Windows.

---
When choosing a terminal, consider your functional requirements and personal preferences. x-cmd is committed to broad compatibility and continuously adapts to the trends of mainstream terminal development.

url: /start/uninstall.md
---

# Uninstall x-cmd

In the early stages of x-cmd, it may not meet all expectations, and we apologize for any inconvenience. For this reason, we've placed this document near the beginning to help users restore their environment.

## Uninstall Principle

The entire design of x-cmd aims for a portable and easy-to-remove approach, making it **very easy to uninstall**. Here are two key points:

1. x-cmd stores all its code and runtimes in the `$HOME/.x-cmd.root` folder.
2. To load x-cmd when starting bash and zsh, x-cmd adds the following line to `.bashrc` and `.zshrc`:<br>
`[ ! -f "$HOME/.x-cmd.root/X" ] || . "$HOME/.x-cmd.root/X"`.

**Based on these principles, you only need to:**

1. Remove the loading code from `.bashrc` and `.zshrc`. Locate the line containing `.x-cmd` and delete it.
2. Delete the `$HOME/.x-cmd.root` folder.

## Removing `$HOME/.x-cmd.root` May Affect Running x-cmd Instances

1. When you delete this directory, other running x-cmd instances will encounter some issues because they still rely on the environment variables in this directory. This can lead to some undefined behavior.
2. Therefore, it's best to ensure all the loaded shells have exited before deleting this directory.
3. If you don't mind the disk space consumed by `$HOME/.x-cmd.root`, you can first remove only the **loading code**. This will avoid any unknown impacts on other shells. After unloading the code, wait for all shells to exit, or simply restart your system before deleting `$HOME/.x-cmd.root`.
   1. Typically, `$HOME/.x-cmd.root` contains extracted code and configuration files, which occupy a limited amount of disk space.
   2. If you've used a lot of packages, the directory may also contain binaries and cached packages, which make up the main disk space usage.

## Uninstall Solutions

1. Unload all automatic loading: `x boot clear`, clear the "start x-cmd" code set in the rc file
2. Users can manually delete the following: `rm -rf ~/.x-cmd.root`

## Why We Don't Provide a Mechanism to Detect if x-cmd is Loaded in Other Shells

Providing such a mechanism would have some side effects that we are not willing to accept:

1. Using a resident process
2. Writing files - if x-cmd becomes corrupted, there may be issues with residual files
3. Extra checks during startup

We may eventually accept a resident process solution, but the details of this issue will be decided after v0.2.0.

url: /start/upgrade.md
---

# Upgrading to the Latest Version

We only release versions that have passed internal testing, which means we thoroughly verify the latest version pointed to by 'latest' and update it locally to point to the latest stable version.

**The methods for upgrading are as follows:**

1. You can directly use the installation script: `eval "$(curl https://get.x-cmd.com)"`. This script combines the initial installation and upgrading into one step.
2. You can use the `x upgrade` command, which essentially executes option 1 but also checks for a new version in advance. If a new version is available, it will execute option 1.

## Upgrading Does Not Affect Open Shells

1. If you have an open shell (let's call it shell A) that is loaded with the current 'latest' version, this shell will load the version pointed to by 'latest' (let's say it's v0.1.15).
2. You perform an upgrade, and the current 'latest' is v0.2.0.
3. After the upgrade, the previously opened shell (shell A) will still point to v0.1.15.

**What about the shell where you executed the upgrade command?**

1. If the shell where you executed the upgrade doesn't have x-cmd loaded, then after the upgrade, this shell will load the latest version.
2. If the shell where you executed the upgrade already has x-cmd loaded, then after the upgrade, this shell will not load the latest version. We will start a new shell on this one, which will load the latest version.

## The Underlying Concept: x-cmd as a Library for Shells

This issue brings us to a fundamental aspect: for shells, x-cmd is a library, not an external script or tool. Therefore, hot-swapping is very challenging.

I've put considerable effort into addressing this issue, but it involves too many environment variable modifications (and users also modify the environment during shell usage). Furthermore, x-cmd needs to remain highly efficient, and to ensure the sustainability of the project, it must maintain a simple and maintainable design. As a result, I ultimately abandoned the hot-swapping design.

Hence, in the design of various processes, we ensure that a shell does not load different versions of x-cmd --- more precisely, we need to ensure that **x-cmd is loaded only once**.

url: /start/user.md
---

# Target Users And Design Philosophy

1. **Beginner-Friendly:** Easy to get started with. I believe even seasoned developers encounter unfamiliar territories. When diving into a new domain, it's common to feel anxious (well, at least it might be just me). We strive to make the introductory functionalities of each domain/module very user-friendly, often focusing on common functionalities.

2. **Designed for Advanced Users:** Overall design targets advanced users. x-cmd aims to be a flexible and powerful tool. Simplification could not only compromise flexibility but also introduce additional concepts and models, which might not be required for users familiar with the field, thereby increasing management overhead and the likelihood of operational errors.

## AI and Networking

1. **AI Enhancement:** AI assists users in simplifying x-cmd's usage. However, x-cmd should not be reliant on AI. Throughout development, I aim to use deterministic algorithms as much as possible or provide alternative deterministic algorithms to satisfy fundamental functionalities. Who knows, one day we might need x-cmd to confront Skynet.

2. **Dependency on Networking:** x-cmd relies on networking for rapid deployment of capabilities. However, it shouldn't be mandatory to depend on the external network. Internal network usage will be a focal point for enhancing securityâ€”I certainly don't want to be at the mercy of a complete Cylon network shutdown.

In 2019, I realized that with tools like npx and [deno](/pkg/deno.md), I must elevate the goal to execute any script. Thus, naturally, "x" became the command.

In this process, I attempted to implement it with TypeScript, Go, C, and Bash, but eventually, I used shell+awk as the final solution, although I was not very familiar with it. # Installing and Using x-cmd on Windows

ðŸŽ¯ This document describes how to install and use `x-cmd` in the `WSL`, `Git-Bash`, `Cygwin`, and `Mingw` environments on Windows.

## Installing x-cmd

### Method 1: Installed using a shell script, suitable for users familiar with the command line terminal

This method is suitable for WSL, Git-Bash (Git-For-Windows), Cygwin, and MinGw environments. The installation method is the same as [the installation method on Linux](/start/linux.md). You can run any of the following commands:

```bash
eval "$(curl https://get.x-cmd.com)"
```

```bash
eval "$(wget -O- https://get.x-cmd.com)"
```

- Although `x-cmd` can run on `WSL1`, development for `WSL1` has stagnated, and the `x-cmd` PKG system is not adapted for `WSL1`. Therefore, we recommend using `x-cmd` on `WSL2`.
- `x-cmd` has been optimized for `Git-Bash`, but due to its inherent mechanisms, there still exist certain performance differences compared to `WSL2`.

### Method 2: Install using the `x-cmd.bat` script, suitable for command line beginners

The [`x-cmd.bat`](https://get.x-cmd.com/x-cmd.bat) script is a batch script prepared specifically for Windows users, requiring no administrator privileges. It is designed as a startup script that installs `Git-Bash` and `x-cmd` as needed during the startup process. The specific usage process is as follows:

1. [Download the `x-cmd.bat` script](https://get.x-cmd.com/x-cmd.bat) from the x-cmd official website.
2. Double-click the `x-cmd.bat` script file and wait for the installation to complete. After installation, it will automatically enter the command line interface.
3. After the first installation, the `x-cmd.bat` script file can be used as a quick launch method for `x-cmd`. It is recommended that users place it on their desktop.

<video id="video" controls preload>
  <source id="mp4" src="/imgs/x-bat-install.mp4" type="video/mp4">
</video>

- Note: If users face restrictions during the installation of `x-cmd` related to the installation of Git for Windows, please refer to [Installing x-cmd under restricted software installation conditions](https://cn.x-cmd.com/start/windows#%E9%99%90%E5%88%B6%E8%BD%AF%E4%BB%B6%E5%AE%89%E8%A3%85%E6%83%85%E5%86%B5%E4%B8%8B%E5%AE%89%E8%A3%85)

<!-- TODO: Add two screenshot examples of the windows screen. -->
:::info Warning about Windows Screen
- From the perspective of Windows system designers, directly downloading and executing external scripts poses security risks. Therefore, Windows has introduced a Screen mechanism to intercept content from unknown sources, which is a responsible security measure.
- The `x-cmd.bat` file is directly downloaded from the x-cmd official website (via HTTPS secure access). This script is open source and hosted on [GitHub](https://github.com/x-cmd/get/blob/main/x-cmd.bat), and the script behavior description can be found later in this document.
- We are actively seeking methods to pass Windows Screen certification (such as attempting to submit file checksums). Until then, users will need to manually allow `x-cmd.bat` to bypass the Screen interception. The specific steps can be viewed in the video demonstration.
:::

### Method 3: Install using the PowerShell script, suitable for users accustomed to PowerShell

Users can open PowerShell and run the following command:

```powershell
[System.Text.Encoding]::GetEncoding("utf-8").GetString($(Invoke-WebRequest -Uri "https://get.x-cmd.com/x-cmd.ps1").RawContentStream.ToArray()) | Invoke-Expression
```

This script will download the `x-cmd.bat` from the x-cmd official website and execute it to install Git-Bash and `x-cmd` as needed. After a successful installation, the script will automatically execute `x pwsh --setup` to load `x-cmd` when PowerShell starts. Therefore, users do not need to manually call `x pwsh --setup` for configuration.

If you want to further understand the usage instructions for `x-cmd` in PowerShell (such as configuring themes, calling LLM via aliases) and the principles involved, please refer to our [PowerShell topic document](/start/powershell.md).

:::info Note:
- To execute PowerShell scripts, you may need to adjust the execution policy in PowerShell.
- By default, the execution policy of PowerShell is set to Restricted - which means no PowerShell scripts can be run, including user profile scripts `Microsoft.PowerShell_profile.ps1`.
- You can use the following commands to view and modify the policy:
  - View current policy: `Get-ExecutionPolicy -List`
  - Change execution policy to allow script execution: `Set-ExecutionPolicy RemoteSigned -Scope CurrentUser`
- For more information, please refer to the following Microsoft official technical documentation: [PowerShell Execution Policies](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/powershell/module/microsoft.powershell.core/about/about_execution_policies?view=powershell-7.4) and [Set-ExecutionPolicy documentation](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/powershell/module/microsoft.powershell.security/set-executionpolicy?view=powershell-7.4).
:::

### Common Installation Issues

#### No Installation Permissions

If you are a Windows PowerShell user, you might encounter issues with restricted installation permissions for Git for Windows during the installation process. Here's how to resolve it:
1.  Install Git Bash: Download the appropriate architecture's installer (e.g., Git-${version}-64-bit.tar.bz2) from the [Git Bash releases page](https://github.com/git-for-windows/git/releases/) and extract the package.
2.  Once extracted, directly run the `bash.exe` file located in the `bin` directory.
3.  In the terminal command window that opens automatically, run the x-cmd command: `eval "$(curl https://get.x-cmd.com)"` and wait for the installation to complete.

## Using x-cmd

### On Posix Shell (Bash, Zsh)

Once installed successfully, you are welcome to read our [Getting Started Guide](/start/get-started.md) ~ This guide will help you quickly master the core features of `x-cmd`, including autocompletion, theme customization, module management, and package management, to help you get started quickly.

### On Non-Posix Shell (Fish, Elvish, Nushell, Xonsh)

Once installed successfully, users need to run the corresponding command based on the Non-Posix Shell environment to automatically load `x-cmd` when opening the Non-Posix Shell.

For example, in the Fish environment, run the following command in the command line:

```bash
x fish --setup
```

This script will add a line to the Fish loading files to load `x-cmd`.

For more Non-Posix Shell, please refer to the relevant topic documents:
- [fish](start/fish.md)
- [elvish](/start/elvish.md)
- [nushell](/start/nushell.md)
- [xonsh](/start/xonsh.md)
- [tcsh](/start/tcsh.md)

## Aside

## Enhancing User Experience with Official and Third-Party Package Management Commands

In addition to the `pkg` package management tool provided by `x-cmd` and a series of integrated cross-platform software management tools [pixi](/mod/pixi.md), [asdf](/mod/asdf.md), `x-cmd` has also specifically implemented the following modules to improve the user experience of relevant tools.

- [x scoop](/mod/scoop.md): An open-source tool manager supported by the scoop community; users can input `x scoop` to download and enable it as needed. Additionally, `x-cmd` provides a quick software search function and proxy/mirror configuration. Please refer to the [scoop module documentation](/mod/scoop.md) for details.
- [x choco](/mod/choco.md): A long-established Windows software tool manager.
- [x winget](/mod/winget.md): A software tool manager provided by Microsoft.

## Enhancing WSL2 Experience

### Better interaction with Windows in WSL environment

The arrival of WSL has simplified our work. This is equivalent to Linux, but in addition, we have done some work to allow users to better interact with the Windows system while using WSL:

1. If WSL is detected, desktop application behavior will use Windows GUI applications: `x open <file|url>`, `x browse <file|url>` will open the default Windows browser.
2. The [pwsh module](/mod/pwsh.md) uses PowerShell to achieve some host information retrieval and management.

### Introduced `wslx` and `wslr` for direct invocation of commands in the WSL environment

Starting from version 0.5.10, we provide `wslx` and `wslr`, along with the [wsl module](/mod/wsl.md) to improve the usage of WSL:

```bash
# Run x ls in the WSL environment
wslx ls

# Run jq in the WSL environment. Unlike `wsl jq`, wslr will load the binpath under the default WSL user space, allowing the invocation of software installed in the default user directory, such as pixi, asdf, pip, npm, etc.
wslr jq
```

## Our Efforts on Windows

Although Windows is not a Posix-compliant system, with the support of MSYS and WSL, `x-cmd` can still play a significant role.

1. Although Git-Bash has some efficiency issues, `x-cmd` has made some adaptations, especially in themes and other modules, to maximize user experience.
2. Using Windows' WSL2 provides an almost perfect Linux experience, just like on a native Linux system, and `x-cmd` operates efficiently on it.
3. Although our product is primarily designed for Linux and Unix systems, we strive to provide several modules that improve efficiency for Windows users. For instance, interoperability modules with PowerShell [pwsh](/mod/pwsh.md), and providing [scoop](/mod/scoop.md), [winget](/mod/winget.md), and [choco](/mod/choco.md) modules.

It is worth noting that the current `x-cmd` cannot run directly on **Busybox-For-Windows**.

- `busybox for windows` lacks emulation for some system files.
- If we make it compatible, it would lead to overly complex internal designs, thereby compromising engineering quality.
- Considering usersâ€™ actual usage scenarios, and as WSL2 has gradually proliferated, we are not pursuing development in this technical direction for the time being.
