# Development Preview x7

This version is intended for expert users:

- So they can quickly experience the features and capabilities of the latest version of x-cmd.
- Bug fixes and enhancements for experimental modules will also be pushed to this release first.
- Hourly updates and feedback improvements.

## Introduction to x7

x7 has existed within the development team for two years, designed as an internal testing version for testing new features and modules before official release.

Currently, our release cycle is weekly, and will be changed to bi-weekly or even monthly in the future. We considered providing nightly builds, but the increased number of releases could introduce unnecessary complexity.

In the past month, we have had a very pleasant collaboration with our users and are confident that expert users can handle the complexities of rolling releases (potential bugs and inconsistencies); therefore, we decided to make our internal testing release public. On the one hand, it allows expert users to quickly experience the latest features and capabilities; on the other hand, we can get feedback faster and push relevant adjustments to x7 based on the feedback. Users can confirm or provide further feedback based on this, thus achieving more efficient iteration.

## Risks

x7 cannot be used in a production environment, not only because it may contain bugs and unstable features, but also because x7 does not guarantee that the original open shell session will continue to load the initialized x-cmd version after the update, as detailed below:

1. The already open shell initializes the x7 release of x-cmd, commit is x11111
2. Later, due to the x7 update, the commit of the github repo code is x22222
3. In the original open shell session, the module code of x222222 will be loaded directly on demand, resulting in unknown behavior.

This problem is avoided in the official release, where we ensure that each shell session only uses one commit version; however, this feature is not implemented in x7.

Why this incorrect approach is used:

1. To reduce management complexity, we don't want to have a large number of intermediate versions in the v directory, which would require the introduction of gc.
2. Generally speaking, we restart the shell frequently.
3. The x-cmd core is becoming more and more stable, and this problem will not cause too much trouble for expert users.
4. In addition to x7, we have several internal releases that use this simplified mode; we have been using it for three years without any significant problems.

Although x7 is open to all users, we only recommend that a select group of invited users use this version. We continue to keep the official release updated frequently to ensure that all users have access to the latest bug fixes and feature enhancements.

## Using x7

```bash
x upgrade x7
```

Or using

```bash
eval "$(curl https://get.x-cmd.com/x7)"
```


Note that currently in x7 release mode, `x upgrade` still updates the x7 release.

If you want to switch to the official release, just use the official installation method:

```bash
x upgrade latest
```

Or using

```bash
eval "$(curl https://get.x-cmd.com)"
```

## x7 hosted on [codeberg.org](https://codeberg.org/x-cmd/x7)

The current x7 version is not hosted on github, but is publicly hosted on codeberg.org. This is mainly due to the following considerations:

1. Codeberg.org is more accessible in China than GitHub.com.
2. We'd considered hosting on both Github and Codeberg, but that would've introduced unnecessary complexity, synchronization headaches, and a heavier maintenance load.complexity and synchronization delays.
3. We are trying and preparing to host more code on codeberg ~

We are happy to see the success of codeberg and hope that users will have more experience with codeberg through this.

## Acknowledgements

Thanks again to our users for their feedback, we will continue to work hard ~

<h1 class="visually-hidden">Xonsh</h1>

## Overview

xonsh is a Python-powered shell that supports users in mixing Python and shell commands in the command line. We are attempting to introduce the x-cmd toolset into xonsh to enhance its functionality and user experience.

## Install x-cmd

1. **Use curl:**
    ```sh
    curl https://get.x-cmd.com | sh -i
    xonsh
    ```

2. **Use wget:**

    ```sh
    wget -O- https://get.x-cmd.com | sh -i
    xonsh
    ```

3. **Other:**

    ```sh
    # x-cmd is installed, but no related commands for x-cmd were found in xonsh.
    sh -c '. "$HOME/.x-cmd.root/X"; x upgrade latest; x onsh --setup'
    xonsh
    ```

:::info Note, When executing the above command, you might see the following error message:

```sh
sh: Cannot set tty process group (No such process)
```

This error occurs because `sh -i` is used and commands are piped, preventing `sh -i` from acquiring a controlling terminal (tty) for interaction. This is normal shell behavior and will not affect the installation or normal operation of x-cmd. You can safely ignore this error.
:::

## Changes to .xonshrc by `x onsh --setup`

When the user runs 'x onsh --setup', we add a line of code to $HOME/.xonshrc to enable the [x-cmd xonshrc](https://github.com/x-cmd/x-cmd/blob/main/mod/onsh/lib/rc/xonshrc) module when starting xonsh.

**About the code to activate x-cmd in .xonshrc**

- [`test -e "$HOME/.x-cmd.root/local/data/xonsh/xonshrc" && source "$HOME/.x-cmd.root/local/data/xonsh/xonshrc" # boot up x-cmd.`](https://github.com/x-cmd/x-cmd/blob/main/mod/onsh/lib/__setup#L40)
- Note that this line ends with our identifying comment `boot up x-cmd.`
- The main purpose of this line is to introduce enhanced functions and add some PATH paths;
- Sometimes, due to human or code reasons, x-cmd may insert new code repeatedly. Our strategy is to avoid deleting code in '.xonshrc' to prevent the loss of user customization.
- We simplify the code of x-cmd in .xonshrc (only one line) as much as possible to make it easier for users to understand our basic working principles. This way, users can disable (comment or delete) or enable it for personalized customization as needed.

**Activating and configuring shell tools**

- If you **use x-cmd** to install some tools (such as starship, asdf) and need to **activate or configure** them in .xonshrc as required, it is recommended to add your configuration code after the x-cmd activation code.


## Support Information

1. **Supported Systems/Environments:** Linux, MacOS, WSL (Windows Subsystem for Linux), Cygwin, MSYS2 (such as Gitbash)
2. **Tools Provided by x-cmd:**
    - [Wrappers for Common Commands (e.g., cd, ip, ps, tar, apt, brew)](/mod/zuz.md): These wrapped commands are more intelligent and easier to use compared to the native commands.
    - [Lightweight Package Management Tool](/pkg/.md): We have implemented a lightweight package management tool using shell and awk. Through it, you can quickly obtain most common software tools, such as jq, 7za, bat, nvim, python, node, go, etc.
    - [CLI for Useful Websites (e.g., github.com, cht.sh)](/mod/cht.md): We have wrapped their APIs using shell and awk for daily use and to obtain corresponding services in scripts.
    - [AI Tools](/mod/openai.md): We provide CLIs for ChatGPT, Gemini, Jina.ai, etc., and have wrapped corresponding shortcut commands for different application scenarios, such as `@gemini` for chatting with Gemini AI and `@zh` for using AI to translate specified content or command results.

**Note**: The above support is still in beta.

## Current Issues

1. **@ Command Invocation Issue:** In xonsh, `@<name>` is interpreted as an annotation, so if no parameters are provided (e.g., `@gemini`), xonsh waits for the user to pass the function to be decorated. Users can input `;` to avoid this issue, such as `@gemini ;`.
2. **Pipe Issue:** We tried to wrap x commands as functions to obtain xonsh environment variables, but we found that this approach presents some difficult-to-handle issues in pipe processing and judgment. Therefore, the current x commands will disable environment variables and use file passing instead to ensure that pipes can be used normally.

# x apk - Enhanced Package Management Tool for Alpine Linux

Alpine Linux is favored for its lightweight and security features, and `apk`, its official package manager, is equally simple and efficient. However, sometimes we desire a more user-friendly interactive way, easier mirror switching, and more proactive security protection. `x apk` was created for this purpose, providing a brand new user experience built on the original `apk`.

<Terminal demo="/cookbook/mod/apk.1.en.json" size="large" />

## Interactive Exploration: Browse Software Packages Like a Store

Forget about the days of needing to remember package names precisely! Just run `x apk`, and you'll enter an interactive software package exploration interface (defaults to the powerful `fzf` tool). Here, you can:

*  **Fuzzy Search:** Real-time input of keywords to dynamically filter the package list.
*  **Real-time Preview:** Select a package, and the details will appear in the right-side window instantly.
*  **Convenient Operations:** After selecting a desired package, you can directly choose to install it or view more detailed information.

> If you haven't installed `fzf`, the `x-cmd` will automatically download and launch `fzf` after you execute the `x apk` command, no manual installation is required.

```sh
x apk
```

![x apk](/data-image/cookbook/mod/apk.1_1.webp)

This interactive method greatly lowers the barrier for finding and installing packages, especially useful in scenarios where you are unsure of the exact package name.

## One-Click Mirror Switching: Say Goodbye to Slow Downloads

In a domestic environment, connecting directly to the official Alpine repository can sometimes result in unsatisfactory speeds. `x apk` thoughtfully integrates mirror management features, allowing you to easily switch to faster domestic mirrors.

Want to see which recommended mirror sources are available?

```sh
x apk mirror ls
```

Executing this command will present a list similar to the one below, encompassing the official source as well as common domestic mirror sources such as Alibaba Cloud, Huawei Cloud, Tsinghua University, etc.

```
Code  Url  Name
official  dl-cdn.alpinelinux.org  Official Source
ali  mirrors.aliyun.com  Alibaba Cloud Mirror
huawei  mirrors.huaweicloud.com  Huawei Mirror
tuna  mirrors.tuna.tsinghua.edu.cn  Tsinghua University Mirror
ustc  mirrors.ustc.edu.cn  University of Science and Technology of China Mirror
sjtu  mirrors.sjtug.sjtu.edu.cn  Shanghai Jiao Tong University Mirror
```

Once you find a mirror source you prefer (like Tsinghua University's `tuna`), you only need a single command to switch:

```sh
x apk mirror set tuna
```

`x apk` will automatically back up the original configuration, modify the `/etc/apk/repositories` file, and execute `apk update` to refresh the index. From now on, enjoy lightning-fast download speeds! If you wish to revert to the official source, you can use `x apk mirror unset`.

## Security Scanning: Proactive Defense, Preparing for Risks

Software supply chain security is increasingly important. Are the packages installed on your system free from known security vulnerabilities? `x apk` integrates `osv-scanner`, which allows you to conveniently scan for vulnerabilities in installed packages and their dependencies.

```sh
x apk osv
```

This command will analyze the `/lib/apk/db/installed` file and submit the list of installed packages to the OSV-Scanner for detection. Upon completion, it will report any potential vulnerabilities found, helping you assess risks and take appropriate measures (like upgrading packages). This is crucial for maintaining system security.

---

`x apk` significantly enhances the user experience of Alpine Linuxâ€™s native `apk` through its interactive interface, convenient mirror management, and integrated security scanning features. Whether you're a newcomer or an experienced user of Alpine, `x apk` can help you manage your packages more efficiently and securely. Give it a try!

# x apt - Say Goodbye to Complications, Embrace a Smarter Debian/Ubuntu Package Management

If you often work on Debian, Ubuntu, or their derivatives (like Kali, Raspberry Pi OS), you're certainly familiar with the `apt` command. But have you ever felt that the native `apt` is somewhat inconvenient for searching software packages, switching domestic mirrors, or checking security vulnerabilities? `x apt` was created to address these pain points! It includes all the functionalities of `apt` while providing many enhanced features to make your package management workflow more efficient and enjoyable.

<Terminal demo="/cookbook/mod/apt.1.en.json" size="large" />

## Highlights Overview

*  **Interactive Exploration:** Say goodbye to the information overflow of `apt search`. Use the `fzf` or `pick` driven interactive interface to easily search for, preview, and select software packages.
*  **One-click Mirror Switching:** Built-in common domestic mirrors (Alibaba, Tsinghua, USTC, etc.), allowing you to easily switch with `x apt mirror`, eliminating the hassle of manually modifying `sources.list`.
*  **Security Scanning:** Integrated with `osv-scanner`, `x apt osv` helps you scan installed packages for known vulnerabilities with a single command, ensuring system security.
*  **Smart Proxy Management:** `x apt proxy` makes it easier for you to configure and manage network proxies for `apt` operations.
*  **Seamless sudo:** For operations requiring root privileges (such as installation, updates, or changing sources), `x apt` intelligently uses `sudo` without the need for manual input.

## Interactive Exploration: Search for Software Like You're Browsing an App Store

Tired of scrolling through screens of results with `apt search`? Give `x apt` (or `x apt fz`) a try!

```sh
x apt
```

This will launch an interactive interface based on `fzf` (if your environment supports it). You can:

1. **Real-time Search:** Type in keywords, and the list will dynamically filter software packages.
2. **Detailed Preview:** Highlight a software package, and the right window will display `apt show` information, including description, version, dependencies, and syntax highlighting for a more comfortable reading experience.
3. **Quick Actions:** After selecting a software package, a menu will pop up for you to choose the next action: install, reinstall, view details, or even browse the package's official repository page!

<!-- **(x apt interactive interface -- you can imagine a terminal window, with a scrollable list of software packages on the left, detailed information of the selected package on the right, and operation hints at the bottom )** -->
![x apt](/data-image/cookbook/mod/apt.1_1.webp)

This interactive way greatly enhances the efficiency of searching and deciding to install software.

## Say Goodbye to Manual Mirror Switching: Easily Switch Domestic Mirrors

In the domestic network environment, the official `apt` sources may not be ideal in speed. `x apt mirror` makes switching mirror sources unprecedentedly simple.

First, check which mirror sources are currently supported:

```sh
x apt mirror ls
```

You'll see a list similar to this, containing commonly used domestic mirror sites and their abbreviations:

```
Code  Url  Name
ali  mirrors.aliyun.com  Alibaba Cloud Mirror
tuna  mirrors.tuna.tsinghua.edu.cn  Tsinghua University Mirror
bfsu  mirrors.bfsu.edu.cn  Beijing Foreign Studies University Mirror
ustc  mirrors.ustc.edu.cn  University of Science and Technology of China Mirror
tencent  mirrors.tencent.com  Tencent Cloud Mirror
```

Want to switch to the Tsinghua University mirror? Just execute:

```sh
x apt mirror set tuna
```

`x apt` will automatically back up your current source configuration, then intelligently modify `/etc/apt/sources.list` or related files based on your system (Ubuntu/Debian/Kali/Raspberry Pi) and architecture, replacing the official sources with the Tsinghua source (safety update sources are usually retained as official or specific mirrors). Finally, it will automatically run `apt update` to refresh the software package list. The whole process requires no manual file editing, one step does it all! If you want to revert to the previous configuration, you can use `x apt mirror unset`.

## System Security Scanning: Prevent Problems Before They Occur

Are there any installed packages on your system that contain known vulnerabilities? `x apt osv` can help you check.

```sh
x apt osv
```

This command will invoke the powerful `osv-scanner` tool, scanning all software packages installed on your system via `dpkg` (i.e., packages managed by `apt`) and comparing them with the OSV (Open Source Vulnerability) database, listing any existing security vulnerabilities. This is crucial for maintaining the security of servers or development environments.

---

Through these well-designed enhanced features, `x apt` significantly improves the user experience of native `apt`. It not only retains all the capabilities of `apt` (you can still use commands like `x apt update`, `x apt upgrade`, `x apt remove <package>`, etc. as before), but also makes your package management work in Debian/Ubuntu systems smoother with its interactive interface, convenient mirror and proxy management, and security scanning features.

Try `x apt` now and experience smarter, more efficient command-line package management!

# x arp - Get ARP Cache Table Information

The `x arp` module displays the local system's ARP cache table information. It supports multiple output formats, including an interactive TUI application, CSV, and TSV, allowing users to view and analyze ARP table data in different ways.

## Quick Start

The simplest way to use it is to run the `x arp` command directly:

```bash
x arp
```

This command is equivalent to `x arp --auto`. The system automatically selects the output mode based on whether standard output is connected to a terminal (tty): if connected to a terminal, it launches the interactive TUI application (`--app`); otherwise, it outputs in TSV format (`--tsv`).

## Output Format Options

`x arp` provides several output format options to meet different needs:

* **`--app` (Interactive TUI Application):** Displays the ARP table in an interactive TUI application, making it easy for users to browse and filter information. This is the default behavior if standard output is connected to a terminal.

* **`--tsv` or `-t` (Tab-Separated Values):** Outputs the ARP table data in TSV format, making it easy to import into spreadsheets or other data processing tools. The header information is: `ip, mac, if, suspicious, scope, type, vendor`.

* **`--csv` or `-c` (Comma-Separated Values):** Outputs the ARP table data in CSV format, similar to TSV format, but uses a comma as the delimiter. The header information is the same as TSV.

* **`--raw` or `-r` (Raw Data):** Outputs the ARP table data in its raw format.

## Advanced Options

Besides the basic output format options, `x arp` also provides some advanced options:

* **`--all` or `-a` (Show All Entries):** Shows all ARP entries, including those with a MAC address of `incomplete`. By default, only complete entries might be displayed.

* **`--no-vendor` or `-n` (Do Not Show Vendor Information):** Does not display the vendor or organization information corresponding to the MAC address. This can reduce the amount of output information and improve efficiency.

## Examples

Here are some examples of `x arp` commands:

* **View the ARP table using the interactive TUI application:**

```bash
x arp --app
```

* **Output the ARP table in TSV format:**

```bash
x arp --tsv
```

* **Output the ARP table in CSV format and show all entries:**

```bash
x arp --csv --all
```

* **Output the ARP table in raw format without vendor information:**

```bash
x arp --raw --no-vendor
```

## More Information

Visit [https://x-cmd.com/mod/arp](https://x-cmd.com/mod/arp) for more information.

# x ascii - ASCII Art and Tools

The `x ascii` module provides a suite of commands for handling ASCII-related tasks, including querying the ASCII table, generating ASCII art text, converting images to ASCII art, drawing ASCII line graphs, rendering Mermaid diagrams, and simulating ASCII art fireworks.

## Querying the ASCII Table

The `table` subcommand queries the ASCII table.  It supports various output formats and allows filtering for specific character ranges.

```bash
# Output the ASCII table in CSV format
x ascii table --csv

# List ASCII codes for all lowercase letters
x ascii table lower

# Return the ASCII code for Ctrl-A
x ascii table ^A

# Return the ASCII code for 0x11
x ascii table 0x11
```

## Generating ASCII Art Text

The `cfonts` (or `cfont`) subcommand converts text into ASCII art. You can customize the font, color, background color, and text alignment.

```bash
# Convert the string "x-cmd" to ASCII art
x ascii cfont x-cmd

# Convert "x-cmd" to ASCII art with a red-to-blue gradient
x ascii cfont x-cmd -g red,blue

# Convert "x-cmd" to ASCII art with a red background and centered alignment
x ascii cfont x-cmd -a center -b red
```

## Image to ASCII Art Conversion

The `imagec` subcommand uses `ascii-image-converter` to convert images into ASCII art. You need to provide the image file path as an argument.

```bash
# Convert an image to ASCII art (replace <image_path> with your image path)
x ascii imagec <image_path>
```

## Drawing ASCII Line Graphs

The `graph` subcommand draws ASCII line graphs based on input data.  Input data is typically a column of numerical values, for example, generated by the `seq` command.

```bash
# Draw a simple ASCII line graph
seq 1 10 | x ascii graph
```

## Rendering Mermaid Diagrams

The `mermaid` subcommand renders Mermaid diagrams in the terminal. You need to provide the Mermaid code as input.

## Simulating ASCII Art Fireworks

The `firework` subcommand downloads and runs `firework-rs` to simulate ASCII art fireworks. You can choose different demo effects.

```bash
# Display ASCII art fireworks using demo 1
x ascii firework -d 1
```

(Press `esc` to exit the firework program)

## Summary

The `x ascii` module provides a rich set of tools for easily creating and manipulating various ASCII art works. From simple ASCII code queries to complex image conversion and firework simulations, the module offers a convenient command-line interface.  Visit [https://x-cmd.com/mod/ascii](https://x-cmd.com/mod/ascii) for more information.

# x asdf - A Tool for Effortlessly Managing Multiple Version Environments

As a CLI enthusiast, have you ever struggled with managing different programming languages and tool versions required by various projects? Ruby, Node.js, Python, Java... Each project might have its specific version requirements, and manually switching and configuring them is not only cumbersome but also prone to errors. Now, with `x asdf`, all of this will become simple!

`asdf` itself is a powerful and extensible version manager, and the `x-cmd` module for `asdf` has been meticulously refined and enhanced to provide you with a smoother and more intuitive command-line experience. Say goodbye to lengthy commands and complex configurations, let `x asdf` become your reliable assistant in managing your development environment!

<Terminal demo="/mod/asdf.en.json" size="large" />

## Interactive Exploration: Your Dedicated Software Steward

When you first run `x asdf`, it acts like a smart software steward. If `asdf` is not installed on your system, `x-cmd` will kindly ask and help you automatically download and install it.

```sh
x asdf
```

Once everything is set up, `x asdf` will present you with a clean interactive interface. Here, you can easily browse the list of all software supported by `asdf` and quickly locate the tools you need using fuzzy search. Whether you want to install the latest Node.js or a specific version of Python, just move up and down to select, press Enter to confirm, and `x asdf` will handle the installation and configuration for you.

<!-- **(A dynamic image of the `x asdf` interactive interface showing various optional software packages)** -->
![x asdf](/data-image/cookbook/mod/asdf.1_1.webp)

This interactive interface allows you to forget about memorizing complex plugin names and version numbers, making it as easy to manage your development tools as browsing an app store.

## One-Click Ready: Easy Installation and Switching

Tired of the step-by-step operations like `plugin add`, `install`, and `global`? The `use` command of `x asdf` combines these steps into one! Want to install and globally use the latest version of `nodejs` on your system? Just one command:

```sh
x asdf use nodejs
```

`x asdf` will automatically help you:

1.  Add the `asdf` plugin for `nodejs`.
2.  Install the latest stable version of `nodejs`.
3.  Set the newly installed version as the global default version.

The entire process flows smoothly, allowing you to focus on the code itself rather than the minor details of environment configuration. Of course, you can also specify a version number, for example, `x asdf use nodejs 18.17.0`.

## Cleaning Up the Environment: Uninstalling Made Simple

When a tool or version is no longer needed, cleaning up can be just as easy. `x asdf` provides the `unuse` command, allowing you to uninstall the specified software and its `asdf` plugin with one click. For instance, if you want to uninstall the previously installed `nodejs`:

```sh
x asdf unuse nodejs
```

`x asdf` will neatly remove all installed versions of `nodejs` and delete the related `asdf` plugin information. Keeping your development environment clean and orderly has never been so effortless.

## Precise Control: Activate and Deactivate

`asdf` manages different versions of executable files through the `shims` directory and environment variables. When you first use `x asdf`, it will automatically activate `asdf`, meaning that the software versions installed by `asdf` will be prioritized by the system.

However, sometimes you may want to temporarily disable `asdf` management and use the system's built-in or other tool versions. In this case, the `--deactivate` parameter comes in handy:

```sh
x asdf --deactivate
```

Executing this command will remove the `asdf` `shims` path from your `PATH` environment variable, making the software installed by `asdf` unavailable in the current terminal session (unless you specify the full path). This gives you more flexible environment control capabilities. When you need to re-enable `asdf`, just run `x asdf --activate`.

---

`x asdf` is more than just a simple wrapper for `asdf`. It significantly simplifies the complexity of managing multiple version environments through an intelligent interactive interface and the convenient `use` / `unuse` commands. Whether you are an experienced developer or a command-line novice, `x asdf` can help you manage your development tools more efficiently and elegantly. So open your terminal, type `x asdf`, and start your efficient development journey now!

# x brew (1) - Interactive UI and Mirror Management

## Interactive Search for Software Tools

Executing the `x brew` command will launch an interactive `fzf` application via **x-cmd**.  Users can search for various software tools and their installation information.

```sh
x brew
```

![x brew](/data-image/cookbook/mod/brew.1_1.webp)

In the interactive application, the left column lists the package names of software tools, while the right window displays installation information such as version and dependencies.


## Changing Homebrew's Mirror Source

`x brew` uses the `$HOMEBREW_PREFIX/etc/homebrew/brew.env` file to configure the download source for `Homebrew`.

Use the following command to set the Homebrew download source to Tsinghua University's mirror:

```sh
x brew mirror set tuna
```

Additionally, `x brew` supports setting mirrors from Alibaba Cloud, University of Science and Technology of China, and others. You can run the `x brew mirror ls` command to view available mirrors.

# x brew (2) - Homebrew Download Statistics and Privacy Settings

## Obtaining Homebrew's Official Software Download Statistics

`x brew` supports viewing download and installation data for core Homebrew packages and cask software.

```sh
x brew analytics data
```

![x brew analytics data](/data-image/cookbook/mod/brew.2_1.webp)

Additionally, it supports specifying the output format and the number of days to query. For example, to output the top 10 Homebrew cask software packages downloaded in the last 30 days in CSV format:

```sh
x brew analytics data cask --csv --30 | head -n 10
```

## Disabling Homebrew's Analytics Tracking

Homebrew defaults to collecting usage data, such as software installation, uninstallation, and update actions, to optimize the software installation and user experience.

If you have concerns about this, you can run the following command to disable it:

```sh
x brew analytics off
```

# x btop - Real-time System Resource Monitoring

## Introduction

The `x btop` module provides a convenient way to monitor your system resources, including the processor, memory, disk, network, and processes. It prioritizes using the locally installed `btop` command. If `btop` is not installed on your system, `x btop` will automatically download and run it using `pixi` (Linux/macOS) or `scoop` (Windows), requiring no manual installation and leaving your system environment untouched.


## Quick Start

Simply run the following command to start `btop`:

```bash
x btop
```

This will launch `btop` and display real-time system resource usage. You can interact with `btop` using your mouse or keyboard to view more detailed information.


### Running btop Commands Directly

You can use the `--` argument to pass arguments directly to the `btop` command:

```bash
x btop -- -h  # Equivalent to running btop -h, showing help information
```

This allows you to utilize all of `btop`'s features and options.


### Future Enhancements

We plan to add more features in the future, such as:

* **Custom Configuration:** Allow users to customize `btop`'s display and parameters.
* **Data Export:** Export `btop`'s monitoring data to a file.


## Integration with Other Tools

`x btop` seamlessly integrates with other `x-cmd` modules. For example, you can combine `x btop`'s output with other tools to create more powerful monitoring and analysis tools.


## Summary

`x btop` provides a simple, easy-to-use, and powerful way to monitor your system resources.  Regardless of whether `btop` is already installed on your system, you can easily use it to obtain real-time system information. We encourage you to try `x btop` and explore its features.

url: /mod/buse/cookbook-1.md

# Control the Browser with Natural Language

`x buse` is an enhanced module designed for the [browser-use](https://github.com/browser-use/browser-use) project. It combines AI with the command line, allowing you to **drive the browser to complete tasks with just one natural language command**, such as opening web pages, searching for content, taking screenshots, filling out forms, and even navigating click buttons.

## I. Preparation

Before using `x buse`, you need to ensure a few basic conditions:

* Install `browser-use` and its related dependencies (such as Python, playwright Chrome browser, etc.). If `browser-use` is not present in your local environment, `x buse` will automatically install it for you;
* Obtain at least one usable AI model API Key (like OpenAI, Gemini, Grok, DeepSeek).

## II. Basic Usage

### Start the Interactive Console

```bash
x buse
```

This command enters an interactive TUI interface where you can directly input natural language commands to control the browser, such as "open the official website of OpenAI and take a screenshot." The command will be parsed by the AI model and the actions like clicking, taking a screenshot, etc., will be carried out through CDP to drive Chrome.

### Use `--init` to Initialize Configuration

For first-time use, it is recommended to execute:

```bash
x buse --init
```

This command will guide you to configure the default model, whether to use headless mode, and whether to enable MCP mode. The configuration will be saved in the `x-cmd` configuration system for future use.

### Specify the AI Model for Tasks

```bash
x buse --model gpt-4o
```

If a model is not explicitly specified, the system will read the model configuration from the saved settings, or default to using `gemini-2.0-flash`.

You can also pass other model names via `--model` (provided you have configured the corresponding API key):

* `gpt-4o` (OpenAI)
* `gemini-pro` / `gemini-2.0-flash` (Google)
* `deepseek-coder` (DeepSeek)

## III. Run a Single Task Directly (Prompt Mode)

You can bypass the interactive interface and write the task command directly in the command line:

```bash
x buse -p "Search 'Usage of Python decorators' and take a screenshot of the first page of search results"
```

This will automatically:

1. Launch the browser;
2. Execute the search;
3. Find and take a screenshot of the search results;
4. Save the file to the local directory.

## IV. Advanced Features

### Run the Browser in Headless Mode

Use the browser in headless mode:

```bash
x buse --headless
```

This is suitable for automation tasks, CI environments, or running scripts on servers.

### Use MCP Mode for System Integration

MCP (Machine Command Protocol) mode exposes a JSON-RPC interface via standard input/output (stdin/stdout).

This allows `x buse` to be embedded in larger systems, such as:

* Integrating with backend services;
* Connecting to web control panels;
* Embedding into VS Code plugins or GUI frontends.

To start MCP mode:

```bash
x buse --mcp
```

You can send standard JSON-RPC requests from stdin, such as:

```json
{
  "method": "run",
  "params": {
  "prompt": "Open GitHub and take a screenshot"
  }
}
```

### Customize Browser Parameters

You can customize browser window size, user data directories, and other options:

```bash
x buse --window-width 1280 --window-height 720
x buse --user-data-dir ~/.config/buse/chrome --profile-directory Default
```

Or connect to an existing Chrome instance (with debug port enabled):

```bash
x buse --cdp-url http://localhost:9222
```

## V. Combine Shell Scripts for Automation

With the `x buse -p` format, you can easily embed it into bash scripts:

```bash
#!/bin/bash

keyword="$1"

x buse -p "Search $keyword and take a screenshot of the first result"
```

Save as `screenshot.sh` and run:

```bash
chmod +x screenshot.sh
./screenshot.sh "Linux Command Quick Reference"
```

## VI. Configuration Management and Model API Keys

You can set API keys for each model separately:

```bash
x openai --cur set apikey=sk-xxx
x gemini --cur set apikey=xxx
x grok --cur set apikey=xxx
x deepseek --cur set apikey=xxx
```

View current settings:

```bash
x buse --cur
```

Modify the default model:

```bash
x buse --cfg set model=gpt-4o
```

## VII. Common Issues and Troubleshooting

### 1. Prompting for Missing API Key?

Ensure you have set the `OPENAI_API_KEY` environment variable, or configured the key via `x xxx --cfg set apikey`.

### 2. Unable to Take Screenshots or Click?

This may be due to incomplete page loading or CDP call failure. Try running in non-headless mode to observe:

```bash
x buse --headless
```

# x bwh --cfg

Manage the configuration file.


::: warning
After using the x bwh --cfg load command to load the relevant file contents, you cannot use the x bwh --cfg cat command to view the file contents in the current terminal environment.
:::


## Examples

Set the value of the configuration item veid in the configuration file to 1234567, and the value of apikey to private_XXXXXXXX

```sh
x bwh --cfg set veid=1234567 apikey=private_XXXXXXXX
```

Get the value of veid in the profile file named X, and then output it to stdout

```sh
x bwh --cfg get --profile X veid
```

Get the value of the corresponding field in the config yml file, then assign it to the corresponding variable and output it to stdout

```sh
x bwh --cfg var veid=veid && echo $veid
```

| [x bwh --cfg current](#x-bwh-cfg-current) | View current profile information |

# x bwh current

View or modify the current VPS configuration.

## Examples

Sets the VEID for the current environment.  This changes which VPS the subsequent commands will affect.

```sh
x bwh current set veid=<new_veid>
```

Prints the current VPS configuration (config path, profile name, VEID, API key, and proxy settings) to the console.

```sh
x bwh current print
```

Gets the path to the current VPS configuration file and assigns it to the variable `x_`.

```sh
`x bwh current get_ config` or `x bwh current config_`
echo "$x_"

```

Gets the VEID of the currently selected VPS.

```sh
x bwh current getor veid
```

Sets the API key for the current VPS.

```sh
x bwh current import apikey:=<API KEY>
```

Clears the current VPS configuration variables.

```sh
x bwh current clear
```

x-title: x cal (1) - Gregorian and Julian Calendars
x-desc: x cal (1) - The 'cal' Command and Whether 1700 Was a Common Year
x-sidebar: Sneak Peek
---

# Gregorian and Julian Calendars: The Leap Year Mystery of 1700

## Starting with a Question

When you attempt to query the calendar for the year 1700 in the command line, you might encounter an interesting phenomenon:

```bash
cal 1700
gcal 1700
```

The `cal` command displays February 1700 as having 29 days (a leap year), while `gcal` shows February with only 28 days (a common year). This discrepancy is not a software error; rather, it reflects the fundamental differences in leap year rules between two distinct calendar systemsâ€”the **Julian Calendar** and the **Gregorian Calendar**â€”as well as their historical adoption processes.

### Leap Year Rules of the Julian and Gregorian Calendars

As we know, leap years are instituted to keep the calendar year synchronized with the Earth's orbital period.

*   **Julian Calendar**: Introduced by Julius Caesar of the Roman Republic in 45 BCE. Its leap year rule is relatively simple: a leap year is set every four years, meaning any year divisible by 4 is a leap year.
*   **Gregorian Calendar**: Promulgated by Pope Gregory XIII in 1582. It refined the Julian Calendar to improve accuracy. Its leap year rules are:
    1.  A year divisible by 4 is a leap year.
    2.  However, a year divisible by 100 is not a leap year.
    3.  Unless the year is also divisible by 400, in which case it remains a leap year.

According to the Gregorian calendar rules, 1700 is divisible by 100 but not by 400, making it a common year. The Julian calendar, however, would consider it a leap year.

## The Long Road to Gregorian Calendar Adoption

The Gregorian calendar was promulgated to correct the accumulated error of the Julian calendar (which was approximately 11 minutes longer than the actual solar year, accumulating about 10 days of error by 1582), ensuring that Easter would accurately fall after the vernal equinox. However, its adoption was not immediate but rather a process fraught with political, religious, and cultural contention.

### Gradual Adoption Process

In October 1582, the Gregorian calendar officially came into effect, but the timing of its adoption varied significantly among nations:

1.  **Catholic Regions (1582)**: Catholic countries and their colonies, such as Italy, Spain, Portugal, the Polish-Lithuanian Commonwealth, and the Kingdom of France, rapidly adopted it.
    *   For instance, Italy, Poland, Spain, and Portugal designated the day after Thursday, October 4th (Julian calendar), as Friday, October 15th (Gregorian calendar), effectively skipping 10 days.
    *   France, meanwhile, designated the day after Sunday, December 9th (Julian calendar), as Monday, December 20th (Gregorian calendar).

2.  **Protestant Regions (1700 and later)**: Due to religious opposition, many Protestant nations delayed adoption for a century, with some converting in 1700 (the first year where the Gregorian calendar's leap year rule diverged from the Julian).
    *   **Great Britain and its territories**: Reform was not enacted until 1752, under the Calendar (New Style) Act 1750. In September 1752, Britain designated the day after Wednesday, September 2nd, as Thursday, September 14th, skipping 11 days (due to an additional day of accumulated error).

3.  **Orthodox Regions (Early 20th Century)**: Orthodox countries adopted the Gregorian calendar even later.
    *   **Russia**: Adopted the Gregorian calendar as its civil calendar only in 1918 (after the fall of the Tsarist regime).
    *   **Greece**: Became the last European country to adopt the Gregorian calendar (for civil use only) in 1923.

4.  **Other Regions**:
    *   **Turkey**: Became the last country to adopt the Gregorian calendar in 1926.
    *   **Alaska**: As a special case, it used the Julian calendar during its Russian ownership. After the United States purchased Alaska in 1867, the day after Friday, October 6th, 1867 (Julian calendar), was designated as Friday, October 18th (Gregorian calendar), resulting in the curious phenomenon of two consecutive Fridays.

### Social Adjustments Brought by the Reform

Calendar reform was not merely a change in dates; it profoundly impacted social life at the time:

1.  **Farmer Opposition**: Farmers at the time opposed the new calendar, fearing that landlords would "collect 10 extra days of rent" because they believed the new calendar shortened the farming cycle.
2.  **Tax Year Start Date**: In medieval Christian regions, March 25th (Annunciation, also known as Lady Day) in the Julian calendar was considered the start of quarter days and the agricultural season, as well as the beginning of tax and rent collection. The adoption of the Gregorian calendar (which added 10 or 11 days) shifted this date to the current April 5th. This is precisely the origin of the current UK personal tax year end date.

### Advantages of the Gregorian Calendar

Despite the convoluted adoption process, the advantages of the Gregorian calendar are evident:

*   **Greater Accuracy**: The more precise length of a year is 365.2422 days. The Julian calendar, at 365.25 days, had an annual error of approximately 11 minutes; the Gregorian calendar, at 365.2425 days, has an annual error of only about 26 seconds, significantly improving accuracy.
*   **400-Year Cycle**: The Gregorian calendar's leap year rules result in 97 leap years every 400 years (400 * 365 + 97 = 146097 days). This total number of days is divisible by 7 (146097 / 7 = 20871 weeks), meaning that every four centuries, the same date will fall on the same day of the week, which facilitates long-term planning.

## Beyond Leap Years: The Evolution of the Year Start Date

Beyond leap year rules, calendar reform also addressed another critical question: **On which day does the year begin?** In modern times, January 1st as the first day of the new year seems to be a self-evident consensus, but this was not the case in the Middle Ages.

### Ancient Roman Origins

1.  **God Janus**: In the ancient Roman calendar, January is named after Janus, the two-faced god in Roman mythology who presides over beginnings, endings, gates, passages, and transitions. Associating the start of the new year with this deity carried inherent symbolic meaning.
2.  **Consular Inauguration Day**: Crucially, January 1st was defined as the inauguration date for Roman consuls, which naturally established it as the beginning of Rome's civil and administrative year.

### Medieval Deviations

After the fall of the Roman Empire, with the spread of Christianity in Europe, the status of January 1st as the year's starting day gradually diminished, and was even replaced.

*   **Pagan Associations**: January 1st was associated with the Roman pagan deity Janus and pagan festivals (such as the revelries after Saturnalia), which made early Christian churches uncomfortable.
*   **Christian Festivals**: Many regions instead adopted significant Christian festivals as the new year's starting day, emphasizing Christian values:
    *   **December 25th (Christmas)**: Celebrating the birth of Jesus.
    *   **March 25th (Annunciation/Lady Day)**: Celebrating the angel's announcement to the Virgin Mary that she would conceive Jesus. This was very popular in places like England, Ireland, and Florence.
    *   **Easter**: Celebrating the resurrection of Jesus, but this was a movable feast, varying each year, leading to greater calendar confusion.

For example, in England, March 24th, 1752, was considered the last day of 1751, with the next day, March 25th, directly entering 1752. However, in France, since they had adopted the Gregorian calendar reform as early as 1582 and unified the year's start date to January 1st, the same day for them was March 24th, 1752. Such discrepancies caused significant inconvenience in international communication and trade.

### Re-establishment by Gregorian Reform

The Gregorian calendar reform not only corrected the leap year rules but also explicitly stipulated that **January 1st** was re-established as the new year's starting day for all countries and regions adopting the new calendar. This led to greater calendar uniformity, facilitating administrative management and international communication.

## Calendar Challenges in Modern Computing

The complex historical origins described above pose considerable challenges for modern software and databases when handling dates and times. Different software implementations adopt varying strategies when processing dates prior to the Gregorian calendar's adoption.

### Software and Database Differences

*   **`cal` command**: It actually defaults to the conversion date of the British Calendar Act (September 1752); prior to this, it calculates according to Julian calendar rules.
*   **`gcal` command**: It defaults to October 1582 as the conversion date; prior to this, it calculates according to Julian calendar rules.
*   **Mainstream Programming Languages and Databases (e.g., Python, Java, SQLite)**: These typically employ the **Proleptic Gregorian Calendar**. This means that even for dates prior to the Gregorian calendar's promulgation in 1582, they apply the Gregorian rules backward to calculate dates. The advantage of this approach is that data maintains consistency, avoiding date jumps caused by the missing 10 (or 11) days during the Julian-to-Gregorian calendar conversion.

**Example: October 4th and October 15th, 1582**

In regions that adopted the Gregorian calendar, the day after Thursday, October 4th, 1582 (Julian calendar), directly jumped to Friday, October 15th (Gregorian calendar). Let's examine how modern programming languages and databases handle this:

```python
import datetime
# Python's datetime module uses the Proleptic Gregorian Calendar
print(datetime.date(1582, 10, 4).strftime("%A"))  # Output: Monday
print(datetime.date(1582, 10, 15).strftime("%A")) # Output: Friday
# Note: If following the Julian calendar, October 4th would be a Thursday, but the next day implemented the Gregorian calendar, meaning October 15th was a Friday, skipping 10 days in between.
# Python's calculation results indicate that it applies Gregorian weekday calculation rules even for dates prior to October 4th.
```

```sql
-- SQLite also uses the Proleptic Gregorian Calendar
sqlite3 :memory: ".mode column" ".headers on" "SELECT '1582-10-04' AS Date, STRFTIME('%w', '1582-10-04') AS DayOfWeekNum UNION ALL SELECT '1582-10-15' AS Date, STRFTIME('%w', '1582-10-15') AS DayOfWeekNum;"
```

```txt
Date        DayOfWeekNum
----------  ------------
1582-10-04  1  -- Monday
1582-10-15  5  -- Friday
```

```js
// JavaScript's Date object also uses the Proleptic Gregorian Calendar
node -e 'console.log(new Date(1582, 9, 4).toLocaleString("en-US", { weekday: "long" }))'  // Output: Monday
node -e 'console.log(new Date(1582, 9, 15).toLocaleString("en-US", { weekday: "long" }))' // Output: Friday
```

These examples all demonstrate that mainstream computing systems generally adopt the "Proleptic Gregorian Calendar" strategy to maintain the continuity and consistency of date sequences.

## Solution for x-cmd's `cal` Module

Considering the aforementioned historical complexities and modern computing practices, the `cal` module has adopted the following design approach:

### Default Adoption of Gregorian and Proleptic Gregorian Systems

1.  **Consistency with Mainstream System Behavior**: This ensures that `cal`'s date calculation results align with most database systems and programming languages (such as Python, Java, JavaScript), facilitating data exchange and comprehension.
2.  **Data Coherence, Avoiding Abrupt Changes**: Employing the Proleptic Gregorian Calendar ensures the continuity of date sequences, preventing date jumps or omissions caused by calendar conversions.
3.  **Respecting History, Providing Explicit Choice**: While defaulting to the Proleptic Gregorian Calendar, `cal` will also offer options allowing users to explicitly select the Julian calendar system for calculations, thereby enabling a clearer display of calendars for different countries during specific historical periods.

### Provision of Julian Calendar System and Julian Day Calculation

To meet specific historical research or compatibility requirements, `cal` will provide independent Julian calendar calculation functionality, as well as Julian Day Number conversion, facilitating precise date conversion and comparison between different calendar systems.

### Common Era Dating

The `cal` module uniformly adopts the Common Era (CE / Anno Domini), which is the modern internationally accepted dating system.

---

## References

*   [History of the Gregorian Calendar Adoption - Wikipedia](https://zh.wikipedia.org/wiki/%E6%A0%BC%E9%87%8C%E5%8E%86%E9%87%87%E7%BA%B3%E5%8F%B2)
*   [Pope Gregory XIII - Wikipedia](https://zh.wikipedia.org/wiki/%E9%A1%8D%E6%88%91%E7%95%A5%E5%8D%81%E4%B8%89%E4%B8%96)

# x cb cl

shortcut for `x cb repo clone`

## Usage

```sh
x cb cl [OPTIONS] [FLAGS] <#1> <#2>
```

## Arguments

| Argument | Description |
| ------- | ------- |
| `#1` | &lt;ownerPath&gt;/&lt;RepoPath&gt; (default ownerPath: current user) |
| `#2` | directory |


## Options

| Name, Shorthand | Default | Description |
| ------- | ------- | ------- |
| `-o`, `--origin` &lt;name&gt; |  | use &lt;name&gt; instead of 'origin' to track upstream |
| `-b`, `--branch` &lt;branch&gt; |  | checkout &lt;branch&gt; instead of the remote's HEAD |
| `-u`, `--upload-pack` &lt;path&gt; |  | path to git-upload-pack on the remote |
| `-j`, `--jobs` &lt;n&gt; |  | number of submodules cloned in parallel |
| `--separate-git-dir` &lt;gitdir&gt; |  | separate git dir from working tree |
| `--depth` &lt;depth&gt; |  | create a shallow clone of that depth |


## Flags

| Name, Shorthand | Description |
| ------- | ------- |
| `--recursive` | initialize all contained submodules |
| `--shallow-submodules` | any cloned submodules will be shallow |

# x ccal - Your Terminal Lunar Calendar Assistant

For Chinese users, the Lunar calendar, solar terms, traditional festivals, and the Chinese almanac's auspicious/inauspicious activities are important references for daily life and holiday planning. However, the standard `cal` command in Unix/Linux systems only provides a simple Gregorian calendar view, which cannot meet the demand for traditional cultural information.
`x ccal` was created precisely for this purpose. It is a terminal calendar tool designed for Chinese users, dedicated to providing comprehensive Lunar calendar and Chinese almanac information directly in your command line.

With `x ccal`, you can quickly view Lunar dates, solar terms, traditional festivals, holiday schedules, and even Chinese almanac information in the terminal, without needing to rely on websites or mobile apps. It integrates powerful interactive interfaces, fuzzy search, multi-view switching capabilities, offering an elegant and practical Lunar calendar support for terminal enthusiasts.

## Quick Start: Interactive Calendar Overview

The most common and intuitive way to use `x ccal` is to run the command directly. It will display the current month's Gregorian and Lunar calendar comparison in interactive mode.

```sh
# Equivalent to x ccal fz
x ccal
```

![ccal_fz](/data-image/cookbook/mod/ccal.1_1.webp)

When you execute `x ccal`, it defaults to entering the interactive calendar interface based on `fzf` (equivalent to running `x ccal fz`).
This interface clearly displays the Gregorian dates for the current month, alongside the corresponding Lunar dates, weekdays, festivals, and the "Auspicious" (å®œ) and "Inauspicious" (å¿Œ) activities from the Chinese almanac. Lunar information is presented at a glance.

Furthermore, `x ccal` possesses several practical interactive features:
- **Pagination Navigation**: Use the shortcut `Ctrl-p` to jump to the previous month, and `Ctrl-n` to jump to the next month.
- **Fuzzy Search**: Enter a Gregorian date (e.g., `2023-10-01`), a festival name (e.g., `ä¸­ç§‹èŠ‚` - Mid-Autumn Festival, `æ¸…æ˜Ž` - Qingming Festival), or even fuzzy keywords, and `fzf` can quickly locate it, greatly improving search efficiency.
- **View Switching**: In addition to the default day view, x-cmd also provides **month view** and **year view**. You can use TAB and ENTER to switch between different views.

### Monthly Solar Terms and Holiday Quick View (Month View)

In the month view, you can easily see the twenty-four solar terms, holiday dates, and compensatory working days for each month at a glance.
Besides switching via `TAB` in the day view, you can also directly launch the interactive month view interface using the `fzm` subcommand.

```sh
x ccal fzm
```

![ccal_fzm](/data-image/cookbook/mod/ccal.1_2.webp)

### Annual Festivals and Zodiac Overview (Year View)

If you want to see the dates of traditional festivals for a specific year, the zodiac animal for that year, and information like whether there is a leap month, the year view is your best choice.
Similarly, besides switching via `TAB` in other views, you can also directly launch the interactive year view interface using the `fzy` subcommand.

```sh
x ccal fzy
```

![ccal_fzy](/data-image/cookbook/mod/ccal.1_3.webp)

## Querying Detailed Information for a Specific Date

The interactive interface is suitable for browsing and searching, but if you only need to quickly obtain detailed "Chinese almanac" information for a specific day, including Lunar date, Heavenly Stems and Earthly Branches, Duty Star, and auspicious/inauspicious activities, the `info` subcommand is a more direct option.

### Viewing Today's Details

If you want to know the detailed information for today, simply run the `info` subcommand without any parameters:

```sh
x ccal info
```

![ccal_i](/data-image/cookbook/mod/ccal.1_4.webp)

This command will output detailed "Chinese almanac" information for the current date. You will see the Gregorian date, Lunar date, Heavenly Stems and Earthly Branches for the year/month/day, the Duty Star for the day, and most importantly, the "Auspicious" (å®œ) and "Inauspicious" (å¿Œ) activities from the Chinese almanac. This information is very valuable for users who follow traditional customs.

### Viewing Specific Year and Day

The `info` subcommand also supports querying specified dates in the future or past.

```sh
x ccal info 2025-6-20
```

![ccal_info](/data-image/cookbook/mod/ccal.1_5.webp)

Simply add the date you want to query after `info` (in the format `YYYY`, `YYYY-MM`, or `YYYY-MM-DD`), and `x ccal` will present the detailed calendar information for that day.

## Personalization Settings: Customizing Your `x ccal`

`x ccal` provides some configuration options, allowing you to adjust the display according to your personal preferences. Use the `--cfg` option to view or modify these settings.

### Modifying Weekday Naming (`--cfg wdtitle`)

Some people are accustomed to referring to weekdays as "å‘¨ä¸€" (Zhou Yi - Week One), "å‘¨äºŒ" (Zhou Er - Week Two), while others prefer "ç¤¼æ‹œä¸€" (Libai Yi - Worship One), "ç¤¼æ‹œäºŒ" (Libai Er - Worship Two). `x ccal` allows you to easily switch between these using the `--cfg` option.

```sh
x ccal --cfg wdtitle=libai
```

![ccal_cfg](/data-image/cookbook/mod/ccal.1_6.webp)

This command will change the display of weekdays in the calendar from the default "å‘¨" to "ç¤¼æ‹œ". You can view all configurable options and their current values by running `x ccal --cfg`.

## More Information

Please visit our homepage for more information: https://x-cmd.com/mod/ccal

# About Weekdays

`x ccal` supports various weekday naming conventions, aiming to accommodate different users' habits. (From the author's perspective, implementing these was purely for fun~)

As early as the pre-Qin period, China already adopted a seven-day cycle, distinguishing these seven days by the seven celestial bodies (the Seven Luminaries: Sun, Moon, Mars, Mercury, Jupiter, Venus, Saturn). This tradition is still preserved in Japan and Korea today, using the names Sun, Moon, Fire, Water, Wood, Gold, Earth. In ancient times, the order of these celestial bodies might have differed, but they all shared the characteristic of placing the Sun first.

During the late Qing and early Republic periods, Chinese people gradually adopted "æ˜ŸæœŸ" (xingqi, literally meaning planet and cycle, indicating its origin) combined with numbers, or "ç¤¼æ‹œ" (libai) as names. However, no matter how simplified, the seventh day is never called "æ˜ŸæœŸä¸ƒ" or "ç¤¼æ‹œä¸ƒ", but rather "æ˜ŸæœŸæ—¥/å¤©" (Sunday/Heaven) or "ç¤¼æ‹œæ—¥" (Sunday). If computers had been invented 50 years earlier, there might have been terms like "æ˜ŸæœŸé›¶" or "ç¤¼æ‹œé›¶" (0 resembles the character for Sun/Day, which is quite philosophical).

Chinese also has the term "å‘¨" (zhou), which in this context, the concept of celestial bodies has faded, emphasizing more the nature of the cycle.

In `x ccal`, you can freely set different weekday names:

```bash
x ccal --cfg wdtitle=yao     # Uses the Seven Luminaries names still preserved in Japan and Korea
x ccal --cfg wdtitle=xingqi  # Uses æ˜ŸæœŸæ—¥...æ˜ŸæœŸå…­ (Sunday...Saturday)
x ccal --cfg wdtitle=zhou    # Uses å‘¨æ—¥...å‘¨å…­ (Sunday...Saturday)
x ccal --cfg wdtitle=libai   # Uses ç¤¼æ‹œæ—¥...ç¤¼æ‹œå…­ (Sunday...Saturday)

x ccal init # Modify the wdtitle attribute in the interactive interface
```

![ccal_cfg](/data-image/cookbook/mod/ccal.1_6.webp)

[Reference](https://zh-classical.wikipedia.org/wiki/%E6%98%9F%E6%9C%9F)

## The First Day of the Week

As a programmer, I personally prefer the scheme starting with `Day (0)`, so [`x ccal`](/mod/ccal.md) defaults to Sunday as the first day of the week. Of course, users can adjust this according to their needs.

Different organizations and cultures have different considerations for this. For example, in the ISO 8601 date and time standard, the first day of the [standard week](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ISO_8601#Week_dates) is Monday.

Therefore, we provide flexible configuration options:

```bash
x ccal --cfg wdstart=0    # Starts on Sunday, default
x ccal --cfg wdstart=1    # Starts on Monday
x ccal --cfg wdstart=2    # Starts on Tuesday

x ccal init # Modify the start attribute in the interactive interface
```

This concludes the technical introduction and design philosophy regarding weekdays and dates in [`x ccal`](/mod/ccal.md).

## Digression: Ten-Day Cycle, From Sun Worship to Shooting the Suns

As mentioned above, the weekly cycle always places the Sun first. From a modern astronomical perspective, this is because we are in the solar system, centered around the Sun. But a deeper reason is rooted in humanity's ancient sun worship.

In fact, besides the seven-day cycle, there is also the ancient custom of a ten-day cycle. This custom is still preserved today, for example, we often divide a month into three "æ—¬" (xun), with ten days (or approximately ten days) constituting one "æ—¬". If you look at the structure of the character "æ—¬", it also contains "æ—¥" (sun/day). Tracing back to oracle bone script, it is a cross (åå­—) plus a cyclical arc shape (æ—¥), perfectly illustrating the concept of a cycle.

The most famous and interesting story of the ten-day cycle is arguably Hou Yi shooting the suns. I first heard this story at the age of 7 ("Five Thousand Years of Culture"). The story goes that the Heavenly Emperor had ten sun sons, originally each sun was on duty for one day (perhaps the origin of the term "å€¼æ—¥", meaning 'on duty for the day'), while the other nine rested on a tree (perhaps similar to the World Tree in the Norse Odin system). But one day, all ten suns suddenly jumped into the sky to play, and the weather immediately became scorching hot and dry, causing a great catastrophe for humanity. Humans were helpless (for ancient agricultural societies, this was undoubtedly a fatal blow, hence records of witches exposing themselves to the sun to pray for rain; this kind of sacrifice ritual left a deep impression on me, frankly speaking, the book "Classic of Mountains and Seas" is somewhat unsuitable for children).

At this point, a celestial being named Hou Yi stepped forward, holding a divine bow, and shot down the suns one by one. Perhaps because he was shooting too enthusiastically, fortunately someone reminded him, so one sun was left in the end. From then on, the surviving sun obediently went to work, changing from `on duty one day, rest nine` to `no rest all year`.

The Heavenly Emperor was thus enraged, and as punishment, demoted Hou Yi and his wife Chang'e to mortals, denying them eternal life. Chang'e, seeking eternal life, overdosed on medicine and fled to the moon. Hou Yi was later betrayed by his apprentice and died from a hidden arrow. (Perhaps this story wants to tell us that behind success... there are always hidden dangers?)

Later, when I read about the history of the Xia and Shang dynasties, specifically Taikang losing his state and Shaokang's restoration, I learned that Hou Yi was actually "åŽ" (Hou, meaning leader) Yi (his name), and as the leader of the Youqiong clan, he expelled Taikang and overthrew the Xia regime. This is the historical "shooting the suns". And later, reading about Hou Yi being murdered and usurped by his subordinate Han Zhuo, I immediately thought of the apprentice who injured him with a hidden arrow in the myth.

Even later, reading about King Wu Yi of Shang shooting the sky, and the reforms in the late Shang period such as gradually simplifying sacrificial rites, appointing minor officials, adopting primogeniture, marginalizing nobles and priests, and monopolizing oracle bone divination to further centralize power, I could vaguely see the shadow of the "ten suns worship gradually evolving into one sun in the sky" within them.

## Materialized Artifacts: The Bronze Sacred Tree of Sanxingdui

Specifically regarding archaeological artifacts, the Bronze Sacred Tree of Sanxingdui must be mentioned. Thanks to the archaeologists' nearly ten years of restoration efforts, we can once again see how the concepts of the ten-day worship and being on duty were materialized in ancient times â€“ our generation has seen many ancient objects that even Sima Qian never saw.

Furthermore, Sanxingdui is not an alien civilization, nor is it ancient Egyptian civilization. The "Eastern Origin of Sanxingdui" theory is supported by relatively sufficient archaeological evidence. From an archaeological perspective, this also seems related to the Yellow Emperor tribe's conquest of Sanwei (San Miao, Chi You). I will add relevant materials later.

The sacred tree in the image above only has nine suns; the "center position" at the top of the tree is empty â€“ Sanxingdui has multiple burial pits, and a host of divine artifacts were deliberately damaged and buried (as a form of suppression). Perhaps they can never be fully restored â€“ or perhaps, the tenth sun is in the sky. (This is like some seven-story pagodas only having five stories, one in the sky, one on the ground, primarily relying on abstract imagination and sublimation~)

# Chronology Systems

## Our Country Adopts the Gregorian Calendar

The Gregorian calendar, known as the Western calendar during the Qing Dynasty, is the standard calendar used in China. After the establishment of the Republic of China, Mr. Sun Yat-sen, upon assuming the provisional presidency, immediately issued the "Order to Adopt the Solar Calendar".

On September 27, 1949, the First Plenary Session of the Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference decided that the People's Republic of China would adopt the universally used Common Era (AD) chronology system.

> **AD One == Yuanshi One**: Emperor Ping of Han, Liu Kan, ascended the throne in the year before Common Era One (BC 1). Due to his youth, Wang Mang held power and changed the era name to [`Yuanshi`](https://baike.baidu.com/item/%E5%85%83%E5%A7%8B/3167180) the following year (i.e., Common Era One). Therefore, the `Yuanshi First Year` of Emperor Ping of Han is `Common Era One`. This adds another piece of evidence to the argument that [Wang Mang was a time traveler](https://www.bing.com/search?q=çŽ‹èŽ½æ˜¯ä¸ªç©¿è¶Šè€…).

## No Year Zero in AD and Numerical Representation of BC Years

The Common Era chronology system designates the year of Jesus' birth as the first year, i.e., Common Era One (AD 1). The year before Common Era One (BC 1) is the year before the first year, not Common Era Zero.
Therefore, the year following BC 1 is AD 1.

For ease of calculation, for years before the Common Era, a negative sign is used, and the numerical value is increased by one:

| Event                                     | Numerical Representation | Common Era Chronology |
| :---------------------------------------- | :----------------------- | :-------------------- |
| Article Written                           | 2025                     | AD 2025               |
| Birth of Jesus, Emperor Ping of Han Changes Era (Yuanshi Year 1) | 1                        | AD 1                  |
| Qin Shi Huang Destroys Qi, Unifies China  | -220                     | BC 221                |
| Battle of Muye, King Wu Conquers Yin      | -1045                    | BC 1046               |

This also **gives rise** to a question â€“ does the 21st century begin in 2000 or 2001?

Official documents generally recognize 2001 as the first year of the 21st century, and 2000 as the last year of the **20th** century. For example, the [New Year's Address for 2001: Jointly Create a Beautiful New Century](https://www.gov.cn/gongbao/content/2001/content_61231.htm) mentions "extending congratulations for the first New Year of the new century".

## Xuanyuan (Yellow Emperor) Chronology, Daoist Calendar

1.  Uses the traditional Chinese lunar calendar, not the Gregorian calendar.
2.  According to Daoist teachings, the Yellow Emperor began his reign at the age of 20, which corresponds to BC 2697.
3.  Therefore, the formula is `(Lunar Calendar) Year + 2697 Years`.

-   [Baidu Baike on "Yellow Emperor Chronology"](https://baike.baidu.com/item/%E9%BB%84%E5%B8%9D%E7%BA%AA%E5%B9%B4/3152927)
-   [CPPCC Proposal: Proposal on Establishing the Xuanyuan Chronology (XY)](https://ihistory.ifeng.com/mip/43334638/news.shtml)

Disagreements:

1.  The calculation process is not necessarily widely accepted. The era is distant, and historical texts may contain errors or forgeries, lacking archaeological support, making it difficult to unify.
2.  Mr. Sun Yat-sen's "Order to Adopt the Solar Calendar" also introduced the Yellow Emperor Chronology as a reference. The "Circular on Calendar and Era Change" stipulated: "The Republic of China shall adopt the solar calendar, with the 4609th year of the Yellow Emperor's era, which is the 13th day of the 11th month of the Xinhai year, as the first day of the first year of the Republic of China."
3.  The widely used Yellow Emperor calendar is based on the lunar calendar, but the aforementioned CPPCC proposal, to be compatible with the Gregorian calendar, directly uses `(Gregorian Calendar) Year + 2697`.

Current Approach:

1.  I believe that, like the Heavenly Stems and Earthly Branches, the Yellow Emperor calendar is more about paying tribute to traditional culture.
2.  Since the Gregorian calendar is widely used, changing the era would incur costs. Therefore, the role of the Yellow Emperor chronology is not for practical use but for tribute.
3.  Given this, it should be carried through consistently, using the traditional Chinese lunar calendar as the basis for the Yellow Emperor chronology. The current implementation of [`x ccal`](/mod/ccal.md) **calculates the Yellow Emperor chronology based on the lunar calendar**.

We have adopted the more concise term `Xuanyuan xxxx Year`:

1.  `(The Yellow Emperor) received the state at Youxiong, resided at Xuanyuan Hill, hence taking it as his name and also his appellation.`
2.  Refer to [Wikipedia](https://zh.wikipedia.org/wiki/%E9%BB%84%E5%B8%9D) for reference.
3.  Legend has it he was born on the third day of the third lunar month; a common saying is "Second day of the second month, the dragon raises its head; third day of the third month, Xuanyuan is born."

## Buddhist Calendar

1.  The year of the Buddha's (Shakyamuni's) Nirvana is the first year of the Buddhist calendar - BC 543.
2.  Disagreements arise regarding whether to use the Gregorian or lunar calendar year. Note that different countries' time zones may lead to differences in the date of the full moon.
3.  The specific date of the Buddha's Nirvana (Vesak Day) varies among different Buddhist traditions. For example, Theravada Buddhist regions (such as Thailand, Sri Lanka, etc., and parts of Yunnan, China) usually set it on the fifteenth day of the fourth lunar month (the full moon day of the fourth month), while Japan designates it as April 8th of the Gregorian calendar.

Since [`x ccal`](/mod/ccal.md) is primarily for Chinese users, its implementation uses the year of the Buddha's Nirvana (BC 543) as the first year of the Buddhist calendar. Regarding the specific date of the Buddha's Nirvana (Vesak Day), the date differs in different traditions; for example, Theravada Buddhist regions usually set it on the fifteenth day of the fourth lunar month.

**First Buddhist Conference:**

-   [Conference Website](https://wfbhq.org/general-conference-detail.php?id=015000018)
-   [Conference CommuniquÃ©](https://wfbhq.org/uploads/conferences/015000018/01505/Resolution-1st.pdf)
-   [Conference Proceedings](https://wfbhq.org//uploads/conferences/015000018/01507/Record-of-Proceedings-1st.pdf)

> Quote: The Conference also pledged to the government of countries where Buddhist communities are to be found to recognize the first full moon day of May as Buddha Day or Vesak Day.

This quote refers to a resolution from the First Conference of the World Fellowship of Buddhists regarding the date of Vesak Day, suggesting that the first full moon day of May in the Gregorian calendar be recognized as Vesak Day; this is the day of Nirvana, which is the first day of the first year of the Buddhist calendar.

**Popular Science Article Referenced in This Article:**

[By what calendar is "Buddha's Birthday" celebrated?](https://www.163.com/dy/article/F6AG8O7L05239F82.html)
