# Auspicious and Inauspicious Days

Folk customs regarding auspicious and inauspicious days can only be viewed as a social and cultural phenomenon, belonging to a form of mysticism that cannot be disproven. However, I believe they serve two purposes:

1.  **Alleviating Decision Fatigue**: When deciding where to eat lunch at the company, those of us with decision fatigue wrote a random number generator to determine the restaurant for the day. In my view, auspicious/inauspicious days can serve as a substitute for random numbers, helping people with decision fatigue allocate their decision-making energy to areas where it is truly needed.
2.  **Community Coordination**: For example, happy events and sad events should ideally not be held on the same day.

Of course, my primary motivation is curiosity! Curiosity is the biggest driving force behind this [ccal module](/mod/ccal.md) ~

## Currently Integrated Features of `x ccal`

```bash
x ccal              # Interactive view
x ccal i            # View today
x ccal i 2008-8-8   # View the opening day of the Beijing Olympics
x ccal i 2025-6-8   # View June 8, 2025. Note that this day is a San Niang Sha day.
```

## Common Taboos

### [San Niang Sha](https://baike.baidu.com/item/%E4%B8%89%E5%A8%98%E7%85%9E/3683402) (also mistakenly called San Yang Sha)

1.  Wedding ceremonies should avoid San Niang Sha days.
2.  Background Story: San Niang was an independent, modern-minded single woman who firmly refused to tolerate displays of affection. While protecting single people, she potentially created more single people.
3.  It is said that if a wedding takes place on a "San Niang Sha" day, the bride's auspicious energy will be overwhelming. Therefore, the bride should wear a red veil and be sheltered by a red umbrella during the wedding.

Folk tradition holds that the 3rd, 7th, 13th, 18th, 22nd, and 27th days of each lunar month are San Niang Sha days. However, in reality, the Heavenly Stems and Earthly Branches of the day must also be considered:

```markdown
The 3rd day coinciding with a Geng Wu day
The 7th day coinciding with a Xin Wei day
The 13th day coinciding with a Wu Shen day
The 18th day coinciding with a Ji You day
The 22nd day coinciding with a Bing Wu day
The 27th day coinciding with a Ding Wei day
```

Thus, the actual probability of occurrence is very low. Interestingly, in June 2025, the month when this module was completed, the 8th day is indeed a San Niang Sha day.

### Yang Gong Ji

On Yang Gong Ji days, it is advised not to hold weddings, undertake construction, visit relatives, travel far, or take long journeys.

There are thirteen Yang Gong Ji days throughout the year: the 13th of the 1st month, the 11th of the 2nd month, the 9th of the 3rd month, the 17th of the 4th month, the 15th of the 5th month, the 13th of the 6th month, the 11th of the 7th month, the 29th of the 7th month, the 27th of the 8th month, the 25th of the 9th month, the 23rd of the 10th month, the 21st of the 11th month, and the 19th of the 12th month.

This custom is currently prevalent in areas such as Shijiazhuang City and Lingshou County in Hebei Province, and among the Hakka people in Dongshan, Chengdu, Sichuan Province.

Reference: [Yang Gong Ji](https://baike.baidu.com/item/%E6%9D%A8%E5%85%AC%E5%BF%8C%E6%97%A5/3630656)

## Jian Chu Twelve Day Officers

The Jian Chu Twelve Day Officers are a traditional Chinese method for selecting auspicious dates. These twelve deities, named Jian, Chu, Man, Ping, Ding, Zhi, Po, Wei, Cheng, Shou, Kai, and Bi, take turns presiding over each day in a cycle. The presiding deity determines the auspiciousness or inauspiciousness of the day and the activities suitable for it.

The origin of the Twelve Day Officers is unclear, but it can be traced back to the late Warring States period. In the "Day Books" found in the Jiudian Chu Slips and Yunmeng Qin Slips, there are twelve deity names referred to as "Chu". Based on the regions where they circulated, they are divided into Qin Chu in the Qin state and Chu Chu in the Chu state. Both regions had twelve deity names, which were not entirely identical, suggesting a possible common origin. Because the calendars used by the Chu and Qin states differed, the starting month and day for calculating Jian Chu also differed, with a two-month difference between them, but both followed a twelve-day cycle. The Qin slip "Day Book" integrated both Chu Chu and Qin Chu.

The mnemonic rhyme for the auspiciousness of the twelve stars is: "Jian, Man, Ping, Shou are black; Chu, Wei, Ding, Zhi are yellow; Cheng and Kai are all usable; Po and Bi should not be encountered."

-   **Yellow Path Days (Auspicious Days)**: Chu, Wei, Ding, Zhi. Among these, Cheng and Kai days are particularly suitable for all matters.
-   **Black Path Days (Inauspicious Days)**: Jian, Man, Ping, Shou. Among these, Po and Bi days are unsuitable for all matters.

| Star | Explanation                                                                                                                               |
| :--- | :---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- |
| Jian | Refers to the beginning of something not yet completed. All matters can be undertaken, but construction should be avoided.                |
| Chu  | Refers to the meaning of clearing away. It is very auspicious for getting rid of the old and welcoming the new.                            |
| Man  | Refers to the meaning of completeness. Auspicious for sacrifices, but inauspicious for other matters. Most unsuitable for weddings.        |
| Ping | Refers to the meaning of smoothness. Both happy and sad events can be held.                                                               |
| Ding | Refers to everything being settled. Suitable for adoption, business, visits, exams, etc. Inauspicious for other unfortunate matters.      |
| Zhi  | Refers to being stubborn and inflexible in all matters. All happy and sad events should be avoided.                                       |
| Cheng | Refers to the accomplishment of all matters. Both happy and sad events can be undertaken.                                                 |
| Shou | Refers to the meaning of collecting or gathering. Only suitable for collecting, demanding, or burial. Inauspicious for other unfortunate matters. |
| Po   | Refers to the meaning of breaking or shattering. Avoid all happy and sad events. This day is referred to as the Xing Po day.              |
| Wei  | Refers to the meaning of being cautious in all matters. Matters can be undertaken but with caution; major matters should be treated as minor. |
| Kai  | Refers to being open and smooth, everything can be done.                                                                                  |
| Bi   | Refers to being blocked or closed. Suitable for collecting or burial, but unsuitable for other matters.                                   |

**References:**

-   [Wikipedia Jian Chu Twelve Deities](https://zh.wikipedia.org/wiki/%E5%BB%BA%E9%99%A4%E5%8D%81%E4%BA%8C%E7%A5%9E)
-   [Baidu Baike Twelve Day Officers](https://baike.baidu.com/item/%E5%8D%81%E4%BA%8C%E5%BB%BA%E6%98%9F/2146343)
-   [Twelve Day Officers](https://www.huaxia.com/c/2023/06/26/1718541.shtml)

## RokuyÅ

RokuyÅ first appeared in "Kong Ming Liu Yao Xing" (Zhuge Liang's Six Stars), while another theory attributes its creation to "Li Chunfeng" of the Tang Dynasty (one of the authors of the Tui Bei Tu).

In Japan, after entering the Meiji era, annotations predicting auspiciousness and inauspiciousness on calendars were considered superstition and prohibited by the government. Only "RokuyÅ" was allowed to remain, which led to its rapid popularization among the Japanese public.

The current Japanese RokuyÅ differs from the ancient Chinese version, and even differs from the RokuyÅ before the late Edo period.

`x ccal` includes Japanese RokuyÅ, partly out of curiosity and partly because these terms are used in daily life.

**Calculation Formula**: `(Lunar Month + Lunar Day) % 6`
A remainder of zero is Taian, a remainder of one is Shakku, and the sequence follows below.

The following content is based on [Japanese Wikipedia RokuyÅ](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/%E5%85%AD%E6%9B%9C)

### Taian: All Things Peaceful

Taian (ãŸã„ã‚ã‚“) is considered a day suitable for all matters, meaning "great auspiciousness".

It is considered the most auspicious day among the RokuyÅ, said to be lucky in all endeavors with no unsuccessful outcomes. "Taian" originates from "Tai An" (great peace), hence activities like weddings and JÅtÅ-shiki (ridgepole-raising ceremonies) are often chosen to be held on Taian days. Many people also choose this day for car registration, vehicle delivery, groundbreaking ceremonies for buildings, or property handover.

### Shakku: Quarrels --

-   Unsuitable for happy events, official business, lawsuits, or contracts. Only noon (11 AM to 1 PM, the Wu hour) is considered auspicious during the day; the rest of the time is inauspicious.
-   It is said that the OnmyÅdÅ's Akajita day and Akaguchi day, or Taishaku (å¤§èµ¤), were combined and became one of the RokuyÅ as an inauspicious day. Akajita day is considered the day presided over by the deity Akajita, who governs the western gate of Jupiter. Among the six subordinate Rakshasa deities guarding the gates, the third one is a threatening presence, so lawsuits and contracts should be avoided on this day. Additionally, Akaguchi day is considered the day presided over by the deity Akaguchi, who governs the eastern gate of Jupiter. Among the eight subordinate great demon deities, the fourth one, Happatsu-sotsu, is a presence that obstructs people's arguments, so lawsuits and contracts should also be avoided on this day. Akajita day has a 6-day cycle, and Akaguchi day has an 8-day cycle, so the cycles are different, but it is believed that these were summarized and incorporated into one of the RokuyÅ, becoming "Shakku".
-   Because this day contains the character "èµ¤" (red), caution should be exercised regarding fire and sharp objects. This means being mindful of things associated with "death" on this day.

**Difference from Chinese Chiku Day:**

-   The third day of the first lunar month each year (also called Chi Gou Ri). According to traditional Chinese customs, it is easy to have arguments and disputes with others on this day. To avoid inviting verbal conflict, people do not go out to visit relatives and friends, but stay at home to worship deities. Hence, Chi Kou Ri is also called "Xiao Nian Chao" (Minor New Year's Day).
-   [Wikipedia](https://zh.wikipedia.org/wiki/%E8%B5%A4%E5%8F%A3)

> **Li's Comment**: Suitable for staying home. It's best not even to play RPGs.

### SenshÅ: First Strike Wins

SenshÅ (ã›ã‚“ã—ã‚‡ã† or ã›ã‚“ã‹ã¡ in Japanese pronunciation) is a day suitable for completing tasks early, embodying the meaning of "first strike wins". It is said to be auspicious in the morning and inauspicious in the afternoon. This day is considered auspicious for handling urgent matters or engaging in lawsuits. In the past, it was also written as "Sokki" (é€Ÿå–œ, quick joy) or "Sokichi" (å³å‰, immediate auspiciousness).

> **Li's Comment**: Don't be a 'wait-and-see' person; buy early and enjoy early.

### Tomobiki: Indecisive Outcome

-   Tomobiki (ã¨ã‚‚ã³ã) is considered a day where the outcome is indecisive, neither good nor bad. Alternatively, when interpreted as "no win, no loss" or "attracting friends," it can be considered an auspicious day.
-   Tomobiki days are auspicious in the morning and evening, but inauspicious at noon.
-   It is believed that holding a funeral on a Tomobiki day will "pull friends to the underworld" (i.e., death). Therefore, funeral-related businesses and crematories may be closed on Tomobiki days. However, since RokuyÅ is unrelated to Buddhism, some sects (such as JÅdo ShinshÅ«) may hold funerals on Tomobiki days. Furthermore, an increasing number of local governments are abolishing the rule for crematories to close on Tomobiki days.
-   It is said that the superstition of avoiding funerals on Tomobiki days originally stemmed from confusion with "Tomobiki" (å‹æ›³), which is completely unrelated to RokuyÅ. Tomobiki (å‹æ›³) is a custom referring to avoiding travel in the direction corresponding to the day's zodiac sign, or avoiding holding funerals on that day. Due to the identical pronunciation, it is believed that the two were confused.
-   Additionally, when dealing with celebratory events, some people interpret the aforementioned "no win, no loss" as "marital harmony" and thus choose this day for wedding ceremonies, or send wedding return gifts on this day to "share happiness."
-   Although the reading "ã¨ã‚‚ã³ã" is common, its origin is the Chinese word "LiÃº YÇn" (ç•™å¼•). Since it was read in Japanese and assigned the characters "ã¨ã‚‚ã³ã" (å‹å¼•), it is unrelated to "attracting friends." "LiÃº YÇn" means that current matters continue or stagnate, and it is a "day to assess the situation and take action." If things are good, they continue; if they are bad, countermeasures should be taken.

### Senpu: First Mover Loses --

A day when urgent matters should be avoided. It is said that disputes and official business are also unfavorable, and it is best to remain calm in all matters. It means "the first to act will lose," corresponding to SenshÅ. It is said that on Senpu days, the morning is inauspicious and the afternoon is auspicious.

In the past, "Senpu" was sometimes written as "ShÅkichi" (å°å‰, minor auspiciousness) or "ShÅ«kichi" (å‘¨å‰, surrounding auspiciousness), and was considered an auspicious day. The current interpretation arose from a forced interpretation of the characters.

> **Li's Comment**: No need to wake up early on this day; sleeping until noon can ward off disaster.

### Butsumetsu: All Merits Dissipate

Butsumetsu (ã¶ã¤ã‚ã¤) is the most inauspicious day among the RokuyÅ. Originally called "KyomÅ" (è™šäº¡), meaning no win or loss, it was later also called "KÅ«bÅ" (ç©ºäº¡). People interpreted it as everything being empty, so it was renamed "Butsumetsu" (ç‰©æ»…, things perish), and then transformed to mean the absence of Buddha's merits, thus using the character "ä½›" (Buddha). However, critics point out that historically, the notation "ä½›æ»…" first appeared in the "Banreki RyÅmen Kagami" compiled in EnkyÅ 4 (1747), and subsequent editions also used this notation, while the notation "ç‰©æ»…" first appeared in the "Ansei Zassho Banreki Taisei" (1854).

Butsumetsu day is considered unsuitable for all matters. It is the most inauspicious day in RokuyÅ, and there is a custom of avoiding celebratory events such as weddings. Few people choose to hold weddings on this day. Therefore, some wedding venues offer discounts on Butsumetsu days. While other RokuyÅ have multiple readings, Butsumetsu only has one reading, "ã¶ã¤ã‚ã¤".

People often mistakenly interpret it literally as the day of Buddha's (Shakyamuni's) Nirvana (death). In the "Bunsei Ni U no Toshi NenjÅ« KyÅkun Uta Zen" from Bunsei 2 (1819), there is already an explanation for Butsumetsu: "It is said to be the anniversary of Buddha's death, unsuitable for all matters...". However, as mentioned above, RokuyÅ did not originate from Buddhism and is unrelated to it. The day of Shakyamuni's death is considered to be February 15th, and it is merely a coincidence that the 15th of the second lunar month is always a Butsumetsu day.

Some also say: "On this day, one should be cautious in all matters, illness will be prolonged, but Buddhist services are permissible."

Furthermore, some interpret "ç‰©æ»…" (things perish) as "once things perish, new things begin," believing that this day is more suitable for starting new things than "Taian."

# x cd (1) - History Directory

## Interactive Search for History Directory

Executing the `x cd` command will launch an interactive app within **x-cmd**.  Users can search their history directory and jump to the desired location.

```sh
x cd
```

Additionally, `x cd` provides `c` as a shorthand command. For example, `c <dir>` is equivalent to `x cd <dir>`.


## Filtering History Directory with Keywords

Executing `c ,[keyword]` will filter the interactive app to only display history directories related to the keyword.

For example, to only display history directories containing "src" in their path:

```sh
c ,src           # Equivalent to `x cd ,src`
```

Note: If only one directory matches after keyword filtering, the directory will be switched directly instead of launching the interactive app.

## Maintaining the Original `cd` Command Habits

The `c` command retains the original usage habits of the `cd` command, ensuring a smooth transition for users.

```sh
c ..        # Go to the parent directory
c -         # Go back to the previous directory
```

---
url: /mod/cd/cookbook-2.md
---

# x cd (2) - Directory Backtracking

## Interactive Search for Parent Directories

The `c ...` command is an alias for the `c -b` command. After executing the `c ...` command, **x-cmd** will provide an interactive app allowing users to search and jump to all parent directories.

```sh
c ...
```

![c ...](/data-image/cookbook/mod/cd.2_1.webp)

When using the `cd` command, `..` usually represents the parent directory. Therefore, **x-cmd** uses `...` to represent all parent directories.


## Backtracking to Parent Directories Matching a Keyword

Executing the `c .../[keyword]` command ensures that the opened interactive app only displays parent directories related to the keyword.

For example, to ensure that the opened interactive app only displays parent directories containing the string "src" in their path:

```sh
c .../src        # Equivalent to the `c -b src` command
```

![c .../src](/data-image/cookbook/mod/cd.2_2.webp)


---
url: /mod/cd/cookbook-3.md
---

# x cd (3) - Abbreviation Exploration and Forward Exploration

## Exploring Directories using Abbreviated Paths

The `c` command supports searching for directories using abbreviated paths and jumping to them.

For example, with the command `c /u/b`. First, it checks if the `/u/b` directory exists. If it exists, it immediately changes the directory; otherwise, the user can choose to create the `/u/b` directory or search for similar directories (e.g., `/usr/bin`, `/Users/bun`).

```sh
c /u/b
```

If multiple similar directories exist, **x-cmd** will provide an interactive app for the user to further search and jump to the desired directory.

## Forward Exploration of Subdirectories

After executing the `c -f` command, **x-cmd** will provide an interactive app allowing the user to search and jump to all subdirectories.

```sh
c -f
```

Executing the `c -f [keyword]` command ensures that the opened interactive app only displays subdirectories related to the keyword.

For example, to ensure that the opened interactive app only displays subdirectories whose path contains the string "theme":

```sh
c -f theme
```

---
url: /mod/cd/cookbook-4.md
---

# x cd (4) - Directory Alias

## Setting a Directory Alias

`c -r <...>` is a shorthand for the `x cd --relm <...>` command.

Use the following command to set the directory alias `xcbin` to point to the `~/.x-cmd.root/bin` directory.

```sh
c -r set xcbin ~/.x-cmd.root/bin
```

## Using a Directory Alias

Generally, if a path starts with a colon `:`, it indicates the use of a directory alias.

For example, using the **directory alias `xcbin`** set in Demo 1 to jump to the `~/.x-cmd.root/bin` directory.

```sh
c :xcbin
```

## Listing Existing Directory Aliases

In an interactive scenario, **x-cmd** provides an interactive APP that allows users to quickly search and view existing directory aliases.

```sh
c -r ls
```

After selecting an option in the interactive APP and pressing Enter, a further operation menu will be provided, such as switching to the corresponding folder, deleting the directory alias, etc.

## Deleting a Directory Alias

Delete the directory alias `xcbin` set in Demo 1.

```sh
c -r rm xcbin
```

# x choco - Simplify Windows Package Management using Chocolatey

## Introduction

The `x choco` module is a command-line tool designed for Windows system developers and administrators. It leverages the powerful Chocolatey package manager to simplify the installation, update, and uninstallation of Windows software. `x choco` runs within environments like WSL2 or Git Bash, eliminating the need to switch to PowerShell and improving workflow efficiency.


## Key Features

`x choco` provides the following core functionalities:

* **Convenient Package Installation:** Use the `install` command to easily install various packages.  Supports installation from local `nuspec` or `nupkg` files, as well as from Chocolatey sources.

```bash
# Install a package from the Chocolatey source
x choco install <package_name>

# Install from a local nuspec file
x choco install <path/to/nuspec>

# Install from a local nupkg file
x choco install <path/to/nupkg>
```

* **Efficient Package Uninstallation:** Use the `uninstall` command to quickly uninstall installed packages.

```bash
# Uninstall a single package
x choco uninstall <package_name>

# Uninstall multiple packages
x choco uninstall <package_name1> <package_name2> ...

# Uninstall all packages (use with caution!)
x choco uninstall all
```

* **Proxy Configuration:** The `x choco proxy` command allows you to configure a proxy server, facilitating the use of Chocolatey in restricted network environments. This is particularly important for users in mainland China.

```bash
# Configure proxy (example)
x choco proxy --http-proxy http://your_proxy:port --https-proxy http://your_proxy:port
```

* **Administrator Privileges:** Some operations require administrator privileges. The `x choco admin` command allows running specified Chocolatey commands with administrator rights.

```bash
# Install a package with administrator privileges
x choco admin install <package_name>
```

* **Execute Native Chocolatey Commands:** `x choco -- <choco_command>` allows you to execute any native Chocolatey command. This provides maximum flexibility, enabling you to use all of Chocolatey's advanced features.

```bash
# Execute the native choco search command
x choco -- search <keyword>
```


## Advanced Usage

### Configuration Files

(This section could include details on configuration files, such as how to configure default sources and manage multiple configuration files for different environments.)


### Tab Completion

`x choco` provides command completion functionality to help users quickly input commands and parameters. (This section could include instructions on enabling tab completion.)


## Examples

Here are some examples of `x choco` usage:

```bash
# Install Git
x choco install git

# Uninstall Node.js
x choco uninstall nodejs

# Search for packages containing "python"
x choco -- search python

# Upgrade Chocolatey with administrator privileges
x choco admin upgrade chocolatey
```


## Summary

The `x choco` module significantly improves the efficiency of Windows system package management by simplifying the use of Chocolatey. It is easy to use, powerful, and an ideal tool for Windows developers and system administrators. Visit [https://x-cmd.com](https://x-cmd.com) for more information.

# x cht - A Developer's Command-Line Cheat Sheet Tool

## Introduction

The `x cht` module is a powerful command-line tool that helps developers quickly find cheat sheets for various commands and programming languages.  It sources its data from [cheat.sh](https://cht.sh/), a community-maintained repository containing a vast collection of cheat sheets for programming languages, database systems, and Unix/Linux commands. `x cht` provides concise and clear examples, making it easy for developers to quickly learn and find specific functionalities â€“ like having a cheat sheet always at hand.

Compared to lengthy help documents, `x cht` offers more concise and easier-to-understand usage examples, allowing you to quickly grasp command usage. It complements `x tldr` and traditional help documentation; `x tldr` provides the most commonly used short examples, help documentation provides detailed explanations, and `x cht` covers various functionalities and usages of commands.


## Main Features

`x cht` offers the following main features:

* **Directly lookup command or programming language cheat sheets:** Use the `x cht <command|language>` command to quickly retrieve the cheat sheet for a specified command or programming language. For example, `x cht ls` will display the cheat sheet for the Linux `ls` command, and `x cht python` will display the cheat sheet for the Python language.

* **Keyword search:** Use the `x cht -s <keyword>` command to search cheat sheets based on keywords. This command supports case-insensitive search, recursive search, and limiting keywords to word boundaries, making it easy to find commands or code examples containing specific keywords. For example, `x cht -s python` will search for all cheat sheets containing "python". `x cht -s -r regex` will recursively search for all cheat sheets containing "regex".

* **Specific types of cheat sheets:** `x cht` also supports finding specific types of cheat sheets:

    * `x cht :learn <language>`: Retrieves `learn-x-in-minutes` language cheat sheets suitable for beginners.
    * `x cht :1line <language>`: Retrieves a collection of one-line code snippets for a programming language.
    * `x cht :weirdness <language>`: Retrieves some rather unusual examples in a programming language.


## Usage Examples

Here are some usage examples of `x cht`:

* **Get the cheat sheet for the `ls` command:**

```bash
x cht ls
```

* **Get the cheat sheet for the Python language:**

```bash
x cht python
```

* **Search for cheat sheets containing the keyword "regex" (case-insensitive, recursive search):**

```bash
x cht -s -i -r regex
```

* **Get a cheat sheet suitable for learning Python as a beginner:**

```bash
x cht :learn python
```

* **Get a collection of one-line code snippets for Python:**

```bash
x cht :1line python
```

* **List all available cheat sheets:**

```bash
x cht -l
```

* **View the `x cht` help information:**

```bash
x cht -h  # or x cht --help or x cht :h
```


## Summary

`x cht` is an efficient and convenient command-line tool that helps developers quickly find cheat sheets for various commands and programming languages, significantly improving development efficiency.  With its concise commands and powerful search functionality, `x cht` becomes a valuable assistant in your development process.  It's recommended to use it in conjunction with `x tldr` and help documentation for more comprehensive information.

# x Claude - Say Goodbye to Tedious Configurations! One-click Activation of Claude Code, Quickly Getting Started with the Terminal AI Programming Agent

This guide will help you understand the common features of x Claude in just a few minutes and get started using Claude Code to experience the powerful capabilities of the intelligent AI programming agent.

## I. No Threshold! Automatic Installation and Startup of Claude Code

**You do not need to install Claude Code manually**. When you run the x Claude command, x-cmd will automatically detect whether Claude Code is already installed in the current environment. If it is not installed, x-cmd will automatically download and configure it for you, requiring no manual operation, no manual deployment of Node.js, or handling of dependency installation.

## II. Freedom to Switch Models! Integrate AI Models like Claude, DeepSeek, Gemini, ChatGPT, Kimi, glm, etc.

### Integrating the Official Claude Model

Claude Code uses Anthropic's Claude series models (such as Claude Sonnet 4.5, Claude Opus 4.1, etc.) by default. Logging into your Claude account is required to use these models.

- Login Methods: Upon the first run of x Claude, the system will automatically prompt you to log in. You can choose from the following options:
    * Claude.ai Account (Recommended): Suitable for personal subscription users. Simply log in with your Claude.ai account without additional configuration.
    * Claude Console Account: Suitable for developers and enterprise users. Log in with API Key, billed based on actual usage, providing more flexible payment options and higher usage quotas.

![1](/data-image/cookbook/mod/claude.1_1.webp)

Once logged in, your credentials will be automatically encrypted and stored locally. Subsequent uses do not require re-logging, as the system will automatically retrieve the saved credential information.

### Integrating Models like DeepSeek/Gemini

In addition to the Claude series models, x Claude also supports integrating other AI models as back-end drivers for Claude Code.

For example, you can easily switch Claude Code to use the DeepSeek model:
```bash
x deepseek init
x claude ds
```

![2](/data-image/cookbook/mod/claude.1_2.webp)

After executing the above commands, Claude Code will automatically use the DeepSeek model for conversations and programming assistance. Similarly, you can integrate Gemini, Kimi, Zhipu, etc., as needed.

For more detailed methods of model integration, please refer to the respective documents:
- [Integrating DeepSeek Model](/mod/claude/cookbook-2.md)
- [Integrating Gemini Model](/mod/claude/cookbook-3.md)

## III. Terminal Technology! Call x-cmd in Claude Code Conversations

Claude Code has a built-in terminal command execution function, allowing you to directly call `x` commands in conversations to execute system operations or scripts. The specific operations are as follows:

![3](/data-image/cookbook/mod/claude.1_3.webp)

1. In the Claude Code conversation, use the `!` key to enter Bash mode.
2. Continue to input your desired `x` command (e.g., `x ip` command) in the dialog box, and upon pressing Enter, Claude Code will execute the command in the terminal environment and automatically incorporate the output result into the conversation context for further analysis, formatting, or processing.

You can also have Claude Code actively call command lines to complete tasks, such as mentioning x-cmd in the conversation:

```bash
> Use x-cmd to fetch and analyze network interface information
```

Claude Code will generate and execute the command based on the instructions and return structured results.

## IV. Extend AI Skills! Manage Claude Agent Skills with x-cmd

Claude Code supports an Agent Skills mechanism, allowing your Claude Code to better handle specific complex tasks through skill extensions, such as writing technical documentation adhering to brand guidelines, performing advanced data analysis, or reviewing code according to best practices. You can use the `skill` command in the `x claude` module to uniformly manage these skills, with the following common usage examples:

1. Query available professional skills: You can use the `x claude skill ll` command to query the list of Agent Skills shared by the **x-cmd platform and community**.
2. Add professional skills to Claude Code: Once you identify the skills you need, use the `x claude skill use` command to quickly install from a remote repository or local path.

![4](/data-image/cookbook/mod/claude.1_4.webp)

> Important Reminder: After completing the installation, please be sure to restart Claude Code to ensure that the new Agent Skills are successfully loaded and activated.

For more information on `x claude skill`, please refer to the following article:
- [x claude skill - AI Agent Professional Skill Management](/mod/claude.md)

# `x claude ds` - No Claude Account Needed! Seamless Access to the DeepSeek AI Model

By default, using `x claude` launches the official model bound to Claude Code. However, you can switch to a domestic open-source/low-cost modelâ€”DeepSeek AI. DeepSeek is a Chinese AI company established in 2023, dedicated to providing low-cost, high-performance large language models. If you encounter access issues, latency, or high costs while using Claude Code in a domestic network environment, DeepSeek offers advantages in terms of access, cost, and localization.

## Get DeepSeek API Key

1. Visit the [DeepSeek Open Platform](https://platform.deepseek.com/api-keys) to register.

2. After registering your account, create a new key on the "API Keys" page. It is advisable to create different API Keys for different projects to facilitate management and usage tracking.

## Start Claude Code and Access DeepSeek Model

Once you have obtained your key, you can import it into x-cmd's configuration or enable it via environment variables.

* Sample configuration and startup:

```bash
# Configure DeepSeek API key
x deepseek init
# You can also configure the API Key for DeepSeek via x-cmd -> x deepseek --cfg apikey="<your_api>"

# Start Claude Code and access DeepSeek model
x claude ds
```

* Alternatively, use the environment variable approach:

```bash
export ANTHROPIC_AUTH_TOKEN="<your_deepseek_api_key>"
x claude ds
```

Once configured, Claude Code will use the DeepSeek model to handle your programming requests. The operation is almost identical to that of the native Claude model, and the entire proxy process and command line interaction logic remain the same, so there's no need to learn a new way to interact.

```

## Step 3: Start Claude Code!

Everything is set, and now it's time to witness the power of "the strongest from Blue Star."

# Start! Let Gemini 3.0 officially take over your Claude Code
x claude router code
```

# `x claude or` - Leveraging OpenRouter to Empower Claude Code with GPT-5.2

claude-code natively supports only the Claude series models. However, in some complex programming scenarios, we may wish to try OpenAI's **GPT-5.2** (or other cutting-edge models) to gain different reasoning perspectives or superior logical performance.

With the **`x claude or`** command provided by `x-cmd`, you can transform **OpenRouter** into a powerful relay hub, breaking down the original model barriers of claude-code. This means you can utilize top reasoning engines like GPT-5.2 without switching tools, directly through OpenRouter.

## Quick Setup: Initialize Environment

After obtaining the OpenRouter API Key, you can complete the environment initialization directly using the interactive command of `x-cmd`, without having to manually modify complex configuration files.

```bash
# Configure OpenRouter API key
x openrouter init
```

![1](/data-image/cookbook/mod/claude.4_1.webp)

- **Interactive Configuration**: The system will prompt you to enter the API Key you just obtained and to set up the use of the GPT-5.2 model.

- **Automatic Saving**: x-cmd will automatically save the key securely to global environment variables for subsequent calls to `x claude` and OpenRouter-related modules.

## Start and Run: Accessing GPT-5.2

Once configured, you can start Claude Code and access the GPT-5.2 model using the `x claude or` command.

```bash
# Start claude-code and access GPT-5.2 (or specified model) via OpenRouter
x claude or
```

## Frequently Asked Questions (FAQ)

### Q: How do I obtain the OpenRouter API Key?

1. Visit the [OpenRouter Open Platform](https://openrouter.ai/settings/keys) to register.
2. After registering, create a new key on the "API Keys" page. It is recommended to create different API Keys for different projects for easy management and tracking.

### Q: Will all functions of claude-code be available after accessing GPT-5.2?

Yes, all core functions of claude-code can be used normally after accessing GPT-5.2, including code understanding, code generation, refactoring, debugging assistance, command suggestions, and multi-turn dialogue, ensuring an overall experience consistent with natively supported models.

### Q: Will there be any delays when using OpenRouter integration?

There will be a slight increase (typically in the millisecond range) because requests need to go through OpenRouterâ€™s scheduling. However, in actual programming interactions, this delay is almost negligible compared to the time it takes for the model to generate code.

### Q: How can I check how much I have spent so far?

You can directly access the [OpenRouter Activity](https://openrouter.ai/activity) page to view the details of each request from `x claude or` and the associated costs.

### Q: What should I do if I encounter a â€œModel not foundâ€ error?

Please check if the model ID you set is correct. It is recommended to copy the complete ID from the [OpenRouter Model List](https://openrouter.ai/models) (e.g., `openai/gpt-5.2` or `google/gemini-3-flash-preview`).

# `x claude sess` â€“ Efficiently Manage Your Claude Code Session History

As you use Claude Code more frequently, a large number of session history files will accumulate locally. Many of these records are low-value or even undesirable: empty sessions, one-line test prompts, or sessions that may contain sensitive project information that should not be retained. Beyond disk usage, this clutter makes it much harder to resume real work with the `resume` commandâ€”while manually inspecting and deleting sessions one by one is both time-consuming and error-prone.

To address this, `x claude sess` provides a complete toolkit for working with Claude Code session history. With an **FZF-powered interactive interface**, you can quickly review past sessions and clean them up safely, keeping your development environment tidy and focused.

## Key Feature: Interactive Preview with FZF

`x claude sess` integrates the FZF terminal UI, allowing you to browse conversations interactively and see essential context at a glanceâ€”when a session occurred, which project it belongs to, and a short content preview.

**This is the best way to answer the question: â€œWhat exactly did I ask Claude to change last week?â€**

![1](/data-image/cookbook/mod/claude.6_1.webp)

Launch the interactive session browser with:

```bash
x claude sess
```

Once you locate the session youâ€™re interested in, simply select it and press Enter to open the action menu. From there, you can perform common operations without memorizing complex command-line options:

![2](/data-image/cookbook/mod/claude.6_2.webp)

* **Resume**: Restore the full context and continue where you left off.
* **View**: Open the session in fullscreen mode to read the entire conversation.
* **Delete**: Permanently remove an unnecessary or incorrect session.

## Keeping Things Clean: Session Cleanup

When too many historical sessions start to affect productivity, regular cleanup becomes essential. `x claude sess rm` offers a safe and flexible way to delete sessions.

### 1. Safe Preview (Dry Run)

Before deleting anything, you can inspect what would be removed to avoid accidental data loss:

```bash
# Show sessions that would be deleted, without actually deleting them
x claude sess rm --dry-run <session_id>
```

![3](/data-image/cookbook/mod/claude.6_3.webp)

### 2. Batch Deletion

You can delete multiple sessions at once by specifying their session IDs, making it easy to clean up large amounts of clutter in a single command:

```bash
x claude sess rm <session_id_1> <session_id_2> <session_id_3>
```

## Frequently Asked Questions (FAQ)

### Q1: Can I view all Claude Code history without entering a specific project directory?

Yes. Running `x claude sess ls -a` lists session history across all project paths on your machine. In FZF interactive mode, a global index is typically loaded as well (depending on your configuration), allowing you to search across projects seamlessly.

### Q2: How can I view the full content of an old session without deleting it?

If you donâ€™t need interactive search and simply want to print a sessionâ€™s contentâ€”for example, to copy it into documentationâ€”you can use the `cat` or `preview` commands:

* `x claude sess preview <session_id>`: Displays the conversation flow in a clean, human-readable format (what the user asked, how the assistant replied), ideal for quick review.
* `x claude sess cat <session_id>`: Outputs the raw session data in formats such as TSV or JSON, suitable for further processing (for example, token usage analysis or prompt pattern research).

| `--json`, `-j` | Output results in JSON format |

url: /mod/codex/cookbook-1.md

# `x codex` - No barriers to using Codex, connect to DeepSeek/Kimi/Zhipu with a single command and turn your terminal into an intelligent coding assistant instantly!

This guide will help you understand the common functions of x codex in a few minutes and quickly get started with OpenAI Codex, experiencing the powerful capabilities of an intelligent AI programming agent.

## 1. No Barriers! Automatic Installation and Launch of OpenAI Codex

**You do not need to install Codex manually**. When you run the x codex command, x-cmd will automatically check whether Codex is already installed in your environment.
If it is not installed, x-cmd will automatically download and configure it for you, requiring no manual intervention, no manual deployment of Node.js, or handling of dependency installations.

## 2. Free Switching of Models! Connect to AI models like ChatGPT, DeepSeek, Kimi, Zhipu, etc.

### Connect to ChatGPT Model

Codex defaults to using ChatGPT series models (e.g., gpt-5-codex, gpt-5, etc.). To use these models, you need to log in to your ChatGPT account or configure the API Key.

- Login methods: When you run x codex for the first time, the system will automatically prompt you to log in. You can choose either of the following methods:
    * ChatGPT account login: Suitable for ChatGPT Plus or Team subscription users. Just log in with your ChatGPT account, no additional configuration required.
    * API Key access: Suitable for developers and enterprise users. Charges are based on actual usage, providing higher concurrency and API call quotas.

![1](/data-image/cookbook/mod/codex.1_1.webp)

After logging in, your credentials will be automatically encrypted and stored locally. For subsequent uses, you will not need to log in again; the system will automatically retrieve the saved credential information.

### Connect to DeepSeek/Kimi Models

In addition to the ChatGPT series models, x codex also supports connecting other AI models as the backend for Codex.

For example, you can easily switch Codex to use the DeepSeek model:
```bash
x deepseek init
x codex ds
```

![2](/data-image/cookbook/mod/codex.1_2.webp)

After executing the above commands, Codex will automatically use the DeepSeek model for conversation and programming assistance. Similarly, you can connect other models such as Kimi and Zhipu as needed.

For more detailed methods of connecting models, please refer to the relevant documentation:
- [Connect to DeepSeek Model](/mod/codex/cookbook-2.md)

## 3. Expand AI Skills! Manage Codex Agent Skills with x-cmd

Codex officially supports the Agent Skills mechanism, allowing your Codex to handle specific complex tasks more effectively through extended Skills, such as writing technical documentation in compliance with brand guidelines, performing advanced data analysis, or reviewing code based on best practices. You can use the `skill` command of the `x codex` module to uniformly manage these Skills. Here are some common usage examples:

1. Query available professional skills (Skills): You can use the `x codex skill ll` command to query the list of Agent Skills shared by the **x-cmd platform and community**.
2. Add professional skills to Claude Code: After determining the needed skills, you can quickly install them from remote repositories or local paths using the `x codex skill use` command.

For more content on `x codex skill`, please refer to the following article:
- [x codex skill - AI Agent Professional Skills Management](/mod/codex.md)

url: /mod/codex/cookbook-2.md
---

# `x codex ds` - No need for a ChatGPT account! Zero threshold for connecting Codex to the DeepSeek AI model

By default, when using x codex, the ChatGPT series models are launched. However, you can also switch to domestic open-source/low-cost models â€” DeepSeek AI. DeepSeek is an AI company established in 2023 in China, dedicated to providing low-cost and high-performance large language models. If you experience access, latency, or high cost issues while using Codex in a domestic network environment, DeepSeek offers advantages in access, cost, and localization.

## Obtaining a DeepSeek API key

1. Visit the [DeepSeek open platform](https://platform.deepseek.com/api-keys) to register.

2. After registering your account, create a new key on the â€œAPI Keysâ€ page. It is recommended to create different API Keys for different projects to facilitate management and tracking of usage.

## Launching codex and connecting to the DeepSeek model

Once you obtain the key, you can import it into the x-cmd configuration or enable it via environment variables.

* Configuration and launch example:

```bash
# Configure Deepseek API key
x deepseek init
# You can also configure DeepSeek's API Key via x-cmd -> x deepseek --cfg apikey="<your_api>"

# Launch codex and connect to the DeepSeek model
x codex ds
```

* Alternatively, use the environment variable method:

```bash
export CODEX_API_KEY="<your_deepseek_api_key>"
x codex ds
```

After configuration is complete, codex will utilize the DeepSeek model to handle your programming requests. The working method is almost identical to the native ChatGPT model; the entire proxy process and command line interaction logic remain consistent, and you do not need to learn a new interaction method.

---
url: /mod/codex/cookbook-3.md
---

# `x codex zhipu` - Say Goodbye to ChatGPT Limitations, Enable Codex to Seamlessly Access the Zhipu GLM Model

By default, Codex uses the ChatGPT series of models (such as GPT-4, GPT-3.5). However, for domestic users, accessing ChatGPT may face network or account restrictions. At this point, you can choose to access the GLM series models provided by Zhipu AI.

Zhipu AI is one of the leading large model providers in the country, with its GLM models (such as GLM-4.5, GLM-4.5-Air, GLM-4.5-Flash, etc.) demonstrating outstanding performance in tasks like general understanding, code generation, and knowledge Q&A. By using the `x codex zhipu` command, you can switch Codex to the Zhipu models, allowing you to enjoy faster responses and lower network barriers in domestic environments (no need for VPNs or overseas accounts)!

## Get Zhipu API Key

1. Visit the [Zhipu AI Open Platform](https://bigmodel.cn/usercenter/proj-mgmt/apikeys) to register.

2. After registering your account, create a new key on the â€œAPI Keysâ€ page. It is advisable to create different API Keys for different projects to facilitate management and usage tracking.

## Start Codex and Access Zhipu AI Model

Once you have obtained your key, you can import it into x-cmd's configuration or enable it via environment variables.

* Sample configuration and startup:

```bash
# Configure Zhipu API key
x zhipu init
# You can also configure the API Key for Zhipu via x-cmd -> x zhipu --cfg apikey="<your_api>"

# Start Codex and access Zhipu AI model
x codex zhipu
```

* Alternatively, use the environment variable approach:

```bash
export CODEX_API_KEY="<your_zhipu_api_key>"
x codex zhipu
```

Once configured, Codex will use the Zhipu model to handle your programming requests. The functionality remains almost identical to that of the native ChatGPT models, and the entire proxy process and command line interaction logic remains the same, so thereâ€™s no need to learn a new way to interact.

url: /mod/codex/cookbook-4.md
---

# `x codex skill` - Aggregating community wisdom, enabling your AI assistant to instantly master parsing and automation capabilities.

**Skill** is an extension of the capabilities of an AI assistant. If we consider the large model as the "brain," then Skill is its "toolbox." Through the x codex skill command, you can quickly obtain ready-made skills (such as document parsing, code analysis, API calls, etc.) from the x-cmd community and seamlessly integrate them into your workflow.

## Discover Skills: Explore Community Wisdom

Before you begin, you can browse the pre-set skill library in the x-cmd community. These skills have been deeply optimized for various productivity scenarios.

```bash
# Query the list of community-shared Agent Skills
x codex skill ll
```

![1](/data-image/cookbook/mod/codex.4_1.webp)

- Identify Identifiers: The list will display identifiers such as anthropics/docx (Word parsing) or anthropics/frontend-design (frontend design), etc.

- View Details: You can quickly locate a suitable Skill for your current task through this command.

## Install Skills: Plug and Play

When you find a skill that meets your project needs, use the add command to achieve "one-click enhancement."

```bash
# Add the docx deep parsing skill to the current project
x codex skill add anthropics/docx
```

- Automated Operation: This command will automatically create a `.codex/skills` directory and download the related files for the anthropics/docx skill into it.
- Zero Configuration Loading: There is no need to modify any global configuration. When you run x codex, the AI will automatically scan this directory and "awaken" the relevant capabilities.

## Manage Skills: Keep Your Project Lightweight

As your project evolves, you may need to clean up or update your toolbox.

### View Installed Skills

Confirm what "superpowers" the AI has in the current project environment:

```bash
x codex skill ls
```

### Remove Unnecessary Skills

Keep your project tidy and avoid interference by having too many skills when the AI processes simple tasks:

```bash
x codex skill rm anthropics/docx
```

## Frequently Asked Questions (FAQ)

### Q: Can I customize skills?

Of course! You just need to create a folder under `.codex/skills` and write an execution script and SKILL.md.

### Q: Can I add skills directly from a GitHub URL?

The `x codex skill add` command is constantly evolving and will support adding skills directly through a GitHub URL or private Git repository address in the future.

# x coin - CoinCap Platform Information Viewer

The `x coin` module is a powerful command-line tool for conveniently accessing and viewing cryptocurrency information from the CoinCap platform.  Without cumbersome web browsing, you can get the data you need with simple commands.

**The coin module is currently unavailable. This is due to the unavailability of the Public API upon which it relies. We are actively seeking alternative solutions. We apologize for the inconvenience.**

## Quick Start

After installing `x-cmd`, you can use the `x coin` command directly. This module provides several ways to view CoinCap platform information: interactive application, CSV format, and JSON format.

### Interactive Application (`--app`)

Want to view data more intuitively? Use the `--app` parameter to launch the interactive application:

```bash
x coin --app
```

This application will provide a user-friendly interface for easily browsing real-time information on various cryptocurrencies.


### CSV Format (`--csv`)

If you need to import data into a spreadsheet or other data analysis tool, use the `--csv` parameter to export the data in CSV format:

```bash
x coin --csv > coin_data.csv
```

This will save the cryptocurrency information from the CoinCap platform to the `coin_data.csv` file.


### JSON Format (`--json`)

If you prefer JSON formatted data, use the `--json` parameter:

```bash
x coin --json
```

This will output the CoinCap platform's cryptocurrency information in JSON format, facilitating programmatic processing.


## Advanced Usage (Future Possible Support)

Future versions may add more advanced features, such as:

* **Filtering and Sorting:** Filter and sort cryptocurrency information based on specific criteria (e.g., market capitalization, price, etc.).
* **Customizable Fields:** Select the fields to display to reduce output information.
* **Data Update Frequency:** Customize the data update frequency to meet different needs.


## Error Handling and Prompts

The `x coin` module will try its best to handle various error situations and provide user-friendly prompts. For example, network connection failures or API request errors will have corresponding prompts.


## More Information

Visit our homepage for more information: [https://x-cmd.com](https://x-cmd.com)


We hope this brief introduction helps you quickly get started with the `x coin` module.  If you have any questions or suggestions, please feel free to contact us.

# x colr: Your Terminal Color Assistant

`x colr` is a powerful command-line tool for easily finding and using colors in your terminal. It supports multiple color systems, including 8-color, 256-color, and RGB, and provides various features to help you find the right color and display it in different ways.

## Quick Start

Using `x colr` is straightforward. The most basic usage is to simply run `x colr`, which will list all the color codes and their approximate colors in the 256-color palette.

```bash
x colr
```

Want to see the 8-color palette? Simply run:

```bash
x colr 8
```

## Finding Similar Colors

The power of `x colr` lies in its ability to find similar colors based on a provided color name or code. For example, to find colors similar to green:

```bash
x colr ls green
```

You can also use RGB color codes:

```bash
x colr rgb(0, 128, 0)  # or use hexadecimal #008000
```

Or, directly input the hexadecimal color code:

```bash
x colr #008000
```


## Advanced Usage: Rainbow Effect and Custom Ranges

`x colr` also supports generating rainbow-colored output and allows you to customize the color range and step:

```bash
x colr rainbow --min 100 --max 200 --step 50
```

This will generate a rainbow-colored output with a minimum RGB value of 100, a maximum RGB value of 200, and a step of 50. You can adjust the `--min`, `--max`, and `--step` parameters as needed. The `--color` parameter can specify the use of true color or 256 colors. The `--norand` parameter disables random color generation.


## Preset Color Schemes

`x colr` provides some preset color schemes, such as:

* `--blue`: Displays approximate colors of blue, cyan, and teal.
* `--pink`: Displays approximate colors of purple, pink, and magenta.
* `--purple`: Displays approximate colors of blue, purple, and magenta.
* `--red`: Displays approximate colors of red, maroon, and pink.
* `--yellow`: Displays approximate colors of yellow and orange.
* `--green`: Displays approximate colors of green, teal, olive, and bright green.
* `--gray`: Displays approximate colors of gray.
* `--black`: Displays approximate colors of gray and black.
* `--white`: Displays approximate colors of gray and white.


For example, to view approximate colors of red:

```bash
x colr --red
```


## Summary

`x colr` is a powerful color tool that helps you easily handle colors in your terminal. Whether you're looking for similar colors, generating rainbow effects, or using preset color schemes, `x colr` meets your needs, making your terminal more colorful. Try it out; you'll find it very useful in shell scripts and terminal applications.

# Can C Language Truly Achieve "Compile Once, Run Anywhere"? The Ultimate Solution for C Developers | Cosmopolitan

In modern software development, **cross-platform building and distribution** has always been a challenging pain point. While many languages and frameworks offer cross-platform capabilities, most require a sacrifice in performance or depend on a large runtime environment. C/C++, as a high-performance systems language, is irreplaceable in terms of low-level control and execution efficiency, yet when it comes to cross-platform building and distribution, it necessitates tedious multi-platform compilation and packaging processes.

**Cosmopolitan C Library** (referred to as Cosmopolitan or Cosmo) was born in this context. Developed by Justine Tunney, its goal is to allow C programs to be compiled into a special binary formatâ€”APE (Actually Portable Executable). This format enables files to run natively on **Windows, Linux, macOS, FreeBSD, OpenBSD, NetBSD, and even BIOS**, truly realizing "compile once, run anywhere."

## Core Values of Cosmopolitan

The main issues that Cosmopolitan addresses are as follows:

1. **Unified Distribution**: Developers only need to build one binary file that can run directly on multiple operating systems, reducing the cost of maintaining multi-platform build systems.
2. **Zero Dependency**: No virtual machine or interpreter is required; the generated files are native binaries, making them lighter and more efficient.
3. **Performance Assurance**: Compared to other libc implementations, Cosmopolitan employs vectorized optimizations in basic libraries such as string handling, allowing common CLI tools to achieve even higher performance.

## Running Cosmopolitan Applications

To lower the threshold for using Cosmopolitan, **x-cmd** provides the `x cosmo` module, which offers a unified capability to run, install, and manage applications compiled with Cosmopolitan. Compared to manually downloading and invoking APE files, `x cosmo` is closer to everyday usage habits, enabling users to quickly experience and manage Cosmo applications.

### 1. Basic Running

The simplest usage of `x cosmo` is to directly run an application compiled with Cosmopolitan. For example, running Lua:

```bash
x cosmo lua [arguments]
```

At this moment, if it's the first execution, the tool will automatically download the APE loader and cache it locally, running it directly thereafter. Users do not need to worry about the underlying binary format or compatibility issues.

You can also enter an interactive mode to select the program you want to run:

```bash
x cosmo
```

Once in the TUI interface, you can use the keyboard to select which Cosmo application to run.

### 2. Installation and Deployment

Different from simply running, `x cosmo` also supports installing programs to a specified directory or to PATH for long-term use.

* Install Lua to a specified directory:

  ```bash
  x cosmo -i lua ~/tools
  ```

  This way, the user can find the executable file for Lua under `~/tools`.

* Choose an installation directory in PATH and place `make`:

  ```bash
  x cosmo -i make
  ```

  The tool will interactively list all directories in PATH, allowing the user to select one, after which the program will automatically install `make` for immediate use.

This method is particularly suitable for team environments, enabling developers to quickly deploy a batch of commonly used tools in their development machines or container environments.

### 3. Global Environment Management

`x cosmo` provides functionalities similar to a package manager, allowing applications to be added or removed from the global environment.

* Add a tool to the global environment:

  ```bash
  x cosmo --use lua
  ```

* Cancel usage in the global environment:

  ```bash
  x cosmo --unuse lua
  ```

In this way, users can easily enable or disable specific applications system-wide without manually modifying PATH.

### 4. Program Location and Information Query

* Query the installation path of a certain application:

  ```bash
  x cosmo --which lua
  ```

* View all available applications interactively:

  ```bash
  x cosmo --ls
  ```

* List all supported Cosmo applications:

  ```bash
  x cosmo --ll
  ```

* View information about the author of Cosmopolitan:

  ```bash
  x cosmo --author
  ```

These features enable `x cosmo` to function both as a tool runner and as a "Cosmo application indexer," helping users quickly locate and understand applications.

### 5. Usage Scenario Examples

* **Quick Experience of Cross-Platform Applications**: New users only need to run `x cosmo <bin>` to experience a zero-dependency cross-platform program.
* **Team Development Environment**: Teams can use `x cosmo -i` to batch install tools (like `make`, `vim`, `lua`), avoiding inconsistencies caused by operating system differences.
* **Temporary Tool Usage**: For programs that are needed occasionally, users can activate globally using `x cosmo --use` and then deactivate with `x cosmo --unuse` to avoid environmental pollution.
* **Containers and CI/CD Environments**: When building container images or CI/CD pipelines, you can directly use `x cosmo` to install binaries, reducing dependency layers and increasing image lightweightness.

## Typical Application Scenarios

1. **Cross-Platform Distribution**
  The Cosmo applications compiled by developers can be handed directly to users, paired with `x cosmo` for management, eliminating the need to differentiate between operating systems and significantly reducing publishing and maintenance costs.

2. **Research and Education**
  Teachers can use `x cosmo` to quickly distribute experimental tools, ensuring that students achieve consistent execution results across different systems.

3. **Operations and Emergency Response**
  Operations personnel can swiftly install necessary tools (like `curl`, `vim`) on different platforms via `x cosmo`, without dealing with complex dependency issues, making it suitable for emergency situations.

# x ddgo - Your Smart Command-Line DuckDuckGo Search Tool

DuckDuckGo is favored by many users for its emphasis on privacy. The `x ddgo` command, as part of the `x-cmd` ecosystem, brings DuckDuckGo's search capability directly into your terminal, integrating the unique convenience and AI intelligence of `x-cmd`. This allows you to efficiently and precisely retrieve online information directly from the command line.

Whether you want quick research, technical investigation, or AI-assisted filtering and understanding of search results, `x ddgo` can be your reliable assistant.

## Basic Search: Get Information Instantly

The simplest use is very straightforward; just follow `x ddgo` with your search keywords.

```sh
x ddgo bash
```

![ddgo.1_1](/data-image/cookbook/mod/ddgo.1_1.webp)

After executing, `x ddgo` will connect to DuckDuckGo to perform the search. If your terminal is interactive, it will display search results in a clean, interactive â€œappâ€ interface, typically including titles, summaries, and links. If in a non-interactive environment (e.g., pipeline output), it defaults to output in YAML format.

![ddgo.1_2](/data-image/cookbook/mod/ddgo.1_2.webp)

The default interactive interface is very user-friendly, allowing you to browse results and perform further actions, such as opening links or copying content to the clipboard.

## Precise Result Control: `--top` Option

Sometimes, you may only need the most relevant few results rather than a large number. `x ddgo` offers the `--top` option, letting you specify how many search results you want.

For example, to get the top 10 results for "bash":

```sh
x ddgo --top 10 bash
```

![ddgo.1_3](/data-image/cookbook/mod/ddgo.1_3.webp)

This helps you focus on the most relevant information at the top, saving filtering time.

## AI-Enabled: Intelligent Filtering and Insights (`--ai`)

A major highlight of `x ddgo` is its integrated AI capability. Using the `--ai` option, you can involve AI in processing search results to evaluate relevance and generate summaries.

- When you run `x ddgo --ai <your query>`:
  1. `x ddgo` performs a standard DuckDuckGo search.
  2. It then passes the retrieved results to an AI model (like Gemini or OpenAI GPT).
  3. The AI analyzes each result, assigns a relevance score (1-5, 5 being highest), and generates a brief title (Headline) and comment explaining the score.
  4. These AI-enhanced results are then presented in an interactive table, sorted by AI relevance score by default, allowing you to quickly see the most relevant findings as judged by AI.

Try this command and feel the difference brought by AI:

```sh
x ddgo --ai bash
```

![ddgo.1_4](/data-image/cookbook/mod/ddgo.1_4.webp)

In the interactive table, you'll see each resultâ€™s AI evaluation, including the score, AI-generated title and comment, along with the original search result title, snippet, and link. This is extremely helpful for quickly filtering high-quality content from lots of information.

## Advanced Search and Formatting Output: `dump` and Output Options

The `x ddgo` `dump` subcommand (also the default action) performs the core task of executing a search and outputting results. Combined with specific search syntax and formatting options, it enables more advanced search needs.

For example, if you want to search for content about `jq` within a specific website `x-cmd.com` and output the results in JSON format:

```sh
x ddgo dump --json "site:x-cmd.com jq"
```

![ddgo.1_5](/data-image/cookbook/mod/ddgo.1_5.webp)

Here, `site:x-cmd.com` is a standard DuckDuckGo search syntax to limit the scope. The `--json` option specifies the output format.

Besides `--json`, `dump` supports various output formats to suit different scenarios:
*  `--yml`: Output in YAML format.
*  `--csv`: Output in CSV format.
*  `--raw`: Output the raw HTML/text data retrieved from DuckDuckGo (with initial parsing).
*  `--llm`: Output in a format suitable for directly inputting into large language models (LLMs), often including raw results and initial AI analysis (if combined with `--ai`).
*  `--app` (default when outputting to TTY): Display as an interactive TUI application.

You can also use `--nocache` to ensure fresh results are fetched from the network each time, bypassing local cache.

## Summary

`x ddgo` is more than just a simple DuckDuckGo command-line client; through deep integration with `x-cmd`, especially the AI capabilities, it provides a powerful, intelligent, and highly customizable command-line search experience. Whether for daily queries or deep information mining, `x ddgo` is well worth trying.

# x df - Your Disk Space Management Master

In everyday system administration on Linux or macOS, the `df` (disk free) command is a powerful tool for checking filesystem disk space usage. However, sometimes you want more than just how much space is used; you'd also like to understand the mount properties of these partitions. The `x df` command was created to do exactly thatâ€”it ingeniously combines the output of `df` and `mount`, offering a more comprehensive and readable view of disk information.

`x df` not only enhances information display but also supports various output formats, including an interactive TUI application, CSV, TSV, and the raw `df` output. Letâ€™s explore its powerful features together!

## Intelligent Default Experience: `x df`

When you run `x df` directly, it showcases its â€œintelligentâ€ side:

*  **If your output is connected to a terminal (TTY)**: It automatically launches a sleek text user interface (TUI) application. In this interactive interface, you can easily browse detailed information about each partition, including filesystem, type, total size, used space, available space, usage percentage, as well as critical information like **Mounted_path** and **Mounted_attr**.
*  **If your output is redirected to a file or piped**: It defaults to outputting in TSV (Tab-Separated Values) format, making it highly suitable for scripting or further text processing.

```sh
x df
```

![df.1_1](/data-image/cookbook/mod/df.1_1.webp)

The core advantage of this command is that itâ€™s not just a simple wrapper around `df`; it also executes `mount`, parses its output, and associates each partitionâ€™s mount options (like `rw`, `noatime`, `nodiratime`, etc.), so you have a clear understanding of partition characteristics.

**Header explanation:**
Different operating systems have slightly different headers to accommodate their specific `df` command features:
*  **Linux/Windows**: `Filesystem, Type, Size, Used, Avail, Use%, Mounted_path, Mounted_attr`
*  **macOS**: `Filesystem, Type, Size, Used, Avail, Capacity, iused, ifree, %iused, Mounted_path, Mounted_attr`

## CSV Format Output: `x df --csv`

For users who need to import disk information into spreadsheets (like Excel, Google Sheets, LibreOffice Calc) or use it as input for other data processing tools, CSV (Comma-Separated Values) format is undoubtedly the best choice.

Using `x df --csv`, you can easily obtain comma-separated disk partition information. Each line represents a partition, fields are separated by commas, and it also includes additional mount options provided by the `mount` command.

```sh
x df --csv
```

![df.1_2](/data-image/cookbook/mod/df.1_2.webp)

This makes data analysis and report creation straightforward.

## TSV Format Output: `x df --tsv`

TSV (Tab-Separated Values) is another popular plain-text data interchange format, especially favored in command-line tools and scripts because it handles fields with commas more robustly.

`x df --tsv` outputs disk information separated by tab characters. As mentioned, this is also the default output format when `x df` is used outside of a terminal environment.

```sh
x df --tsv
```

![df.1_3](/data-image/cookbook/mod/df.1_3.webp)

This format is ideal for further processing with Unix tools like `awk`, `cut`, `sort`, etc.

## Raw Data Output: `x df --raw`

Sometimes, you may need the most raw output from the system's `df` command, but with some basic organization such as sorting by filesystem name. The `x df --raw` option is designed for this purpose.

It runs the systemâ€™s built-in `df` command (on Linux typically `df -aTh`, on macOS `df -aYkh`, unless using the `--numeric` option), then sorts the output (excluding the header row).

```sh
x df --raw
```

![df.1_4](/data-image/cookbook/mod/df.1_4.webp)

This provides a clean, sorted view of the raw `df` data, useful for custom analysis or quick overviews.

---

By integrating `df` and `mount` information and offering flexible output options, `x df` greatly enhances our ability to view and manage disk space. Whether for interactive exploration, scripting automation, or data import and analysis, `x df` provides a convenient and efficient solution. Try it now and experience the difference it makes!

# x dingtalk - Sending Messages Using DingTalk Group Robot

## Initialization: Setting the Webhook URL

To start sending messages using the DingTalk group robot, you first need to obtain the Webhook URL. Follow these steps:

- In your DingTalk group, click the "..." button in the upper right corner.
- Select "Smart Group Assistant" -> "Add Robot".
- Choose "Custom Robot" and follow the prompts to complete the creation. After successful creation, you can find the webhook URL on the robot's details page.

After obtaining the Webhook URL, you can use the `init` command and paste the URL into the designated location to quickly complete the initialization configuration.

```sh
x dingtalk init
```

<!-- ![x dingtalk init](/data-image/cookbook/mod/dingtalk.init.webp)  *(needs to be replaced with an actual screenshot)* -->
**image demo**

Alternatively, you can add the Webhook URL by running the following command:

```sh
x dingtalk --cfg webhook=<webhook_URL>
```

## Sending Simple Text Messages

After completing the initialization configuration, you can easily send messages to the group chat by simply specifying the message type and content.

```sh
x dingtalk send --text "x-cmd New version released successfully"
```

<!-- ![x dingtalk send --text](/data-image/cookbook/mod/dingtalk.1_1.webp)  *(needs to be replaced with an actual screenshot)*
![text](/data-image/cookbook/mod/dingtalk.1_2.webp)  *(needs to be replaced with an actual screenshot)* -->
**image demo**


## Sending Markdown Messages

If you want to send messages in a more formatted way, you can use Markdown format.

```sh
x dingtalk send --markdown --title "x-cmd New Version Released" "## âœ…  x-cmd New version v1.0.0 released successfully <at>æ‰€æœ‰äºº</at>\nUsers who have installed **x-cmd**, please upgrade using `x upgrade`!\n>Website: [https://x-cmd.com](https://x-cmd.com)\n>Github: [github.com/x-cmd/x-cmd](https://github.com/x-cmd/x-cmd)"
```

*(Note: DingTalk's Markdown syntax may be slightly different from other platforms.  `@æ‰€æœ‰äºº` needs to use `<at>æ‰€æœ‰äºº</at>` or similar syntax)*

<!-- ![x dingtalk send --markdown](/data-image/cookbook/mod/dingtalk.2_1.webp)  *(needs to be replaced with an actual screenshot)*
![markdown](/data-image/cookbook/mod/dingtalk.2_2.webp)  *(needs to be replaced with an actual screenshot)* -->
**image demo**


## Sending Link Messages

DingTalk also supports sending link messages, allowing users to quickly access related resources.

```sh
x dingtalk send --link \
  --title "x-cmd Website" \
  --url "https://x-cmd.com" \
  --picurl "https://codeberg.org/curry798/tea/raw/branch/main/og.png" \
  --text "Welcome to the x-cmd website!"
```

<!-- ![x dingtalk send --link](/data-image/cookbook/mod/dingtalk.3_1.webp)  *(needs to be replaced with an actual screenshot)*
![link](/data-image/cookbook/mod/dingtalk.3_2.webp)  *(needs to be replaced with an actual screenshot)* -->
**image demo**


## Sending Rich Text Messages (ActionCard)

DingTalk's rich text messages are usually presented in the form of ActionCard, which can include interactive elements such as buttons.

```sh
x dingtalk send --sing_action \
  --title "x-cmd New Version Released" \
  --text "x-cmd has released a new version, upgrade now!" \
  --btn "View Details" "https://x-cmd.com"
```

*(This shows a single-button ActionCard; you can also use `--multi_action` to send a multi-button ActionCard)*

<!-- ![x dingtalk send --richtext](/data-image/cookbook/mod/dingtalk.4_1.webp)  *(needs to be replaced with an actual screenshot)*
![richtext](/data/image/cookbook/mod/dingtalk.4_2.webp)  *(needs to be replaced with an actual screenshot)* -->
**image demo**


## Sending Messages Using Different Group Robots

`x dingtalk` also supports sending messages using different group robots. Similar to `x qywx`, you can use the `--webhook` parameter to temporarily specify the webhook URL, or manage multiple robots through a configuration file. (The configuration file content is similar to qywx; refer to the qywx section).


Using the above steps, you can easily use `x dingtalk` to send various types of messages to your DingTalk group. Remember to replace the image paths in the examples with actual valid image links.

# x discord - Sending Messages with a Discord Bot

## Initialization: Setting the Webhook URL

To start sending messages using a Discord bot, you first need to obtain a Webhook URL. Follow these steps:

- In your Discord server, locate the channel where you want to send messages.
- Click the gear icon (Settings) in the top right corner of the channel.
- Select "Webhooks" from the left-hand menu.
- Click "Create Webhook".
- Set a name and avatar (optional) for your Webhook, then click "Create".
- You will see the generated Webhook URL.

After obtaining the Webhook URL, use the `init` command and paste the URL into the designated location to quickly complete the initialization configuration.

```sh
x discord init
```

You can also add the Webhook URL by running the following command:

```sh
x discord --cfg webhook=<webhook_URL>
```

## Sending Simple Text Messages

After completing the initialization configuration, you can easily send messages to the Discord channel by simply specifying the message content.

```sh
x discord send --text "x-cmd New version released successfully!"
```

<!-- ![x discord send --text](/data-image/cookbook/mod/discord.1_1.webp)  *(Replace with actual screenshot)*
![text](/data-image/cookbook/mod/discord.1_2.webp)  *(Replace with actual screenshot)* -->
**discord image demo**


## Sending Embedded Messages (Cards)

Discord supports richer message types, such as embedded messages (Cards), which can include titles, descriptions, images, fields, and more.

```sh
x discord send --card \
  --username "x-cmd Bot" \
  --avatar_url "https://example.com/avatar.png" \
  --title "New Version Released!" \
  --description "x-cmd New version v1.0.0 released successfully!" \
  --url "https://x-cmd.com" \
  --color 16711680  # Red
```

<!-- ![x discord send --card](/data-image/cookbook/mod/discord.2_1.webp)  *(Replace with actual screenshot)*
![card](/data-image/cookbook/mod/discord.2_2.webp)  *(Replace with actual screenshot)* -->
**discord image demo**

## Sending Files

You can use the `--file` parameter to send local files to the Discord channel.

```sh
x discord send --file --file_path ./my_image.png
```
<!-- ![x discord send --file](/data-image/cookbook/mod/discord.3_1.webp)  *(Replace with actual screenshot)* -->
**discord image demo**

## Sending Messages with Different Bots

`x discord` allows you to send messages using different bots as needed.

### Using the `--webhook` Parameter

If you want to temporarily use a different bot's Webhook URL, use the `--webhook` parameter.

```sh
x discord send --text --webhook <webhook> "A test"
```

<!-- ![x discord send --webhook](/data-image/cookbook/mod/discord.4_1.webp)  *(Replace with actual screenshot)* -->
**discord image demo**


### Using Configuration Profiles

You can also manage different Discord bots using configuration profiles.
First, create a profile named `mybot` and save the specified `<webhook>` to this profile:

```sh
x discord --cfg set --profile mybot webhook=<webhook>
```

Then, you can use the Webhook URL configured in the `mybot` profile to send messages:

```sh
# The `:` prefix is used to specify the profile to use
x discord :mybot send --text "A test"
```

<!-- ![x discord :mybot](/data-image/cookbook/mod/discord.5_1.webp)  *(Replace with actual screenshot)*
![mybot](/data/image/cookbook/mod/discord.5_2.webp)  *(Replace with actual screenshot)* -->

**discord image demo**

This allows you to quickly switch to other bots without modifying the global configuration.
