# x dnf - Enhance Your Fedora/CentOS Package Management Experience

For users of Fedora or CentOS (and other RPM-based distributions), `dnf` is an essential tool for daily package management. The `x dnf` command provides a series of enhanced features on top of native `dnf`, aiming to simplify common operations, improve efficiency, and enhance user experience, especially in scenarios with poor network conditions or when frequently switching mirror sources.

<Terminal demo="/mod/dnf.en.json" size="large" />

## Interactive Exploration: Easily Discover and Install Packages

Tired of the workflow of `dnf search` followed by `dnf install`? `x dnf` offers a powerful interactive interface that allows you to search for, view information about, and install software packages all in one view.

Simply enter the following in your terminal:

```bash
x dnf
```

By default, `x dnf` will launch a fuzzy search interface based on `fzf` (if your system has `fzf` installed). You can directly type keywords to filter the package list.

<!-- **(Screenshot: Showcases the interactive UI provided by x dnf, allowing users to search for applications and install them through the UI)** -->

In this interface:

1. **Real-time Search**: Begin typing characters to filter the package list in real-time.
2. **Preview Information**: When selecting a package, the right window shows the output of `dnf info`, allowing you to quickly learn about the package details.
3. **Select an Operation**: After pressing Enter to select a package, a menu will pop up allowing you to choose the next action:
  * **Install**: Install the selected package.
  * **Reinstall**: Reinstall the selected package.
  * **Info**: View the package's detailed information again.
  * **Browse Repo**: Open the package's page on the Fedora Packages website in your browser.
  * **dnf --help**: View the help for native dnf.
  * **EXIT**: Exit.

This interactive interface significantly simplifies the process of finding and installing new software, especially when you are unsure of the exact package name.

## Convenient Mirror Management

Accessing the official Fedora/CentOS repositories from within China can sometimes be slow. Switching to domestic mirrors is a common optimization method. `x dnf` makes this process exceedingly simple.

### View Available Mirrors

`x-cmd` comes pre-configured with several commonly used domestic mirrors. You can use the following command to list them:

```bash
x dnf mirror ls
```

The output will look like this:

```
Code  Url  Name
ali  https://mirrors.aliyun.com  Alibaba Cloud Mirror
huawei  https://mirrors.huaweicloud.com  Huawei Cloud Mirror
tuna  https://mirrors.tuna.tsinghua.edu.cn  Tsinghua University Mirror
ustc  https://mirrors.ustc.edu.cn  University of Science and Technology of China Mirror
bfsu  https://mirrors.bfsu.edu.cn  Beijing Foreign Studies University Mirror
```

Here the mirror code (Code), URL, and name are listed.

### One-click Switch Mirror

Want to switch to the Alibaba Cloud mirror? Just execute:

```bash
x dnf mirror set ali
```

`x dnf` will automatically perform the following actions:

1. **Backup**: Back up the current `/etc/yum.repos.d/fedora.repo` and `/etc/yum.repos.d/fedora-updates.repo` files (in case you need to restore them).
2. **Modify Configuration**: Modify the repository configuration files, comment out the `metalink` line, and enable and modify the `baseurl` to point to the corresponding address of the Alibaba Cloud mirror.
3. **Permission Handling**: If the current user does not have permission to modify the configuration files directly, `x dnf` will prompt and use `sudo` to perform the modifications.
4. **Refresh Cache**: Automatically execute `dnf clean all` and `dnf makecache --refresh` to clear old cache and apply the new mirror source.

Similarly, you can replace `ali` with `tuna`, `huawei`, or any other code listed in `x dnf mirror ls` to switch to the corresponding mirror.

## Summary

`x dnf` is a powerful assistant to the native `dnf`, significantly enhancing the efficiency and convenience of package management on Fedora/CentOS systems by providing an interactive package browser and extremely simplified mirror management. Whether looking for software quickly or optimizing download speed, `x dnf` can save you a lot of time and effort. Try `x dnf` now and experience a smoother package management process!

# x dns - Domain Name System (DNS) Manager

The `x dns` module provides a set of convenient command-line tools for managing your Domain Name System (DNS) configuration information. You can use simple commands to view the current DNS configuration, list available DNS addresses, and flush the DNS cache.

## Viewing Current DNS Configuration Information

Use the `x dns` or `x dns current` command to quickly view the current system's DNS configuration information:

```bash
x dns
```

or

```bash
x dns current
```

This command will display information such as the DNS server addresses currently being used by your system.


## Listing Available DNS Addresses

Use the `x dns ls` command to list all available DNS addresses in the system:

```bash
x dns ls
```

This command displays the results in a table format by default. You can use the following parameters to output the results in different formats:

* `--json`: Output results in JSON format.
* `--yml`: Output results in YAML format.
* `--csv`: Output results in CSV format.

For example, to output the results in JSON format:

```bash
x dns ls --json
```


## Flushing the DNS Cache

Use the `x dns refresh` command to flush the system DNS cache:

```bash
x dns refresh
```

This action ensures that your system uses the latest DNS records.


## Setting DNS Configuration Information (TODO)

Currently, the `x dns set` command is under development.  Future versions will support the functionality to set DNS configuration information.


## More Information

Please visit our homepage for more information: [https://x-cmd.com](https://x-cmd.com)


## Examples

Here are some examples of `x dns` commands and their output results (output results may vary depending on the system):

**(Assuming the system currently uses 8.8.8.8 and 8.8.4.4 as DNS servers)**

**`x dns` or `x dns current`:**

```
Current DNS Servers:
  8.8.8.8
  8.8.4.4
```

**`x dns ls`:**

```
+-----------------+-----------------+
| Name            | Address          |
+-----------------+-----------------+
| Google Public DNS | 8.8.8.8         |
| Google Public DNS | 8.8.4.4         |
| ...             | ...              |
+-----------------+-----------------+
```

**`x dns ls --json`:**

```json
[
  {
    "Name": "Google Public DNS",
    "Address": "8.8.8.8"
  },
  {
    "Name": "Google Public DNS",
    "Address": "8.8.4.4"
  },
  // ...
]
```


**(Note: The above example output is for reference only. The actual output may vary depending on your system configuration.)**

# x docker alpine

Alpine based application sandbox


::: info
Main Objectives:
- Rapid Application Execution: To quickly run nearly 30,000 applications available in the Alpine apk package manager, as well as a vast number of applications from ecosystems like Go, Rust, Node/Deno/Bun, and pip. The first run will build a local image on demand, while subsequent runs will use the cache, improving efficiency.
- Application Sandboxing: To provide an isolated runtime environment, ensuring application security and preventing impact on the host system.



Future Plans:
- Adapt to container runtimes such as Podman
- Integrate tools like x-cmd, pixi, adsf, and pkgx in a suitable manner to expand functionality
:::

::: tip
This feature is in an experimental testing phase. It may be unstable and subject to significant changes in future releases.
:::


## Examples

Run typeinc to test your typing speed and accuracy

```sh
xd alp typeinc
```

Use Google's official gemini-cli tool to interact with the Gemini model via the command line

```sh
xd alp --pwd -e GEMINI_API_KEY="YOUR_API_KEY" gemini
```

Lookup ASN and routing information for bing.com

```sh
xd alp asn -n bing.com
```

Analyze registration status and availability of multiple domains

```sh
xd alp tldx x-cmd.com github.com xcmd-test.com
```

Run firework to enjoy beautiful fireworks in your terminal (uses cargo in container to fetch and build from firework-rs project)

```sh
xd alp cargo/firework-rs:firework
```

Pipe ASCII character info in YAML format into yq for processing

```sh
x ascii --yml | xd alp yq
```

```sh
x docker alpine|alp [SUB_COMMAND] <#1>
```

| [x docker alpine ps](#x-docker-alpine-ps) | View containers created by "x docker alpine" (those prefixed with xal-) |

| `--publish`, `--port`, `-p` |  | Map port, format &lt;host_port&gt;:&lt;container_port&gt; |
| `--network`, `--net` |  | Specify network (e.g., bridge, host, custom network name) |
| `--env`, `-e` |  | Set environment variable, format &lt;VAR&gt;=&lt;VALUE&gt; |

| Name, Shorthand | Description |
| ------- | ------- |

| `--daemon`, `-d` | Run container in daemon mode, suitable for long-running tasks (requires --name) |
| `--dind` | Enable Docker-in-Docker (run Docker inside container) |
| `--home` | Mount home directory (~) to container |
| `--priv` | Run in privileged mode (required for some system tools or dind) |
| `--pwd` | Mount current directory and set workdir to /p (useful for development) |
| `--root`, `-r` | Run as root user (equivalent to --user root) |

# x docker Usage Guide - Boost Container Management with Terminal & GUI Integration

In modern development and operations workflows, Docker is one of the core infrastructures. To enhance the efficiency and readability of daily operations, the `x docker` command encapsulates the native Docker commands, providing a more unified, interactive, and adaptable experience for multiple scenarios.

This guide will introduce four core commands in `x docker`:

* `x docker ps`: List currently running containers
* `x docker images`: View pulled images
* `x docker fz`: Filter and manipulate containers or images through an interactive interface
* `x docker lz`: Monitor container status and log output in a structured view

By integrating use cases, interaction features, and design philosophies, this guide aims to help you improve efficiency and reduce costs in daily Docker container managementâ€”whether you are a developer, tester, or operations personnel, you will benefit from it.

To reduce repetitive input and improve operational efficiency, `x docker` provides a default alias of `xd` and command completion support. You can quickly complete subcommands and parameters by pressing the Tab key in the interactive terminal, reducing the memory burden. In the subsequent examples, we will use the shorthand alias `xd` to illustrate each command's functions and interactions.

## I. Information Retrieval Commands: `xd ps` and `xd images`

These two commands are the most commonly used basic operations by Docker users. In `x docker`, they not only retain their original semantics but also automatically switch display modes based on terminal environments: if the terminal supports interactive interfaces (like TTY), it will display container or image information in TUI format; if in a script or plain text environment, it will automatically fallback to structured CLI output, compatible with automation tasks.

### `xd ps`

![1](/data-image/cookbook/mod/docker.1_1.webp)

**Function**: Lists currently running containers on the system.

**Characteristics (interactive mode)**:

* Supports scrolling up and down through the container list;
* Displays key information like container name, image, status, port, etc.;
* Quickly fuzzy searches and enters container detail view;
* Opens an operation menu for exec, stop, inspect, etc.

### `xd images`

![2](/data-image/cookbook/mod/docker.1_2.webp)

**Function**: Lists all local Docker images on the current host.

**Characteristics (interactive mode)**:

* Image ID, Repository, Tag, size are all clearly visible;
* Allows quick searches, comparing image sizes and versions;
* Supports entering the image detail interface or operation menu to execute delete, run, etc.

### Example Scenarios

* When you need to quickly locate the status of a service container;
* To confirm before batch cleaning unused images;
* To maintain consistent output behavior in CI/CD, remote debugging, and other non-UI environments.

This automatic adaptation mechanism embodies one of the core philosophies of `x docker`: **Automatically switch between interactive and plain-text modes based on the environment, accommodating human operations and scripting automation.**

## II. Core Interactive Command: `xd fz`

`xd fz` is the most interactive and efficient command in the `x docker` toolkit, implemented using the `fzf` developed TUI interface, integrating image and container management functions, providing unified browsing, fuzzy searching, previewing, and operational capabilities, making it a high-frequency tool for daily use.

### Function Overview

* ðŸ“¦ Supports switching between image and container views (shortcut: `tab` or `ctrl-s`);
* ðŸ” Real-time preview of the selected item's `docker inspect` output (can wrap/zoom/hide);
* âŒ¨ï¸ Rich shortcuts, supporting fuzzy search and quick operations;
* ðŸ“œ Operation menu includes: enter container, view logs, delete image, run container, etc.

### Shortcut Key Overview

| Shortcut Key  | Function Description  |
| ---------------- | ---------------------------- |
| `tab`/`ctrl-s`  | Switch between container and image views |
| `enter`  | Open the operation menu  |
| `ctrl-w`  | Toggle preview window wrapping |
| `ctrl-r`  | Toggle preview window size/hide |
| `â†‘ / â†“`  | Select up/down  |

### Usage

```bash
x docker fz
```

![3](/data-image/cookbook/mod/docker.1_3.webp)

Default enters the container view, and you can switch to the image view using the shortcut `ctrl-s`.

![4](/data-image/cookbook/mod/docker.1_4.webp)

### Recommended Use Cases

* Quickly locating target resources when managing a large number of containers and images;
* When you remember the container name or port but not the container ID;
* To directly complete operations like start, stop, delete in the command line without leaving the interface;
* If you need to view detailed container information or image metadata for update decisions.

### Why Choose It?

Compared to `xd ps` or `xd images`, `fz` provides a more complete interactive experience, enabling a wider range of daily operations without the need for a GUI, making it suitable for intermediate to advanced users.

## III. Terminal Graphical Interface: `xd lz`

`xd lz` calls the [lazydocker](https://github.com/jesseduffield/lazydocker) command. Lazydocker is a full terminal graphical tool for managing containers, images, networks, volumes, and other Docker resources.

Execution method:

```bash
xd lz
```

This is equivalent to directly running:

```bash
lazydocker
```

![5](/data-image/cookbook/mod/docker.1_5.webp)

### Features

* Displays modules like containers, images, networks, logs in split-screen;
* Supports log viewing, status monitoring, and resource analysis;
* Intuitive operations suitable for beginners and users accustomed to graphical interfaces.

### Suitable Scenarios

* Observing container operation logs or resource usage;
* Debugging container network problems;
* Comprehensive monitoring of multi-module resources.

The difference with `xd fz` is that `lz` emphasizes "continuous observation" and "full-stack perspectives," making it suitable for users who require more comprehensive status feedback.

## IV. Summary: How to Combine Commands?

`x docker` provides complete capability coverage from command line to interactive interface, to graphical interface. Depending on different needs and terminal environments, you can choose flexibly:

| Command  | Main Purpose  | Recommended Scenarios  |
| ------------------ | ---------------------------- | ------------------------------------------- |
| `x docker ps`  | View container status  | Quickly obtaining running containers, used in scripts |
| `x docker images`  | View local images  | Image cleaning, version comparison, text filtering |
| `x docker fz`  | Efficient interactive resource management | Daily primary tool for heavy container users |
| `x docker lz`  | Graphical view and management | Log observation, state diagnosis, visual resource scheduling |

Based on actual workflows, hereâ€™s some suggestions:

* **Daily interaction operations**: It is recommended to use the interactive interface provided by `x docker fz` for quickly browsing and managing container resources.
* **Batch queries and cleanup tasks in scripts**: It is recommended to use `x docker ps/images` for automated processing.
* **State monitoring and log analysis scenarios**: Utilize `x docker lz` to quickly review operating status and container logs, improving diagnostic efficiency.

Through the `x docker` toolset, we not only improve the efficiency of container resource management but also unify the operational entry points and enhance terminal interaction experiences. This aligns with the core goal of `x-cmd`: **Do more things with fewer commands; maintain consistent operating experiences across more environments.**

# Run Any CLI Tool Safely in a Sandbox with One Command | x docker alpine snap

In modern development workflows, developers often face the dilemma of needing to temporarily use a CLI tool but being deterred by complex installation steps, numerous dependencies, or the potential pollution of the local environment. To address this pain point, the `x docker alpine snap` mechanism has emerged. It is based on Docker and Alpine and provides a lightweight container environment that allows users to quickly start applications as if they were running local commands, without the need for tedious installations and without polluting the host system.

This article will delve into its usage, applicable scenarios, design philosophy, and operational principles through specific examples.

**Important Note: `x docker snap` is not related to or affected by Ubuntu Snapcraftâ€™s `snap`.**

## 1. What is `x docker alpine snap`

The `snap` mechanism allows you to quickly and easily run specific applications in `x docker`. Its core principle is to use a very small base image (like the 5MB Alpine) and leverage its official `apk` repository to build and run the required application images locally.

In `x docker`, the command format is as follows:

```bash
x docker alpine snap <app>
```

You can omit `snap`, as it is the default subcommand of `x docker alpine`; additionally, `x docker` provides a default alias `xd`; `alp` is an abbreviation for the alpine subcommand; thus, we also have:

```bash
xd alp <app> [args...]
```

## 2. Usage Examples

### 1. Typing Speed Test: `typeinc`

```bash
xd alp typeinc
```

![1](/data-image/cookbook/mod/docker.2_1.webp)

This is a shortcut to run [typeinc](https://github.com/AnirudhG07/typeinc), a simple and elegant command-line typing test tool. By default, it will pull the latest version from the apk repository, build a local image, and run it in a brand new Alpine container sandbox.

Thereâ€™s no need to install Python locally or configure a build environment, and you wonâ€™t have to worry about the reliability and security of new software; you can start using it in just seconds.

### 2. IP Ownership Query: `asn`

```bash
xd alp asn -n bing.com
```

![2](/data-image/cookbook/mod/docker.2_2.webp)

This is an ASN query tool based on [ipinfo.io](https://ipinfo.io). The `asn` command can resolve domains or IP addresses to their associated Autonomous System (AS) information, including organization name, AS number, geographical location, etc.

This tool is included in the Alpine official `apk` repository, and `x-cmd` will directly download `asn` from that source and use it to build the application image.

### 3. Isolated AI Assistant, Safeguarding Privacy

```bash
xd alp --pwd -e GEMINI_API_KEY="YOUR_API_KEY" gemini
```

![3](/data-image/cookbook/mod/docker.2_3.webp)

[gemini-cli](https://github.com/mrgnr/gemini-cli) is an open-source command line AI assistant released by Google, allowing you to interact conversationally with Googleâ€™s Gemini language model (such as Gemini 2.5 Pro) via the terminal. It offers natural language interaction capabilities, including chatting, file analysis, code generation, and debugging assistance.

Running Gemini CLI through the x docker snap method ensures that all operations occur in an isolated Alpine container, completely independent from the local system with no persistent traces. Additionally, by using the `--pwd` parameter, the container only mounts the current working directory, facilitating AI access to context files within the current project (such as code and documentation) while effectively preventing access to other directories, maximizing user privacy and data security.

This method is particularly suitable for using AI in sensitive environments, such as handling proprietary data or in restricted networks, ensuring minimal privilege execution with no residue left after the operation.

### 4. Play the Classic Roguelike Game - NetHack

```bash
xd alp nethack
```

![4](/data-image/cookbook/mod/docker.2_4.webp)

[NetHack](https://www.nethack.org/) is an open-source dungeon exploration game that originated in 1987 and is regarded as the foundation of the Roguelike genre. It is known for its high degree of freedom and complex item and event system, unfolding gripping dungeon adventures within an ASCII character interface.

Running `nethack` using `x docker snap` allows you to:

* Instantly obtain a well-configured NetHack environment;
* Avoid installing ncurses, graphical front ends, or complex dependencies in the system;
* Experience 1980s black-and-white character-style dungeon adventures within a pure terminal interface.

This low-barrier, high-nostalgia approach is perfect for developers, gaming enthusiasts, or nostalgic players wishing to try it out quickly.

### 5. Celebrate with Fireworks: `firework` (A Cargo Usage Example)

```bash
xd alp cargo/firework-rs:firework
```

![5](/data-image/cookbook/mod/docker.2_5.webp)

This is an example of running the Rust project [firework-rs](https://github.com/felko/firework-rs) through the `snap` mechanism, which simulates colorful fireworks animation in the terminal.

Although this project has not yet been included in the `install` system of `x-cmd`, it remains incredibly convenient to use it within `docker snap` by simply specifying `cargo/firework-rs:firework`:

* `x-cmd` will use the community `cargo` image to pull the `firework-rs` project from GitHub;
* It will automatically compile and run the binary named `firework` within it.

This combination of Docker + Snap is excellent for trying out exciting small projects from the Rust community without configuring a toolchain or a Cargo environment.

## 3. The Operational Principles and Process of `x docker alpine snap`

The core operational principles and processes of the `snap` mechanism are as follows:

* **Image Reuse and Lightness:** All applications run on a unified `x-cmd/alpine` base image, which is extremely small and downloads quickly.
* **On-Demand Pulling and Compilation:** When executing commands in the `cargo/<project>` format, `snap` will automatically pull the corresponding Rust project source code from GitHub and compile and run it within the container.
* **Intelligent Caching Mechanism:**
  * The compiled binary files will be cached in the local Docker image layer to ensure that subsequent runs start almost instantaneously;
  * Leverage Docker's image-building caching mechanisms so that tools like `cargo` and `npm` do not need to download repeatedly; users also do not need to worry about introducing intermediate image layers;
  * `x-cmd` will attempt to retain `apt`, `dnf`, `apk`, and other package manager caches when constructing images, thereby maximizing the reuse of already downloaded packages.
* **Environment Isolation:** Each run occurs in a standalone, clean container environment, effectively avoiding pollution and state residuals on the host system.
* **Dynamic Command Injection:** The entry point of the container dynamically assembles execution logic based on the commands input, truly realizing the ability to "run once."

This method cleverly combines the advantages of container lightness, minimalism of Alpine, and security isolation while hiding the complexity of building and dependencies, allowing users to try any CLI tool in seconds.

**Comparison with Official and Third-Party Images**

1. Most software does not have or maintain its own official Docker images;
2. We first thank the contributors of third-party images. However, using third-party images often requires additional security checks. In contrast, `x docker snap` builds application images based on a base image and the official software sources of Linux distributions, ensuring transparency and security.

**Optimizations for China**

1. For package managers like `apt`, `apk`, and `dnf`, `x-cmd` will automatically switch to domestic mirror sources like TUNA, Alibaba Cloud, etc., to ensure the best user experience and download speeds.
2. In mainland China, the base image downloads occur through AWS ECR, effectively avoiding the slow download issues from the Docker official image repository.

It should be noted that AWS ECR only provides basic Linux distribution container images for download and is not a complete Docker image source.

## 4. Image Management for `x docker alpine snap`

After running multiple `x docker alpine` commands, you might accumulate some temporary images locally. In this case, you can use:

```bash
xd alp fz
```

![6](/data-image/cookbook/mod/docker.2_6.webp)

This command will list all the container images created by `x docker alpine` and supports quick searching, cleaning, sorting, etc. It is based on `fzf` and provides a smooth interactive experience.

Applicable scenarios:

* View which `snap` tools are currently in use;
* Clean up unused `snap` images;
* Fine management of Alpine container environments created during development.

## 5. Review of Design Philosophy

As an efficient tool distribution mechanism, the core design philosophy of `snap` can be summarized as follows:

* **Instant Use:** No complicated setup; run simply by typing the command;
* **No Residue:** By default, it doesnâ€™t write any files to the host machine, completely avoiding environmental pollution;
* **Minimal Dependencies:** Based on Alpine + BusyBox, the container size is extremely light;
* **Universal Support:** Can broadly support projects written in Rust, Go, Python, and other languages;
* **Shell Environment Adaptability:** Automatically forwards signals and intelligently identifies pipeline operations, adjusting command behavior to ensure seamless integration with the Shell environment.

In a sense, it redefines the process of â€œtrying out a CLI toolâ€: users no longer need to manually `clone`, `install`, or sift through application images; just one command is all it takes to get a sandboxed, securely sourced solution.

## 6. Conclusion: Enjoy the Alpine Software Application Sandbox

In `x-cmd`, we provide a `pkg` system that allows users to use a series of powerful tools without special privileges; combined with the efforts of open-source companies and communities, we have also integrated a range of advanced software management systems like [pixi](/mod/pixi.md), [asdf](/mod/asdf.md), [cosmo](/mod/cosmo.md).

Today, through [docker snap](/mod/docker/snap.md), the nearly ten thousand software packages from official Alpine, Ubuntu, Kali, and other software sources can be transformed into convenient, safe, and reliable application usage solutions; furthermore, leveraging `cargo`, `pip`, `go`, `npm`, and other tools, one can quickly and safely **try out** the latest version of an application in a container sandboxâ€”all without installing additional dependencies or polluting the local environment.

# x docker daemon

Manages the Docker daemon, allowing configuration of proxies, registry sources, and restarts.


::: info
This command modifies the /etc/docker/daemon.json file to configure the docker daemon, so it uses the sudo module to run.
:::


## Examples

Set the docker mirror to "https://docker.m.daocloud.io"

```sh
x docker daemon mirror set https://docker.m.daocloud.io
```

View the configuration mirror

```sh
x docker daemon mirror info
```

Set the daemon proxy to 127.0.0.1:7070

```sh
x docker daemon proxy set 127.0.0.1:7070
```

Unset daemon proxy

```sh
x docker daemon proxy unset
```

| Name | Description |
| ------- | ------- |

| [x docker daemon restart](#x-docker-daemon-restart) | Restarting the Docker daemon is a high-stakes maneuver; any running or paused containers will be brought down. |

# x docker debian

Debian based application sandbox


::: tip
This feature is in an experimental testing phase. It may be unstable and subject to significant changes in future releases.
:::


## Examples

Run typeinc to test your typing speed and accuracy

```sh
xd deb typeinc
```

Use Google's official gemini-cli tool to interact with the Gemini model via the command line

```sh
xd deb --pwd -e GEMINI_API_KEY="YOUR_API_KEY" gemini
```

Lookup ASN and routing information for bing.com

```sh
xd deb asn -n bing.com
```

Analyze registration status and availability of multiple domains

```sh
xd deb tldx x-cmd.com github.com xcmd-test.com
```

Run firework to enjoy beautiful fireworks in your terminal (uses cargo in container to fetch and build from firework-rs project)

```sh
xd deb cargo/firework-rs:firework
```

Pipe ASCII character info in YAML format into yq for processing

```sh
x ascii --yml | xd deb yq
```

## Usage

```sh
x docker debian|deb [SUB_COMMAND] <#1>
```

## Arguments

| Argument | Description |
| ------- | ------- |
| `#1` | Available commands of the software |


## Sub Commands

| Name | Description |
| ------- | ------- |
| [x docker debian image](#x-docker-debian-image) | Manage images created by "x docker debian" (images prefixed with xde-) |
| [x docker debian ps](#x-docker-debian-ps) | View containers created by "x docker debian" (those prefixed with xde-) |
| [x docker debian fz](#x-docker-debian-fz) | Interactive Docker management interface powered by fzf, allowing quick access to containers and images |
| [x docker debian snap](#x-docker-debian-snap) | Run the specified package. If the image is not available locally, it will be built automatically |


### x docker debian image

Manage images created by "x docker debian" (images prefixed with xde-)


- **Sub Commands**:


| Name | Description |
| ------- | ------- |
| [x docker debian image ls](#x-docker-debian-image-ls) | List images |
| [x docker debian image exist](#x-docker-debian-image-exist) | Check if a specific Docker image exists |
| [x docker debian image id](#x-docker-debian-image-id) | Retrieve the image ID of a specific Docker image |
| [x docker debian image lsid](#x-docker-debian-image-lsid) | List the image IDs of all local Docker images |


### x docker debian image ls

List images


- **Usage**:


### x docker debian image exist

- **Examples**:


- **Usage**:

```sh
x docker debian|deb image|img exist <#1>
```

- **Arguments**:


| Argument | Description |
| ------- | ------- |
| `#1` | Image name (e.g., alpine:latest). If no tag is given, defaults to "latest". |


### x docker debian image id

Retrieve the image ID of a specific Docker image


- **Examples**:

Get the image ID of alpine:latest

```sh
x docker image id alpine:latest
```

- **Usage**:

```sh
x docker debian|deb image|img id <#1>
```

- **Arguments**:


| Argument | Description |
| ------- | ------- |
| `#1` | Image name (e.g., alpine:latest). If no tag is given, defaults to "latest". |


### x docker debian image lsid

List the image IDs of all local Docker images


- **Usage**:

```sh
x docker debian|deb image|img lsid
```

### x docker debian ps

View containers created by "x docker debian" (those prefixed with xde-)


- **Usage**:

```sh
x docker debian|deb ps [FLAGS]
```

- **Flags**:


| Name, Shorthand | Description |
| ------- | ------- |
| `--app` | List Docker containers using an interactive table |
| `--csv` | Output in CSV format |
| `--json` | Output in JSON format |


### x docker debian fz

Interactive Docker management interface powered by fzf, allowing quick access to containers and images



::: tip
- ctrl-w: Toggle preview line wrapping
- ctrl-r: Change preview size or hide it
- ctrl-s/tab: Switch view (images/containers)
- enter: Open action menu
:::


- **Sub Commands**:


| Name | Description |
| ------- | ------- |
| [x docker debian fz img](#x-docker-debian-fz-img) | Interactively browse and select local Docker images for actions like run or remove |
| [x docker debian fz ps](#x-docker-debian-fz-ps) | Interactively list running containers and perform common actions like exec, stop, or inspect |


### x docker debian fz img

Interactively browse and select local Docker images for actions like run or remove


- **Usage**:

```sh
x docker debian|deb fz img
```

### x docker debian fz ps

Interactively list running containers and perform common actions like exec, stop, or inspect


- **Usage**:

```sh
x docker debian|deb fz ps
```

### x docker debian snap

Run the specified package. If the image is not available locally, it will be built automatically


- **Usage**:

```sh
x docker debian|deb snap [OPTIONS] [FLAGS] <#1>
```

- **Arguments**:


| Argument | Description |
| ------- | ------- |
| `#1` | Available commands of the software |


- **Options**:


| Name, Shorthand | Default | Description |
| ------- | ------- | ------- |
| `--name`, `-n` |  | Specify container name |
| `--image`, `--img` |  | Specify full image name |
| `--volume`, `-v` |  | Mount volume, format &lt;host_path&gt;:&lt;container_path&gt; |
| `--publish`, `--port`, `-p` |  | Map port, format &lt;host_port&gt;:&lt;container_port&gt; |
| `--network`, `--net` |  | Specify network (e.g., bridge, host, custom network name) |
| `--env`, `-e` |  | Set environment variable, format &lt;VAR&gt;=&lt;VALUE&gt; |
| `--user` |  | Specify user to run the command in container (format: uid[:gid]) |


- **Flags**:


| Name, Shorthand | Description |
| ------- | ------- |
| `--nocache` | Disable cache volume mount between host and container |
| `--daemon`, `-d` | Run container in daemon mode, suitable for long-running tasks (requires --name) |
| `--dind` | Enable Docker-in-Docker (run Docker inside container) |
| `--home` | Mount home directory (~) to container |
| `--priv` | Run in privileged mode (required for some system tools or dind) |
| `--pwd` | Mount current directory and set workdir to /p (useful for development) |
| `--root`, `-r` | Run as root user (equivalent to --user root) |

# x docker mirror

Configure the default mirror and pull images from either this source or a specified one

## Examples

Set "docker.m.daocloud.io" as the default mirror for pull image

```sh
x docker mirror set "docker.m.daocloud.io"
```

Pull the image from the default mirror

```sh
x docker mirror pull hello-world
```

## Sub Commands

| Name | Description |
| ------- | ------- |
| [x docker mirror pull](#x-docker-mirror-pull) | Provide a method to download images from the image source without modifying the Docker Daemon. |
| [x docker mirror set](#x-docker-mirror-set) | Setting the default mirror for pull image |
| [x docker mirror unset](#x-docker-mirror-unset) | Unset mirror |
| [x docker mirror get](#x-docker-mirror-get) | Get the currently set default mirror |


### x docker mirror pull

Provide a method to download images from the image source without modifying the Docker Daemon.



::: info
Principle: First, download the image from a mirror site, then modify the tag (for example, download codeberg.org/x-cmd/alpine:latest, then change it to alpine:latest).

If you need to modify the Docker proxy and image source, you can use `x docker daemon proxy` or `x docker daemon mirror`.
:::


- **Examples**:

Pull the image kali-rolling:latest from the codeberg.org/x-cmd

```sh
x docker mirror pull -m codeberg.org/x-cmd kali-rolling:latest
```

Set the docker mirror to https://docker.m.daocloud.io

```sh
x docker daemon mirror set https://docker.m.daocloud.io
```

Set "docker.m.daocloud.io" as the default mirror for `x docker mirror pull`

```sh
x docker mirror set "docker.m.daocloud.io"
```

- **Usage**:

```sh
x docker mirror pull [OPTIONS] <#1>
```

- **Arguments**:


| Argument | Description |
| ------- | ------- |
| `#1` | image path |


- **Options**:


| Name, Shorthand | Default | Description |
| ------- | ------- | ------- |
| `--mirror`, `-m` |  | mirror url |


### x docker mirror set

Setting the default mirror for pull image


- **Usage**:

```sh
x docker mirror set
```

### x docker mirror unset

Unset mirror


- **Usage**:

```sh
x docker mirror unset
```

### x docker mirror get

Get the currently set default mirror


- **Usage**:

```sh
x docker mirror get
```

# x emoji - Your Command Line Emoji Assistant

Still annoyed about typing or searching for specific emojis in the command line? Or want to know which category a particular emoji belongs to? The `x emoji` command is your trusted helper! It not only allows you to browse and search through a huge collection of emojis effortlessly but also makes it easy to use them in scripts or documents. Plus, it can keep your local emoji library synchronized with the Unicode standard.

Letâ€™s quickly get started with the core features of `x emoji` through some simple and practical examples!

## Interactive Exploration: Your Personal Emoji Encyclopedia

Sometimes, you just want to browse interesting emojis or find one based on a rough idea. The simplest way is to launch the interactive `x emoji` application.

Just enter in your terminal:

```sh
x emoji
```

![emoji.1_1](/data-image/cookbook/mod/emoji.1_1.webp)

This command will launch a full-screen, interactive emoji viewer. You can:
*  Navigate through different emojis using the up and down arrow keys.
*  View each emojiâ€™s character, description, and category.
*  Usually, this interactive app supports search features (triggered by `/` key), allowing you to quickly locate emojis.

Itâ€™s like having an always-up-to-date, handy emoji dictionary â€” very visual and convenient.

## Precise Search: Filter by Category and Subcategory

If you have a more specific target emoji in mind, such as belonging to the â€œSmileys & Emotionâ€ category under the â€œFace Smilingâ€ subcategory, the `x emoji ls` command can help you find it precisely.

For example, to find all emojis under the â€œSmileys & Emotionâ€ category in the â€œFace Smilingâ€ subcategory, you can run:

```sh
x emoji ls smileys face-smiling
```

![emoji.1_2](/data-image/cookbook/mod/emoji.1_2.webp)

This command will list all emojis matching both criteria. Itâ€™s very useful for quickly locating a set of related emojis, such as when you're adding a themed set of emojis to an article or script comments.

## Data Export: CSV Format for Further Processing

`x emoji` not only allows viewing emojis but also enables exporting results in various formats, making them ready for additional processing. CSV (Comma-Separated Values) is a common tabular data format that can be easily imported into spreadsheet software or parsed with scripts.

To export the previous search result (for â€œsmileysâ€ category and â€œface-smilingâ€ subcategory) as CSV, simply add the `--csv` option:

```sh
x emoji ls smileys face-smiling --csv
```

![emoji.1_3](/data-image/cookbook/mod/emoji.1_3.webp)

Each line contains information about an emoji, including description, the emoji character itself, subcategory, main category, Unicode code point, status, and Unicode version. You can easily import this data into spreadsheets or use scripts to analyze or utilize the emojis.

## Keep Your Library Up-to-Date: Updating Your Emoji Resources

The world of emojis is constantly evolving, with new emojis being added periodically by the Unicode standard. To ensure that your `x emoji` command uses the latest emoji list, you should regularly update your local emoji data package.

Updating is very simple:

```sh
x emoji update
```

This command will download the latest emoji data files from official or mirror sources (like `unicode.org` or its mirrors). Itâ€™s recommended to run this regularly so you can access all the newest and coolest emojis!

---

With these `tldr` examples, you now grasp the core usage of the `x emoji` command. Whether itâ€™s quick browsing, precise searching, data exporting, or keeping your library current, `x emoji` provides a powerful and convenient emoji solution for CLI users. Now go ahead and try these commands in your terminal â€” add more fun and color to your command line experience!

# x env (1) - Interactive Search and Installation of Software Tools

## Interactive Search and Installation of Software Tools

The `x env` module is a development environment and dependency management tool built upon the `x-cmd pkg` system. It can be used to install and manage over `500` software tools without requiring `root` privileges.

Execute the following command to open the interactive app, allowing you to easily search and install the tools and dependencies you need.

```sh
x env
```

<!-- [image] Showing x env's interactive app -->
![x env --app 1](/data-image/cookbook/mod/env.1_1.webp)
<!-- [image] Showing x env's next step shortcut menu -->
![x env --app 2](/data-image/cookbook/mod/env.1_2.webp)

- Within the interactive app:
    - **Left column**: Displays the categories and package names of software tools, such as `lang/python`, `lang-js-ts/node`, `data-line/fzf`, etc.
    - **Middle column**: Shows the available versions of the selected software tool, helping users choose the appropriate version to install.
    - **Right column**: Provides relevant information about the software, including a brief introduction, official website link, open-source license, etc., to help users quickly understand the software details.
    - After selecting the software and pressing Enter, a shortcut menu for the next step will be provided, such as installing and using the software.


## Installing and Using a Specific Software Tool

Use the `x env use` command to install software globally. Whether you restart the terminal or start a new session, the software will be activated and ready to use.

If you need to use a specific version of the software, you can specify the version number in the command. For example, to install and use `python`:

```sh
x env use python
x env use python=v3.11.0+23.11.0-1
```

<!-- [image] Showing the process of installing python using x env use python -->
![x env use](/data-image/cookbook/mod/env.1_3.webp)

## Removing a Specific Software Tool from the Global Environment

If you want to remove a software from the global environment, you can use the `x env unuse` command. For example, to remove `python` from the global environment:

```sh
x env unuse python
```

<!-- [image] Showing the output of the x env unuse python command -->
![x env unuse](/data-image/cookbook/mod/env.1_4.webp)

## Installing and Using a Specific Software Tool Only in the Current Environment

Sometimes you might want to try new software or new versions without affecting your global environment configuration.

For example, to try `fzf` and version `v23.9.0` of `node`:

```sh
x env try fzf node=v23.9.0
```

<!-- [image] Showing the process of installing and using software with the x env try command -->
![x env try](/data-image/cookbook/mod/env.1_5.webp)

Software or versions installed in this way will only be effective in the current session. After closing the terminal or exiting the current session, they will be automatically removed, making them ideal for development testing or temporary tasks.

---
[More] For more information about the env module, please visit the x-cmd official website - x-cmd.com/mod/env

url: /mod/env/cookbook-2.md
---

# x env (2) - Managing and Upgrading Software Tools

## Upgrading Installed Software

`x env` simplifies software management. If you need to upgrade installed software tools to access new features or fix known issues, use the `x env upgrade` command.

For example, to upgrade `deno`:

```sh
x env upgrade deno
x env upgrade deno=v2.2.2
```

<!-- [image] x env upgrade output -->
![x env upgrade](/data-image/cookbook/mod/env.2_1.webp)

## Viewing Globally Enabled Software Tools

For easy viewing of software tools installed using `x env use`, `x env ls` provides an interactive app by default in interactive environments.

```sh
x env ls
```

<!-- [image] Showing x env ls interactive app -->

# x env upgrade

Same as 'x env use --upgrade' -&gt; Upgrade the version of the specified package used in the user environment, defaulting to the 'default' version

## Examples

Upgrade all packages used in the user environment to the default version

```sh
x env upgrade --all
```

Upgrade the jq, yq, and fzf packages used in the user environment to the default version

```sh
x env upgrade jq yq fzf
```

## Usage

```sh
x env upgrade [OPTIONS] [FLAGS] [SUB_COMMAND] <#n>
```

## Arguments

| Argument | Description |
| ------- | ------- |
| `#n` | Package and its version, format: &lt;package_name&gt;[=&lt;version_to_upgrade&gt;] |


## Options

| Name, Shorthand | Default | Description |
| ------- | ------- | ------- |
| `--sphere` |  | sphere name |
| `--sphereroot` |  | sphere root path |
| `--osarch` |  | The system and CPU architecture that the package matches, in the format &lt;os&gt;/&lt;arch&gt;, such as linux/x64. If not specified, the system and CPU architecture of the current environment will be used. |


## Flags

| Name, Shorthand | Description |
| ------- | ------- |
| `--default` | Upgrade to the default version (the latest stable version, relatively) |
| `--latest` | Upgrade to the latest version (which may be less stable and not recommended for use) |
| `--force` | After upgrading, enforce the recycling mechanism for the old version |


## Sub Commands

| Name | Description |
| ------- | ------- |
| [x env upgrade --all](#x-env-upgrade-all) | Upgrade the versions of all packages used in the global environment |


### x env upgrade --all

Upgrade the versions of all packages used in the global environment

```sh
x env upgrade --all
```

# x feishu - Sending Messages Using Feishu Group Bot

## Initialize Configuration, Set Webhook URL

To start sending messages using the Feishu group bot, you first need to obtain the Webhook URL. Follow these steps:

- In your Feishu group, click the "..." button in the upper right corner.
- Select "Add Bot".
- Choose "Custom Bot".
- After successful creation, you can find the webhook URL on the bot details page (note: select the `v3` version of the bot).


After obtaining the Webhook URL, you can use the `init` command and paste the Webhook URL into the specified location to quickly complete the initialization configuration.

```sh
x feishu init
```

<!-- ![x feishu init](/data-image/cookbook/mod/feishu.init.webp)  *(Replace with actual screenshot)* -->
**image demo**

Alternatively, you can add the Webhook URL by running the following command:

```sh
x feishu --cfg webhook=<webhook_URL>
```

## Sending Simple Text Messages

After completing the initialization configuration, you can easily send messages to the group chat by simply specifying the message type and content.

```sh
x feishu send --text "x-cmd New version released successfully"
```

<!-- ![x feishu send --text](/data-image/cookbook/mod/feishu.1_1.webp)  *(Replace with actual screenshot)*
![text](/data-image/cookbook/mod/feishu.1_2.webp)  *(Replace with actual screenshot)* -->
**image demo**

## Sending Rich Text Messages

The Feishu bot supports sending rich text messages, including text, images, and links.

```sh
x feishu send --richtext \
   --title "Demo of feishu"  \
   --text "Welcome to x-cmd's website for details." \
   --url "website" "https://x-cmd.com/mod/feishu"
```

<!-- ![x feishu send --richtext](/data-image/cookbook/mod/feishu.3_1.webp)  *(Replace with actual screenshot)*
![richtext](/data-image/cookbook/mod/feishu.3_2.webp)  *(Replace with actual screenshot)* -->
**image demo**

## Sending Image Messages

You can send image messages using `image_key`.  `image_key` needs to be obtained through the Feishu image upload interface.

```sh
x feishu send --image --image_key <image_key>
```

<!-- ![x feishu send --image](/data/image/cookbook/mod/feishu.image.webp) *(Replace with actual screenshot)* -->
**image demo**

## Sending Shared Group Card Messages

You can share group cards to the Feishu group.

```sh
x feishu send --share_chat --chat_id <chat_id>
```

<!-- *(Explain how to obtain `chat_id` here)* ![x feishu send --share_chat](/data-image/cookbook/mod/feishu.share_chat.webp) *(Replace with actual screenshot)* -->
**image demo**

## Sending Messages Using Different Group Bots

`x feishu` can select different group bots to send messages as needed.

### Using the `--webhook` Parameter

If you want to temporarily use the Webhook URL of another group bot, you can use the `--webhook` parameter.

```sh
x feishu send --text --webhook <webhook> "A test"
```

<!-- ![x feishu send --webhook](/data-image/cookbook/mod/feishu.4_1.webp)  *(Replace with actual screenshot)* -->

**image demo**

### Using Configuration File Profile

You can also manage different group bots through a configuration file.
First, create a Profile named `xbot` and save the specified `<webhook>` to this Profile:

```sh
x feishu --cfg set --profile xbot webhook=<webhook>
```

Then, you can use the Webhook URL configured in the `xbot` Profile to send messages:

```sh
# The `:` prefix is used to specify the Profile to use
x feishu :xbot send --text "A test"
```

<!-- ![x feishu :xbot](/data-image/cookbook/mod/feishu.5_1.webp)  *(Replace with actual screenshot)*
![xbot](/data-image/cookbook/mod/feishu.5_2.webp)  *(Replace with actual screenshot)* -->
**image demo**

In this way, you can quickly switch to other bots without modifying the global configuration.


**(Remember to replace all `/data-image/cookbook/mod/feishu.*.webp` with the actual image paths and filenames)**

# x fjo cl

shortcut for `x fjo repo clone`

## Usage

```sh
x fjo cl [OPTIONS] [FLAGS] <#1> <#2>
```

## Arguments

| Argument | Description |
| ------- | ------- |
| `#1` | &lt;ownerPath&gt;/&lt;RepoPath&gt; (default ownerPath: current user) |
| `#2` | directory |


## Options

| Name, Shorthand | Default | Description |
| ------- | ------- | ------- |
| `-o`, `--origin` &lt;name&gt; |  | use &lt;name&gt; instead of 'origin' to track upstream |
| `-b`, `--branch` &lt;branch&gt; |  | checkout &lt;branch&gt; instead of the remote's HEAD |
| `-u`, `--upload-pack` &lt;path&gt; |  | path to git-upload-pack on the remote |
| `-j`, `--jobs` &lt;n&gt; |  | number of submodules cloned in parallel |
| `--separate-git-dir` &lt;gitdir&gt; |  | separate git dir from working tree |
| `--depth` &lt;depth&gt; |  | create a shallow clone of that depth |


## Flags

| Name, Shorthand | Description |
| ------- | ------- |
| `--recursive` | initialize all contained submodules |
| `--shallow-submodules` | any cloned submodules will be shallow |

# `x font` -- Font Installation and Terminal Beautification

We frequently receive inquiries regarding garbled characters in terminals and how to display symbols like Powerline icons or various programming-related glyphs. If you've encountered these issues, the `x font` module is designed specifically for you.

The primary purpose of the `x font` module is to offer a swift and convenient solution for installing [Nerd Fonts](https://www.nerdfonts.com/) and [Noto Fonts](https://fonts.google.com/noto). This module addresses several key challenges:

1.  **Automated Installation:** It assists users by automatically identifying the appropriate method (e.g., `brew`, `apt`, or direct download) to globally install fonts based on the user's system and requirements.
2.  **China Region Optimization:** For users in China, we have prioritized specific installation methods and download sources to mitigate potential network issues, ensuring smooth font download and installation.
3.  **Terminal Beautification:** By installing Nerd Fonts, which incorporate a vast collection of icon glyphs, your terminal, Terminal User Interface (TUI) applications (such as Neovim, tmux, lazygit, etc.), and various prompts (like Oh My Posh, Starship) will correctly display a wide range of icons and symbols, eliminating "tofu blocks" (missing character boxes) and garbled text.

## Bid Farewell to Garbled Text, Embrace a Beautiful Terminal

In modern development environments, an aesthetically pleasing and powerful terminal is crucial for enhancing both efficiency and user experience. Many popular terminal tools, plugins, and themes (such as Oh My Posh, Starship, Neovim plugins, Powerline, etc.) rely on specific fonts to render various icons, symbols, and ligatures. Without proper terminal font configuration, you might encounter:

*   **Garbled Characters or "Tofu Blocks":** Specific characters fail to display, appearing as empty squares or question marks.
*   **Missing Icons:** Attractive icons within prompts or tools do not render.
*   **Poor Typography:** Code ligatures do not function, negatively impacting code readability.

The `x font` module was created to resolve these very issues.

## What Are Nerd Fonts?

![nerd-fonts](/data-image/cookbook/mod/font.1_1.webp)

[Nerd Fonts](https://www.nerdfonts.com/) is a project that merges popular programming fonts (such as Fira Code, JetBrains Mono, Hack, Cascadia Code, etc.) with an extensive collection of icon glyphs. These icon glyphs are sourced from numerous popular icon libraries, including:

*   **Font Awesome**
*   **Devicons**
*   **Octicons**
*   **Powerline Symbols**
*   **Material Design Icons**
*   ...and many more!

By installing Nerd Fonts, your terminal gains the ability to display these rich icons, making your command-line interface more intuitive and visually appealing.

## What Are Noto Fonts?

[Noto Fonts](https://fonts.google.com/noto) are a family of fonts developed by Google, designed to support all languages worldwide and eliminate "tofu blocks" (the square boxes that appear when a font does not support a particular character). Among these, the **Noto Color Emoji** font is particularly crucial for correctly displaying full-color Emoji symbols in the terminal, especially when handling text that includes Chinese, Japanese, Korean, and other characters.

## `x font` Command Details

The `x font` module aims to simplify the font installation process, abstracting away the underlying mechanisms like `brew` or `apt`, and eliminating the need for manual downloading and unzipping.

### TLDR (Quick Start)

Enable `fzf` interactive TUI selection and download fonts

```sh
x font i
```

Considering the icons and ligatures required for terminal usage and the beautification of common TUI applications, we highly recommend using **Fira Code Nerd Font**.

```sh
x font install nerd/FiraCode
# or
x font nerd installl FiraCode
```

### Core Subcommand

*   **Install Fonts (`install` / `i`)**

    This is the most frequently used `x font` command, employed to install a specified Nerd Font.

    ```sh
    x font install nerd/<font_name>
    # Examples:
    x font i nerd/FiraCode         # Installs Fira Code Nerd Font (Recommended)
    x font i nerd/CascadiaCode     # Installs CaskaydiaCove Nerd Font
    x font i nerd/JetbrainsMono    # Installs JetBrains Mono Nerd Font
    x font i nerd/CascadiaCode     # Installs Cascadia Code Nerd Font
    ```

    1. `x font` will automatically detect your operating system and select the download source ([GitHub](https://github.com/ryanoasis/nerd-fonts/releases), [Codeberg](https://codeberg.org/x-cmd-sourcecode/nerd-fonts/releases))
    2. Install to the corresponding system directory
    3. Use `fc-cache` to refresh the font directory cache so that the system or apps can recognize the added fonts


*   **List Nerd Fonts (`nerd` / `nerd ls`)**

    If you are unsure which Nerd Fonts are available for installation, you can use this command to view the supported list.

    ```bash
    x font nerd
    ## Or
    x font nerd ls
    ```

    Executing this command will list all Nerd Fonts, enable `fzf` interactive TUI to preview font information, and allow you to select a font to download

<!-- *   **List Noto Fonts (`noto` / `noto ls`)**

    While `x font` primarily focuses on the automated installation of Nerd Fonts, it also addresses the needs for Noto fonts. You can use this command to view relevant information or installation options for Noto fonts (if `x font` directly supports automated Noto installation).

    ```bash
    x font noto
    ## Or
    x font noto ls
    ```
    *Note: Currently, `x font` primarily handles Nerd Fonts via system package managers or direct downloads. For fonts like Noto Color Emoji, they are typically included with the system or installed through the system's package manager. `x font` ensures that your system environment has robust support for these fonts.* -->

*   **Get Help (`-h` / `--help`)**

    If you forget a command or wish to see more options, you can always use the help command.

    ```bash
    x font -h
    ```

    You will clearly see a series of TLDRs and detailed explanations, from which you can choose.

## Important Note

After installing the font to the system, <u>you still need to apply the font to specific terminals and editors</u>. Different editors have different configuration methods. We have collected some of these methods; please see [the next chapter](/mod/font/cookbook-2.md).

## Common Issues and Troubleshooting

*   **Garbled Characters or "Tofu Blocks":**
    *   **Cause:** The most common reason is that the terminal emulator is not configured to use a Nerd Font, or the installed font is not a Nerd Font version.
    *   **Solution:** Ensure you have installed a Nerd Font using `x font` and have correctly configured your terminal emulator as per the instructions above, selecting a font name ending with "Nerd Font."
*   **Icons Not Displaying:**
    *   **Cause:** Similar to the above, the terminal is not configured to use a Nerd Font, or the icon set configured in your tool (e.g., Oh My Posh) does not fully match the Nerd Font you have installed.
    *   **Solution:** Verify that your terminal font configuration is correct. If issues persist, check your tool's configuration to ensure that the icon set it uses is included in your Nerd Font.
*   **Network Issues Causing Download Failure:**
    *   **Cause:** Although `x font` includes optimizations for networks in China, occasional network fluctuations may still occur.
    * **Solution:** Try running the `x font install` command again. If the problem persists, check your network connection or try manually downloading the font files from the [Nerd Fonts official website](https://www.nerdfonts.com/font-downloads) and installing them (although this will lose the convenience of `x font`).

## Recommended Fonts

* **Fira Code Nerd Font:**
    * **Recommendation:** Excellent readability, beautiful ligature features (e.g., `->` displays as an arrow), and broad community support and usage. It is a preferred programming font for many developers.
    * `x font nerd install FiraCode`
* **CaskaydiaCove Nerd Font:**
    * **Recommendation:** [Cascadia Code](https://github.com/microsoft/cascadia-code) is a monospaced programming font designed by Microsoft specifically for developers and is the default font in Windows Terminal. It offers excellent readability and aesthetics. Caskaydia Cove is a Nerd Fonts repackaged version based on this font, adding numerous programming symbols and icons (such as Powerline, development tools, and file type icons), making it more practical and visually clear in terminals and editors.
    * `x font nerd install CascadiaCode`
* **JetBrains Mono Nerd Font:**
    * **Recommendation:** Designed specifically for developers, featuring unique glyphs and excellent readability. It also supports ligatures and is another very popular choice.
    * `x font nerd install JetbrainsMono`
* **NotoSansM Nerd Font:**
    * **Recommendation:** Ensures your terminal can correctly display full-color Emoji, avoiding black-and-white or missing emoji.
    * `x font nerd install Noto`

## Summary

The `x font` module significantly simplifies the installation process for Nerd Fonts and Noto Fonts, particularly addressing network download challenges for users in China. With simple commands, you can inject new vitality into your terminal, eliminating garbled characters and missing icons, and enjoying a truly aesthetic and efficient development environment.

Start now and make your terminal a pleasure to behold!

# A Crucial Step After Font Installation: Configuring Terminal Emulators and Editors

**Important Note:** Merely installing a font onto your system (for example, using the `x font install` command) does not automatically mean your terminal emulator or code editor will use it! You must manually configure these applications to instruct them to use your newly installed font, especially for fonts like Nerd Font which include special symbols.

Below are examples of configuration methods for common terminal emulators and code editors:

## VS Code Integrated Terminal

1.  Navigate to Settings in the bottom-left corner.
2.  In the search bar, type `terminal.integrated.fontFamily`.
3.  Set its value to the name of your installed Nerd Font, for example, `"FriaCode Nerd Font"`.
4.  Next, search for `terminal.integrated.fontLigatures` and check this option to enable font ligatures (if supported by the font).

or add a JSON configuration item

```json{2}
{
  "terminal.integrated.fontFamily": "FiraCode Nerd Font"
}
```

## Windows Terminal (Windows)

1.  Open Terminal settings using the shortcut <kbd>Ctrl</kbd> + <kbd>,</kbd>.
2.  Select 'Defaults' --> Click to modify 'Appearance' --> Choose your desired font under the 'Font face' section --> Click 'Save'.
    ![terminal_font.win](/image/terminal_font.win.1.webp)
2.  Alternatively, in the left navigation bar, select the `Profile` you wish to configure (e.g., `PowerShell`, `CMD`, `WSL`).
3.  Or, access and edit the `settings.json` file via the "Open JSON File" button in the bottom-left of the `Settings` interface:
    ```json{4-6}
    {
      "profiles": {
        "defaults": {
          "font": {
              "face": "FiraCode Nerd Font Mono"
          }
        }
      }
    }
    ```

## iTerm2 (macOS)

1.  Open Terminal settings using the shortcut <kbd>âŒ˜</kbd> + <kbd>,</kbd>.
2.  Navigate to `Profiles` -> `Text`.
3.  In the `Font` section, search for and select the font.
4.  Choose your installed Nerd Font from the list, for example, `Fira Code Nerd Font`.
5.  If the font supports ligatures (e.g., Fira Code), check `Use ligatures` to enable them.

![iTerm2-SetupFont](/data-image/cookbook/mod/font.2_1.webp)

## Terminal.app (macOS)

1.  Open Terminal settings using the shortcut <kbd>âŒ˜</kbd> + <kbd>,</kbd>.
2.  Select 'Profiles' --> Click 'Change...' for Font --> Choose your desired font under the 'Font face' section.
    ![Terminal.app-SetupFont](/image/terminal_font.darwin.1.webp)

## Warp (Cross-platform)

1. Click the avatar in the top-right corner -> Select 'Settings'.
2. Search for the 'font' setting -> Select the corresponding font.

![Warp-SetupFont](/data-image/cookbook/mod/font.2_2.webp)

## Alacritty (Cross-platform)

1.  Edit your `alacritty.yml` configuration file (typically located at `~/.config/alacritty/alacritty.yml`).
2.  Locate the `font` section and modify the `family` for `normal`, `bold`, and `italic` to the name of your installed Nerd Font.
    ```yaml
    font:
      normal:
        family: FriaCode Nerd Font # Replace with the name of your installed font
        style: Regular
      bold:
        family: FriaCode Nerd Font
        style: Bold
      italic:
        family: FriaCode Nerd Font
        style: Italic
      size: 14.0 # Font size, adjustable as needed
    ```

## Kitty (Cross-platform)

1.  Edit your `kitty.conf` configuration file (typically located at `~/.config/kitty/kitty.conf`).
2.  Add or modify the following lines:

    ```properties
    font_family         FriaCode Nerd Font # Replace with the name of your installed font
    bold_font           auto
    italic_font         auto
    font_size           14.0 # Font size, adjustable as needed
    disable_ligatures   never # Enable ligatures
    ```

## Ghostty (Cross-platform)

Edit your `config` configuration file (typically located at `~/.config/ghostty/config`)

```properties{1}
font-family = FriaCode Nerd Font
font-style = Medium
font-size = 18
```

## GNOME Terminal (Linux)

1.  Open `GNOME Terminal` -> Right-click or select from the navigation -> `Preferences`.
2.  Select the `Profile` you wish to configure.
3.  Under the `Text` tab, check `Custom font`.
4.  Click the font selection button, then choose your installed Nerd Font.

## Konsole (Linux)

1. In the navigation bar, select 'Settings' to open the settings.
2. In `Profiles`, click 'New' or 'Edit' for the target `Profile`.
3. After entering the configuration, select 'Appearance' -> Click Font 'Choose...', then choose your installed Nerd Font.

## Termux (Android)

1. Rename the target font file and move it to `~/.termux/font.ttf`.
2. Run the `termux-reload-settings` command to apply the changes.

:::tip
After downloading font resources with the `font` module, it will detect if it's a Termux environment and enter a single-font interactive selection mode. Pressing <kbd>Enter</kbd> after selecting will automatically perform the above operations to enable the font.

```sh
x font
```
:::

## Verifying Font Activation

After configuration is complete, be sure to **restart** your terminal emulator or code editor. Then, you can try the following methods to verify if the font is displayed correctly:

*   **Display Powerline/Oh My Posh/Starship Symbols:** If you use these tools, observe whether your prompt displays the correct arrows, branches, locks, and other special symbols. This is the most direct way to verify if the Nerd Font icon character set is active.
*   **Display File Type Icons:** Use the `x yazi` or `x eza -l --icons` command. If your file manager or theme (such as `lsd` or `eza` with Nerd Font) supports it, file and folder icons will be displayed.
*   **Display Emoji:** Try typing some Emoji characters in the terminal (e.g., `ðŸ˜€ðŸš€âœ¨`) to see if they display correctly in color.
*   **Code Ligatures:** If you have installed a font that supports ligatures (such as Fira Code), type `->`, `=>`, `!=`, `===`, etc., in the terminal or VS Code to see if they merge into a more aesthetic single symbol.

If all the above verification steps are successful, congratulations! Your new font has been successfully activated in your terminal and editor!

# Fonts in System Package Managers

At times, installing x-cmd might not be convenient; however, users can still install fonts on the target host using its native package manager.

## brew -- Applicable to macOS, Linux (via Linuxbrew)

Brew font packages typically begin with `font-` and are usually located within the `homebrew/cask-fonts` Cask repository.

**Searching for Fonts**

To search for all available font packages, you can use:

```bash
brew search font-
```

Alternatively, if you know part of the font name, such as `fira-code`:

```bash
brew search font-fira-code
```

**Installing Fonts**

To install Fira Code Nerd Font:

```bash
brew install font-fira-code-nerd-font
```

To install Noto Sans CJK:

```bash
brew install font-noto-sans-cjk
```

To install Hack Nerd Font:

```bash
brew install font-hack-nerd-font
```

## apt -- Applicable to Debian, Ubuntu, Kali, and similar distributions

`apt` is the package manager for Debian and its derivative distributions (such as Ubuntu, Kali Linux, and Mint). Font packages typically begin with `fonts-`.

**Updating Package Lists**

Before searching and installing, it is recommended to update your local package list:

```bash
sudo apt update
```

**Searching for Fonts**

To search for fonts, use the `apt search` command. For example, to search for all font packages:

```bash
apt search fonts-
```

To search for specific fonts, such as `fira` or `noto`:

```bash
apt search fonts-fira
apt search fonts-noto
```

**Installing Fonts**

To install Fira Code font:

```bash
sudo apt install fonts-firacode
```

To install Noto CJK font (which includes Chinese, Japanese, and Korean characters):

```bash
sudo apt install fonts-noto-cjk
```

To install Powerline fonts (commonly used for terminal customization):

```bash
sudo apt install fonts-powerline
```

**Nerd Fonts Considerations**

The official Debian/Ubuntu repositories may not directly provide all the latest Nerd Fonts. You might need to:
1.  Install base fonts like `fonts-hack-ttf` or `fonts-fira-code`, then manually download the patched Nerd Font versions.
2.  Add a third-party PPA (Personal Package Archive), such as `ppa:rael-gc/ubuntu-fonts` (please verify its security independently).
3.  Download directly from the Nerd Fonts GitHub repository and install manually (recommended approach, offering the most flexibility).

## apk -- Applicable to Alpine Linux

`apk` is the package manager for Alpine Linux, known for its lightweight nature and security.

**Updating Package Lists**

Before searching and installing, it is recommended to update your local package list:

```bash
sudo apk update
```

**Searching for Fonts**

To search for fonts, use the `apk search` command. For example:

```bash
apk search font-
```

To search for specific fonts, such as `noto`:

```bash
apk search font-noto
```

**Installing Fonts**

To install Noto font:

```bash
sudo apk add font-noto
```

To install Fira Code font (if available):

```bash
sudo apk add font-fira-code
```

**Nerd Fonts Considerations**

Alpine Linux's official repositories offer fewer Nerd Fonts directly. Typically, you will need to:
1.  Manually download Nerd Fonts and place them in directories like `/usr/share/fonts/TTF/` or `/usr/local/share/fonts/`.
2.  Run `fc-cache -fv` to update the font cache.

## pacman -- Applicable to Arch Linux, Manjaro, EndeavourOS, and similar distributions

`pacman` is the package manager for Arch Linux and its derivative distributions (such as Manjaro).

**Updating Package Lists**

Before searching and installing, it is recommended to synchronize your local package database:

```bash
sudo pacman -Sy
```

**Searching for Fonts**

To search for fonts, use the `pacman -Ss` command. For example:

```bash
pacman -Ss font
```

To search for Nerd Fonts:

```bash
pacman -Ss nerd-font
```

**Installing Fonts**

To install Fira Code font:

```bash
sudo pacman -S ttf-fira-code
```

To install Noto CJK font:

```bash
sudo pacman -S noto-fonts-cjk
```

To install common Nerd Fonts (e.g., Hack Nerd Font):

```bash
sudo pacman -S ttf-hack-nerd
```

To install Nerd Fonts Symbols (if a separate symbols font is needed):

```bash
sudo pacman -S ttf-nerd-fonts-symbols
```

**AUR (Arch User Repository) Considerations**

Many of the latest or less common Nerd Fonts may not be found in the official repositories but can be located in the AUR (Arch User Repository). Installing AUR packages typically requires an AUR helper (such as `yay` or `paru`).

For example, to install Fira Code Nerd Font using `yay`:

```bash
yay -S ttf-fira-code-nerd
```

## scoop -- Applicable to Windows

`scoop` is a command-line installer for Windows, similar to Homebrew on macOS. It organizes software packages through "buckets."

**Installing Scoop (if not already installed)**

Run the following in PowerShell:

```powershell
Set-ExecutionPolicy RemoteSigned -Scope CurrentUser # Only needs to be run once
irm get.scoop.sh | iex
```

**Adding Font Buckets**

Scoop's fonts are typically found in buckets like `nerd-fonts` or `extras`. You must first add these buckets:

```powershell
scoop bucket add nerd-fonts
scoop bucket add extras
```

**Searching for Fonts**

To search for fonts, use the `scoop search` command. For example:

```powershell
scoop search font
```

To search for Nerd Fonts:

```powershell
scoop search nerd-font
```

**Installing Fonts**

To install Fira Code Nerd Font:

```powershell
scoop install fira-code-nerd-font
```

To install Hack Nerd Font:

```powershell
scoop install hack-nerd-font
```

To install Noto Fonts (potentially found in the `extras` bucket):

```powershell
scoop install noto-fonts
```

**Tips**

*   Fonts installed via `scoop` are typically registered automatically in the Windows font directory.
*   After installation, you may need to restart your terminal or applications for the newly installed fonts to appear.
*   `scoop` provides a very convenient way to manage fonts on Windows, especially Nerd Fonts.

# x gemini chat

chat with gemini

## Sub Commands

| Name | Description |
| ------- | ------- |
| [x gemini chat request](#x-gemini-chat-request) | send a request |


### x gemini chat request

send a request


- **Usage**:

```sh
x gemini chat request [OPTIONS] [FLAGS] <#n>
```

- **Arguments**:


| Argument | Description |
| ------- | ------- |
| `#n` | The parameter content will be concatenated with spaces and sent to AI as a question |


- **Options**:


| Name, Shorthand | Default | Description |
| ------- | ------- | ------- |
| `--temperature`, `-t` |  | Control the diversity of model generated results, with a value greater than or equal to 0, when the temperature is higher, the model will be more random |
| `--seed` |  | Control the reproducibility of the job. Passing in the same seed and job parameters should produce the same results, but may differ in rare cases. If a seed is not specified, one will be generated for you. |
| `--maxtoken` |  | Control the maximum token length of the model response |
| `--jina` |  | Through jina reader, send the webpage content as context to AI |
| `--ddgo` |  | Send ddgo search content as context to AI |
| `--tldr` |  | Send tldr content as context to AI |
| `--eval` |  | Send the execution command results as context to AI |
| `-e` |  | Send the variable value as context to AI |
| `--file`, `-f` |  | Send file content as context to AI |
| `--kv` |  | Send key-value pairs as context to AI |
| `--session` |  | Specify session value |
| `--minion` |  | Specify minion file |
| `--history`, `-n` |  | Specify the number of history as context |
| `--model` |  | Specify AI model |
| `-p`, `--pipe` |  | Specify to get pipe content |
| `--tool`, `--allowed-tools` |  | Comma-separated list of tool names to allow (e.g. "writefile,writefile,shcmd") |
| `--provider` |  | Specify AI provider |


- **Flags**:


| Name, Shorthand | Description |
| ------- | ------- |
| `--count` | Calculate how many tokens were used in this request |
| `-P`, `--nopipe` | Specify not to get pipe content |
| `-c` | Confirm before sending the request content to AI |
| `--edit` | Edit the request content in the terminal |
| `--question` | Request content |
| `--reasoning` | Show AI's reasoning process |
| `--no-reasoning` | Do not show AI's reasoning process, default on |
| `--stream` | Use streaming output, default on |
| `--no-stream` | Do not use streaming output |
| `--require-question` | Disallow empty request content |
| `--start-with-repl` | Start in REPL mode before sending the request |
| `--end-with-repl` | Start in REPL mode after sending the request (default behavior in interactive mode) |
| `--start-without-repl` | Start without REPL mode before sending the request |
| `--end-without-repl` | End without REPL mode after sending the request |
| `--without-repl` | Do not start REPL mode |

# x gemini gg

Call Google Search tool in Gemini AI, do not output the URL of the search result source by default

## Examples

Search who won the Euro 2024?

```sh
x gemini gg "Who won the euro 2024?"
```

## Usage


| `--event` &lt;event&gt; |  | Returns workflow run triggered by the event you specify |
| `--sta`, `--status` &lt;status&gt; |  | Returns workflow runs with the check run status |
| `--per_page` &lt;num&gt; |  | per_page data number |
| `--page` &lt;num&gt; |  | target page |
| `--created` &lt;ISO 8601&gt; |  | Returns workflow runs created within the given date-time range |
| `--check_suite_id` &lt;id&gt; |  | Returns workflow runs with the check_suite_id that you specify |


- **Flags**:


| Name, Shorthand | Description |
| ------- | ------- |
| `--json`, `-j` | output raw JSON data |
| `--exclude_pull_requests` | Not pull requests are omitted from the response |


### x gh action workflow run

Run a workflow by creating a workflow_dispatch event


- **Examples**:

Run the &lt;workflow_name is Lint&gt; workflow by creating a workflow_dispatch event

```sh
x gh action workflow run --repo <owner/repo> Lint
```

Run &lt;remote file .github/workflows/lint.yml&gt; workflow_dispatch event and use key and values parameter

```sh
x gh action workflow run --repo <owner/repo> -f name=x-cmd -f msg=hello lint.yml
x gh action workflow run --repo <owner/repo> --inputs '{"name":"x-cmd","msg":"hello"}' lint.yml

```

Run a workflow_dispatch event and use key and values parameter from stdin

```sh
echo '{"name":"x-cmd"}' | x gh action workflow run --repo <owner/repo> --inputs - .id=<workflow_id>
```

- **Usage**:

```sh
x gh action workflow run|dispatch [OPTIONS] <#1>
```

- **Arguments**:


| Argument | Description |
| ------- | ------- |
| `#1` | workflow &lt;name&gt; or &lt;relative_file_path&gt; or .id=&lt;workflow_id&gt; |

| `--field`, `-f` &lt;key=val&gt; |  | Input &lt;key&gt;=&lt;value&gt; parameter in the workflow file |
| `--inputs` &lt;key_val_json&gt; |  | Input keys and values parameter in the workflow file. '-' from stdin |

# Basic Usage

Why build another tool?
What advantages does it have compared to **gh**?

1. `x gh` has been used internally for a long time (since 2021) and has accumulated many integrated features.
2. Itâ€™s lightweight â€” included in x-cmdâ€™s 1 MB installer and only depends on `curl`.
3. We want a unified TUI and interaction experience. With the same design, weâ€™ve also built CLIs for GitLab, Gitee, Codeberg, Gitea, and Forgejo.

## x-cmd's pkg also includes the official gh package

Note that x-cmd also makes it easy to use the official **gh** command:

```bash
x env use gh
x env try gh  # or activate it only for the current session
```
