### x gh model chat request

send a request


- **Usage**:

```sh
x gh model chat request [OPTIONS] [FLAGS] <#n>
```

- **Arguments**:


| Argument | Description |
| ------- | ------- |
| `#n` | The parameter content will be concatenated with spaces and sent to AI as a question |


- **Options**:


| Name, Shorthand | Default | Description |
| ------- | ------- | ------- |
| `--temperature`, `-t` |  | Control the diversity of model generated results, with a value greater than or equal to 0, when the temperature is higher, the model will be more random |
| `--seed` |  | Control the reproducibility of the job. Passing in the same seed and job parameters should produce the same results, but may differ in rare cases. If a seed is not specified, one will be generated for you. |
| `--maxtoken` |  | Control the maximum token length of the model response |
| `--jina` |  | Through jina reader, send the webpage content as context to AI |
| `--ddgo` |  | Send ddgo search content as context to AI |
| `--tldr` |  | Send tldr content as context to AI |
| `--eval` |  | Send the execution command results as context to AI |
| `-e` |  | Send the variable value as context to AI |
| `--file`, `-f` |  | Send file content as context to AI |
| `--kv` |  | Send key-value pairs as context to AI |
| `--session` |  | Specify session value |
| `--minion` |  | Specify minion file |
| `--history`, `-n` |  | Specify the number of history as context |
| `--model` |  | Specify AI model |
| `-p`, `--pipe` |  | Specify to get pipe content |
| `--tool`, `--allowed-tools` |  | Comma-separated list of tool names to allow (e.g. "writefile,writefile,shcmd") |
| `--provider` |  | Specify AI provider |


- **Flags**:


| Name, Shorthand | Description |
| ------- | ------- |
| `-P`, `--nopipe` | Specify not to get pipe content |
| `-c` | Confirm before sending the request content to AI |
| `--edit` | Edit the request content in the terminal |
| `--question` | Request content |
| `--reasoning` | Show AI's reasoning process |
| `--no-reasoning` | Do not show AI's reasoning process, default on |
| `--stream` | Use streaming output, default on |
| `--no-stream` | Do not use streaming output |
| `--require-question` | Disallow empty request content |
| `--start-with-repl` | Start in REPL mode before sending the request |
| `--end-with-repl` | Start in REPL mode after sending the request (default behavior in interactive mode) |
| `--start-without-repl` | Start without REPL mode before sending the request |
| `--end-without-repl` | End without REPL mode after sending the request |
| `--without-repl` | Do not start REPL mode |


| ------- | ------- | ------- |

| `--direction` &lt;asc,desc&gt; | `"desc"`  | sort direction |

| Name, Shorthand | Description |
| ------- | ------- |
| `--json`, `-j` | output raw JSON data |


### x gh org apply

Manage org by declare configure


- **Examples**:

Use org.yml declare configure manage org

```sh
x gh org apply ./org.yml
```

Use org.yml declare configure manage org, And replace configure's user 'bot' alias name to 'x-cmd-bot'

```sh
x gh org apply ./org.yml bot=x-cmd-bot
```

Use stdin declare configure data manage org

```sh

```

- **Usage**:

```sh

```

- **Arguments**:


| Argument | Description |
| ------- | ------- |
| `#1` | declare file path(yml, json), stdin '-' |
| `#n` | alias replace list |


| Name, Shorthand | Default | Description |
| ------- | ------- | ------- |

- **Examples**:

```sh

```

Run &lt;remote file .github/workflows/lint.yml&gt; workflow_dispatch event and use key and values parameter

```sh

x gh action workflow run --repo <owner/repo> --inputs '{"name":"x-cmd","msg":"hello"}' lint.yml

```

Run a workflow_dispatch event and use key and values parameter from stdin

```sh
echo '{"name":"x-cmd"}' | x gh action workflow run --repo <owner/repo> --inputs - .id=<workflow_id>
```

| `--ref` &lt;branch&#124;tag&gt; |  | The git reference for the workflow. Empty will get default branch |
| `--inputs` &lt;key_val_json&gt; |  | Input keys and values parameter in the workflow file. '-' from stdin |
| `--field`, `-f` &lt;key=val&gt; |  | Input &lt;key&gt;=&lt;value&gt; parameter in the workflow file |

# x git cl

Clone a repository into a new directory

## Usage

```sh
x git cl|clone [OPTIONS] [FLAGS] <#1> <#2>
```

## Arguments

| Argument | Description |
| ------- | ------- |

## Options

| Name, Shorthand | Default | Description |
| ------- | ------- | ------- |
| `-o`, `--origin` &lt;name&gt; |  | use &lt;name&gt; instead of 'origin' to track upstream |

| `-u`, `--upload-pack` &lt;path&gt; |  | path to git-upload-pack on the remote |
| `-j`, `--jobs` &lt;n&gt; |  | number of submodules cloned in parallel |
| `--separate-git-dir` &lt;gitdir&gt; |  | separate git dir from working tree |
| `--depth` &lt;depth&gt; |  | create a shallow clone of that depth |


## Flags

| Name, Shorthand | Description |
| ------- | ------- |
| `--recursive` | initialize all contained submodules |
| `--shallow-submodules` | any cloned submodules will be shallow |

# x git sp

Mainly for optimizing access to Bitbucket, Codeberg, GitHub, and GitLab in China, including setting up short names and configuring proxies

## Examples

Set http, https, and socks5 proxies for github, gitlab, codeberg, and bitbucket, with the address localhost:9999ï¼›This is the most common scenario

```sh
x git sp setup localhost:9999

```

View the configuration status of the current service provider

```sh
x git sp status

```

Clear the contents of setup

```sh
x git sp cleanup
```

Configure short names and set proxies using HTTP/SSH

```sh
x git sp setup --http socks5://localhost:9999 --ssh localhost:9999
x git sp setup --proxy socks5://localhost:9999

```

## Sub Commands

| Name | Description |
| ------- | ------- |

| [x git sp cleanup](#x-git-sp-cleanup) | Clear the contents of setup |
| [x git sp status](#x-git-sp-status) | View the configuration status of the current service provider |


### x git sp setup

Initialize configuration service provider short name and set proxy


- **Examples**:

Set http, https, and socks5 proxies for github, gitlab, codeberg, and bitbucket, with the address localhost:9999ï¼›This is the most common scenario

```sh
x git sp setup localhost:9999

```

Setting up short names and configuring proxies using HTTP/SSH

```sh
x git sp setup --http socks5://localhost:9999 --ssh localhost:9999
x git sp setup --proxy socks5://localhost:9999

```

- **Usage**:

```sh
x git sp setup [OPTIONS]
```

- **Options**:


| Name, Shorthand | Default | Description |
| ------- | ------- | ------- |
| `--http` |  | Setup proxy using the http protocol |
| `--ssh` |  | Setup proxy using the SSH protocol |
| `--proxy` |  | Setup proxy using both http and SSH protocols |


### x git sp cleanup

Clear the contents of setup


- **Usage**:

```sh
x git sp cleanup
```

### x git sp status

View the configuration status of the current service provider


- **Usage**:

```sh
x git sp status
```

# x gl cl

shortcut for `x gl repo clone`

## Usage

```sh
x gl cl [OPTIONS] [FLAGS] <#1> <#2>
```

## Arguments

| Argument | Description |
| ------- | ------- |
| `#1` | &lt;ownerPath&gt;/&lt;repoPath&gt; (default ownerPath: current user) |
| `#2` | directory |


## Options

| Name, Shorthand | Default | Description |
| ------- | ------- | ------- |
| `-o`, `--origin` &lt;name&gt; |  | use &lt;name&gt; instead of 'origin' to track upstream |
| `-b`, `--branch` &lt;branch&gt; |  | checkout &lt;branch&gt; instead of the remote's HEAD |
| `-u`, `--upload-pack` &lt;path&gt; |  | path to git-upload-pack on the remote |
| `-j`, `--jobs` &lt;n&gt; |  | number of submodules cloned in parallel |
| `--separate-git-dir` &lt;gitdir&gt; |  | separate git dir from working tree |
| `--depth` &lt;depth&gt; |  | create a shallow clone of that depth |


## Flags

| Name, Shorthand | Description |
| ------- | ------- |
| `--recursive` | initialize all contained submodules |
| `--shallow-submodules` | any cloned submodules will be shallow |

| `--order_by` |  | Return requests ordered by created_at, title, or updated_at fields. Default is created_at |
| `--reviewer_id` |  | Returns merge requests which have the user as a reviewer with the given user id |
| `--reviewer_username` |  | Returns merge requests which have the user as a reviewer with the given username |
| `--scope` |  | Return merge requests for the given scope. Defaults to created_by_me |
| `--search` |  | Search merge requests against their title and description |
| `--sort` |  | Return requests sorted in asc or desc order. Default is desc |
| `--state` |  | Return all merge requests or just those that are opened, closed, locked, or merged |
| `--source_branch` |  | Return merge requests with the given source branch |
| `--target_branch` |  | Return merge requests with the given target branch |
| `--updated_after` |  | Return prs updated on or after the given time |
| `--updated_before` |  | Return prs updated on or before the given time |
| `--view` |  | If simple, returns the iid, URL, title, description, and basic state of merge request |
| `--with_labels_details` | `"false"`  | If true, the response returns more details for each label in labels field: :name, :color, :description, :description_html,:text_color.Default is false |
| `--with_merge_status_recheck` | `"false"`  | If true, this projection requests (but does not guarantee) that the merge_status field be recalculated asynchronously |


- **Flags**:


| Name, Shorthand | Description |
| ------- | ------- |
| `--non_archived` | Return merge requests from non archived projects only. Default is true |
| `--json`, `-j` | output raw JSON data |

# x gt cl

shortcut for `x gt repo clone`

## Usage

```sh
x gt cl|clone [OPTIONS] [FLAGS] <#1> <#2>
```

## Arguments

| Argument | Description |
| ------- | ------- |
| `#1` | &lt;owner_path&gt;/&lt;repo_path&gt; |
| `#2` | directory |


## Options

| Name, Shorthand | Default | Description |
| ------- | ------- | ------- |
| `-o`, `--origin` &lt;name&gt; |  | use &lt;name&gt; instead of 'origin' to track upstream |
| `-b`, `--branch` &lt;branch&gt; |  | checkout &lt;branch&gt; instead of the remote's HEAD |
| `-u`, `--upload-pack` &lt;path&gt; |  | path to git-upload-pack on the remote |
| `-j`, `--jobs` &lt;n&gt; |  | number of submodules cloned in parallel |
| `--separate-git-dir` &lt;gitdir&gt; |  | separate git dir from working tree |
| `--depth` &lt;depth&gt; |  | create a shallow clone of that depth |


## Flags

| Name, Shorthand | Description |
| ------- | ------- |
| `--recursive` | initialize all contained submodules |
| `--shallow-submodules` | any cloned submodules will be shallow |

# x gtb - Project Gutenberg eBook Search and Browsing

The `x gtb` module provides a convenient command-line interface for searching and browsing eBooks on Project Gutenberg. Project Gutenberg is a large digital library containing a vast number of public domain books.

## Searching for Books

You can use the `search` or `s` command to search for books matching specific criteria.

```bash
x gtb search [keywords]
```

For example, to search for books containing "Dumas":

```bash
x gtb search Dumas
```

You can use the `--csv` flag to output the results in CSV format, or the `--app` flag to view the results in an interactive UI:

```bash
x gtb search --csv Dumas  # CSV output
x gtb search --app Dumas  # Interactive UI
```


## Viewing Book Metadata

The `meta` command displays the storage location of book data and lists all books:

```bash
x gtb meta
```

You can use the `which` subcommand to view the storage location of book data:

```bash
x gtb meta which
```

Similarly, the `ls` subcommand lists all books and supports the `--csv` and `--app` flags:

```bash
x gtb meta ls  # List all books
x gtb meta ls --csv # CSV output
x gtb meta ls --app # Interactive UI
```

## Using DuckDuckGo Search

The `x gtb : [keywords]` command uses DuckDuckGo to search for relevant information on the Hacker News website:

```bash
x gtb : dumas  # Search "dumas" on DuckDuckGo
```


## Retrieving Book Text Content

The `txt` command retrieves the plain text content of a specified book:

```bash
x gtb txt [bookID]
```

For example, to retrieve the text content of book ID 100:

```bash
x gtb txt 100
```

## Interactive Book Browsing

The `show` command allows you to interactively browse the content of a book:

```bash
x gtb show [bookID]
```

For example, to interactively browse book ID 100:

```bash
x gtb show 100
```

## Opening Books in a Browser

The `open` command opens the book in your default browser, supporting EPUB, text, and metadata formats:

```bash
x gtb open [bookID] [--pub|--txt|--meta]
```

For example, to open the EPUB version of book ID 100 in your default browser:

```bash
x gtb open 100 --pub
```


## Quick Start

Here are some common `x gtb` command examples:

- `x gtb`: Lists all books
- `x gtb search Dumas`: Searches for books containing "Dumas"
- `x gtb : dumas`: Searches "dumas" using DuckDuckGo
- `x gtb show 100`: Gets details for book ID 100


For more information, please visit [https://x-cmd.com](https://x-cmd.com)

# x hash - Calculate File Checksums

The `x hash` command calculates MD5, SHA1, SHA256, SHA384, and SHA512 checksums for files. It supports various subcommands and parameters for flexible checksum calculation.

## Quick Start

The simplest usage is to specify the file path directly:

```bash
x hash <file path>
```

This calculates and outputs the file's SHA1 checksum. If the system supports `shasum`, it uses `shasum`; otherwise, it uses `sha1sum`.

To calculate other types of checksums, use the following subcommands:

* `md5`: Calculate MD5 checksum
* `sha1`: Calculate SHA1 checksum
* `sha256`: Calculate SHA256 checksum
* `sha384`: Calculate SHA384 checksum
* `sha512`: Calculate SHA512 checksum

For example, to calculate the MD5 checksum of a file:

```bash
x hash md5 <file path>
```

## Handling Multiple Files

`x hash` can process multiple files simultaneously. Just pass the file paths as arguments:

```bash
x hash <file1> <file2> <file3>
```

The output will show the SHA1 checksum for each file in order.

## Reading Data from Standard Input

If you don't need to specify a file, you can read data from standard input for checksum calculation:

```bash
echo "Hello, world!" | x hash
```

This calculates the SHA1 checksum of the "Hello, world!" string.  Similarly, you can combine pipes and other subcommands to process standard input.

## Checksum Verification

`x hash` provides `verify` and `assert` subcommands for checksum verification:

### `verify` Command

The `verify` command compares a file's checksum with a known value. It automatically infers the algorithm based on the checksum length.

```bash
x hash verify <file path> <checksum>
```

For example:

```bash
x hash verify myfile.txt a1b2c3d4e5f678901234567890abcdef
```

The command outputs the verification result to the log.

### `assert` Command

The `assert` command is similar to `verify`, but it returns an exit code:

* 0: Checksum matches
* 1: Checksum mismatch
* 2: Algorithm cannot be determined

This makes `assert` convenient for checksum verification in scripts.

```bash
x hash assert <file path> <checksum>
```

## Information Output (`info`)

The `info` subcommand outputs the MD5, SHA1, SHA256, SHA384, and SHA512 checksums of a file.

```bash
x hash info <file path>
```


## Summary

`x hash` is a powerful tool for easily calculating and verifying file checksums, suitable for various scenarios such as software package integrity checks and data consistency verification. Its simple command-line interface and flexible options make it easy to use and integrate into other scripts.

# Is MD5 Secure?

In the realm of information security, the storage and protection of passwords constitute a core issue. MD5 (Message-Digest Algorithm 5), as a widely used hash function, frequently becomes the subject of discussion regarding its security: "Is MD5 secure?" This question does not have a simple "yes" or "no" answer; it depends on the specific application scenario and implementation method. This article will delve into the security of MD5 and explore the more secure practices we should adopt for modern password storage and data integrity verification.

## TLDR

1.  For information digest scenarios, it still has its uses (but be aware of collision risks; not suitable for high-security scenarios).
2.  For password storage -- insecure.
3.  For information tamper prevention -- vulnerable to Hash collisions, insecure.

## The Nature and Limitations of MD5

MD5 is a cryptographic hash function that takes an input of arbitrary length (such as a password or file) and produces a fixed-length output (128 bits, typically represented as a 32-character hexadecimal string), known as a hash value or message digest. MD5 was originally designed for data integrity verification, meaning comparing the MD5 value of a file to confirm whether it has been tampered with during transmission.

**Characteristics of MD5:**
1.  **One-way function:** Theoretically, it is impossible to derive the original input from the hash value.
2.  **Fixed output length:** Regardless of the input length, the output hash value has a fixed length.
3.  **Avalanche effect:** Even a minor change in the original input results in a drastically different hash value.
4.  **Fast computation:** MD5 is highly efficient in computation.

However, MD5's "speed" and "one-way nature" paradoxically become security vulnerabilities in password storage scenarios.

## MD5 for Password Storage: Why It's No Longer Recommended

In earlier times, MD5 was widely used for password storage due to its one-way property. Developers believed that by storing only the MD5 hash of a password, attackers could not directly obtain user passwords even if the database was leaked. However, with advancements in computing power and attack techniques, MD5 is no longer considered a secure password hashing algorithm, especially without additional protective measures.

**The primary reason lies in "Rainbow Table Attack":**

A rainbow table is a pre-computed table of hash values and their corresponding original inputs (passwords). Because MD5 computation is very fast, attackers can pre-generate a massive database containing common passwords and their MD5 hash values. Once leaked MD5 hash values are obtained, attackers can quickly find the corresponding original password by simply looking it up in the rainbow table, without needing complex computations.

For example, if your password is "password123", its MD5 hash value is `202cb962ac59075b964b07152d234b70`. An attacker only needs to look up this hash value in a rainbow table to quickly find the corresponding original password.

### "Salting": The First Step to Enhancing Password Hash Security

To counter rainbow table attacks, the concept of "Salting" was introduced.

**What is "Salt"?**
"Salt" is a randomly generated string that is combined with the user's original password (typically by concatenation) before the hashing computation. Each user's salt value is unique and is usually stored alongside the hash value in the database (the salt value is stored in plaintext because its purpose is to increase the complexity of the hash, not to be kept secret).

**How does Salting counter rainbow tables?**
By salting, even if two users set the same password, their different salt values will result in completely different final hash values. This means attackers can no longer use a single, generic rainbow table to crack all passwords. They would have to generate a separate rainbow table for every unique salt value, which significantly increases the computational cost and storage requirements for the attack, making it impractical.

**Example:**
*   User A password: "password123", salt: "abcde" -> MD5("password123abcde") -> Hash Value A
*   User B password: "password123", salt: "fghij" -> MD5("password123fghij") -> Hash Value B

Hash Value A and Hash Value B will be completely different.

### More Secure Password Hashing Algorithms: Slow Hashing Functions

Although salting effectively counters rainbow tables, MD5's inherent speed remains a weakness. Attackers can still crack salted MD5 hashes through brute-force attacks (trying passwords one by one and computing their hash values). If MD5 computation is fast, an attacker can attempt billions of password combinations per second.

To address this problem, modern password storage recommends using "Slow Hashing Functions," also known as "Adaptive Hashing Functions" or "Key Derivation Functions" (KDFs). These algorithms are designed to intentionally consume more computational resources (CPU time, memory), thereby significantly slowing down brute-force attacks.

**Common slow hashing algorithms include:**
1.  **bcrypt:** Based on the Blowfish cipher algorithm, it controls the number of computation iterations via a "work factor" or "cost factor," which can be dynamically adjusted based on hardware performance to maintain a certain computation time.
2.  **scrypt:** In addition to CPU consumption, it also increases memory consumption, making large-scale parallel attacks using specialized hardware (like GPUs) more difficult.
3.  **Argon2:** The winner of the 2015 Password Hashing Competition (PHC), it offers higher security and flexibility, allowing configuration of CPU time, memory, and parallelism.

These algorithms all incorporate built-in salting mechanisms and allow adjustment of their "slowness" by configuring iteration counts or memory consumption, adapting to future advancements in computing power.

### After a Database Leak, What is the Significance of Cracking Passwords?

Some might ask: "Since the database has already been compromised, and information has leaked, what's the point of cracking passwords?" This question is crucial because the harm of cracked passwords extends far beyond the initial leak:

1.  **Legitimate Website Access:** Once passwords are cracked, attackers can directly use them to log into the compromised website, obtain users' personal information, perform illicit operations, or even impersonate users.
2.  **"Credential Stuffing" Attacks:** This is one of the most common subsequent attacks. Many users habitually use the same or similar passwords across different websites. Attackers will use the usernames and passwords cracked from one website (Site A) to attempt logging into other websites (Site B, Site C, etc.). Due to the widespread phenomenon of password reuse, the success rate of such attacks is very high, potentially leading to account compromise on multiple platforms.
3.  **Identity Theft:** Combined with other leaked information (such as name, email, phone number), cracked passwords can help attackers build a more complete user profile, enabling deeper identity theft or fraud.

### Comprehensive Defense Strategies

To maximize user password security, both developers and users should adopt a multi-layered defense strategy:

**For Developers:**
1.  **Use Modern Slow Hashing Algorithms:** Abandon fast hashing algorithms like MD5 and SHA-1, and switch to bcrypt, scrypt, or Argon2.
2.  **Enforce Salting:** Ensure a unique and sufficiently long random salt value is generated for each user and stored along with the hash value.
3.  **Adjust Iteration Count/Work Factor:** Regularly evaluate and adjust the iteration count or work factor of the hashing algorithm based on server performance and security requirements, ensuring computation time remains within an acceptable range (e.g., approximately 200-500 milliseconds per hash computation).
4.  **Implement Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA):** Provide users with MFA options such as SMS verification codes, TOTP (e.g., Google Authenticator), or hardware keys. Even if passwords are cracked, MFA can effectively prevent unauthorized logins.
5.  **Limit Login Attempts:** Prevent brute-force and credential stuffing attacks.
6.  **Regular Security Audits:** Conduct security vulnerability scans and penetration tests on the system.

**For Users:**
1.  **Use Unique and Complex Passwords:** Set different, sufficiently long, and complex passwords containing uppercase and lowercase letters, numbers, and symbols for each important online service.
2.  **Enable Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA):** Whenever a website offers MFA options, be sure to enable it. This is one of the most effective ways to prevent account theft.
3.  **Use a Password Manager:** Password managers can help users generate and store complex and unique passwords, significantly reducing the risk of password reuse.
4.  **Be Wary of Phishing Attacks:** Do not click suspicious links or enter passwords on unknown websites.

## Tamper Prevention -- Hash Collisions: Why MD5 Is No Longer Reliable?

MD5 was initially widely used for verifying data integrity. For instance, when downloading software or files, an MD5 checksum would be provided. Users could calculate the MD5 value of the downloaded file and compare it with the official checksum to confirm whether the file had been tampered with during transmission. This mechanism relies on the "collision resistance" of the hash function, meaning it is extremely difficult to find two different inputs that produce the same hash value.

However, this property of MD5 was broken in 2004 by Professor Xiaoyun Wang's team of Chinese cryptographers, followed by the emergence of more practical "chosen-prefix collision" attacks.

### MD5's Application in Everyday Tamper Prevention (and why it failed)

Let's take a common scenario as an example: you want to download an important file, such as a 1GB Linux system image (ISO file), for operating system installation.

**In the past (when MD5 was considered secure), the tamper prevention process was:**

1.  **Official Release:** The official website of the Linux distribution would release the system image file and simultaneously provide its MD5 hash value (often called an MD5 checksum or MD5sum) alongside it. This MD5 value was like a unique "digital fingerprint" for that specific file.
    *   For example, the official website might state:
        *   `Linux_Distro_v1.0.iso`
        *   `MD5: 202cb962ac59075b964b07152d234b70` (This is an example MD5 value)

2.  **User Download:** You download the 1GB Linux image file from the official website.

3.  **User Verification:** After the download is complete, you worry whether the file might have been tampered with during the download process (e.g., the website was hacked, or you downloaded it over an insecure public Wi-Fi, and the file was maliciously modified in transit). To verify, you would use a tool (such as the `certutil -hashfile` command on Windows, or the `md5sum` command on Linux/macOS) to calculate the MD5 hash value of your downloaded file.

4.  **Comparison of Results:**
    *   If the MD5 value you calculated **was exactly the same as the one provided by the official website**, you would conclude: "Great! My downloaded file is complete and hasn't been modified by anyone; I can use it with confidence."
    *   If the MD5 value you calculated **did not match the one provided by the official website**, you would know: "Oh no! The file might have been corrupted during download or maliciously tampered with. I cannot use this file and need to re-download it or find another source."

**The intention behind this process was good, relying on MD5's "avalanche effect" and "collision resistance":**
*   **Avalanche Effect:** Even if only one byte of the file content changes, the MD5 value will change drastically.
*   **Collision Resistance (ideal scenario):** Theoretically, finding two different files that produce the same MD5 value is extremely difficult, almost impossible.

### MD5's Collision Problem: Why Is It No Longer Secure?

However, MD5's "collision resistance" was broken in 2004 by Professor Xiaoyun Wang's team of Chinese cryptographers. This means that **attackers can now relatively easily construct two completely different files that produce the same MD5 hash valueâ€”a "collision."**

**What does this mean for tamper prevention?**

Imagine an attacker wants you to download a Linux image file containing a virus, but they don't want you to discover it. They can do this:

1.  **Prepare Malicious File:** The attacker first obtains the clean Linux image file released by the official source.
2.  **Create Collision:** The attacker exploits the MD5 collision vulnerability to meticulously craft a **malicious Linux image file containing a virus**. This malicious file is completely different in content from the official clean file, but miraculously, the attacker can ensure that the MD5 hash value of this malicious file **is exactly the same as the MD5 hash value of the official clean file!**
3.  **Replace File:** The attacker, through some means (e.g., by compromising the official website and replacing the file pointed to by the download link, or by performing a "man-in-the-middle attack" on your insecure network connection, secretly replacing the file during your download), replaces the official clean file with their crafted malicious file.
4.  **User Deceived:** When you download this replaced malicious file, you follow your usual habit and calculate its MD5 value. Because the attacker has meticulously designed it, the MD5 value you calculate **perfectly matches the MD5 value provided by the official website!**
5.  **Consequences:** You mistakenly believe the file is safe and untampered, then confidently install this operating system containing a virus, leading to your computer being infected, data stolen, or even becoming part of a botnet.

**Simply put, MD5's collision problem is like this:** Previously, every file had a unique fingerprint, and you could confirm if a file had been swapped by comparing fingerprints. But now, a clever forger can create two completely different files that **have identical fingerprints**. If you only check the fingerprint, you cannot distinguish between the genuine and the fake.

Therefore, MD5 is no longer suitable for high-security data integrity verification and tamper prevention scenarios. For these applications, it is strongly recommended to use more secure hash algorithms such as SHA-256, SHA-3, or BLAKE2, which are currently still considered to have sufficient collision resistance.

# x hn - Command-line Hacker News Browser

The `x hn` module provides a powerful command-line interface for browsing news and information on Hacker News (HN). It allows you to view various HN posts in an interactive tabular format and provides convenient features for opening links and viewing data.

## Quick Start

By default, `x hn` displays the top posts from HN:

```bash
x hn
```

You can view other types of posts using the following commands:

* **New posts:** `x hn new`
* **Best posts:** `x hn best`
* **Ask posts:** `x hn ask`
* **Show posts:** `x hn show`
* **Job posts:** `x hn job`


## Viewing Post Details

Use the `item` subcommand to view the content of a specific post:

```bash
x hn item <item_id>
```

`<item_id>` is the ID number of the post. You can customize the output format using the following options:

* `--browse`: Opens the HN article's comment page.
* `--link`: Opens the HN article link page (if available).
* `--reader`: Uses jina reader to fetch information from the HN article link page.
* `--preview`: Displays using a preview style.
* `--csv`: Displays using CSV style.
* `--json`: Displays using JSON style.

For example, to view the comment page for post with ID 12345:

```bash
x hn item 12345 --browse
```


## Viewing User Information

Use the `user` subcommand to view information about an HN user:

```bash
x hn user <user_id>
```

`<user_id>` is the user's ID number.  Similarly, you can use the `--app` (default, human-readable format), `--csv`, `--json` options to customize the output format.


## Calculating a User's h-index

Use the `hi` or `hidx` subcommand to calculate a user's h-index:

```bash
x hn hi <user_id>
```

`<user_id>` is the user's ID number.


## Configuration Management

`x hn` provides flexible configuration management:

* **`init`**: Initializes the configuration using an interactive mode.
* **`cfg`**: Manages configuration items, such as data storage time, data location, and proxy information. You can use `cfg set` to set configurations, `cfg cat` to view the current configuration, and `cfg clear` to clear the current session settings and restore defaults.


## Using DuckDuckGo Search

`x hn` integrates with DuckDuckGo search, making it easy to search for information on the HN website:

* **`x hn : <keyword>`**: Uses DuckDuckGo to search for relevant information on the Hacker News website.
* **`x hn :: <keyword>`**: Uses DuckDuckGo with AI to search for relevant information within Hacker News.


## Other Features

* **Pagination:** `x hn` supports pagination for displaying large numbers of posts, making browsing easier.
* **Translation:** Combined with other tools, such as `@zh` (Simplified Chinese translation), you can easily translate HN post content.
* **Data Range:** You can specify the range of posts to view, for example, `x hn top 11,20` views posts 11 to 20 from the top posts.


## Examples

* View the best HN posts and display them using the preview style: `x hn best --preview`
* View HN top posts 11 to 20, outputting in JSON format: `x hn top --json 11,20`
* Search for "nodejs" related information on Hacker News: `x hn : nodejs`
* Search for "llama3" related information on Hacker News using AI assistance: `x hn :: llama3`
* Translate the preview style content of the best HN posts (requires installing the appropriate translation tool): `x hn best --preview | @zh`


This document should help you use the `x hn` module more effectively. For more information, please visit [https://x-cmd.com](https://x-cmd.com) (replace with the actual link).

# x host - Local Hosts File Management

The `x host` module is used to manage the mapping between local hostnames and IP addresses, facilitating local domain name resolution and testing. It provides functionalities for viewing, adding, modifying, and deleting hostname mappings.

**Note:**

1. Currently, all operations of `x host` are centered around the `/etc/hosts` file; some systems may use other files to handle hostname resolution, in which case the `x host` module may not be effective.
2. Modifying the `/etc/hosts` file affects the entire system and therefore requires sudo privileges.

## Viewing Hostname Mappings

The `cat` command can be used to view all current hostname and IP address mappings:

```bash
x host cat
```

or

```bash
x host
```

## Getting the IP Address of a Specific Hostname

The `get` command can be used to obtain the IP address mapped to a specific hostname in the local configuration:

```bash
x host get localhost
```

This will return the IP address corresponding to `localhost`. You can replace `localhost` with any hostname you want to query. If the hostname does not have a mapping, no result will be returned. The command will prompt you to enter a hostname; you can use `___x_cmd_host___advise_get_candidate` to get a list of candidate hostnames.


## Editing Hostname Mappings

The `ed` command can be used to add, modify, or delete hostname mappings.

### Adding or Modifying Mappings

Use the `=` symbol to connect the hostname and IP address, for example:

```bash
x host ed hub.x-cmd.com=192.168.3.1
```

This will add or modify the mapping for `hub.x-cmd.com`, pointing it to `192.168.3.1`. If `hub.x-cmd.com` already exists, its IP address will be updated; otherwise, a new mapping will be added.

### Deleting Mappings

Use the `-` prefix to delete the mapping of a specified hostname:

```bash
x host ed -hub.x-cmd.com
```

This will delete the mapping for `hub.x-cmd.com`.


## Usage Examples

Here are some examples of `x host` commands:

* **View all mappings:** `x host cat`
* **Get the IP of localhost:** `x host get localhost`
* **Add a mapping for hub.x-cmd.com:** `x host ed hub.x-cmd.com=192.168.3.1`
* **Delete the mapping for hub.x-cmd.com:** `x host ed -hub.x-cmd.com`


The `x host` module allows you to conveniently manage the mapping between local hostnames and IP addresses, simplifying the configuration of your local development and testing environment.

# x htop - Real-time System Monitoring Tool

## Quick Installation and Usage of htop

htop is a powerful interactive system monitoring tool that displays real-time information about processes, CPU, memory, disk, and network usage. The `x htop` module simplifies the installation and usage process of htop, allowing for quick access even in environments without htop pre-installed. It leverages `pixi` (a fast package manager, see [https://prefix.dev/](https://prefix.dev/) or run `x pixi --help` for details) to automatically handle the installation in the background.

### Basic Usage

Simply run the following command to start htop:

```bash
x htop
```

This will automatically install (if necessary) and launch htop, displaying real-time system resource information. You can use htop's built-in commands for navigation and operations, such as sorting processes, viewing process details, etc.

<!-- ![x htop](/data-image/cookbook/mod/htop.1.webp)  *(æ­¤å¤„åº”æ›¿æ¢ä¸ºå®žé™…æˆªå›¾)* -->

### Passing Arguments to htop

`x htop` supports passing arguments directly to the htop command. For example, to view htop's help information, use:

```bash
x htop -- -h
```

This is equivalent to running the `htop -h` command directly.


## Summary

The `x htop` module provides a simple and convenient way to use htop for monitoring system resources.  With the support of `pixi`, it eliminates the tedious steps of manually installing htop and allows users to directly use the htop command and its arguments. This makes `x htop` an efficient and easy-to-use system monitoring tool.

# x hua - Your Pocket Chinese Classics Library

In the digital age, how can you conveniently enjoy the treasures of classical Chinese literature? The `x hua` command opens a door to the world of ancient wisdom and poetry. It's not just a command; it's like a portable electronic library, allowing you to easily browse timeless masterpieces such as the *Classic of Poetry*, *Chu Ci*, and *Three Hundred Tang Poems* within the confines of your terminal. For those who love Chinese culture and the command line, this is undoubtedly a tool worth exploring.

## One-Click Start: An Overview of Chinese Cultural Classics

When you first encounter `x hua`, the most direct way to use it is to run it without any parameters:

```sh
x hua
```

![hua.1_1](/data-image/cookbook/mod/hua.1_1.webp)
<!-- *(Illustration: Shows the ancient book selection menu interface that appears after the `x hua` command.)* -->

After execution, a clear text selection interface will appear, listing many familiar classic titles, such as:

* `sj`: ã€Šè¯—ç»ã€‹ (Classic of Poetry)
* `cc`: ã€Šæ¥šè¾žã€‹ (Chu Ci)
* `ts`: ã€Šå”è¯—ä¸‰ç™¾é¦–ã€‹ (Three Hundred Tang Poems)
* `sc`: ã€Šå®‹è¯ä¸‰ç™¾é¦–ã€‹ (Three Hundred Song Words)
* `qjs`: ã€Šåƒå®¶è¯—ã€‹ (Poems of a Thousand Families)
* `dx`: ã€Šå¤§å­¦ã€‹ (Da Xue)
* `zy`: ã€Šä¸­åº¸ã€‹ (Doctrine of the Mean)
* `ly`: ã€Šè®ºè¯­ã€‹ (The Analects)
* `mz`: ã€Šå­Ÿå­ã€‹ (Mencius)
* `gwgz`: ã€Šå¤æ–‡è§‚æ­¢ã€‹ (Guwen Guanzhi)
* `caocao`: ã€Šæ›¹æ“è¯—é›†ã€‹ (Cao Cao's Poems)

You can use the up and down arrow keys to navigate the list, and press Enter to select and enter the corresponding classic reading interface.

Select the classic you are interested in, such as *The Analects*, and press Enter. Next, you will enter a powerful interactive selection interface. This is thanks to the integration of the `fzf` tool, which allows you to perform fast fuzzy searches.
In this interface:

  * **Left side** is the list of chapters in the classic. You can directly enter keywords (such as the author "Li Bai" or the title "Quiet Night Thought") to filter the list in real time.
  * **Right side** will synchronously display a content preview of the chapter currently selected by your cursor, allowing you to quickly browse before selecting, greatly improving search efficiency.

![hua.1_2](/data-image/cookbook/mod/hua.1_2.webp)
<!-- *(Illustration: Shows the `fzf` interactive selection interface that appears after pressing Enter to select a column. The left side is the list of poems, and the right side is a preview of the selected poem.)* -->

Once you find the chapter you like, press Enter again to confirm.
The full text of the chapter will be output completely and clearly to your terminal interface for you to read carefully. From selecting the classic to reading the full text, the whole process is smooth and seamless.

![hua_3](/data-image/cookbook/mod/hua_3.webp)
<!-- *(Illustration: Shows the full text of the selected poem being output to the terminal after pressing Enter.)* -->

## Poetic Delight: Roaming Through *Three Hundred Tang Poems*

If you have a special fondness for Tang poetry and want to directly consult *Three Hundred Tang Poems*, `x hua` also provides a convenient path. Just enter:

```sh
x hua ts
```

![hua_4](/data-image/cookbook/mod/hua_4.webp)
<!-- *(Illustration: Shows the `fzf` interactive selection interface for *Three Hundred Tang Poems* after the `x hua ts` command. The left side is the list of poems, and the right side is a preview of the selected poem.)* -->

Here, `ts` is the abbreviation for `tangshi300` (å”è¯—ä¸‰ç™¾ - Three Hundred Tang Poems). After executing the command, you will skip the main menu and directly enter the exclusive chapter selection interface for *Three Hundred Tang Poems*.

You can directly enter keywords (such as poem title, author name, or poem fragment) to perform a fuzzy search, and `fzf` will filter the matching results in real time. There is usually a preview window on the right that displays the complete content of the currently selected poem in real time. After finding the poem you like, press Enter to read the full poem clearly in the terminal.

## Lingering Rhymes: Savoring *Three Hundred Song Words*

Similar to consulting Tang poetry, if you want to savor the graceful and bold styles of Song lyrics, you can use the following command:

```sh
x hua sc
```

![hua_5](/data-image/cookbook/mod/hua_5.webp)
<!-- *(Illustration: Shows the `fzf` interactive selection interface for *Three Hundred Song Words* after the `x hua sc` command. The structure is similar to that of Tang poetry.)* -->

`sc` is the abbreviation for `songci300` (å®‹è¯ä¸‰ç™¾ - Three Hundred Song Words). Similarly, this will open an `fzf`-driven interactive interface, allowing you to efficiently browse and search for works in *Three Hundred Song Words*.

The interface layout and operation method are basically the same as the Tang poetry query interface, including information such as the lyric title, author, and content preview. You can quickly locate Su Shi's "The Great River Flows East" or Li Qingzhao's "Searching, Searching, Searching" through keywords.

## Advanced Techniques: Flexibly Adjusting the Reading Experience

When using the `fzf` interactive interface (such as when consulting Tang and Song poetry), `x hua` also provides a very practical tip to optimize your reading experience:

*   **`Ctrl-r`**: Switch the layout of the preview window.
    This shortcut allows you to switch between different preview modes, such as adjusting the preview window from the right side to the bottom, or temporarily hiding the preview window to focus more on the list itself. This is very useful for terminal windows of different sizes or personal preferences.

![hua_6](/data-image/cookbook/mod/hua_6.webp)
<!-- *(Illustration: Shows the fzf preview window being adjusted from the right side to the bottom.)* -->

`x hua` condenses the profound and extensive Chinese classics into a small command line, and through the convenience of modern CLI tools, makes the reading and retrieval of classical literature more efficient and enjoyable than ever before. Whether you want to quickly find a poem or systematically read a classic, `x hua` can be your powerful cultural assistant. Now, start your command-line cultural journey!

# x hub access

Access management, set file access permissions

## Examples

Make the cloud file &lt;path&gt; publicly accessible

```sh
x hub access set --public <path>
```

Grant user &lt;username&gt; access to the cloud file &lt;path&gt;

```sh
x hub access set --user <username> <path>
```

Grant users a, b, c, and d access to the cloud file &lt;path&gt;

```sh
x hub access set --user a,b,c,d <path>
```

Remove all non-owner access to &lt;path&gt; (keep the owner)

```sh
x hub access unset <path>
```

Revoke &lt;username&gt;'s access to the cloud file &lt;path&gt;

```sh
x hub access unset --user <username> <path>
```

Revoke access for users a, b, c, and d to the cloud file &lt;path&gt;

```sh
x hub access unset --user a,b,c,d <path>
```

## Sub Commands

| Name | Description |
| ------- | ------- |
| [x hub access set](#x-hub-access-set) | Configure access for a cloud file, make it public or grant to specific users only |
| [x hub access unset](#x-hub-access-unset) | Revoke access permissions. If not using --user, remove all non-owners. If using --user, remove only the specified user (multiple users are allowed). |


### x hub access set

Configure access for a cloud file, make it public or grant to specific users only


- **Usage**:

```sh
x hub access set [OPTIONS] [FLAGS] <#1>
```

- **Arguments**:


| Argument | Description |
| ------- | ------- |
| `#1` | Cloud file path |


- **Options**:


| Name, Shorthand | Default | Description |
| ------- | ------- | ------- |
| `--user` |  | Grant access to one or more users (separate multiple users with commas, e.g., a,b,c) |


- **Flags**:


| Name, Shorthand | Description |
| ------- | ------- |
| `--public` | Make the file publicly accessible (anyone can access) |


### x hub access unset

Revoke access permissions. If not using --user, remove all non-owners. If using --user, remove only the specified user (multiple users are allowed).


- **Usage**:

```sh
x hub access unset [OPTIONS] <#1>
```

- **Arguments**:


| Argument | Description |
| ------- | ------- |
| `#1` |  |


- **Options**:


| Name, Shorthand | Default | Description |
| ------- | ------- | ------- |
| `--user` |  | Specify users to revoke (separate multiple with commas, e.g., a,b,c) |

# x hub account

Account management, view account information, bind accounts

## Examples

View the account information of the current user, including username, email

```sh
x hub account info
```

Rename the account name of the current user

```sh

```

| ------- | ------- |

| [x hub account info](#x-hub-account-info) | View account information, and display the cloud space usage of the current user |
| [x hub account rename](#x-hub-account-rename) | Rename account |
| [x hub account upgrade](#x-hub-account-upgrade) | Upgrade account plan |
| [x hub account bind](#x-hub-account-bind) | Bind to other platforms, such as email. |

- **Flags**:


| Name, Shorthand | Description |

# x hub ai

x-cmd AI knowledge base construction and search.

## Examples

Upload files to build your personal knowledge base.

```sh
x hub ai emb --title <title> -f <path/file_name>
```

Enter text content to build a personal knowledge base in the cloud.

```sh
x hub ai emb <content>
```

Find answers to &lt;question&gt; in existing knowledge bases.

```sh
x hub ai <question>
```

Use x-cmd AI agent to write Python scripts. For example x hub ai agent 'Write a Hello World program in Python'

```sh
x hub ai agent <task>
```

## Sub Commands

| Name | Description |
| ------- | ------- |
| [x hub ai chat](#x-hub-ai-chat) | Find answers to question in existing knowledge bases. |
| [x hub ai emb](#x-hub-ai-emb) | Upload files or enter embedded content and store it in the cloud as a personal knowledge base. |
| [x hub ai agent](#x-hub-ai-agent) | Use x-cmd AI agent to execute a specified task. |


### x hub ai chat

Find answers to question in existing knowledge bases.


- **Usage**:


- **Arguments**:


| Argument | Description |
| ------- | ------- |
| `#1` | Problem Description |


- **Flags**:


| Name, Shorthand | Description |
| ------- | ------- |

### x hub ai emb

Upload files or enter embedded content and store it in the cloud as a personal knowledge base.

```sh
x hub ai emb|embedding [OPTIONS] <#1>
```

- **Arguments**:


| Argument | Description |
| ------- | ------- |

| ------- | ------- | ------- |

Use x-cmd AI agent to execute a specified task.


- **Usage**:

```sh
x hub ai agent <#1>
```

- **Arguments**:


| Argument | Description |
| ------- | ------- |
| `#1` | Describe the task you want the agent to perform. |

# x hub file

File management, put/download/view files

## Examples

List all files under the &lt;path&gt; folder of the current user in the cloud

```sh
x hub file ls <path>
```

View the contents of the &lt;path&gt; file of the &lt;username&gt; user in the cloud

```sh
x hub file cat [<username>:]<path>
```

Convert https://example.com/example.txt link to cloud file me:demo

```sh
x hub file link https://example.com/example.txt demo
```

Upload local file &lt;local path&gt; to cloud &lt;remote path&gt;

```sh
x hub file put <local path> <remote path>
```

## Sub Commands

| Name | Description |
| ------- | ------- |
| [x hub file ls](#x-hub-file-ls) | List all files or directories under the specified folder of the current user in the cloud, the default is the root directory |
| [x hub file ll](#x-hub-file-ll) | List all files or directories under the specified folder of the current user's cloud, and display extended file metadata in table form. |
| [x hub file cat](#x-hub-file-cat) | View the contents of the cloud file |
| [x hub file put](#x-hub-file-put) | Upload file to the cloud, the default is private files |
| [x hub file get](#x-hub-file-get) | Download cloud files to local, by default download to the current directory |
| [x hub file link](#x-hub-file-link) | Convert a url link to a cloud file |
| [x hub file which](#x-hub-file-which) | Download and print the path from local, default cache 1 hour |
| [x hub file rm](#x-hub-file-rm) | Delete the cloud file |
| [x hub file update](#x-hub-file-update) | Updating local cache file. |


### x hub file ls

List all files or directories under the specified folder of the current user in the cloud, the default is the root directory


- **Examples**:

List all files or directories under the &lt;path&gt; folder of the current user in the cloud

```sh
x hub file ls <path>
```

Recursively list all files or directories under the &lt;path&gt; folder of the current user in the cloud, and display extended file metadata as a table

```sh
x hub file ls -R -l <path>
```

List all files or directories under the root directory of the current user in the cloud, and display extended file metadata as a table

```sh
x hub file ls -l
```

- **Usage**:

```sh
x hub file ls [FLAGS] <#1>
```

- **Arguments**:


| Argument | Description |
| ------- | ------- |
| `#1` | Specify the folder path |


- **Flags**:


| Name, Shorthand | Description |
| ------- | ------- |
| `--recurse`, `-R` | Recurse into directories |
| `--long`, `-l` | Display extended file metadata as a table |
| `--json` | Output in JSON format |


### x hub file ll

List all files or directories under the specified folder of the current user's cloud, and display extended file metadata in table form.


- **Usage**:

```sh
x hub file ll
```

### x hub file cat

View the contents of the cloud file


- **Usage**:

```sh
x hub file cat <#1>
```

- **Arguments**:


| Argument | Description |
| ------- | ------- |
| `#1` | File path |


### x hub file put

Upload file to the cloud, the default is private files


- **Examples**:

Upload local file example.txt to cloud me:example.txt, and set it as a public file

```sh
x hub file put --public example.txt
```

Upload local file example.txt to cloud me:demo/example.txt

```sh
x hub file put example.txt demo/
```

Upload local file example.txt to cloud me:demo

```sh
x hub file put example.txt demo
```

- **Usage**:

```sh
x hub file put|upload [FLAGS] <#1> <#2>
```

- **Arguments**:


| Argument | Description |
| ------- | ------- |
| `#1` | Local file path |
| `#2` | Cloud file path |


- **Flags**:


| Name, Shorthand | Description |
| ------- | ------- |
| `--force`, `-f` | Force put, even if the file already exists |
| `--public` | Set as public file |


### x hub file get

Download cloud files to local, by default download to the current directory


- **Examples**:

Download cloud file me:demo/example.txt to local example.txt, when no local file path is specified, the default is the current directory

```sh
x hub file download demo/example.txt
```

Download cloud file me:demo/example.txt to local example.txt

```sh
x hub file download demo/example.txt example.txt
```

Download cloud file me:demo/example.txt to local /tmp/example.txt, if the local file already exists, it will be overwritten

```sh
x hub file download -f demo/example.txt /tmp/
```

- **Usage**:

```sh
x hub file get|download [FLAGS] <#1> <#2>
```

- **Arguments**:


| Argument | Description |
| ------- | ------- |
| `#1` | Cloud file path |
| `#2` | Local file path |


- **Flags**:


| Name, Shorthand | Description |
| ------- | ------- |
| `--force`, `-f` | Force overwrite local file |


### x hub file link

Convert a url link to a cloud file


- **Examples**:

Convert https://example.com/example.txt link to cloud file me:demo

```sh
x hub file link https://example.com/example.txt demo
```

- **Usage**:

```sh
x hub file link [FLAGS] <#1> <#2>
```

- **Arguments**:


| Argument | Description |
| ------- | ------- |
| `#1` | Specify the url link (support http/https)<br>`http://` &#124; `https://` |
| `#2` | Specify the cloud file path |


- **Flags**:


| Name, Shorthand | Description |
| ------- | ------- |
| `--force`, `-f` | Force put, even if the file already exists |
| `--public` | Set as public file |


### x hub file which

Download and print the path from local, default cache 1 hour


- **Usage**:

```sh
x hub file which [FLAGS] <#1>
```

- **Arguments**:


| Argument | Description |
| ------- | ------- |
| `#1` |  |


- **Flags**:


| Name, Shorthand | Description |
| ------- | ------- |
| `--no-cache` | No cache |


### x hub file rm

Delete the cloud file


- **Usage**:

```sh
x hub file rm [FLAGS] <#1>
```

- **Arguments**:


| Argument | Description |
| ------- | ------- |
| `#1` |  |


- **Flags**:


| Name, Shorthand | Description |
| ------- | ------- |
| `--recurse`, `-r` | Recursively delete |
| `--force`, `-f` | Force delete, even if the file does not exist |
| `--cache` | Delete local cache files. |


### x hub file update

Updating local cache file.


- **Usage**:

```sh
x hub file update <#1>
```

- **Arguments**:


| Argument | Description |
| ------- | ------- |
| `#1` | The filename that needs to be updated. |

# x install - Your Cross-Platform Software Installation Swiss Army Knife

In the command line world, installing software is a daily routine. But have you ever been frustrated by searching for and executing the correct installation commands on different operating systems (Linux distributions, macOS, Windows/WSL)? `apt`, `yum`, `dnf`, `pacman`, `brew`, `scoop`, `winget`... Different package managers, different command formats, and sometimes needing to add PPAs or configure sources can disrupt your workflow.

Now, with `x install`, you can say goodbye to these troubles! It acts like a Swiss Army knife, designed to be your unified software installation entry point, helping you quickly find and execute the installation commands suitable for your current system.

<Terminal demo="/cookbook/mod/install.en.json" size="large" />

## Interactive Exploration: Your Personal Software Marketplace

When you only have a vague impression of the software you want to install, or you want to see what goodies `x install` has to offer, simply run the `x install` command to open a powerful interactive interface (usually based on `fzf` or similar tools).

```sh
x install
```

![x install](/data-image/cookbook/mod/install.1_1.en.webp)

In this interface, you can:

1.  **Fuzzy Search**: Enter keywords, and the list will be filtered in real-time, quickly locating the software you need.
2.  **Real-time Preview**: Select a piece of software, and the preview window on the right will immediately display detailed information about the software, including:
  *  Software Name (Name)
  *  Official Website (Homepage)
  *  Feature Description (Description)
  *  Primary Language (Language)
  *  **Key Installation Command (cmd)**: `x install` will intelligently display the most suitable installation method and its source (reference) based on your current operating system and environment.
3.  **Select and Execute**: Once youâ€™ve found the software youâ€™re interested in, press Enter, and `x install` will guide you to confirm and execute the selected installation command.

This interactive experience is like having a portable, on-demand software marketplace!

## Precise Targeting: Directly Obtain Installation Guides

If you know exactly which software you want to install, like `docker` or `dust`, you can directly pass the software name as an argument to `x install`.

```sh
x install docker
x install dust
```

`x install` will quickly locate the information for `docker` and analyze your current system environment (e.g., whether itâ€™s Ubuntu or macOS), then clearly list the recommended installation commands. If there are multiple installation methods available (like system package managers, official scripts, Snap, etc.), it may offer options for you to choose from. Once confirmed, you can start the installation.

Whether it's a common development tool or a niche utility, if `x install` has it in its database, you can quickly get installation guides and execute installations in this way.

## Stay Updated: Update Your Software Installation Library

The software world is ever-evolving, with new versions and installation methods emerging continuously. To ensure that `x install` provides accurate and effective information, you need to regularly update its metadata.

```sh
x install --update
```

Running this command will make `x install` pull the latest software installation information database from its configured sources (usually the x-cmd repository). Itâ€™s like updating the product catalog of your â€œsoftware marketplaceâ€ application, ensuring you can find the latest and best installation methods.

---

`x install` greatly simplifies the complexity of cross-platform software installation with its sleek interaction and intelligent backend logic. Whether you're a command line novice or a seasoned user, it helps you save a lot of time spent searching for documentation and commands, allowing you to focus on what truly matters. Try `x install` now and experience a smoother command line workflow!

# x ip (1) - Get Local IP Address and Network Information

## Get Your Local and Public IP Addresses

Retrieving local and public IP address information varies across different operating systems, and sometimes requires installing additional tools via package managers.

To simplify this process, `x-cmd` provides the `x ip` command, offering a consistent experience across various operating systems.

```sh
x ip
```

![x ip](/data-image/cookbook/mod/ip.1_1.webp)

Running this command will automatically detect and display your current local and public IP addresses, allowing you to quickly check and confirm your network status.

## Get the Geographical Location of a Public IP Address

`x ip` supports retrieving the geographical location of a specified IP address using the `ipinfo.io` service.

Running the following command will display the geographical location data of your public IP address, such as the country and city.

```sh
x ip geolite
```

You can also query the location information of any other IP address to analyze the geographical distribution of network connections.

```sh
x ip geolite 8.8.8.8
x ip geolite 185.199.108.153
```

## List Active Hosts on the Same Local Network

`x ip` provides a simple IP scanning feature that helps you quickly detect active hosts on the same local network.

For example, running the following command will scan all active hosts within the `192.168.89.0/24` subnet and display their IP addresses. This is useful for device discovery and network troubleshooting within a local network.

```sh
x ip map 192.168.89.0/24
```

![x ip map](/data-image/cookbook/mod/ip.1_2.webp)

# x jq (1): Interactive JSON Data Exploration Tool

## 1. Introduction: Challenges of JSON Data Processing and Solutions

In modern software development, JSON (JavaScript Object Notation) has become the de facto standard for data interchange. However, directly processing large amounts of JSON data can be cumbersome, especially in a command-line environment. `jq` is a powerful command-line JSON processing tool that allows you to query, transform, and filter JSON data using a functional programming-style DSL (domain-specific language).

Despite `jq`'s powerful capabilities, its imperative syntax and complex expressions may present a learning curve for beginners. To address this problem, websites like [jqplay.org](https://jqplay.org) and the [jqp](https://x-cmd.com/install/jqp) command-line solution provide interactive ways to explore jq.

The `x jq r` discussed in this article is an interactive JSON data exploration tool built on `fzf`, provided by x-cmd, designed for a more intuitive and efficient JSON data processing experience.

## 2. Core Features and Advantages of `x jq r`

The core goal of `x jq r` is to make JSON data exploration simpler, faster, and more efficient. It achieves this through the following key features:

*  **Interactive Exploration:** Say goodbye to the tedious command execution and result viewing loops. `x jq r` allows you to input and modify jq expressions in real-time, immediately seeing results, which greatly accelerates the learning and debugging process.
*  **YAML Preview:** While JSON is universal, it may not always be easy to read. `x jq r` uses `yq` to convert JSON results into YAML format for previewing. YAML is more compact and easier to understand, especially when dealing with nested structures.
*  **Dependency Management:** No need to manually install `jq`, `yq`, and `fzf`. `x-cmd` automatically detects and downloads the necessary tools, ensuring that your environment remains clean and minimizing impacts on the system environment.
*  **Fuzzy Search and Filtering:** The powerful fuzzy search capabilities of `fzf` can help you quickly locate specific fields or values within JSON data, thus simplifying the process of selecting and filtering data.

## 3. Workflow of `x jq r`: Step-by-Step JSON Data Exploration

The workflow of `x jq r` is very simple and straightforward:

1.  **Data Input:** Pass JSON data to the `x jq r` command through a pipeline. For example:
  ```bash
  x docker image ls --json | x jq r
  ```
  This command takes the JSON output of `x docker image ls` as input for `x jq r`.

2.  **Expression Input:** `x jq r` launches the `fzf` interface. In the interface, you can enter `jq` expressions.
3.  **Real-time Preview:** As you input the `jq` expression, `x jq r` executes the expression in real-time, displaying results converted into YAML format within the `fzf` interface. If the expression is incorrect, corresponding error messages will be displayed. This real-time feedback mechanism helps you quickly understand the effects of `jq` expressions and spot errors promptly.
4.  **Exit and Output:** Press the `Enter` key to exit the `fzf` interface. The final `jq` expression will be output to the terminal, which you can use for subsequent commands or scripts.

## 4. Demonstration: Extracting Specific Attributes from Docker Image List

Letâ€™s demonstrate the use of `x jq r` through a concrete example:

### 4.1. Retrieve Docker Image List

First, use the `x docker image ls --json` command to get the list of Docker images in JSON format.

```bash
x docker image ls --json
```

This command outputs a JSON array containing information about all Docker images.

### 4.2. Explore Data with `x jq r`

Pass the JSON data through a pipeline to `x jq r`:

```bash
x docker image ls --json | x jq r
```

This will launch the `fzf` interface and display the JSON data of Docker images.

### 4.3. Exploring the JSON Structure

*  **`.` (Dot):** Inputting `.` (dot) in the `fzf` interface represents the entire JSON object. This will display the complete JSON data, giving you a preliminary understanding of the overall structure.

*  **`.[]` (Bracket):** Inputting `.[ ]` indicates all elements within the JSON array. This will expand the JSON array and display each element one by one.

### 4.4. Extracting Specific Attributes

*  **`.[] | .RepoTags` (Pipe):** Inputting `.[] | .RepoTags` retrieves the `RepoTags` attribute for all images. The `.` accesses the object's properties, and `|` (pipe) passes the result of the previous expression to the next one.

*  **`.[] | .RepoTags[0]` (Array Index):** Inputting `.[] | .RepoTags[0]` retrieves the first `RepoTag` of each image.

### 4.5. Real-time Preview and Adjustment

During the inputting of the `jq` expression, `x jq r` will display results in real-time, allowing you to see the effects of the expression immediately. If the results do not meet your expectations, you can modify the expression at any time until you obtain the correct outcome.

## 5. Summary of Advantages: Why Choose `x jq r`?

*  **Easy to Get Started:** The interactive exploration approach lowers the learning curve of `jq`, enabling even beginners to quickly get started.
*  **Efficient Debugging:** The real-time preview feature can quickly pinpoint and resolve issues in JSON data processing, saving significant debugging time.
*  **No Installation Required:** `x-cmd` manages dependency tools automatically, avoiding the hassle of manual installation and keeping the environment clean.
*  **YAML Preview:** YAML format is more readable and understandable, especially when dealing with complex nested structures.

## 6. Further Reading: Other Interactive Tools in the x-cmd Ecosystem

`x-cmd` also provides similar interactive exploration tools based on `fzf` for commands like `yq`, `find`, `rg`, etc. These tools all follow the same design philosophy, aiming to simplify command-line operations and enhance user experience.

*  **`x yq r`:** An interactive YAML data exploration tool, similar to `x jq r`, but for handling YAML data.
*  **`x find r`:** An interactive file search tool built on the `find` command and `fzf`.
*  **`x rg r`:** An interactive code search tool built on the `ripgrep` command and `fzf`.

## 7. Extension: x-cmd Automatically Installs Required jq, yq, fzf Dependencies on Demand

1. If you already have jq, yq, and fzf installed in your local environment, then `x jq` will use the local binaries first.
2. If the required dependencies are not present in your local environment, x-cmd will download the corresponding tools from its managed x-cmd pkg (to ensure safety) and use them.
3. Note that by default (except in the Termux environment), to minimize impacts on the user's system and environment, x-cmd does not directly install these tools to your system directories or change your environment variables; if users need to install them, they can do so by using `x env use jq` or `x i jq` to select an appropriate installation method.
4. Starting from v0.6.0, x-cmd provides a dependency system management method to replace x-cmd pkg for on-demand software installation. This approach was introduced primarily for Termux, iSH, container Linux, or brew environments, and this mode requires the current user to have permission to directly install software.

# x kev - Known Exploited Vulnerability (KEV) List Query Tool

## Introduction

The `x kev` module is a command-line tool used to query a list of Known Exploited Vulnerabilities (KEVs).  This tool provides two main functions: listing all KEVs and listing the top N KEVs.

## Usage

The `x kev` module supports the following subcommands:

### `ls` Command

Lists all vulnerabilities in the KEV list.

```bash
x kev ls
```

This command will output information about all vulnerabilities in the KEV list.


### `top` Command

Lists the top N vulnerabilities in the KEV list.

```bash
x kev top <number>
```

Where `<number>` represents the number of vulnerabilities to list. For example, to list the top 100 vulnerabilities, use the following command:

```bash
x kev top 100
```

This command will output information about the top N vulnerabilities in the KEV list.


## Examples

Here are some examples of using the `x kev` module:

**Example 1: List all KEVs**

```bash
x kev ls
```

This command will list all vulnerabilities in the KEV list.


**Example 2: List the top 100 KEVs**

```bash
x kev top 100
```

This command will list the top 100 most impactful vulnerabilities in the KEV list.


## More Information

Please visit our homepage [https://x-cmd.com](https://x-cmd.com) for more information.

# x last - View User Login/Logout Records and System Reboot History

The `x last` command is used to view recent user login and logout records, as well as system reboot history. It supports various output formats (JSON, CSV) and views (tree view), allowing users to quickly view and analyze login/logout information.

## Quick Start

Here are some common `x last` command examples:

* **View recent user login and logout records:**

```bash
x last
```

* **View recent user login and logout records in CSV format:**

```bash
x last --csv
```

* **View recent user login and logout records in JSON format:**

```bash
x last --json
```

* **View system reboot history:**

```bash
x last --reboot
```

* **View user login and logout records, grouped by reboot, displayed in a tree view:**

```bash
x last --tree
```

## Output Formats and Views

The `x last` command supports the following output formats and views:

* **Default Format:** Displays user login and logout times, usernames, and other information in an easy-to-read table format.
* **JSON Format (`--json`):** Outputs data in JSON format, making it easy for programs to process and analyze.
* **CSV Format (`--csv`):** Outputs data in CSV format, making it easy to import into spreadsheet software.
* **Tree View (`--tree`):** Groups user login and logout records by system reboot and displays them in a tree structure, clearly showing login activity within each reboot cycle.

## More Information

The `x last` command provides rich functionality to help users better understand system login activity. You can get more information by visiting [https://x-cmd.com](https://x-cmd.com).

## Combining with Other Commands

The `x last` command can be used in conjunction with other `x-cmd` commands. For example, you can combine it with the `x grep` command to filter login records for a specific user.

### x llmf chat request

send a request


- **Usage**:

```sh
x llmf chat request [OPTIONS] [FLAGS] <#n>
```

- **Arguments**:


| Argument | Description |
| ------- | ------- |
| `#n` | The parameter content will be concatenated with spaces and sent to AI as a question |


- **Options**:


| Name, Shorthand | Default | Description |
| ------- | ------- | ------- |
| `--temperature`, `-t` |  | Control the diversity of model generated results, with a value greater than or equal to 0, when the temperature is higher, the model will be more random |
| `--seed` |  | Control the reproducibility of the job. Passing in the same seed and job parameters should produce the same results, but may differ in rare cases. If a seed is not specified, one will be generated for you. |
| `--maxtoken` |  | Control the maximum token length of the model response |
| `--jina` |  | Through jina reader, send the webpage content as context to AI |
| `--ddgo` |  | Send ddgo search content as context to AI |
| `--tldr` |  | Send tldr content as context to AI |
| `--eval` |  | Send the execution command results as context to AI |
| `-e` |  | Send the variable value as context to AI |
| `--file`, `-f` |  | Send file content as context to AI |
| `--kv` |  | Send key-value pairs as context to AI |
| `--session` |  | Specify session value |
| `--minion` |  | Specify minion file |
| `--history`, `-n` |  | Specify the number of history as context |
| `--model` |  | Specify AI model |
| `-p`, `--pipe` |  | Specify to get pipe content |
| `--tool`, `--allowed-tools` |  | Comma-separated list of tool names to allow (e.g. "writefile,writefile,shcmd") |
| `--provider` |  | Specify AI provider |


- **Flags**:


| Name, Shorthand | Description |
| ------- | ------- |
| `-P`, `--nopipe` | Specify not to get pipe content |
| `-c` | Confirm before sending the request content to AI |
| `--edit` | Edit the request content in the terminal |
| `--question` | Request content |
| `--reasoning` | Show AI's reasoning process |
| `--no-reasoning` | Do not show AI's reasoning process, default on |
| `--stream` | Use streaming output, default on |
| `--no-stream` | Do not use streaming output |
| `--require-question` | Disallow empty request content |
| `--start-with-repl` | Start in REPL mode before sending the request |
| `--end-with-repl` | Start in REPL mode after sending the request (default behavior in interactive mode) |
| `--start-without-repl` | Start without REPL mode before sending the request |
| `--end-without-repl` | End without REPL mode after sending the request |
| `--without-repl` | Do not start REPL mode |

# x ls (1) - View directory or compressed package content

## View the content of the current directory

`x ls` provides an interactive APP that helps users quickly view the content of the current directory or a specific path, especially suitable for scenarios where it is necessary to frequently view directory content during debugging.

```sh
x ls
x ls ls ~/.x-cmd.root
```

![x ls (1)](/data-image/cookbook/mod/ls.1_1.webp)

![x ls (2)](/data-image/cookbook/mod/ls.1_2.webp)

- In the interactive APP:
   - Users can quickly switch between different directories and view their files and basic information using keyboard keys.
   - After selecting a file or directory and pressing Enter, a shortcut menu for the next step will be provided, such as switching directories, deleting files, etc.

## View the content of directories introduced by PATH

In some scenarios, you may need to view the directories introduced by the PATH environment variable in the system to analyze environment variable configurations or troubleshoot whether commands are executed correctly.

Running the following command will provide an interactive APP to view the content of directories introduced by the PATH environment variable in the system.

```sh
x ls :path
```

![x ls :path](/data-image/cookbook/mod/ls.1_3.webp)

## View the content of compressed packages

`x ls` also provides the function of quickly listing the file structure of compressed packages without decompression, to cope with scenarios where it is necessary to check the content of compressed packages or confirm whether the compressed files are valid.

```sh
x ls :/path/<Compressed package name>.zip
x ls :/path/<Compressed package name>.tar.gz
x ls :/Users/xcmd/Download/x-cmd.zip
```

![x ls :tar](/data-image/cookbook/mod/ls.1_4.webp)

---
[More] If you want to learn more about the ls module, please visit the x-cmd official website - x-cmd.com/mod/ls

---
url: /mod/ls/cookbook-2.md
---

# x ls (2) - View System Information

## View Process Information

`x ls :ps` provides an interactive APP that helps users quickly view all running processes in the current system and their basic information (such as process ID, memory usage, etc.). It is suitable for users who need to frequently check and control processes.

```sh
x ls :ps
```

![x ls :ps 1](/data-image/cookbook/mod/ls.2_1.webp)

![x ls :ps 2](/data-image/cookbook/mod/ls.2_2.webp)

- In the interactive APP:
   - Users can use keyboard shortcuts to browse different processes and view the detailed information of each process.
   - After selecting a process and pressing Enter, a shortcut operation menu will be provided for the next step, such as viewing detailed information, ending the process, etc.

## View CPU Information

`x ls :cpu` can quickly view the CPU configuration and status information of the current system, including the processor model, number of cores, number of threads, etc.

```sh
x ls :cpu
```

![x ls :cpu](/data-image/cookbook/mod/ls.2_3.webp)

## View Virtual Memory Information

`x ls :mem` can display the virtual memory usage of the current system, including total memory, used memory, free memory, and other indicators.

```sh
x ls :mem
```

![x ls :mem](/data-image/cookbook/mod/ls.2_4.webp)

# x mac - macOS Command-Line Assistant: Your Terminal Swiss Army Knife

Tired of cumbersome macOS command-line operations?  x mac is here to help! It's like your personal command-line Swiss Army knife â€“ powerful, easy to use, and it will completely change how you interact with your terminal! Say goodbye to tedious commands and embrace a highly efficient and convenient user experience!

## Fingerprint Authentication for sudo: Say Goodbye to Password Hassles

No more repeatedly entering long sudo passwords! x mac supports fingerprint (Touch ID) authentication for sudo commands.  With a single touch, you gain administrator privileges â€“ securely and quickly, transforming you into a macOS master in an instant!

```bash
x mac tidsudo enable  # Enable fingerprint authentication for sudo
```

## Custom Shortcuts: Your Personalized Command Mnemonics

Tired of typing those lengthy commands? x mac lets you create custom shortcuts. For example, set "m" as an abbreviation for x mac; then, simply type "m" to access all functions! You can set any abbreviation you like, making your command-line operations more personalized and efficient.

```bash
x mac alias enable m  # Set "m" as an abbreviation for x mac
# Or customize your abbreviation:
x mac alias enable mymac  # Set "mymac" as an abbreviation for x mac
```


## More Useful Features: A Glimpse of the Highlights

x mac offers far more than just sudo authentication and command abbreviations. It includes a suite of powerful features to help you efficiently manage your macOS system, making your Mac run smoother and more securely!

### Battery Level: Control Your Power

Stay informed about your Mac's battery status at all times; never worry about unexpected power outages again!

```bash
x mac b  # Check battery information
```

### System Information: Understand Your Mac

Quickly view system information, including memory usage, CPU load, and other key metrics, giving you a clear picture of your Mac's performance.

```bash
x mac info  # View system information
```

### One-Click Lock Screen: Protect Your Privacy

Protect your Mac's security; lock the screen with a simple command to keep your data safe.

```bash
x mac lock  # Lock screen
```

## Summary: Embark on Your Efficient macOS Command-Line Journey

x mac provides a powerful set of macOS command-line tools covering system administration, network settings, device information, and more. It not only simplifies your daily operations but also improves your efficiency and security. Experience x mac today, embark on your efficient macOS command-line journey, and enjoy unprecedented convenience and smoothness!

**Stay tuned for subsequent chapters in this series, where we will delve deeper into more application scenarios and advanced features of `x mac`!**

url: /mod/mac/sandbox.md
