# x uninstall - Your Cross-Platform Software Uninstaller

In our daily command-line work, we often use different package managers (such as `brew`, `apt`, `scoop`, etc.) to install various tools and software. Over time, managing these dispersed installations, especially uninstalling them, can become a hassle. You need to remember which manager was used for installation and search for the corresponding uninstall command.

The `x uninstall` command is designed to address this pain point. It provides a unified interface and process that helps you quickly find and uninstall software installed in various ways, and it can even be used to uninstall `x-cmd` itself.

## Interactive Uninstallation: A One-Stop Software Management Experience

When you forget which package manager was used to install a certain software, or you want to browse the software currently installed on your system that can be managed by `x-cmd`, simply running `x uninstall` is the easiest way.

```sh
x uninstall
```

After executing this command, `x uninstall` will launch an interactive application interface. In this interface, it will attempt to list the installed software from different package managers (such as Homebrew, APT, Scoop, etc., depending on your system and installations). You can conveniently browse through this list, select the software you want to manage, and follow the prompts to either uninstall it or view more detailed installation information.

<!-- **ï¼ˆ[image] Show the interface of the interactive `x uninstall`, listing software like `bat (brew)`, `fzf (apt)`, etc.ï¼‰** -->
![1](/data-image/cookbook/mod/uninstall.1_1.webp)

This interactive method greatly simplifies software management, allowing you to perform uninstallation operations without memorizing complex commandsâ€”just a few clicks and you're done.

## Precise Uninstallation: Specify Package Manager and Software

If you clearly know which software you want to uninstall and are aware of the package manager used for its installation, you can use the `rm` subcommand for quick and precise uninstallation.

For example, if you want to uninstall the `bat` software package installed through `brew`:

```sh
x uninstall rm brew bat
```

This command directly invokes `brew`'s uninstall functionality to remove `bat`. Its basic format is:

```
x uninstall rm <package manager name> <software name>
```

This method is ideal for use in scripts or when you have a specific target in mind, allowing you to get straight to the point without entering the interactive interface.

## Bid Farewell to x-cmd: Safely Uninstall Itself

If you decide you no longer want to use `x-cmd`, `x uninstall` also provides an option to uninstall itself.

```sh
x uninstall self
```

Executing this command will guide you through the uninstallation process of `x-cmd`. Given that this is a significant operation (removing the core files and related configurations of `x-cmd`), `x uninstall self` typically provides clear prompts and confirmation steps to ensure you understand the consequences of the operation, preventing accidental actions.

<!-- **ï¼ˆ[image] Show the confirmation prompt interface that appears after running `x uninstall self`ï¼‰** -->
![2](/data-image/cookbook/mod/uninstall.1_2.webp)

---

In summary, `x uninstall` offers a powerful and convenient unified entry point for managing and uninstalling command-line software from different sources through its interactive interface. Whether for daily maintenance or precise operations, it can help you get the job done effortlessly.

# x winget - An Efficient Windows Package Manager

## Introduction

The `x winget` module provides developers and system administrators on Windows with an efficient package management solution. It runs within terminals like WSL2 or Git Bash, eliminating the need to open PowerShell, allowing convenient installation, updating, and uninstallation of Windows programs using the `winget` command-line tool. `x winget` streamlines the Windows package management process, improves efficiency, and allows you to focus on development tasks.


## Key Features

`x winget` offers the following key features:

* **Seamless Integration:** Use the `winget` command directly in terminals like WSL2 or Git Bash without switching terminals.
* **winget Command Integration:** Directly invoke `winget` commands for quick installation, updates, and uninstallation of software.
* **Mirror Source Configuration:** Built-in mirror source configuration for users in mainland China, allowing one-click switching to domestic mirrors (e.g., USTC) to accelerate download speeds.
* **Powerful Autocompletion:** Provides robust command and parameter autocompletion for enhanced user experience.
* **Proxy Settings:** Supports proxy server configuration for use in restricted network environments.
* **Search Functionality:** Integrates DuckDuckGo search for easy lookup of software information.  Provides two search modes:
    * `x winget : <keyword>`: Searches for keywords on learn.microsoft.com and github.com/microsoft/winget-pkgs.
    * `x winget :: <keyword>`: Uses DuckDuckGo and an AI module to summarize and filter search results.


## Quick Start

### Installing Software

Use the `install` or `add` command to install software:

```bash
x winget install 7zip
```

This will install 7-Zip using `winget`. You can list installed software with the `-i` or `--installed` parameter, and list all installable software with `-a` or `--all`.


### Managing Mirror Sources

Use the `mirror` command to manage `winget`'s mirror sources:

* Set the USTC mirror source:

```bash
x winget mirror set ustc
```

* List all available mirror sources:

```bash
x winget mirror ls
```

* Show the current mirror source:

```bash
x winget mirror current
```

* Unset a mirror source:

```bash
x winget mirror unset ustc  # Unset the USTC mirror source
x winget mirror unset all   # Force reset all mirror sources
```


### Setting a Proxy

Use the `proxy` command to configure `winget`'s proxy:

* Set a proxy:

```bash
x winget proxy use http://127.0.0.1:8080
```

* Set a temporary proxy (only effective for the current shell):

```bash
x winget proxy try http://127.0.0.1:8080
```


### Listing Installed Software

Use the `ls` or `list` command to list installed software:

```bash
x winget ls
x winget ls -i  # Equivalent to x winget ls --installed
```

Use the `la` command to list all installable software:

```bash
x winget la
```


### Using DuckDuckGo Search

Use `:` or `::` to search for relevant information on DuckDuckGo:

* Simple search:

```bash
x winget : 7zip
```

* AI-assisted search:

```bash
x winget :: "winget source"
```


### Executing Native winget Commands

Use `--` to execute native `winget` commands:

```bash
x winget -- search notepad++
```


## Summary

The `x winget` module provides a simple, user-friendly, and powerful interface for managing Windows software packages.  Its features allow for more efficient management of your Windows system software. For more information, please visit [https://x-cmd.com](https://x-cmd.com).

# x wkp - Wikipedia Search and Information Extraction

The `x wkp` module provides a convenient set of commands for searching Wikipedia and extracting information. It supports various search methods and output formats, and allows customization of proxies and API endpoints.

## Initialization Configuration

Before first use, it's recommended to use the `init` command for interactive initialization configuration:

```bash
x wkp init
```

This command will guide you through setting up a network proxy (optional) and API endpoint (optional). You can also manually configure using the `--cfg` command:

```bash
# Set proxy
x wkp --cfg proxy=http://your_proxy:port

# Set API endpoint (optional)
x wkp --cfg endpoint=https://your_api_endpoint
```

View the current session configuration:

```bash
x wkp --cfg cat
```

Clear the current session configuration, restoring default values:

```bash
x wkp --cfg clear
```


## Searching Wikipedia Pages

Use the `search` command to search Wikipedia pages by title:

```bash
x wkp search OpenAI
```

This command defaults to text output. You can use the `-j` or `-y` parameters for JSON or YAML output respectively:

```bash
# JSON output
x wkp search -j OpenAI

# YAML output
x wkp search -y OpenAI

# CSV output
x wkp search --csv OpenAI

# Use interactive UI to view
x wkp search --app OpenAI
```

## Getting Page Extracts

Use the `extract` command to get an extract of a specified Wikipedia page:

```bash
x wkp extract OpenAI
```

Similarly, you can use the `-j` or `-y` parameters to change the output format:

```bash
# JSON output
x wkp extract -j OpenAI

# YAML output
x wkp extract -y OpenAI
```

## Getting Search Suggestions

Use the `suggest` command to get Wikipedia search suggestions:

```bash
x wkp suggest OpenAI
```

## Using DuckDuckGo Search

Use the `ddgo` command to search Wikipedia using DuckDuckGo:

```bash
x wkp ddgo: OpenAI
```

This will use DuckDuckGo to search for Wikipedia information related to "OpenAI".


## Opening Wikipedia Pages

Use the `open` command to open the searched Wikipedia page in your default browser:

```bash
x wkp open OpenAI
```


## Quick Search and Extraction

Use the `hop` command for a quick search of the page title and output the extract of the first result:

```bash
x wkp hop OpenAI
```


## Session Default Value Management

Use the `--cur` command to manage the default values for the current session:

```bash
# Set proxy
x wkp --cur set proxy=http://your_proxy:port

# Set API endpoint (optional)
x wkp --cur set endpoint=https://your_api_endpoint
```


## Summary

The `x wkp` module provides a powerful toolset for interacting with Wikipedia.  Through flexible commands and configuration options, you can easily search, extract, and browse Wikipedia information. Visit our homepage for more information: [https://x-cmd.com/mod/wkp](https://x-cmd.com/mod/wkp)

# x wttr - Check Weather Forecast

## Quick Start

The `x wttr` module retrieves weather forecast information from `wttr.in`. By default, it automatically detects your IP address and displays the weather for your location. You can also specify a city or other location, such as an airport code (IATA code), GPS coordinates, or area code.

### Check the Weather at Your Current Location

Simply run `x wttr` to see the weather forecast for your current location:

```bash
x wttr
```

### Check the Weather at a Specific Location

To check the weather at a different location, simply add the location name after the command. For example, to check the weather in Zhongshan:

```bash
x wttr zhongshan
```

### Check the Moon Phase

`x wttr` can also display moon phase information. It displays the current moon phase by default, but you can also specify a date to see the moon phase for a specific date:

```bash
x wttr moon  # Check current moon phase
x wttr moon@2024-03-08 # Check moon phase on March 8, 2024
```

## Advanced Usage

### Using the `--api` Parameter to Customize Requests

`wttr.in` provides a rich set of API parameters. You can use the `--api` parameter to customize your request. For example, to see today's weather:

```bash
x wttr --api ?1
```

### Using the `--unit` Parameter to Set Units

You can use the `--unit` parameter to globally set the units for temperature and wind speed. By default, `x wttr` automatically selects appropriate units based on your request address.For example, to set Celsius and km/h:

```bash
x wttr --unit c,kmh
```

## More Information

`wttr.in` provides very detailed weather information, including:

* Real-time weather conditions
* Temperature
* Humidity
* Wind speed and direction
* Weather forecast for the next few days (3 days by default)
* Weather for morning, afternoon, evening, and night

For more information, please visit the [wttr.in official](https://wttr.in) or visit our homepage for more information: [https://x-cmd.com](https://x-cmd.com)

# xq: Your XML and HTML Swiss Army Knife

When dealing with XML and HTML data, you often encounter messy formatting and difficulties extracting specific information.  xq, this powerful command-line tool, acts like your Swiss Army knife, helping you easily tackle various challenges! It can format cluttered code, precisely extract the data you need, and even convert data into easily usable JSON format. Let's quickly get started and experience the power of xq!

The `x xq` module automatically prepares the xq tool for you and provides convenient features such as an interactive repl.

## Formatting XML and HTML: Making Code Visually Appealing

One of xq's most commendable features is its powerful formatting capabilities. It can transform disorganized XML and HTML code into a well-structured format, improving readability and maintainability.

**Formatting XML files:**

Just use a simple command:

```bash
x xq <your XML file path>
```

Replace `<your XML file path>` with the path to your XML file. xq will automatically beautify your XML code and display it in a clear format.

**Formatting HTML files:**

For HTML files, simply add the `-m` parameter:

```bash
x xq -m <your HTML file path>
```

Again, replace `<your HTML file path>` with the path to your HTML file.

**Processing XML data from a pipe:**

If your XML data comes from a pipe, for example:

```bash
x html testdata 301 | x xq
```

xq can handle this perfectly, directly formatting the XML data output from the pipe.


## XPath and CSS Selectors: Precisely Extracting the Data You Need

xq's true power lies in its robust data extraction capabilities. You can use XPath and CSS selectors to precisely extract target data.

**XPath selectors:**

* Extract the text content of all nodes named "body":

```bash
x html testdata 301 | x xq -x "//body"
```

* Extract the value of the "code" attribute of all "h1" nodes:

```bash
x html testdata 301 | x xq -x "//h1/@code"
```

**CSS selectors:**

* Use the CSS selector "body > center" to extract content:

```bash
x html testdata 301 | x xq -q "body > center"
```

* Extract the value of the "attr" attribute of nodes matching the CSS selector "head > center":

```bash
x html testdata 301 | x xq -q "head > center" -a attr
```

* Extract the content of the "head" node including tags:

```bash
x html testdata 301 | x xq -n -q "head"
```


## JSON Output: Seamless Integration with Other Tools

xq not only extracts data but can also convert the extracted data into JSON format, facilitating seamless integration with other tools and workflows.

```bash
x html testdata 301 | x xq -j
```

This command will convert the processed XML/HTML data into a JSON structure. You can use options like `--compact` and `-d` (to set the maximum depth) to adjust the format of the JSON output.


## Advanced Options: Mastering the Details

xq also provides some advanced options that allow you to more finely control its behavior:

* `-c|--color`: Enables color output for more visually appealing results.
* `--no-color`: Disables color output.
* `--indent <number>`: Sets the number of spaces for indentation, controlling code formatting.
* `--tab`: Uses tabs for indentation.
* `-e|--extract <selector>`: Extracts a single node for more precise targeting of data.


## Summary: Saying Goodbye to XML/HTML Processing Challenges

xq is a powerful and flexible XML and HTML processing tool.  Combining formatting, data extraction, and JSON conversion, it's a valuable asset for every developer and data scientist.  Try these examples, explore more of xq's features, and say goodbye to the hassles of XML/HTML processing!

# x yum - Enhanced yum Command

`yum` is a widely used package manager on Linux distributions such as CentOS, Fedora, and RHEL. The `yum` module of `x-cmd` enhances the native `yum` command by providing a more user-friendly interface, mirror source switching, proxy settings, and other features, making package management more convenient and efficient. Whether you are a Linux novice or an experienced system administrator, `x yum` can greatly improve your package management tasks.

## Core Features

1.  **Interactive Package Installation (`x yum`)**:

  *  Say goodbye to cumbersome command line inputs! `x yum` provides an intuitive interactive list that allows you to easily browse and search for available packages.
  *  After selecting a package, you can choose to install (install), reinstall (reinstall), view information (info), or browse the software repository.
  *  This interactive approach greatly lowers the learning threshold for new users and increases operational efficiency for advanced users.


2.  **Quick Mirror Source Switching (`x yum mirror`)**:

  *  `x yum mirror` allows you to easily switch to domestic mirror sources (like Aliyun, University of Science and Technology of China, Tsinghua University, etc.), greatly improving the speed of package downloads.
  *  `x yum mirror ls`: Lists all available mirror sources, clearly displaying their names, URLs, and codes.
  *  `x yum mirror current`: Check the currently used mirror source to understand your current configuration.
  *  `x yum mirror set <mirror source code>`: Switch to a specified mirror source (e.g., `x yum mirror set ali`).
  *  `x yum mirror unset`: Restore the official default source, ensuring you can revert back to the original settings when needed.


3.  **Flexible Proxy Settings (`x yum proxy`)**:

  *  `x yum proxy` helps you easily manage `yum`'s proxy settings, whether you are on a corporate intranet or need to access external resources through a proxy.
  *  `x yum proxy use <proxy address>`: Set a global proxy, allowing all `yum` operations to go through the specified proxy.
  *  `x yum proxy unuse`: Cancel the global proxy setting and restore direct connection.
  *  `x yum proxy try <proxy address>`: Set a temporary proxy that is valid only for the current shell session, making it convenient for testing or temporary needs.
  *  `x yum proxy untry`: Cancel the temporary proxy, reverting to the previous network configuration.
  *  `x yum proxy run <command>`: Run a specified command in the proxy environment, ensuring that the command can be executed normally through the proxy.

4.  **Seamless Integration with Native Yum Commands**:

  *  `x yum` is fully compatible with all commands and options of the native `yum`, so you don't need to change your existing usage habits.
  *  For commands requiring root privileges (like `install`, `remove`, etc.), `x yum` will automatically use `sudo`, and you only need to enter your password without manually switching users or adding the `sudo` prefix.

## Installation and Configuration

To use the `yum` module of `x-cmd`, you need to first install `x-cmd`. Please refer to the official documentation of `x-cmd` for installation guidelines. Once installed, `x yum` can be used directly without additional configuration.

## Detailed Usage Examples

1.  **Interactive Package Installation**:

  ```bash
  x yum
  ```

  This will open an interactive list. You can browse using the up and down arrow keys, search by entering keywords, and select a package by pressing Enter. You can then choose installation, reinstallation, information viewing, etc.

2.  **Switch to Aliyun Mirror**:

  ```bash
  x yum mirror set ali
  ```

  This will switch your `yum` mirror source to Aliyun, speeding up package downloads.

3.  **View Current Mirror Source**:

  ```bash
  x yum mirror current
  ```

  This command allows you to check the specific mirror source configuration currently used by `yum`.

4.  **Set Global Proxy**:

  ```bash
  x yum proxy use http://127.0.0.1:8234
  ```

  This routes all `yum` traffic through the `http://127.0.0.1:8234` proxy.

5.  **Install the `curl` Package**:

  ```bash
  x yum install curl
  ```

  This is equivalent to `sudo yum install curl` in the native version, but more concise.

6.  **View `yum` Help Information**:

  ```bash
  x yum --help
  ```
  or
  ```bash
  x yum -h
  ```

## Frequently Asked Questions

*  **Why do some commands require a password?**

  Because certain `yum` operations (such as installing or removing packages) require root privileges. `x yum` internally uses `sudo` to execute these commands, so you need to enter your password.

*  **Which distributions does `x yum mirror` support?**

  Currently, `x yum mirror` primarily supports CentOS, Fedora, and RHEL. There are plans to support more distributions in the future.

*  **How to update `x-cmd` and the `yum` module?**

  `x-cmd` typically provides its own update mechanism. Please refer to the `x-cmd` documentation to learn how to update.

## Summary

The `yum` module of `x-cmd` significantly enhances the usability and convenience of `yum` by offering an interactive interface, mirror source switching, proxy settings, and other features. Whether you are a Linux beginner or an experienced system administrator, `x yum` can make your package management tasks more accessible and efficient. We hope this guide helps you quickly get started with `x yum` and enjoy a more pleasant command-line experience!

# x zuz (1) - Multi-functional, Cross-format Compression and Decompression Tool

## Compressing specified files or directories into an archive

In daily use, we often need to package files or directories into compressed archives. However, different compression formats require different tools, and the command formats of these tools are often inconsistent.

Therefore, `x-cmd` designed the `x zuz` module. It is a multi-functional, cross-format compression and decompression tool, aiming to free users from remembering various commands for different compression formats, allowing them to easily complete all tasks with a single simple command.

`x z` is shorthand for `x zuz compress`, used to package specified files or directories and generate a compressed archive in the specified format.

- For example, to compress the `setup.log` file into `zip` format:

    ```sh
    x z log.zip setup.log
    ```

- For example, to package the `setup.log` file and the `bin/` directory together into `tar.gz` format:

    ```sh
    x z example.tar.gz setup.log bin/
    ```

<!-- [image] Output of x z command packaging zip and tar.gz archives -->
![x z](/data-image/cookbook/mod/zuz.1_1.webp)

Whether it's a single file or multiple files and directories, with the `x z` command, users don't need to worry about which compression tool or command options to use. Simply specify the target compression format and the source files or directories, and it will automatically complete the corresponding compression task.

## Viewing supported archive formats

The `x zuz` module supports a variety of compression formats, covering common compression and decompression needs. You can view the currently supported compression and decompression formats with the following command:

```sh
x zuz show
```

<!-- [image] Output of x zuz show command -->
![x zuz show](/data-image/cookbook/mod/zuz.1_2.webp)

- Supported compression formats:
    - `tar`, `tar.gz`, `tar.Z`, `tar.xz`, `tar.zst`
    - `gz`, `bz2`, `xz`, `tgz`, `zst`, `zip`, `rar`, `7z`, `lha`, `lzh`
- Supported decompression formats:
    - `tar`, `tar.gz`, `tar.Z`, `tar.xz`, `tar.zst`, `tbz`
    - `gz`, `bz2`, `xz`, `tgz`, `zst`, `zip`, `rar`, `7z`, `lha`, `lzh`, `Z`

## Listing files within an archive without decompressing

To facilitate checking archive contents, ensuring file integrity, or quickly finding a specific file, the `x zuz` module supports listing files within an archive without decompressing the entire package.

For example, to list the files within the `log.zip` and `example.tar.gz` archives:

```sh
x zuz ls log.zip
x zuz ls example.tar.gz
```

# x zuz (2) - Easily Decompress Various Archives

## Decompressing Archives to the Current Directory

`x uz` is shorthand for the `x zuz decompress` command, used to decompress archives to the current directory or a specified directory. This command allows users to easily decompress files without worrying about the specific format or decompression tool.

For example, to decompress a `zip` archive and extract its contents to the current directory:

```sh
x uz gh_2.67.0_windows_amd64.zip
```

<!-- [image] Showing the output of the x uz command decompressing to the current directory -->
![x uz 1](/data-image/cookbook/mod/zuz.2_1.webp)

Regardless of the archive format, `x uz` will automatically select the appropriate decompression method based on the file extension.

## Decompressing Archives to a Specified Directory

`x uz` supports decompressing archives to a specified directory; simply provide the target directory path.

For example, to decompress a `zip` archive and extract its contents to the `./gh` directory:

```sh
x uz gh_2.67.0_windows_amd64.zip ./gh
```

<!-- [image] Showing the output of the x uz command decompressing to a specified directory -->
![x uz 2](/data-image/cookbook/mod/zuz.2_2.webp)

If the `./gh` directory does not exist, `x uz` will automatically create it, ensuring that the files are correctly extracted to the specified location.

## Decompressing Archives and Deleting the Archive Afterwards

In some cases, users may want to automatically delete the archive after decompression to save disk space. The `x uzr` command (shorthand for `x zuz uzr`) can help achieve this.

For example, to decompress a `zip` archive and automatically delete it after decompression:

```sh
x uzr gh_2.67.0_windows_amd64.zip
```

<!-- [image] Showing the output of the x uzr command -->
![x uzr](/data-image/cookbook/mod/zuz.2_3.webp)

This is particularly useful for handling large numbers of temporary archives or automated tasks, especially when dealing with large files or frequent decompression, as it can effectively save storage space.
